		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Everyone feels anxious sometimes, but generalized anxiety disorder is a condition in which a person has nearly constant anxiety. People with generalized anxiety disorder often feel anxious for no apparent reason. They also may feel tired, restless, irritable, short of breath, have difficulty concentrating or sleeping, or have a racing heartbeat. Doctors aren't sure what causes generalized anxiety disorder, but it can run in families. Stressful life situations also may cause the disorder. It can start anytime in life, even in childhood. Medications and psychotherapy, along with lifestyle changes, can help."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "In many cases, generalized anxiety disorder begins early in life, though it can start at any age. It usually develops more slowly than other types of anxiety disorders. It can make you feel completely consumed by worry or anxious for no reason. It often can occur with substance abuse and other types of mental illness such as depression. Generalized anxiety disorder usually is treated with a combination of medications and cognitive-behavioral therapy."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 6 million adults in the country have generalized anxiety disorder."
		},

		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Alcohol withdrawal happens when someone who drinks a lot of alcohol every day suddenly stops drinking. Symptoms can include anxiety, depression, headaches, nightmares, fatigue, sweating, and shakiness. Severe symptoms can include confusion and hallucinations (delirium tremens) and seizures. The symptoms of alcohol withdrawal can range from mild to severe depending on how heavily you drink. In severe cases, the symptoms can quickly become life threatening."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "Seek emergency care if you have hallucinations, fever, confusion, an irregular heartbeat, seizure or history of seizures."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Withdrawal symptoms usually start about 5 to 10 hours after your last drink, but in some cases the symptoms can start a few days after your last drink. The symptoms can last for several weeks but are usually at their worst 48-72 hours after the last drink. You may have more serious symptoms if you also have another medical condition and should see your doctor. In some cases, you may need treatment in a hospital."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Having another medical condition, quitting other drugs or nicotine at the same time, having gone through withdrawal previously"

	"Alcohol_intoxication": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "Agitation\n\t\t•\tDouble vision (without one eye covered)\n\t\t•\tStool leaking (incontinence)\n\t\t•\tUrine leaking (incontinence)\n\t\t•\tSnoring\n\t\t•\tAbnormal gait (walking)\n\t\t•\tImpaired judgement\n\t\t•\tDifficulty walking\n\t\t•\tLoss of balance\n\t\t•\tMemory problems\n\t\t•\tSlurred speech\n\t\t•\tLoss of coordination\n\t\t•\tDrowsiness\n\t\t•\tJerking eye movements"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Alcohol Intoxication Overview",
			"content": "Alcohol intoxication occurs after you drink enough alcohol to change your behavior and impair your physical and mental abilities. If you have a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of .08, you are legally intoxicated. Depending on their weight, most people hit .08 BAC after 2 to 3 drinks in 1 hour. But responses to alcohol vary from person to person. Some may become intoxicated on less alcohol. It depends upon how your body absorbs and gets rid of alcohol. Alcohol poisoning happens when you drink a lot of alcohol in a short amount of time. It is life-threatening and needs emergency medical care. Binge drinking is often the cause of alcohol poisoning."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Immediately after you drink, your BAC rises sharply and may lead to feelings of pleasure, relaxation, and greater sociability. But with more drinking, behavior varies. Some people become withdrawn. Others are more lively. Still others become angry or aggressive. Generally, the physical and mental effects peak about 45 to 90 minutes after you stop drinking. BAC then quickly declines, falling more slowly until alcohol completely leaves the body several hours later. Exactly when this happens depends in part upon how much you drink."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About two out of three American adults drink alcoholic beverages. Nearly 17.6 million of them have problems with alcohol or are alcoholics."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "There is no treatment to reverse alcohol intoxication. However, for severe alcohol intoxication, you may receive:\n\t\t•\tIntravenous (IV) fluids with B complex vitamins for dehydration\n\t\t•\tA breathing tube\n\t\t•\tFollow-up to monitor recovery until BAC falls."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Seek emergency medical help if you suspect that someone may have alcohol poisoning.\n\t\t•\tRemove the person from the alcohol.\n\t\t•\tDo not let the person drive.\n\t\t•\tKeep the person in a safe place to help prevent falls or dangerous objects.\n\t\t•\tPosition the person on his or her side, in case of vomiting.\n\t\t•\tMake sure you can easily arouse the person by talking or with a slight shake.\n\t\t•\tHave someone stay with the person to make sure he or she gets better.\n\t\t•\tAvoid coffee or cold showers, which have little effect."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Eating little food beforehand, taking other drugs, drinking faster, stronger drinks"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "It's common to vomit when intoxicated. But if vomiting occurs more than once or if the person is unable to express thoughts clearly, take him or her to the emergency room. Call the emergency services if you can't wake the person up, breathing is very slow or stops and starts, the person has a seizure, the skin is very pale or blue, or the skin feels cold. Do the same if there is any doubt about the person's condition."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "What are the risks of alcohol?\n\t\t•\tWhat should I do if someone close to me becomes intoxicated?\n\t\t•\tDo you think I have a drinking problem?\n\t\t•\tWhere can I go to get help?\n\t\t•\tIf I keep drinking, am I at risk for any complications?"
		},

			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "A physical exam may be enough to diagnose alcohol intoxication or rule out other conditions that might mimic it. Alcohol concentration in the breath, urine, or blood also provides a measure of your blood alcohol concentration."

	"Dementia_in_head_injury": [{

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "People who have a serious head injury can develop dementia. They may have memory problems, difficulty speaking, and personality changes. Some people with dementia after a head injury get better over months and years. Others don't. Motor vehicle accidents are the most common cause of a single head injury that leads to dementia. Repeated blows to the head as from boxing or playing football can cause dementia symptoms that will not emerge until years later. This is called chronic traumatic encephalopathy. Treatment focuses on helping the person adjust and relieving symptoms. Anyone who has just had a potentially serious head injury should go to the emergency room."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Symptoms of dementia after a head injury may appear right away or develop slowly over months and years. Therapists can help with behavior changes and other problems. Drugs may help with symptoms, such as depression or anxiety. How soon a person with dementia after a head injury can return to work or physical activity depends on the particular case."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",

			"content": "Dementia after a head injury always needs medical care. Family support is crucial. Reducing stress with breathing exercises, meditation, or yoga can help. Simplify life at home and stick to a regular daily schedule. Don't return to work -- or start playing sports -- until your doctor says it's safe."
		},
		{

If a person has symptoms such as loss of consciousness, confusion, vomiting, blood or fluid leaking from the ears or nose, slurred speech, difficulty walking, muscle weakness, seizures, and pupils of different sizes, go to the emergency room or call the emergency services. Babies who are crying uncontrollably or won't eat after a head injury should also go to the emergency room."

	"Drug_withdrawal": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "Agitation\n\t\t•\tFever"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Drug withdrawal occurs when you suddenly stop taking a drug you've become physically or psychologically addicted to. The drug can be an illicit street drug, a legal substance like alcohol, or a prescription medication you've become dependent on. Symptoms vary from drug to drug and from person to person. With certain drugs, such as alcohol or tranquilizers, complications of withdrawal can be life-threatening. They might include heart attack, seizure, or stroke. With other drugs such as heroin, withdrawal can be extremely uncomfortable, but not life-threatening. Acute withdrawal occurs shortly after you stop using a drug. Physical symptoms are often very intense and can last from a few days to a few weeks. That's followed by a stage called post-acute withdrawal. At this stage, symptoms occur episodically and are primarily psychological. They can include symptoms such as trouble sleeping, headaches, confusion, and depression. Post-acute withdrawal can last up to a couple of years. Relapse can be a major complication during this phase."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "Go to the emergency room or call the emergency services if you are having drug withdrawal and experience seizures, fever, severe confusion, hallucinations, or irregular heartbeat."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Withdrawal occurs in two stages: acute and post-acute. The first, or acute, stage can last up to a few weeks. Symptoms of acute withdrawal depend on what drug you have been taking and also can vary from person to person. They can include emotional symptoms such as anxiety, headaches, an inability to concentrate, and depression. They can also include physical symptoms such as sweating, difficulty breathing, abnormal heart rhythms, nausea, and other symptoms. Certain drugs, such as alcohol and tranquilizers, can cause more serious symptoms such as seizure, heart attack, and stroke. During the post-acute stage, the symptoms are less physical and more emotional. Post-acute symptoms typically occur in episodes that last a few days and then go away -- only to come back. This can go on for a couple of years while you recover."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment depends on the specific drug that's been used. Typically, medications are used to reduce craving and treat symptoms. Other treatments will address specific complications. After withdrawal, behavioral therapy, either on an inpatient or an outpatient basis, is needed to help prevent a return to drug use."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Drug withdrawal should be treated by a medical professional. During post-acute withdrawal and treatment for addiction, you can improve your chances of success by:\n\t\t•\tAvoiding high-risk situations and associations\n\t\t•\tLearning to relax\n\t\t•\tBeing honest with yourself and your supporters about your problem with drugs"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "Drug withdrawal can sometimes have life-threatening complications. Call your doctor or go to an emergency room if you think you may be experiencing drug withdrawal."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\t\t•\tAre my symptoms a result of drug withdrawal?\n\t\t•\tHow long can I expect the symptoms to last?\n\t\t•\tIs there anything I can do to get relief from the symptoms?\n\t\t•\tAfter withdrawal will I need any further treatment? If so, how can I get it?"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "In most cases, a doctor can diagnose drug withdrawal with a physical exam and questions about your medical history and drug use. The doctor may also ask for blood and urine tests to confirm the diagnosis."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Nearly 24.6 million Americans age 12 and over were using illicit drugs in 2013. Of that number, 4.8 million used drugs other than marijuana."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Suddenly stopping drugs or alcohol use, substance abuse, a physical dependence on drugs or alcohol"
		}

	"Epilepsy_(temporal_lobe)": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tAgitation\n\t\t•\tConfusion\n\t\t•\tMood swings\n\t\t•\tParanoid behavior\n\t\t•\tUnusual behavior\n\t\t•\tInappropriate behavior\n\t\t•\tInvoluntary movements (picking, lip smacking etc.)\n\t\t•\tAnxiety\n\t\t•\tPersonality changes\n\t\t•\tSense of impending doom\n\t\t•\tHallucinations\n\t\t•\tFrightening thoughts\n\t\t•\tHearing voices\n\t\t•\tStrange smell or taste"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Epilepsy is a condition marked by seizures. Temporal lobe seizures originate in the part of the brain that processes emotions and short-term memory, among other functions. Unlike other forms of seizures, temporal lobe seizures often don't respond to antiseizure medications. Surgery may be the only treatment option. For many people, surgery can be used to stop seizures."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "If your doctor identifies an underlying cause, such as an infection or a tumor, treating the condition may stop your seizures for good. For some forms of epilepsy, doctors prescribe an anticonvulsant drug to prevent seizures. Temporal lobe epilepsy doesn't always respond to these medications, however. Then the treatment of choice is surgery to remove the abnormal area of the brain. Surgery is successful in eliminating seizures in 70%-80% of people with temporal lobe epilepsy."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "One in 10 adults experiences a seizure sometime during his or her lifetime. Two million people in the country have epilepsy. About half of patients with epilepsy have partial epilepsy, often originating in the temporal lobe."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Some types of epilepsy can be inherited. Other types may result from a severe infection or head injury. Reducing your risk of a head injury by wearing a helmet when riding a bike or engaging in risky sports will lower your risk of injuries that can lead to seizures. Other risk factors include oxygen deprivation, brain infections, stroke, Alzheimer's and other neurologic disease, and brain tumors. Two out of three cases of epilepsy have no known cause."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "If an underlying cause is found, treatment will depend on the cause. If no cause is discovered, your doctor may prescribe an oral medication to help prevent seizures.\n\nThe type of drug and the dosage will depend on the kind of seizures you experience. Some people need to take medication for the rest of their lives. Others can reduce or completely stop taking medications if they go for several years without having another seizure.\n\nIn some cases, brain surgery can be performed to remove a small part of the brain that may be causing certain kinds of seizures.\n\nIf medications don't work and surgery isn't possible, your doctor may recommend vagus nerve stimulation. This treatment involves implanting an electrical device that stimulates a large nerve in the neck.\n\nCertain diets also may help reduce the chances of having seizures."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Eating a healthy diet, getting plenty of sleep, and avoiding alcohol and illegal drugs may lower your risk of having a seizure."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "Call your doctor if you have just experienced a seizure. If you already have been diagnosed with epilepsy, call your doctor if any new symptoms appear.\n\nCall the emergency services or your local emergency number if someone is having a seizure for the first time. If the victim is wearing a medical ID bracelet, follow the instructions on it. If someone with a history of epilepsy is having a seizure, call the emergency services if:\n\t\t•\tThe seizure lasts longer than five minutes without showing signs of slowing down\n\t\t•\tThe person has trouble breathing afterward\n\t\t•\tThe person is injured or in pain\n\t\t•\tRepeated seizures occur over a few minutes\n\t\t•\tThe victim does not regain consciousness or act normally between seizure"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\t\t•\tWas my seizure caused by a condition that can be corrected?\n\t\t•\tWhat kind of seizure did I experience?\n\t\t•\tWill there be lasting damage from the seizure?\n\t\t•\tIs there a problem with my brain's electrical system?\n\t\t•\tAm I likely to have more seizures?\n\t\t•\tWhat can I do to prevent seizures?\n\t\t•\tHow long will I need to take medication?\n\t\t•\tIs surgery an alternative for me?"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "Your doctor will perform a complete physical, along with a test of the electrical activity in the brain, called an electroencephalograph (EEG). People with epilepsy often have abnormal brain function in specific areas of the brain. Your doctor may also do tests to see if there are underlying causes for your epilepsy. These tests may include measurements of blood sugar, a kidney function test, and spinal fluid analysis. Your doctor may also recommend an MRI, PET, or CT scan or other imaging tests."

	"Hypocalcemia": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tAgitation\n\t\t•\tMuscle cramps or spasms (painful)\n\t\t•\tMuscle twitching (painless)\n\t\t•\tHeadache\n\t\t•\tMuscle weakness\n\t\t•\tDifficulty relaxing muscles after contracting them"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Hypocalcemia is a rare condition in which there is not enough calcium in the blood. Calcium is important for healthy bones and teeth, but also for blood clotting and nerve and muscle functions. Severe hypocalcemia can lead to cardiovascular collapse and low blood pressure that doesn't respond to treatment. Kidney failure, low levels of vitamin D or magnesium, some medication and blood disorders, chemotherapy, alcoholism, and underactive parathyroid glands can cause it. You may have symptoms such as tingling, muscle spasms and aches, and confusion. Raising your calcium levels, sometime intravenously, will clear it up. Death from hypocalcemia is very rare."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "Hypocalcemia is a medical emergency. If you have severe muscle cramping, spasms, seizures, or any other symptom of hypocalcemia immediately see your doctor or go to a hospital emergency room."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "If you have long-standing hypocalcemia, you may not have any symptoms. Your doctor may discover it only during a routine blood test. If your hypocalcemia is acute and your blood calcium level drops quickly, your muscles or nerves may start to twitch. With mild hypocalcemia, you may have numbness and tingling around your mouth or in your fingers and toes and be depressed and irritable. With severe hypocalcemia, you may be confused and disoriented. Your heart muscles may contract irregularly because of electrolyte imbalance. For chronic hypocalcemia, calcium and vitamin D supplements probably will be enough to bring your calcium levels back up. But if you have symptoms, you'll be given calcium intravenously and vitamin D supplements to help with its absorption. Your doctor may treat the underlying cause of the problem if it can be identified."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Dehydration"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for hypocalcemia may include:\n\t\t•\tIntravenous calcium and fluids\n\t\t•\tOral calcium supplements\n\t\t•\tVitamin D supplements\n\t\t•\tThiazide diuretics to decrease kidney excretion of calcium\n\t\t•\tTreatment for the underlying cause"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "These self-care strategies can help if your blood calcium levels are low:\n\t\t•\tMake sure you are getting enough calcium in your diet. Dairy products, greens, sardines, salmon, red beans, tofu, and seaweed are good sources.\n\t\t•\tAsk your doctor if you should take calcium supplements.\n\t\t•\tTake vitamin D with calcium supplements for better absorption.\n\t\t•\tDrink orange juice fortified with calcium."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\t\t•\tCould hypocalcemia or another condition be causing my symptoms?\n\t\t•\tWhat tests do I need?\n\t\t•\tIf I have hypocalcemia, what do you think caused it?\n\t\t•\tWhat treatments do I need for it?\n\t\t•\tIs there anything I can do to avoid future episodes?"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "The doctor will do a physical exam and take blood tests to measure calcium levels. The doctor also may order other tests to check for possible causes."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About four in every 100,000 people have hypoparathyroidism, one of the main causes of hypcalcemia."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "You are at increased risk for hypocalcemia if you have low levels of parathyroid hormone, often due to damage to the parathyroid glands during thyroid surgery. Other risk factors include being low in calcium, vitamin D, or magnesium, having some types of leukemia or other blood disorders, having tumor lysis (a complication of chemotherapy), kidney dysfunction, pancreatitis, or certain conditions that decrease calcium absorption. Certain drugs, including bisphosphonates, also put you at increased risk."
		}

	"Hypoparathyroidism": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tAgitation\n\t\t•\tMuscle cramps or spasms (painful)\n\t\t•\tHeadache\n\t\t•\tMuscle weakness"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Hypoparathyroidism is a rare condition in which the parathyroid glands in the neck don't make enough of a key hormone. This leads to low calcium and high phosphorus levels in the blood, which can cause muscle twitches, seizures, cramps, tingling sensations, and developmental delays in children. Neck surgery, radiation treatments, and genetic conditions can cause hypoparathyroidism. Daily dietary supplements will help get calcium and phosphorus levels under control. Prompt treatment can help prevent lasting problems."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Hypoparathyroidism may first appear within a few weeks of a baby's birth. Others develop it later in childhood or as adults. Lifetime treatment with calcium and vitamin D supplements is standard. Getting help quickly is crucial in children; it can prevent growth delays and mental retardation. In adults, treatment can reverse many symptoms, but won't help with stunted growth, cognitive problems, cataracts and calcium deposits in the brain. Severely low levels of calcium can be life-threatening; the best treatment may be IV calcium in a hospital."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Hypoparathyroidism is rare. One study suggests that hypoparathyroidism with an unknown cause affects 1 out of 140,000 people."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Recent surgery in the head or neck, radiation treatment, a family history of hypoparathyroidism, low magnesium levels, excess acid in bodily fluids, DiGeorge syndrome, Addison's disease, autoimmune disorders, adrenal insufficiency. Thyroid surgery is the most frequent cause."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatments include:\n\t\t•\tCalcium supplements\n\t\t•\tVitamin D supplements\n\t\t•\tDietary changes\n\t\t•\tMedications to lower phosphorus levels\n\t\t•\tIV calcium for emergencies"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "People with hypoparathyroidism need medical treatment. In some cases, changing their diets to include more foods with calcium -- such as dairy products, spinach, and kale -- and fewer foods with phosphorus -- such as sodas, eggs, and some meats -- will help."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Not getting enough calcium or getting too much phosphorus in the diet"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",

Symptoms include: muscle cramps and spasms, abdominal pain, dry hair and skin, brittle nails, cataracts, tingling fingers or toes and lips, dental problems, headaches, mood swings and depression, irregular heartbeat, weak bones, painful periods and developmental and growth delays in children. Severely low levels of calcium can be life-threatening. If you have seizures or breathing problems, go to the emergency room."

			"content": "Intoxication occurs when you take any kind of chemical or drug that affects your mental and physical abilities. These drugs can include marijuana, cocaine, heroin, opium, amphetamines, methamphetamines, PCP, LSD, and ecstasy. You can also become intoxicated by chemicals or fumes you accidentally consume, such as mercury, cleaning solvents, bleach, pesticides, gasoline, and paint fumes. Intoxication happens because drugs and chemicals change the signals that go to and from your brain. The symptoms of intoxication can vary widely depending on the type of drug or chemical you take. Intoxication can cause euphoria, slowed reaction time, dizziness, confusion, increased heart rate, paranoia, nausea, hallucinations, increased body temperature, impaired judgment, lowered inhibitions, impaired balance, falling, impaired driving, numbness, sleeplessness, changes in emotions, increased sensitivity, anxiety, sweating, teeth clenching, reduced appetite, and violent behavior. If you take enough of a certain drug or chemical, it can cause stroke, coma, and death."

			"content": "Intoxication increases with the amount of drug, chemical, or fume you ingest. Over time, you may need to take more and more of a recreational drug to get the same effects. Repeated drug use can cause changes in your brain and other systems in your body. You may feel the need to use the drug more often and can become addicted to the drug. Most people take drugs to try to feel good. But certain drugs can cause unpleasant and serious side effects, such as high blood pressure, anxiety, hallucinations, stroke, kidney failure, seizures, and coma. Stopping a drug suddenly can also cause withdrawal symptoms, including fatigue, insomnia, anxiety, nausea, vomiting, stomach cramps, and depression. If you take too much of any drug you may need emergency medical care. If you've consumed another type of chemical or fume and feel unsteady, nauseous, or confused you need to see a doctor or seek emergency care."

Methamphetamine comes in chunks or a crystal-like powder that people snort, swallow, smoke, or dissolve and inject. Caucasian men ages 20 to 40 are most likely to take methamphetamine, often to experience a rush or euphoria, but more adolescents have been taking the drug as well. People who take methamphetamine on purpose or accidentally can overdose and die from heart-related side effects. Therapy and medication can help with quitting."

		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Depression is a painful sadness or down mood that interferes with daily life. Many people feel down for short periods, but depression lasts a long time and may include anxiety, insomnia, and other symptoms. Life events such as the death of a loved one can trigger depression. The illness can run in families, but people with no family history also become depressed. Often, there is no clear cause. Depression is a common but serious illness that usually doesn't go away without treatment. Counseling and/or antidepressant medication can treat depression in most people."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Depression caused by a specific event such as a job loss can come on suddenly. Most of the time, depression develops slowly and gradually gets worse. Signs of depression can be subtle, and a person can be depressed and not know it at first. Men and women often experience depression differently. Men often feel anger, irritability, and have sleep or substance abuse problems. Women often feel sad, guilty, and worthless. Mild depression may go away on its own. However, depression usually doesn't go away and often gets worse without treatment. Severe depression can make it impossible to function and cause suicidal thoughts. Treatment with antidepressants and/or talk therapy can help most people with depression. Antidepressants can take six-eight weeks to work, so it's important to be patient while finding the right treatment for you."

	"Excessive_caffeine_use": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tAnxiety\n\t\t•\tHeadache\n\t\t•\tPalpitations (fluttering in chest)\n\t\t•\tRestless or irritability\n\t\t•\tDifficulty falling asleep\n\t\t•\tDifficulty sleeping\n\t\t•\tIrregular heartbeat\n\t\t•\tRapid heart rate (pulse)\n\t\t•\tIncreased talkativeness"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Excessive caffeine use, typically more than three cups of coffee a day, can drain energy and cause frayed nerves. It also can make your heart beat faster, cause an uneven heart rhythm, raise your blood pressure, worsen anxiety and panic, and cause dehydration. Sensitivity to caffeine varies among people, and some people can consume more without ill effect. But often people don't know how much caffeine they've consumed, because the drug is not only in coffee but in tea, soft drinks, energy drinks, chocolate, and some medications."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Too much caffeine will cause upset stomach, irritability, and other symptoms after a few days of using it. It also can lead to drained energy, depression, and other symptoms. Some people develop caffeine dependence and find they need more caffeine to get the same effect as they've gotten in the past. Caffeine dependence can lead to caffeine withdrawal, which can cause headache, fatigue, or drowsiness, depressed mood, irritability, difficulty concentrating, nausea or vomiting, and muscle pain or stiffness. Withdrawal symptoms can last from two to nine days. Most experts recommend you cut back on caffeine gradually and allow your body to adjust to the lesser amount."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "It's estimated that millions of people in the country consume too much caffeine each day."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for caffeine overuse involves gradually cutting back, then using caffeine in moderation or avoiding caffeine altogether."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "If you stop caffeine completely you may have withdrawal symptoms for 72 hours or longer. Those symptoms might include sleepiness, headache, and fatigue. Gradually tapering off on how much coffee you drink can help your body get used to lower levels of caffeine without withdrawal symptoms. Also, taking small amounts of chocolate or tea can help relieve headaches and other withdrawal symptoms until your body gets used to less or no caffeine."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Certain medications, excess alcohol, smoking, drug use, poor diet"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "It's possible to overdose on caffeine, especially if you use an over-the-counter stimulant or an energy drink. 			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "When someone has a panic attack, that person feels a sudden, intense fear that can't be controlled. People who have panic attacks often feel like they are having a heart attack, losing control, suffocating, or dying. During the panic attack, the person also may have chest pain, nausea, shortness of breath, chills, sweating, dizziness, or a feeling of choking. Doctors don't know for certain what causes panic attacks, but it may have to do with genetics or stress."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Panic attacks usually start suddenly. They can happen at any time and for no apparent reason. The symptoms usually feel most severe after about 10 to 20 minutes and then go away within an hour. During the panic attack, you may feel as if you are going to die. Afterwards you may feel very tired. You can have just one panic attack or have more. If you have panic attacks on a regular basis, you may have a condition called panic disorder. In most cases, panic attacks and panic disorder are treated with medication and therapy."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Stressful or traumatic event, family history of panic attacks, major life changes, history of sexual abuse or child abuse"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for panic attacks may include:\n\t\t•\tAntidepressant medications, such as fluoxetine (Prozac), paroxetine (Paxil), sertraline (Zoloft), and venlafaxine (Effexor)\n\t\t•\tMild sedatives, such as alprazolam (Xanax) and clonazepam (Klonopin)\n\t\t•\tCognitive-behavioral therapy, psychodynamic therapy, or other types of therapy"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Panic attacks need treatment from a doctor. But you may be able to help prevent or lessen attacks by:\n\t\t•\tLearning breathing or relaxation exercises\n\t\t•\tAvoiding alcohol, illegal drugs, and caffeine\n\t\t•\tGetting enough sleep\n\t\t•\tJoining a support group"
		},
		{

			"content": "See your doctor if you have any symptoms of panic attacks, such as: a feeling of doom, shakiness, racing heartbeat, sweating, chills, chest pain, shortness of breath, nausea, faintness, and headache. Seek emergency care right away if you have never had a panic attack before and have chest pain or trouble breathing."

	"Mitral_valve_prolapse": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tAnxiety\n\t\t•\tPalpitations (fluttering in chest)\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tShortness of breath"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Mitral valve prolapse is a type of heart problem. It happens when the valve between your heart's left upper and lower chambers doesn't close completely. It can sometimes cause blood to leak back into the left upper chamber. Mitral valve prolapse often runs in families and can happen with certain medical conditions. It is most common in women ages 20 to 40. Doctors aren't exactly sure what causes it. Many people don't have any symptoms, but it can cause chest pain, heart palpitations, trouble breathing with activity, dizziness, headaches, and fatigue. Often it doesn't need treatment. In rare cases, mitral valve prolapse can cause irregular heartbeats that are life-threatening."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "In most cases, mitral valve prolapse is mild and doesn't cause any problems. Many people have it without even knowing it. Most people with mitral valve prolapse don't need any treatment. But if you start to have symptoms, you may need medication or surgery to repair the valve."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 3% to 4% of people in the country have mitral valve prolapse."

	"Agoraphobia": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "Anxiety\nFearful"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Agoraphobia is the fear of open places or any situation where escape would be difficult. It usually occurs as a result of panic disorder. People with panic disorder have sudden attacks of terror that may include rapid heartbeat, sweating, dizziness, light-headedness, tingling hands, nausea, and chest pain. Because symptoms come on without any warning, people with panic disorder sometimes try to avoid situations or places they associate with feelings of panic. When fear of having a panic attack becomes so intense that the person rarely leaves the house, it's considered agoraphobia. Agoraphobia can make it difficult to hold down a job and makes the person very dependent on others. Depression, alcoholism, or drug abuse often occur with panic disorder. No one knows what causes panic disorders, but they tend to run in families. Antidepressants, anti-anxiety medications, and therapy help treat panic disorder and agoraphobia."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Panic attacks come on suddenly without any warning. They last about 10 minutes, but the lingering worry and dread can stay with you much longer than that. Because attacks occur without warning, most people spend a lot of time worrying about when the next attack may happen. A person with panic disorder may begin avoiding places or situations where panic attacks have occurred. For example, if you had a panic attack at the grocery store, you might avoid grocery stores. Agoraphobia develops when symptoms of panic cause a person to become housebound or only go out with someone they trust. Treating panic disorder early on can help prevent agoraphobia from developing. Medications and therapy treat panic disorder and agoraphobia."
		},

		{
			"heading": "Cocaine Abuse Overview",
			"content": "Cocaine is a very addictive drug that when inhaled, smoked, or injected makes users feel euphoric, excited, and energetic. Cocaine abuse occurs when a person can't stop using the drug even though continued use causes legal problems, job loss, health problems, and relationship problems. People who are addicted to cocaine develop a tolerance to the drug, so that they need more of it to achieve the same high. Abusing cocaine increases the risk of heart attacks, strokes, digestive problems, malnutrition, respiratory problems, paranoia, hallucinations, and of contracting HIV. Treatment for drug addiction includes medications to help ease withdrawal, therapy, and treatment of any underlying mental health problem."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Initially, using cocaine leads to feelings of euphoria and excitement. As cocaine dependence develops, it takes more of the drug to achieve the same feelings. Over time, withdrawal symptoms develop, including irritability, agitation, and general discomfort. This causes the person to want to use more cocaine to avoid withdrawal symptoms. Eventually, the need for cocaine becomes so overwhelming that the person neglects important obligations in the effort to get and use cocaine. Continued use can lead to serious health problems and even death. Treatment with medications to ease withdrawal symptoms, along with behavioral therapy, can help people overcome their craving for cocaine."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Many new mothers experience the\"baby blues\" in the first two weeks after giving birth. Changing hormone levels, lack of sleep, and the huge life changes that occur after having a baby can all contribute to feelings of sadness and loss of energy. Postpartum depression is more severe and long-lasting. It occurs when the depression doesn't go away in two weeks or if depression develops a month or so after delivery. Postpartum depression may cause sadness, hopelessness, anxiety, loss of energy, loss of interest in things, guilt, changes in appetite, and insomnia. A woman may also have negative feelings about her baby or have little interest in her child. Some women have thoughts of harming their baby or committing suicide, although they rarely act on them. In rare cases, postpartum psychosis occurs, with hallucinations and delusions. Any woman experiencing postpartum depression symptoms should tell her doctor right away. Counseling and/or antidepressant medication effectively treat postpartum depression in women."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Many women experience the\"baby blues,\" or mild depression after giving birth. However, if depression doesn't fade within two weeks, is severe, or if symptoms develop after the first month or so, it's considered postpartum depression. A woman may become withdrawn, feel worthless, sad, anxious, hopeless, and have difficulty caring for her baby or herself. Postpartum depression usually doesn't go away on its own, so it's important to get help right away. Treatment with antidepressants and/or talk therapy can help most women with postpartum depression."

	"Epilepsy_(complex_partial_seizures)": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tAnxiety\n\t\t•\tConfusion\n\t\t•\tDisorientation\n\t\t•\tBlank stare\n\t\t•\tBlackouts (memory time loss)\n\t\t•\tInvoluntary movements (picking, lip smacking etc.)\n\t\t•\tBlurred vision\n\t\t•\tLoss of consciousness\n\t\t•\tMuscle twitching (painless)\n\t\t•\tBlinking eyes\n\t\t•\tEyes rolling back\n\t\t•\tStrange smell or taste"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Epilepsy is marked by repeated seizures. There are many different types of seizures, depending on which part and how much of the brain is affected. Epilepsy that causes partial seizures begins in one local area of the brain. Partial seizures are divided into simple and complex partial seizures. During simple partial seizures, people remain fully conscious and able to respond to external stimuli. During complex partial seizures, people lose consciousness briefly. Most people with epilepsy are able to control their symptoms with the use of anti-seizure medications. Surgery can sometimes be performed to remove the damaged brain cells that cause seizures."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Complex partial seizures usually start with a blank stare. The person seems to be unaware of his or her surroundings and appears dazed, unresponsive, and clumsy. Other signs include mumbling, smacking of the lips, fidgeting, chewing, and walking in a random way. After the seizure is over, people typically have no memory of what has happened to them. Seizures do not typically cause brain damage. Between seizures, most people can lead normal lives. If your seizures are caused by an underlying condition such as low blood sugar levels, treating that condition can eliminate seizures. If there is no underlying cause, epilepsy can usually be controlled by anti-seizure medications. Surgery can also sometimes be performed to remove the damaged brain cells that cause seizures."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "If your seizures are caused by an underlying condition, your doctor will recommend treatments based on the medical problem that is causing them. For epilepsy not linked to other conditions, many anti-seizure drugs are available. These can prevent and stop seizures. Medications often need to be adjusted, especially when you first begin taking them. If medications don't control seizures, your doctor may talk to you about surgery to remove the abnormal cells in the brain that are causing seizures. Another option is vagus nerve stimulation, which delivers short bursts of electrical energy into the brain via a large nerve in the neck. In some cases, seizures may also be controlled by following a diet very high in fats and low in carbohydrates, called a ketogenic diet."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "If your seizures are caused by an underlying condition, your doctor will recommend treatments based on the medical problem that is causing them. For epilepsy not linked to other conditions, many anti-seizure drugs are available. These can prevent and stop seizures. Medications often need to be adjusted, especially when you first begin taking them. If medications don't control seizures, your doctor may talk to you about surgery to remove the abnormal cells in the brain that are causing seizures. Another option is vagus nerve stimulation, which delivers short bursts of electrical energy into the brain via a large nerve in the neck. In some cases, seizures may also be controlled by following a diet very high in fats and low in carbohydrates, called a ketogenic diet."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Getting plenty of sleep, avoiding stress, not smoking, and avoiding alcohol may help reduce your likelihood of having a seizure. If you do experience recurring seizures, it's important for the people around you to know what to do:\n\t\t•\tStay calm\n\t\t•\tDon't move the person experiencing a seizure.\n\t\t•\tDon't try to interfere with the seizure.\n\t\t•\tDon't try to wake the person up by shouting or shaking them.\n\t\t•\tNever try to force the person's mouth open or put anything in it.\n\t\t•\tTurn the person on his or her side to allow any fluid in the mouth to come out.\n\t\t•\tPlace a pillow or something soft under the person's head.\n\t\t•\tWhen the seizure stops, watch the person for signs of confusion. Allow the person to rest or sleep.\n\nMost seizures aren't life-threatening. You don't need to call a doctor or an ambulance unless this is the first time someone has experienced a seizure or someone known to have epilepsy has a seizure that lasts longer than 5 minutes."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Drinking alcohol, smoking, not getting enough sleep, stress"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "Call your doctor or go to a hospital emergency room if this is the first time you've experienced a seizure. If you've been diagnosed with epilepsy and are under treatment, you don't need immediate medical attention unless the seizure lasts more than five minutes, you have breathing difficulties, you experience persistent confusion or loss of consciousness, or you've injured yourself as a result of a seizure."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\t\t•\tWere the symptoms I experienced a seizure?\n\t\t•\tDo I have epilepsy?\n\t\t•\tWas my seizure caused by an underlying condition?\n\t\t•\tIf so, can it be treated to prevent another seizure?\n\t\t•\tWill anti-seizure medication help me?\n\t\t•\tWhat form of medication would be best for me?\n\t\t•\tHow long will I need to take medication?\n\t\t•\tAm I likely to have another seizure?\n\t\t•\tDo seizures cause permanent damage?\n\t\t•\tWhat should I do if I experience another seizure?\n\t\t•\tBesides medication, is there anything I can do to lower the risk of having another seizure?"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "Your doctor will ask you about your symptoms and do a physical examination, including tests of strength and reflexes. A test called an electroencephalogram, which measures brainwaves, is often used to diagnose epilepsy. Other tests that may be performed include MRI or CT scans."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Very young age or advanced age, family history of epilepsy, smoking"
		}

			"content": "Epilepsy is a condition marked by repeated seizures. There are many different types of seizures. What type a person has depends on which part and how much of the brain is affected. Epilepsy that causes partial seizures begins in one local area of the brain. Partial seizures are divided into simple and complex partial seizures. During simple partial seizures, people remain fully conscious and able to respond to external stimuli. During complex partial seizures, people lose consciousness briefly."

Seizures do not typically cause brain damage."

		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "Call your doctor or go to a hospital emergency room if this is your first seizure or if the seizure is different than your usual seizures. If you've been diagnosed with epilepsy and are under treatment, you don't need immediate medical attention unless the seizure lasts more than 5 minutes, you have breathing difficulties, you experience persistent confusion or loss of consciousness, or you've injured yourself as a result of a seizure."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",

	"Hyperthyroidism": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tAnxiety\n\t\t•\tDecreased appetite\n\t\t•\tDifficulty sleeping\n\t\t•\tFatigue\n\t\t•\tLump or bulge\n\t\t•\tPalpitations (fluttering in chest)\n\t\t•\tExcessive sweating\n\t\t•\tWeight loss (unintentional)\n\t\t•\tDisorientation\n\t\t•\tShaking hands or tremor\n\t\t•\tApathy\n\t\t•\tBulging eyes\n\t\t•\tChange in hair texture\n\t\t•\tDiarrhea\n\t\t•\tVision fading of colors\n\t\t•\tIrregular heartbeat\n\t\t•\tNervousness\n\t\t•\tRapid heart rate (pulse)\n\t\t•\tTrouble distinguishing color shades\n\t\t•\tMood swings\n\t\t•\tHair loss\n\t\t•\tJumpiness or easily startled\n\t\t•\tIncreased sensitivity to heat\n\t\t•\tWeakness (generalized)"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Hyperthyroidism occurs when the thyroid gland produces too much thyroid hormone. The thyroid is a butterfly-shaped gland that wraps around the front of the windpipe. It controls how the body uses energy. With too much thyroid hormone, your body functions speed up. This causes weight loss, shakiness, tiredness, sensitivity to heat, insomnia, and trouble concentrating. Graves' disease, an immune system disorder, is the most common cause. Thyroid nodules, inflammation of the thyroid gland, consuming too much iodine, and taking too much thyroid hormone also can cause hyperthyroidism. Hyperthyroidism is fairly common and occurs more often in women."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Some people have hyperthyroidism and never have symptoms. Early symptoms may be mild and get worse as hyperthyroidism increases. Early symptoms include heat sensitivity, more frequent bowel movements, agitation, weight loss, and irregular periods in women. More commonly, older adults have irregular heartbeat and shortness of breath. If not treated, severe symptoms called a\"thyroid storm\" can occur, causing fever, rapid heart rate, high blood pressure, disorientation, nausea, and vomiting. If these symptoms occur, get immediate medical help. Treatment often cures the cause of hyperthyroidism and returns thyroid levels to normal."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 1% of people in the country have hyperthyroidism."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",

		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "If you have symptoms of hyperthyroidism, see your doctor to get an evaluation."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Certain medications, excess iodine"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "If you notice symptoms of hyperthyroidism, contact your doctor. If you have a fever, extreme agitation, rapid heart rate, and/or feel disoriented, get immediate medical help. These may be signs of thyroid storm, an emergency condition."
		},

			"content": "Hyperventilation is rapid or shallow breathing. Stress or anxiety usually causes it. You may feel short of breath and panicked; your hands and feet may feel numb. While frightening, hyperventilation is rarely a medical problem. However, in some cases, serious conditions -- such as lung disease or heart problems -- can trigger hyperventilation. If you're hyperventilating without a clear cause -- or for the first time -- get medical help right away to rule out other problems."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "As you breathe faster, the level of carbon dioxide in your bloodstream drops. Low carbon dioxide causes the symptoms, such as tingling in your hands and feet. Hyperventilation can feed on itself -- the symptoms make you anxious, and the more anxious you become, the worse your symptoms get. Some people have hyperventilation syndrome -- they tend to hyperventilate when they get stressed. Usually, calming yourself down with controlled breathing is the best treatment."
		},

			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "An insulin reaction happens to people with diabetes when their blood sugar level is too low, usually below 70 mg/dL. It can happen if you haven't eaten enough food, if you increase your exercise level without eating more, or if you take too much insulin. Low blood sugar can cause sweating, confusion, hunger, headache, and fatigue. If not treated, low blood sugar can cause fainting, seizures, or a coma. So it is important to recognize and treat low blood sugar right away by drinking fruit juice, eating hard candy, or taking glucose tablets."

The symptoms can vary a bit from person to person. But if your blood sugar level goes too low, you can faint, have a seizure, or go into a coma. You can avoid these severe symptoms by following your diabetes treatment plan and testing your blood sugar often. Taking steps to raise your blood sugar right away if it's too low will usually treat insulin reaction."
		},

If it's still less than 70 mg/dL, take another 15 grams of carbohydrates. Keep repeating this process until your glucose is above 70 mg/dL. 	"Low_blood_sugar_(hypoglycemia)": [{
			"heading": "Low Blood Sugar (Hypoglycemia)",
			"content": "Hypoglycemia"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tAnxiety\n\t\t•\tFatigue\n\t\t•\tNumbness or tingling\n\t\t•\tExcessive sweating\n\t\t•\tFainting\n\t\t•\tDisorientation\n\t\t•\tShaking hands or tremor\n\t\t•\tConfusion\n\t\t•\tNausea or vomiting\n\t\t•\tRapid heart rate (pulse)\n\t\t•\tTrembling\n\t\t•\tDifficulty concentrating\n\t\t•\tDrowsiness\n\t\t•\tHunger"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Low blood sugar happens when blood sugar, or glucose, levels in the blood drop too low. It causes shakiness, anxiety, clammy skin, irritability, headache, rapid heartbeat, and hunger. People with diabetes often get low blood sugar, which can be caused by diabetes medications, not eating enough, or exercising. Low blood sugar can be life-threatening for people with diabetes and cause seizures, coma, and even death. Certain medical conditions including cancer, medications, tumors, excess alcohol use, and hereditary conditions can cause low blood sugar in people who don't have diabetes. Some people have a condition called reactive hypoglycemia, which causes low blood sugar within four hours after eating. Treatment for low blood sugar depends on what's causing it. People with diabetes can prevent low blood sugar by checking their blood sugar levels regularly and keeping levels in a normal range. Treating underlying medical conditions can treat low blood sugar. Eating small meals every three hours can help manage reactive hypoglycemia."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Early symptoms of low blood sugar include trembling, tiredness, anxiety, hunger, and irritability. At the first sign of low blood sugar, people with diabetes should eat 15 grams of carbohydrates. Examples include 1 tablespoon of sugar or honey or one-half cup of fruit juice. If blood glucose levels remains below 70 mg/dL after 15 minutes, take another small serving of carbohydrates. Continue eating 15 grams and checking every 15 minutes until glucose levels rise above 70 mg/dL. Severe low blood sugar can cause mental confusion, extreme sleepiness, fainting, and coma. Anyone with these symptoms should get immediate medical attention. A major diabetes control study shows that people with diabetes who have a low blood sugar reaction have a 50% risk of experiencing another one within 24 hours, and a 25% risk of a third one in the following 24 hours."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Millions of people have occasional or mild low blood sugar, but people with diabetes who take insulin and other blood sugar-lowering medications are most susceptible to significant low blood sugar."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for low blood sugar includes:\n\t\t•\tTaking a small amount of carbohydrates\n\t\t•\tAdjusting medications\n\t\t•\tMaking changes to your diet\n\t\t•\tTreating any underlying medical conditions"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "People with diabetes can manage low blood sugar by checking blood glucose levels regularly and taking quick-fix foods as needed until blood sugar levels return to normal. People with reactive hypoglycemia can prevent low blood sugar by eating small meals three hours apart, getting regular exercise, eating a healthy diet, and not eating foods high in sugar in an empty stomach."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Taking too much insulin or diabetes medication, poor diet, not eating regular meals, over-exercising without adjusting insulin dose or diet"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "If you have symptoms of low blood sugar and don't know why, call your doctor. Symptoms of low blood sugar include shakiness, anxiety, trembling, sleepiness, rapid heartbeat, headaches, sweating, clammy skin, irritability, confusion, and hunger. Very low blood sugar can cause fainting, seizures, coma, and death. Call your doctor if you have diabetes and keep having low blood sugar because you may need to adjust your treatment plan. If symptoms of low blood glucose don't improve after taking a quick-fix food, or if symptoms get worse, get immediate medical attention."
		},

People with social anxiety disorder may find any kind of social contact overwhelming, from paying a cashier to eating lunch with a coworker. They may have an intense fear of being judged or embarrassing themselves. They may dread a social interaction for weeks in advance and dwell on it afterward. Their personal lives, friendships, and their ability to go to school or work may suffer. Social anxiety disorder is very treatable. Therapy and sometimes medication can help many people with social anxiety disorder."

Therapy -- one-on-one or in a group -- can help. With an expert, people can work through their fear with controlled exposure to situations that cause anxiety. Many people also benefit from medications for anxiety or depression."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "A thyroid storm occurs when the thyroid gland goes into overdrive, producing dangerously high levels of thyroid hormone. It often is associated with Graves' disease or hyperthyroidism. Symptoms include high fever, racing heartbeat, and excessive sweating. This is a life-threatening condition that requires immediate emergency care. Emergency room doctors treat thyroid storm by administering electrolytes, intravenous fluids, as well as drugs to block the production of thyroid hormone or control their effect on tissues and organs like the heart (beta blockers)."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",

			"content": "Untreated, thyroid storm can be fatal. But with quick diagnosis and treatment, the prognosis is good. Overall, 80%-90% of people with thyroid storm survive."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Doctors will give you intravenous fluids, electrolytes, and oxygen if needed to stabilize your condition. They will then try to determine the cause of the thyroid storm. Medications may include drugs to lower fever, reduce inflammation, and block the production of thyroid hormones. Beta blockers are also important."
		},

	"Hypopituitarism": [{
			"heading": "Hypopituitarism",
			"content": "Pituitary gland deficiency"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tAnxiety\n\t\t•\tConstipation\n\t\t•\tFatigue\n\t\t•\tIncreased thirst\n\t\t•\tNausea or vomiting\n\t\t•\tWeight loss (unintentional)\n\t\t•\tTires quickly\n\t\t•\tLow blood pressure\n\t\t•\tWeakness (generalized)\n\t\t•\tIncreased sensitivity to cold\n\t\t•\tDepressed mood\n\t\t•\tFrequent urination\n\t\t•\tIrregular menstrual periods\n\t\t•\tWeight gain\n\t\t•\tMuscle weakness\n\t\t•\tHair loss\n\t\t•\tMissed or late menstrual period"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Hypopituitarism is a rare disorder in which the pituitary glands don't make enough hormones. Since these hormones are crucial in many bodily functions -- such as growth, metabolism, and sexual development -- hypopituitarism can cause many different symptoms. Benign tumors, head injuries, or infections can trigger hypopituitarism. Most people do well with treatment to control the underlying problem and relieve the symptoms, but treatment may be life-long. Keep in mind that less serious conditions can cause many of the same symptoms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "The pituitary gland usually produces eight different hormones. Hypopituitarism symptoms depend on which hormone levels are low. Children with hypopituitarism may have delayed growth and sexual development. Adults may have fatigue, hair loss from the armpits and pubic area, low libido, and weight changes. Doctors will want to find the underlying cause first. If a tumor is causing hypopituitarism, the doctor may use radiation to shrink it or surgery to remove it. Afterward, many people need ongoing hormone replacement therapy to keep symptoms under control."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Hypopituitarism is rare. Fewer than 200,000 people in the country have hypopituitarism"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Head injuries, brain or pituitary tumors, brain infections, brain surgery, radiation, tuberculosis, aneurisms, stroke, other brain disorders, pregnancy, sarcoidosis and other rare conditions"
		},

This rare disease causes anxiety, depression, and trouble sleeping. Over time a person has difficulty walking and controlling their muscles. Doctors don't know what causes it, although researchers say it's a problem with the way the brain deals with pain signals. Fibromyalgia is most common in women ages 20 to 50, but anyone can get it. Symptoms can be managed through lifestyle changes that include a healthy diet and exercise, medications, and reducing stress. You may need to see a rheumatologist or a chronic pain specialist to help manage your condition."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",

Pain and stiffness are often worse in the morning. You also may feel very tired, have trouble sleeping or concentrating, or have frequent headaches. There is no cure for fibromyalgia, but medications and lifestyle changes can help relieve symptoms."

	"Pellagra": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tApathy\n\t\t•\tDelusions"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Pellagra is a late stage of severe vitamin B3, or niacin, deficiency. Its symptoms have been referred to as the four Ds: dermatitis, diarrhea, dementia, and death. Pellagra is most common in cultures with diets based on corn, which lacks nutritionally available niacin and tryptophan, an amino acid that the body synthesizes into B3. In the country, it occurs rarely, primarily in long-term alcoholics and people whose bodies don't convert tryptophan well. Though it can be fatal if not treated, bed rest, niacin supplements, and a high-protein diet clear it up."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "At first, you may feel weak. Soon you may have gastrointestinal symptoms such as poor appetite, nausea, abdominal pain or discomfort, and diarrhea. After that, you may feel a burning sensation on your skin and develop a dark, scaly, pigmented rash on parts of your body that are exposed to sunlight. If you develop glossitis, your tongue may swell and turn bright red. In the early stages of pellagra, you may be depressed, lethargic, and apathetic, and have trouble concentrating. As the disease advances, you may become confused, forgetful, and disoriented, have hallucinations, and go into a coma. Vitamin therapy with oral niacin or nicotinamide, a component of the B-complex vitamins, helps clear up pellagra. If you are malnourished, a high-protein diet and B-complex vitamins will also help restore your health. You may see results within a few days. Topical emollients can help clear up skin symptoms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Pellagra is very rare in Western culture but still occurs in undernourished adults in poor African countries."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Chronic alcoholism, poor diet, taking the tuberculosis drug isoniazid, gastrointestinal conditions such as chronic diarrhea or inflammatory bowel disease, carcinoid tumors, extreme stress or trauma, prolonged fever"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for pellagra may include:\n\t\t•\tBed rest\n\t\t•\tOral nicotinamide or niacin\n\t\t•\tHigh-protein diet and B-complex vitamins for malnutrition\n\t\t•\tLiquid or soft diet if a swollen tongue makes chewing and swallowing difficult\n\t\t•\tTopical medication to reduce discomfort from cuts or sores on skin"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "The self-care strategies can help you get B3 in your diet daily, to prevent niacin deficiency:\n\t\t•\tHave some avocado with your eggs or on your bagel in the morning. Or eat fortified cereal.\n\t\t•\tHave a lean chicken or turkey sandwich for lunch.\n\t\t•\tHave salmon, halibut, or trout for dinner."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",

	"Alopecia": [{
			"heading": "Alopecia",
			"content": "Hair loss, baldness, alopecia universalis"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tBald spots (hair)\n\t\t•\tSkin rash\n\t\t•\tBrittle hair\n\t\t•\tItching or burning\n\t\t•\tHair loss"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Alopecia is the medical term for losing hair or going bald. It refers to many types of balding, from typical male balding to the balding caused by chemotherapy. Male-pattern baldness, the most common type of hair loss, can progress over a period of years. The earlier it starts, the balder you are likely to become. Other types of hair loss, such as that caused by the physical stress of an illness or surgery, can happen suddenly. Some medications can cause hair loss. Balding also can result from a medical condition such as lupus or diabetes. Alopecia areata is an autoimmune disease that causes hair to fall out in patches from the scalp and other areas of the body. Some types of hair loss are permanent. Others will reverse themselves or can be reversed with proper treatment."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "It depends on what causes your balding. Men with male-pattern balding usually lose hair on top, with just a little remaining on the sides of the head. Women usually have thinning hair on top, and may have some bald patches. The immune disorder alopecia areata often causes a sudden loss of hair in one spot. Hair loss caused by physical stress may occur several months after the illness or surgery is over. With chemotherapy, hair loss typically starts a few weeks after treatment starts. Hair usually grows back 2-3 months after treatment stops."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Hereditary hair loss affects about 80 million men and women in the country By comparison, the autoimmune disorder alopecia areata affects about 4.5 million people in the country at some time in their lives."
		},

	"Telogen_effluvium": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tBald spots (hair)\n\t\t•\tHair loss"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Telogen effluvium is thinning of hair on the scalp. Telogen effluvium does not cause baldness, but it can cause noticeable, uneven thinning. It often starts suddenly one to five months after a person has experienced a shock to their system. In the country, childbirth, severe illness, medications, and crash diets are common causes. The hair usually grows back naturally with time. If the cause is an underlying condition, such as mild iron deficiency or stress, treating the condition helps clear it up. In some cases, telogen effluvium is chronic."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Telogen effluvium happens in three ways. If there is a shock to your system, the hair on your head may begin coming out in handfuls a month or two later when you shampoo or comb your hair. You could rapidly lose up to half of your hair. You may also shed pubic and eyebrow hair. If the trigger to hair loss is short-lived, this will slow over six to eight months and your hair should return to its normal fullness within a year. If the trigger for telogen effluvium is ongoing, the condition can start slower and last longer. In this form, your scalp hair thins because less hair is growing, but you may not shed much hair. In the third pattern, your hair goes through shortened growth cycles. You may shed short, thin hair fibers over a longer period of time. With any form of telogen effluvium, it's important to determine the cause. If it is reversible, treating the cause will restore your hair growth."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Telogen effluvium is likely the second most common cause of hair loss."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Sudden telogen effluvium due to a short-term cause, such as childbirth or a high fever, resolves spontaneously. Telogen effluvia due to an ongoing cause -- such as poor diet, iron deficiency, hyperthyroidism, chronic stress, or medication -- is reversed by treating the cause."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "These self-care strategies may help protect against hair loss after pregnancy:\n\t\t•\tAvoid wearing your hair in cornrows, hair weaves, braids, or pigtails, which pull your hair.\n\t\t•\tEat plenty of fruits and vegetables. They contain antioxidants and flavonoids, which may protect hair follicles and promote growth of hair.\n\t\t•\tUse shampoos and conditioners with biotin and silica.\n\nAsk your doctor if taking vitamin supplement is appropriate."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Hair loss may be more severe if telogen effluvium occurs at the same time as another hair loss disease."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "See your doctor if you have symptoms of telogen effluvia."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",

			"heading": "Short-Acting Sedative Use",
			"content": "Benzodiazepine use, barbiturate use"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tBlackouts (memory time loss)\n\t\t•\tEarly morning waking\n\t\t•\tMemory problems"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Short-acting sedatives are a common type of medication used to treat a wide variety of conditions, from insomnia and anxiety to amnesia. They are a type of depressant and are sold under many names, including Ativan, Klonopin, Valium, and Xanax. While these drugs can help ease the symptoms of many conditions, they can also cause side effects. Short-acting sedatives can cause drowsiness, vertigo, poor concentration, double vision, muscle weakness, slurred speech, memory problems, irritability, and depression. The symptoms can vary widely from person to person. In most cases, the higher your dose, the more likely you are to have symptoms. People who take short-acting sedatives over a long time may also develop an addiction to these drugs."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "The side effects you have will depend on the type of short-acting sedative, your dose, and how your body reacts to the medication. Your doctor will work with you to find the right dose for you. In many cases, people get used to the side effects over time. If you have a side effect that you don't like, your doctor might lower your dose or prescribe another kind of medication."
		},

	"Epilepsy_(absence_or_petit_mal_seizures)": [{
			"heading": "Epilepsy (Absence or Petit Mal Seizures)",
			"content": "Absence seizures, petit mal seizures, seizure disorder"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",

		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Epilepsy is a brain disorder where the nerve cells in the brain signal abnormally and become overactive, causing seizures. There are many different kinds of seizures that cause a range of symptoms. Seizures can last from a few seconds to a few minutes and may occur several times a day or only occasionally. Most people experience the same type of seizure from one episode to the next. Petit mal or absence seizures cause staring spells or chewing motions. Partial or focal seizures cause small, repetitive movements from lip smacking to head tilting along with other symptoms such as hallucinations. Generalized tonic-clonic or grand mal seizures cause a person to cry out, fall down, lose consciousness, and have violent muscle contractions, which cause incontinence and convulsions. Epilepsy can affect anyone and usually has no clear cause. Stroke, brain injury, brain illness or infection, brain tumors, birth defects of the brain, certain diseases, and kidney or liver failure can also cause epilepsy. Treatment with anticonvulsive medication, surgery, or vagus nerve stimulation can help people with epilepsy manage their condition. Following a special high-fat diet may help prevent seizures in children with epilepsy."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Epilepsy can't be cured, but if it is well-controlled with medication, it sometimes goes away on its own. Some types of epilepsy that start in childhood go away with age. But many people will have epilepsy for their entire life. Medication and other treatments control seizures in nearly 80% of people with epilepsy. In people with epilepsy caused by another condition, such as a brain tumor, treating the underlying cause may stop seizures from occurring. Seizures usually don't cause permanent harm, but people with poorly controlled seizures should not drive cars or operate machinery. Prolonged seizures that last longer than five minutes require emergency treatment to prevent brain damage and death."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Two million people in the country have epilepsy."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Epilepsy treatment may include:\n\t\t•\tAnticonvulsive medication\n\t\t•\tSpecial diets for children with epilepsy\n\t\t•\tBrain surgery\n\t\t•\tVagus nerve stimulator"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Along with medical treatment, getting enough sleep, not drinking alcohol to excess, taking epilepsy medication as directed, and trying to avoid stress may help prevent seizures."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Alcohol, illicit drug use, stress, not getting enough sleep, not taking epilepsy medications, hormonal changes, illness, smoking, flashing lights"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "If you have epilepsy and seizures that occur more frequently, the type of seizure changes, or you become injured from a seizure, see your doctor. If this is your first seizure, or you have epilepsy and have seizures that last more than five minutes or have trouble breathing or lasting confusion, get immediate medical help."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",

			"content": "Transient global amnesia is a sudden loss of memory. It's an alarming but harmless condition. Symptoms usually last for hours and then memory returns. It has no lasting consequences. Doctors aren't sure what causes it. It's more common in people over age 50. Anyone with symptoms needs emergency help. While transient global amnesia is not medically serious, more common and more serious conditions such as stroke can cause the same symptoms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Transient global amnesia is most likely to occur after physical exertion or emotional stress. People with transient global amnesia may be confused about the time or where they are. Usually, they will remember their names and recognize people they know well, but not recall recent events. This typically lasts for several hours, but it can last days. After the condition subsides, people have no lasting effects, although they may not remember the time during the attack clearly. There is no treatment for transient global amnesia. Most people only have it once. Between 5% and 25% of people will have transient global amnesia again."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Trauma most often refers to serious bodily injury or wounds. Accidents, falls, blows, burns, or weapons can cause physical trauma. But trauma can also be emotional or psychological injury from an extremely distressing or shocking event, such as an accident, rape, the breakup of a relationship, or a loved one's sudden death. It can occur without physical injury. Acute trauma symptoms are those that happen immediately after injury – such as bruises or bleeding, or shock and denial. Chronic trauma symptoms can occur long after an injury appears to have healed. They can be physical – like pain, headaches, or fatigue – or emotional – like anger, anxiety, and difficulty concentrating. Trauma usually requires medical or psychological treatment."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "Call the emergency services (even if you can't speak) if an injury is life threatening, your condition could become worse on the way to a hospital, or moving you would cause further injury. Any serious trauma to the head, neck, or chest is an emergency.\n\nSymptoms that require emergency medical treatment include:\n\t\t•\tDifficulty breathing or not breathing\n\t\t•\tLoss of consciousness\n\t\t•\tSudden or intense pain\n\t\t•\tSevere bleeding that won't stop after 10 minutes of direct pressure\n\t\t•\tMental change\n\t\t•\tSudden intense pain or headache\n\t\t•\tCoughing up or vomiting blood\n\t\t•\tSuicidal or homicidal feelings\n\nIf you suspect that you have a spinal injury, it's important not to be moved."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Physical trauma usually causes acute physical symptoms. If an injury is life threatening, you'll be treated in an emergency room. If it is urgent but not life threatening, such as a broken bone, you may be treated at a doctor's office or an emergency room and released. You could need surgery, medications, hospitalization, physical therapy, and self-care for physical trauma. Sometimes symptoms of physical trauma are slightly delayed, such as head and neck pain that appears the day after an auto accident. But they can also be delayed months or even years. For example, you could have sudden or gradual pain months after a spinal cord wound. Weeks after a concussion clears up, you may have headaches, mood swings, depression, or difficulty remembering. These symptoms need treatment, but it may be different from the treatment you'd get for acute symptoms.\n\nIf you experience emotional trauma, you may feel anxious, depressed, and unable to eat or sleep. The symptoms may go away or let up after weeks or months, and you're able to resume normal activities. If they don't go away or if they resurface in stressful situations, you may have post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). You could have nightmares or flashbacks, feel emotionally numb or vulnerable, have attention or memory deficits, or other symptoms that affect your relationships or work. A therapist who is experienced in treating trauma can help you deal with thoughts, feelings, and behaviors resulting from trauma with counseling or medication."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for physical trauma depends on the nature and severity of the injury. Surgery, medical procedures, medication, and physical or occupational therapy are common treatments.
