		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "If you think a physical injury does not require medical care, these self-care strategies may help:\n\nFor a minor head injury, apply ice to reduce swelling. If you're not sure how serious a head injury is, don't go to sleep for at least 12 hours so that you can be alert to changes in mental status.\n\nFor strains, bumps, and bruises, use the RICE method: Rest the area, apply ice for 15 minutes at a time to reduce swelling, compress by wrapping in an Ace or other bandage, and elevate to reduce blood flow to the area.\n\nTo stop bleeding, apply firm but gentle pressure, using a clean cloth or gauze, for 10 minutes. If blood soaks through the gauze, add another piece of gauze on top of the first and continue to apply pressure.\n\nImmerse a burn in cool water for 15 minutes or until pain subsides. Apply antibiotic cream and cover with a sterile, nonstick dressing.\n\nFor open wounds, clean well with warm water and soap, apply antibiotic cream or ointment, and cover with a sterile dressing.\n\nThese self-care strategies may help symptoms of emotional trauma:\n\t\t•\tGive yourself time to heal.\n\t\t•\tAvoid making major life decisions until you heal.\n\t\t•\tJoin a support group for people who have been through a similar type of trauma.\n\t\t•\tCommunicate your feelings to a trusted friend or family member, or keep a diary.\n\t\t•\tEstablish or reestablish routines such as regular times for sleeping, eating, exercising, relaxing, and hobbies.\n\t\t•\tKeep healthy to cope better. Eat nutritious foods, exercise regularly, get plenty of rest, and avoid alcohol and drugs."

	"Osteogenesis_imperfecta": [{
			"heading": "Osteogenesis Imperfecta",
			"content": "Brittle bone disease, OI"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "Broken bones (multiple fractures)"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Osteogenesis imperfecta is a condition that causes very fragile bones that break easily. People are born with this condition, and in most cases it is inherited from a parent. Osteogenesis imperfecta is usually caused by a defect in the gene that makes collagen. There are several types of osteogenesis imperfecta, and the symptoms can range from mild to severe. The mild type is the most common. Osteogenesis imperfecta can cause broken bones, hearing loss, a blue tint in the whites of the eyes, short height, loose joints, flat feet, and poor teeth. More severe cases can cause bowed arms and legs or a curving of the spine. In very severe cases, it can cause death."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Osteogenesis imperfecta is usually diagnosed in childhood, but very mild cases are sometimes not diagnosed until later in life. In most cases, people with osteogenesis imperfecta have a normal life span. But the most severe type usually causes death by age 1. There is no cure for osteogenesis imperfecta, but treatments can help reduce the symptoms. Bisphosphonate drugs can help increase bone strength and reduce fractures. Regular exercise can also help keep bones strong. Some people may need surgery to correct deformities or strengthen bones."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About one in every 20,000 babies is born with osteogenesis imperfecta."

	"Hematoma": [{
			"heading": "Hematoma",
			"content": "Blood blister, blood tumor"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tBruising or discoloration\n\t\t•\tTenderness to touch"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "A hematoma is a collection of blood that pools in tissue outside of a damaged blood vessel, usually after an injury. Hematomas look like a deep bruise and range in size from very small to as large as a grapefruit. Taking blood thinners--even aspirin--can increase the risk for hematomas. Most hematomas under the skin and fingernails go away on their own. However, subdural hematomas that form between the brain and skull are very dangerous and even fatal if not treated quickly."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Your body will reabsorb a small hematoma within a week or two. You'll notice it changing color from purples and blues to yellows and browns as it breaks down. A large hematoma can take months to reabsorb. The large amount of decomposing blood cells increases the risk of infection and other complications. A doctor can drain a large hematoma to reduce the risk. Subdural hematomas, which are usually picked up on CT and MRI scans taken after head trauma, need to be drained immediately by a doctor."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "There are many millions of hematomas, large and small, in the country every year. Subdural hematomas in the brain are twice as common in men compared to women, possibly because men are more likely to participate in high-risk activities."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "For hematomas of the skin and muscles, treatment includes:\n\t\t•\tResting the injury\n\t\t•\tIcing the area\n\t\t•\tElevation and/or compression with an elastic bandage\n\t\t•\tTaking over-the-counter pain medication\n\nA large internal hematoma, which may become infected, should be treated by a doctor. Depending on the size and location, your doctor may drain the blood from it.\n\nFor a subdural hematoma, doctors may perform emergency surgery to relieve the pressure on the brain."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Most small hematomas clear up on their own. However, you can drain a hematoma under a fingernail or toenail to relieve pain and pressure. Heat the end of a paper clip until it's red-hot and push it through the nail to allow blood to escape. If you aren't comfortable doing this, your doctor can drain the hematoma. Otherwise, just watch and wait as the body naturally reabsorbs the blood over time."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "A red, swollen area near a hematoma may be a sign of infection and should be evaluated by your doctor. If you have abdominal or other significant trauma or have had surgery and develop pain in the area, see your doctor right away. If you have serious head trauma, go immediately to an emergency room."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",

	"Thrombocytopenia": [{
			"heading": "Thrombocytopenia",
			"content": "Platelet deficiency, low platelet count"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tBruising or discoloration\n\t\t•\tBlood or red colored urine\n\t\t•\tBlack (tar) colored stools\n\t\t•\tEasy bruising\n\t\t•\tNosebleed\n\t\t•\tBleeding gums\n\t\t•\tBloody or red colored stools\n\t\t•\tEasy bleeding\n\t\t•\tHeavy menstrual bleeding\n\t\t•\tProlonged bleeding"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Thrombocytopenia is a condition in which a person has a low level of platelets in the blood. Since platelets help the blood clot, thrombocytopenia can lead to excessive bleeding inside the body or on the skin. Thrombocytopenia causes bruising, frequent nosebleeds, and tiny red dots that look like a rash. Mild cases may need no treatment. Severe cases can be life-threatening. Pregnancy, aspirin and other medications, diseases and immune disorders, and chemotherapy can cause it. Most people do well with treatment, although the specific approach depends on the underlying cause."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Symptoms may develop slowly or suddenly. Bleeding under the skin may cause petechiae, which look like a rash of tiny, red dots. When pressed, they won't lose their color like a normal rash. The skin will also be smooth. Purpura are larger red or purple bruises. Excessive blood loss can be dangerous. It may occur in the stomach or intestines, causing bloody stool or vomit. Bleeding in the brain can cause a stroke. Treatment depends on the underlying cause. For some people, stopping a medication is enough. Others need to stay in the hospital to get treatment. Thrombocytopenia may last days or years, depending on the cause."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Millions of people have some form of thrombocytopenia in the country One type, idiopathic or immune thrombocytopenic purpura, affects about 100,000 to 150,000 people a year."
		},

		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Brain injuries are typically caused by trauma to the head, and can cause effects that last a lifetime. Problems with memory, attention, sight, language, movement, and mood are common. Severe brain injuries often involve many areas of the brain and can lead to a variety of disabilities, including coma. Treatment depends on a person's symptoms and may be lifelong. But many people with brain injuries are able to return to their regular work and home life."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Recovery for severe brain injuries is most rapid within the first six months. After that, you may have gradual recovery for several years. Some symptoms may go away with time and treatment, and others may require continued support and assistance. Right after your injury, you may have headache, nausea, dizziness, confusion, agitation, and amnesia. Some symptoms, such as headache, may continue for several months. Later, brain injury may affect your ability to manage things when you return to regular work, home, or school. You may become easily confused, unable to concentrate, or have problems with abstract reasoning and problem solving. You may have memory loss and be unable to form or store new memories. Trouble understanding language or speaking is also common. You're more likely to have these problems if the injury was severe, but repeated mild injuries can also cause them."
		},

			"heading": "Carbon Monoxide Poisoning",
			"content": "CO poisoning"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tComa\n\t\t•\tFatigue\n\t\t•\tMemory problems\n\t\t•\tLoss of consciousness\n\t\t•\tDizziness\n\t\t•\tHeadache\n\t\t•\tNausea or vomiting\n\t\t•\tUnable to blink or close eyelid"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Carbon monoxide (CO) is a colorless and odorless gas that can cause severe and fatal poisoning. It's in gasoline and diesel exhaust, and can be produced by anything that burns fuel, natural gas heaters, fireplaces, woodstoves, and kerosene heaters. Carbon monoxide is dangerous even in small amounts, because it binds with blood cells much more rapidly and efficiently than oxygen. If heaters and stoves are not used properly, carbon monoxide can build up to dangerous levels quickly in closed spaces like a room or a garage. Carbon monoxide poisoning can cause headache, dizziness, nausea, and vomiting. But someone who is sleeping or intoxicated may not notice the symptoms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "Carbon monoxide poisoning is a medical emergency. Seek medical care immediately if you think you have been exposed to high levels of carbon monoxide."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "The first sign of carbon monoxide poisoning is usually a dull headache. You also may feel dizzy, confused, or nauseated. If you are exposed to low levels of CO, you may have these symptoms over a period of time. These symptoms usually get better when you leave the area where the CO is built up. You may not realize you have carbon monoxide poisoning, because the symptoms are similar to other illnesses. Very high levels of carbon monoxide poisoning can cause brain damage or death. You can treat most cases of carbon monoxide poisoning by getting fresh air or oxygen when you first notice symptoms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for carbon monoxide poisoning may include oxygen or hyperbaric oxygen therapy."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "See your doctor if you have any symptoms of carbon monoxide poisoning."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "In people with diabetes, diabetic ketoacidosis happens when your body doesn't have enough insulin and starts burning fat for energy. This causes a toxic buildup of acids called ketones in the blood – a sign that your diabetes is out of control. If untreated, it can lead to diabetic coma and death. Ketoacidosis happens most often in people with type 1 diabetes. Being sick, missing an insulin dose, not eating well, heart attack, stroke, alcohol abuse, or even stress may trigger it. If you develop ketoacidosis, you may be very thirsty and nauseated. You'll need to be treated in the hospital with IV fluids containing insulin and electrolytes. With aggressive treatment, most people completely recover."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "Immediately see your doctor or go to a hospital emergency room if you have symptoms of ketoacidosis."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Infection, missing doses of insulin, and not knowing you have diabetes most commonly cause diabetic ketoacidosis. It usually comes on over about 24 hours, starting with symptoms such as dry mouth, thirst, and frequent urination. Then you may have fatigue, nausea, abdominal pain, and a hard time breathing. If vomiting occurs, ketoacidosis can develop very rapidly. You'll be treated in the hospital for dehydration and other symptoms with intravenous fluids and insulin. If the condition is mild, you may be sent home with instructions for monitoring and controlling your blood sugar and urinary ketone levels. If your diabetic ketoacidosis is more serious, you'll be kept in the hospital for additional monitoring and treatment for the cause of your ketoacidosis."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Poor diet, lack of insulin, dehydration"
		},

		},

		},

		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Generally, a drug overdose causes extreme versions of a drug's normal effect. For instance, too much of a blood pressure-lowering drug may reduce blood pressure to dangerous levels. Drug overdoses can cause sleepiness, confusion, low breathing rate, abdominal pain, shortness of breath, extreme agitation, and many other problems depending on the drug. Most people recover fully from unintentional overdoses, although certain drug overdoses may cause lasting damage. Recovery from an intentional overdose depends on whether the underlying psychiatric problems can be adequately treated."

		},

If you suspect someone in your family is using illicit drugs, seek help for him or her."

			"heading": "Overview",

Lightning, fallen electrical cables, or faulty wiring are common causes of electrical injuries. Children may injure themselves biting on wires or poking objects in an outlet. Some electrical injuries are minor while others are fatal. Electrical injury is always a medical emergency."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "Anyone who has had an electrical injury needs emergency help. Call the emergency services or get the person to the emergency room."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Burns are the most common electrical injury. They may be mild or severe. Shocks can cause muscle contractions and trauma that can injure the spine and break bones. Electrical injuries can also cause the heart to stop. Even injuries that look minor may have caused severe internal damage. Be very careful when trying to help someone who has an electrical injury. If the person is still exposed to live current, touching him or her could injure you. Some people develop complications, such as unstable heartbeat or other serious problems, hours or days after the injury. Many people need monitoring for a few days. Most people who don't have severe burns or cardiac arrest recover fully after an electrical injury. Some have lasting problems, such as personality changes and seizure disorders."

If you cannot turn off the power, use an object that won't conduct electricity -- such as a wooden pole or rubber mat -- to push the person away from the electrical source. Once you are sure the person is no longer conducting electricity, examine the person. If the person has no pulse or has stopped breathing, perform CPR. Rinse electrical burns with cold water."

			"content": "Head injury occurs when the brain, skull, or scalp are injured. Vehicle accidents, falls from windows, falls at home, accidents at work, and mishaps while playing sports can all cause head injuries. Head injuries usually happen to males, and about half of the people who go to the hospital for a head injury are age 24 or younger. Common types of head injuries include cuts on the scalp, concussions (the accident shakes the brain), contusions or bruises on the brain, and skull fractures. Head injuries may not be visible in cases where the brain knocks against the skull, but there could still be inflammation or bleeding. That's why you need to get medical care immediately. Most people recover with no long-term problems, but surgery may be necessary in some cases. Serious head injuries can cause permanent brain damage or death."

This can lead to brain damage, which is sometimes permanent. Accidents that cause head injuries can damage the spinal cord as well. 	"Hypothermia": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "Coma"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Hypothermia develops when your temperature drops too low. Your body can't keep itself warm enough and starts to shut down. You may start shaking and become confused. Some people get it after being outside too long in the cold. The conditions don't have to be extreme -- an infant or an older person can get hypothermia inside if they're in a chilly room for too long. Alcohol, mental illness, and other conditions increase the risk. Hypothermia needs medical attention right away. Untreated, it can be deadly."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "Hypothermia is an emergency. If you or anyone else has any symptoms -- especially if the body temperature drops below 95 degrees Fahrenheit -- get medical help immediately."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Once symptoms start, move into a warmer area and get medical attention right away. Most people will do well with basic treatments such as covering with blankets and drinking warm beverages. As long as you treat it quickly, hypothermia doesn't usually cause lasting problems. If a person's temperature drops below 95 degrees Fahrenheit, it's a medical emergency."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Staying in the cold despite symptoms, not wearing enough warm clothing, keeping the heat too low inside"
		},

			"content": "Myxedema coma occurs when someone loses brain function because of long-term low levels of thyroid hormone in the blood. It is a rare but serious condition that needs emergency treatment. Infection, certain drugs, injury, stroke, and exposure to cold can cause myxedema coma in someone who has untreated hypothyroidism. It is most common in older women during the winter months. Myxedema coma can cause low body temperature, thin hair, mental changes, seizures, swelling in the face, legs, or feet. In severe cases, it can cause coma and death."

			"content": "Narcotic abuse occurs when you take illegal narcotic drugs, such as heroin, or misuse prescription narcotics. Narcotic drugs stimulate the central nervous system. They can block the sensation of pain and make you feel elated, relaxed, and sleepy. Many people take prescription narcotics to relieve pain. But if you take narcotics that aren't prescribed, or if you take them for reasons other than why they are prescribed, you may be abusing them. Abusing narcotics can cause serious health problems and can lead to addiction."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "When used correctly, prescription narcotics are an effective way to manage pain. They can be used for short time periods without having any negative effects. But when you use narcotics for a longer time, your body can become addicted. You may have to decrease your dose slowly over time to avoid symptoms of withdrawal. When you use narcotic drugs for a reason other than the intended medical purpose or use more than the prescribed dose, it is called abuse. Abusing narcotic drugs over a period of time can cause intense withdrawal symptoms when you try to stop. The longer you have been taking the narcotics, the more severe your withdrawal symptoms will be. Narcotics abuse can be treated with medications and behavioral counseling."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "A brain infection occurs when the brain, spinal cord, or membranes surrounding them become inflamed. Brain infections can be life threatening, so it's important to seek immediate medical care. There are different types of brain infections. Meningitis is an infection of the membranes surrounding the brain and spinal cord. Encephalitis is an infection of the brain itself. Viruses and bacteria commonly cause brain infections. Other less common causes include fungus, parasites, a type of protein called prions, and brain or spine abscesses. Mosquito and tick bites can spread certain types of encephalitis. A brain infection causes the brain to swell and can cause sleepiness, fever, headaches, neck pain and stiffness, nausea, fatigue, confusion, sensitivity to light, seizures, loss of consciousness, and coma. Treatment depends on the cause and ranges from self-care at home to hospitalization and IV medications."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "Get immediate medical attention if you have symptoms of a brain infection."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "When symptoms appear, how long they last and what type of treatment depend on the cause of the brain infection. Symptoms may come on slowly and be mild and flu-like, or they can come on suddenly, causing seizures, loss of consciousness, and coma. Anyone with symptoms of a brain infection should get immediate medical attention. Treatment includes self-care at home or hospitalization. Medications may help ease symptoms and cure the infection. Recovery takes anywhere from 1 to 2 weeks to several months. Serious infections can result in damage to the nervous system and deafness."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Waiting to get medical treatment"

Cancerous primary brain tumors can spread to other parts of the brain or spinal cord. Secondary brain tumors start somewhere else in the body and spread to the brain. See a doctor if you have any symptoms of a brain tumor such as seizures, ongoing headaches, or loss of coordination. Keep in mind that more common and less worrisome conditions can cause similar symptoms."

Other brain tumors can't be cured, and treatment focuses on relieving symptoms. Early detection can lead to more successful treatment."

	"Japanese_encephalitis": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tComa\n\t\t•\tLoss of consciousness"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Japanese encephalitis (JE) is a disease that causes brain inflammation and swelling. A virus spread by mosquitoes in rural areas of Asia causes it. JE is not contagious, and you can't catch it by being around, touching, or kissing someone who has it. Mild cases may go away on their own, but severe cases can be life-threatening. Only about one in every 250 people infected develops a severe case of encephalitis. JE does not occur in the United States or Europe. People mainly at risk are those who live or work in rural areas of Asia and members of the military who are deployed there. Treatment for mild cases involves rest and over-the-counter medications for pain and fever. In severe cases, the person may need to be hospitalized."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Most people with JE have minor symptoms while the disease runs its course. There is no specific treatment for JE. A severe infection usually comes on suddenly. The doctor will monitor the person's brain swelling. The person may need help breathing, IV fluids, and anti-seizure medication. About a third of the people who develop a severe form of the disease and live have long-lasting effects in their central nervous system."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "In Asia, the Japanese encephalitis virus is the most common cause of encephalitis, with 30,000 to 50,000 cases of JE each year. The disease is rare among Americans with less than one case per year in people traveling to or living in Asia."
		},

		},

		},

In rare cases, it can cause severe symptoms such as a high fever, confusion, stiff neck, muscle weakness, and convulsions. Those who have a chronic disease or who are over age 50 are at higher risk for more severe illness."

			"content": "cardiogenic shock, hypovolemic shock, septic shock, neurogenic shock"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tComa\n\t\t•\tDizziness\n\t\t•\tLoss of consciousness\n\t\t•\tCold hands\n\t\t•\tLow blood pressure\n\t\t•\tConfusion\n\t\t•\tExcessive sweating\n\t\t•\tDisorientation\n\t\t•\tCold feet"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Shock is a life-threatening condition that occurs when the body doesn't get enough blood and oxygen flowing to the organs. Any type of condition that reduces blood flow can cause it, including heart problems, spinal injuries, severe allergic reactions, infection, heavy bleeding, and certain medications. Shock causes very low blood pressure and can also cause anxiety, chest pain, confusion, dizziness, heavy sweating, and shallow breathing. If you think someone is experiencing shock, call the emergency services."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "Seek emergency care if you or someone you are with has any symptoms of shock."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "The symptoms of shock can get worse very quickly and damage the organs. Shock needs immediate emergency treatment or it can be fatal."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Not getting treatment right away"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for shock depends on what's causing the shock. First aid measures include:\n\t\t•\tCalling the emergency services\n\t\t•\tHaving the person lie down with their feet elevated, as long as there is no injury to the head, legs, neck, or spine\n\t\t•\tGiving first aid for any injuries\n\t\t•\tKeeping the person warm\n\t\t•\tBegin CPR if needed\n\nAt the hospital, treatments may include:\n\t\t•\tIV fluids\n\t\t•\tBlood products\n\t\t•\tMedications to increase blood pressure\n\t\t•\tOxygen\n\t\t•\tPacemaker\n\t\t•\tBreathing machine\n\t\t•\tSurgery"

			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is a very common developmental disorder that makes it difficult to concentrate, stay still, and control impulses. ADHD usually begins in childhood but often is not diagnosed until adolescence or adulthood. Treatment with medications, therapy, and educational intervention can help. At home, parents can help children with ADHD -- and themselves -- by creating a regular, predictable, and supportive routine."

			"heading": "How Common",

		{
			"heading": "Self Care",

		},
		{
			"heading": "Bipolar Disorder Overview",
			"content": "Bipolar disorder causes extreme mood swings between depression and mania. When depressed, you may feel utterly hopeless. When manic, you may feel elated, productive, and full of energy. People around you may find you frantic, irritable, and reckless. The cycles may last for days, weeks, or months. Untreated, bipolar disorder is destructive and dangerous. Medication -- often coupled with therapy -- can help control symptoms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Bipolar disorder most often appears in late teens and young adults. But it can develop at any age. There are several types. Bipolar disorder type I causes depression and at least one period of mania. Bipolar disorder type II causes depression that alternates with mild mania, called hypomania. Bipolar disorder can have a serious impact on family and career. During manic or hypomanic phases, you may not believe that anything is wrong. But when depressed, you may not be able to function. Bipolar disorder is a life-long condition. Often it gets better and worse at different times of your life. Most people need ongoing treatment. Untreated bipolar disorder tends to get more severe."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "More than 1 in 40 adults in the country have bipolar disorder."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Risk factors for bipolar disorder include a family history of bipolar disorder or a similar condition. Substance abuse, stress, trauma, not getting enough sleep, thyroid problems, and steroids may trigger a mood swing."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatments for bipolar disorder include:\n\t\t•\tMedications called mood stabilizers, such as lithium\n\t\t•\tSome antidepressants, especially when used with a mood stabilizer (some antidepressants can trigger a manic episode)\n\t\t•\tOther drugs\n\t\t•\tElectroconvulsive therapy"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Bipolar disorder always needs medical treatment. Work with a psychiatrist and a doctor. On your own, build a support team of family and friends to help you cope. Make sure to get enough sleep.\n\nExercise regularly. Learn ways to reduce stress and relax, such as using breathing exercises, meditation, and yoga. Learn the signs of an oncoming mood swing so you can get help quickly."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "If you have symptoms of bipolar disorder such as mood swings, hopelessness, or reckless behavior, see your doctor.\n\nIf you're feeling suicidal, call a hotline or go to the emergency room. If someone you know seems at risk of hurting himself -- either because of depression or mania -- call the emergency services or go to the emergency room."

			"heading": "Anorexia Nervosa",
			"content": "Anorexia, eating disorder"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tCompulsive behavior\n\t\t•\tDecreased appetite\n\t\t•\tBinge eating\n\t\t•\tFear of gaining weight\n\t\t•\tExcessive exercising\n\t\t•\tDistorted body image\n\t\t•\tMissed or late menstrual period\n\t\t•\tSwelling\n\t\t•\tIrregular menstrual periods\n\t\t•\tBrittle hair\n\t\t•\tFrequent laxative use\n\t\t•\tRestrictive dieting\n\t\t•\tWeight loss (intentional)"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Anorexia is an eating disorder that people develop to cope with emotional problems. It can cause people to try to restrict food, exercise obsessively, and maintain a bodyweight that's too low. Anorexia distorts what someone thinks about her body. People with anorexia may be convinced that they are heavy and starve themselves even if they're very underweight. While more common in girls and women, boys and men develop it, too. Triggers for anorexia vary. They include a perfectionist personality, low self-esteem, emotional trauma, societal pressure to be thin, and the influence of popular media. Anorexia is hard to treat. It can be life threatening. It also can lead to complications including heart problems, bone loss, and kidney problems. Therapy and behavior changes can help."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Anorexia usually starts in teenagers or young adults. It's more common in people who are driven, successful in school, and perfectionist. For some, it's a brief phase. For others, it becomes a lifelong problem. Treatment involves therapy. A therapist helps people understand the problem and change their behaviors. Experts suggest a slow weight gain of 1 pound to 3 pounds a week until someone has reached a normal weight. Family support is crucial. Some people benefit from a stay in the hospital. People who develop anorexia at a young age are more likely to have a full recovery. Even after successful treatment, anorexia can come back."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Nearly one in 100 girls and women will develop anorexia during her lifetime. Many more have other types of eating disorders."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Anorexia is most common in teenaged girls and young adult women. Other risk factors for anorexia include low self-esteem; high stress or emotional trauma; being a high achiever or a perfectionist; having parents with eating disorders or a preoccupation with weight; and digestive problems in childhood."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for anorexia includes:\n\t\t•\tTherapy and counseling\n\t\t•\tFamily support\n\t\t•\tControlled weight gain\n\t\t•\tAntidepressants, anti-anxiety medications, and other drugs\n\t\t•\tHospital treatment"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "If you have anorexia, get professional help. On your own, try to reduce stress. Learn relaxation techniques, yoga, or breathing exercises. Get your family and friends to support you in recovery."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "If you believe you may have anorexia, see a doctor or therapist soon. If a loved one shows symptoms such as losing too much weight, an obsession with weight loss, or restricting food, get them help.\n\nIf a person is anorexic and has serious symptoms such as seizures or abnormal heart rhythm, go to the emergency room right away."
		},

	"Asperger_syndrome": [{
			"heading": "Asperger Syndrome",
			"content": "Asperger's syndrome, Asperger's disorder, Asperger syndrome"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tCompulsive behavior\n\t\t•\tLoss of coordination\n\t\t•\tDislikes change in daily routine\n\t\t•\tDifficulty learning new things\n\t\t•\tDifficulty solving problems\n\t\t•\tSensitive to noise\n\t\t•\tDevelopmental delays\n\t\t•\tUnusual facial expression\n\t\t•\tSocially withdrawn"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Asperger's syndrome is one of a group of childhood developmental conditions known as\"autism spectrum disorders.\" It is most common in boys. Children with Asperger's syndrome usually have normal to superior intelligence. Unlike children with autism, they don't have delayed cognitive or language development. But they can have odd speech patterns, great difficulties with socializing and communication, and obsessive-compulsive traits. People are born with Asperger syndrome, and research suggests that it may run in families. Though the social impairments of Asperger's syndrome are believed to be lifelong, educational and social support helps many children go on to lead independent lives."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "You may sense that there is something different about your child at around age 3. The first thing you notice may be delays in motor development – such as late crawling or walking. This could evolve into trouble pedaling, catching, or climbing. Obsessive interest in a single topic or object is one of the main characteristics of Asperger's syndrome. For example, a child may spend hours counting passing cars or will only talk about trains. Your child will have difficulty with social interaction, and may be rigid and resist change. Your child may be exceptionally skilled in some areas, such as with numbers, math, computers, or music. A child or adolescent psychiatrist can diagnose your child and work with you to develop an effective program to help him or her. There is no specific way to deal with Asperger's syndrome, but most treatment combines psychotherapy, special education, behavior modification, and support for parents. Medication is sometimes recommended. With good, early help, many children are able to cope with disabilities caused by Asperger's syndrome and go on to college and careers. Your child may continue to need support throughout life to deal with the challenges of social and personal relationships."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Estimates of how common Asperger's syndrome is in the country vary widely. Some studies say it affects 1 in 250 children; others say 1 in 1,000 children."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Males are at higher risk than females."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for Asperger's syndrome may include:\n\t\t•\tSocial skills training – a form of group therapy to help children with Asperger's syndrome learn how to interact with other children\n\t\t•\tCognitive behavioral therapy –\"talk therapy\" to help children manage their emotions and reduce obsessive interests and routines\n\t\t•\tOccupational or physical therapy for poor motor coordination\n\t\t•\tSpeech/language therapy\n\t\t•\tParent training and support\n\t\t•\tMedication if your child has conditions like anxiety, anger, and inattention"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "These home strategies can help a child with Asperger's syndrome:\n\t\t•\tUse routines, minimize change, and prepare for transitions.\n\t\t•\tTalk in a slow, clear language.\n\t\t•\tUse your child's special interests to teach new concepts when possible.\n\t\t•\tProvide breaks from social situations when your child needs them."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\t\t•\tCould Asperger's syndrome or another condition be causing my child's symptoms?\n\t\t•\tWhat tests will my child need?\n\t\t•\tDoes this facility do a lot of Asperger's evaluations?\n\t\t•\tDo you use a multidisciplinary team to evaluate Asperger's?\n\t\t•\tWhat treatments will my child need at this stage?\n\t\t•\tWhat is my child's prognosis?"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "Generally, a comprehensive evaluation is done by a team of specialists – such as a physician, psychologist, and speech and language therapist -- at a medical or evaluation center. It should include psychological, communication, neurological, and medical evaluations."
		},

			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "A strange or overwhelming environment, stress, anger, frustration, adolescence"

	"Autism": [{
			"heading": "Autism",
			"content": "Autism Spectrum Disorder"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "Compulsive behavior\n\t\t•\tLoss of coordination\n\t\t•\tRepetitive behaviors\n\t\t•\tDevelopmental delays\n\t\t•\tUnusual facial expression\n\t\t•\tInappropriate behavior\n\t\t•\tSensitive to noise\n\t\t•\tLack of emotion\n\t\t•\tImpaired social skills\n\t\t•\tDislikes change in daily routine\n\t\t•\tRepeats phrases\n\t\t•\tSocially withdrawn"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Autism represents a range of neurological disorders that cause communication difficulties, inability to interact socially, and other behavioral problems. Autism can be mild or severe. Babies with autism may seem unresponsive or withdrawn. Young children with autism often avoid eye contact or fail to respond to their own names. They may lack the ability to interpret people's expressions and social cues. Many children with this disorder repeat certain movements again and again, such as rocking back and forth or twirling objects. Training programs can help autistic children develop social and communication skills. Medications can treat symptoms such as anxiety or depression."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "With treatment, many children's symptoms improve. Adults with autism usually need social services and support, but many live independently and are able to work. The prognosis is highly correlated with IQ. The higher a person's IQ, the more equipped he or she will be to live a relatively normal life."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Experts estimate that one child in every 110 will develop autism."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Being male"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "There is no cure for autism. The goal of treatment is to ease symptoms. Approaches include:\n\t\t•\tTraining to help children develop social and language skills\n\t\t•\tMedications to treat anxiety, depression, and obsessive-compulsive disorder"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "Make an appointment to see your doctor immediately if you are worried that your child is not developing normally or is demonstrating abnormal behaviors."
		},
		{

		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "There is no definitive test for autism. Instead, doctors use questionnaires that assess information about a child's development and behavior. Some questionnaires are based on observations by the parents. Others include observation from both the parents and health care professionals who examine the child."
		}

Most people with bulimia are a normal weight but think they are overweight. People with bulimia may eat a lot of food in one sitting, fear gaining weight, want to lose weight, be unhappy with their body, make themselves vomit after eating, exercise excessively, or take laxatives or diuretics often."

	"Obsessive_compulsive_personality_disorder": [{
			"heading": "Obsessive Compulsive Personality Disorder",
			"content": "OCPD, anankastic personality disorder"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tCompulsive behavior\n\t\t•\tExcessive exercising\n\t\t•\tSocially withdrawn\n\t\t•\tNervousness\n\t\t•\tEmotional detachment"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Obsessive compulsive personality disorder is a personality disorder in which a person is preoccupied with rules, control, and orderliness. People with OCPD are often so fixated on perfectionism, routines, and work that it can interfere with their relationships. Typically, they believe their way is the right way. OCPD is different from obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD). OCD is an anxiety disorder in which a person suffers from unwanted, uncontrollable repetitive thoughts and behaviors, such as repeated hand-washing or counting."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "People with OCPD often don't believe they have anything wrong with them. They may perform well at work because they are so focused and obsessed with work. It often takes the threat of losing a relationship before they will seek treatment. Medication and psychotherapy usually help. By comparison, people with obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD) have anxiety about their disorder. They also are anxious when they can't complete certain rituals or are consumed with worries. If the OCD isn't controlled, jobs and relationships can deteriorate. Medication and behavioral therapy can help control unwelcome thoughts and behaviors."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 1 in 100 people in the country has OCPD. About 1 in 50 people in the country has OCD."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Family history of OCPD or OPD, being a young adult"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Both OCPD and OCD are usually treated with a combination of psychotherapy and medication. Common medication includes antidepressants called selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs)."
		},

			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "See a doctor if you have symptoms of OCPD or OCD."

It usually develops between the teen years and age 40. Doctors don't understand exactly what causes schizophrenia, but it can run in families. There is no cure for schizophrenia, but therapy and medications can help treat symptoms."

You may have periods where you feel better and then times when you feel worse. People with schizophrenia may have trouble going to school, working, or making friends. There is no cure for schizophrenia, but medications and counseling can help treat symptoms. Most people need treatment for life to function well."

A brain infection causes sleepiness, fever, headaches, neck pain and stiffness, nausea, fatigue, confusion, sensitivity to light, seizures, loss of consciousness, and coma. Encephalitis can be life threatening, so it's important to get immediate medical help. Treatment may include medication and hospitalization."

	"Aspirin_poisoning": [{
			"heading": "Aspirin Poisoning",
			"content": "Salicylate overdose"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tConfusion\n\t\t•\tDizziness\n\t\t•\tDry mouth\n\t\t•\tHearing loss\n\t\t•\tLightheadedness\n\t\t•\tRapid breathing\n\t\t•\tDifficulty concentrating\n\t\t•\tAbnormal gait (walking)\n\t\t•\tUnusual behavior\n\t\t•\tDecreased urination\n\t\t•\tDouble vision (without one eye covered)\n\t\t•\tFever\n\t\t•\tIncreased thirst\n\t\t•\tRinging in ears\n\t\t•\tLoss of consciousness\n\t\t•\tDisorientation\n\t\t•\tDrowsiness"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Aspirin poisoning can come on suddenly after taking a high dose of aspirin or gradually after taking lower doses for several weeks. You may have nausea, vomiting, ringing in your ears, drowsiness, confusion, and rapid breathing. Aspirin poisoning is usually a medical emergency because it can cause unconsciousness or death. It's a common cause of poisoning in children but less so because of child-proof packaging and public education. Intentional aspirin poisoning, such as in an attempted suicide, causes most sudden aspirin poisoning. You can develop gradual poisoning by unknowingly taking a combination of medications that contain aspirin. Activated charcoal, and in severe cases, hemodialysis, are used to treat it. With proper treatment, most people survive."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "If you suspect that you or someone else has taken too much aspirin but there are no symptoms, call your local poison control center."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "If you have sudden, or acute, poisoning from aspirin (salicylate), you'll probably first have nausea and vomiting, ringing in your ears, rapid breathing, and sweating. You may not have symptoms of severe poisoning for a few days. Then you may be lightheaded, drowsy, hyperactive, or confused or have fever, seizures, kidney failure, or difficulty breathing. If you have gradual aspirin poisoning, your symptoms will develop over days or weeks. You may feel drowsy and confused or have hallucinations. Eventually, you could have dehydration, seizures, and brain swelling. For all but the most minor symptoms of aspirin poisoning, you'll need emergency treatment in a hospital. The doctors will give you activated charcoal and intravenous fluids and may pump your stomach (gastric lavage). You may need a ventilator to help you breathe or medications for complications such as seizures. If your condition worsens, you could need dialysis -- a procedure that uses an artificial kidney to filter poisons out of your blood. After emergency treatment, you'll probably be hospitalized for further treatment and monitoring. If the overdose was intentional, you'll see a mental health specialist. If the dose of aspirin was not too high and you get proper treatment, you will most likely recover."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Taking more salicylate in any form"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for aspirin poisoning may include:\n\t\t•\tStopping aspirin use immediately\n\t\t•\tGastric lavage (stomach pumping), depending on when the aspirin was taken\n\t\t•\tActivated charcoal to absorb salicylate from the stomach -- possibly given with a laxative to move it through the gastrointestinal system\n\t\t•\tIV fluids for dehydration\n\t\t•\tIV sodium bicarbonate (sometimes with potassium), to help move salicylate to the urine\n\t\t•\tVentilator, if the person is agitated, in a coma, or having trouble breathing\n\t\t•\tTreatment for complications such as seizures or convulsions\n\t\t•\tDialysis, to eliminate aspirin from the body\n\t\t•\tPsychiatric therapy, in case of an intentional overdose\n\t\t•\tHospitalization for further monitoring and care, especially if the person is an infant, elderly, has long-term aspirin poisoning, or has taken a sustained-release medication with aspirin"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "These self-care strategies can help prevent aspirin poisoning:\n\t\t•\tIf you have children, buy aspirin with child-resistant caps and keep it out of their sight and reach.\n\t\t•\tDo not give aspirin to children or teenagers.\n\t\t•\tNever take more than the recommended dose of a medication.\n\t\t•\tMake sure all your doctors know about all of the medications you take.\n\t\t•\tRead labels carefully to see if a medicine contains aspirin or salicylate.\n\t\t•\tCheck with your doctor about taking more than one product with salicylate.\n\t\t•\tDon't take medicine prescribed for someone else.\n\t\t•\tIf you think someone is in danger or taking too much aspirin to commit suicide, get help."
		},

	"Atrial_fibrillation": [{
			"heading": "Atrial Fibrillation",
			"content": "Atrial arrhythmia, auricular fibrillation, a. fib"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tConfusion\n\t\t•\tDizziness\n\t\t•\tFeeling faint\n\t\t•\tLightheadedness\n\t\t•\tPressure or heaviness\n\t\t•\tFainting\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tFatigue\n\t\t•\tIrregular heartbeat\n\t\t•\tPalpitations (fluttering in chest)\n\t\t•\tShortness of breath\n\t\t•\tWeakness (generalized)"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Atrial fibrillation is the most common problem with the heart's rhythm. It is also the main cause of heart failure and a major risk for stroke. The heart has four chambers. The two upper chambers are called atria. Blood enters these chambers, which then contract to fill the lower chambers, called ventricles. Then the lower chambers contract and pump blood to the rest of the body. With a normal heartbeat, contractions follow in order, and both the upper and lower chambers work at the same pace. With fibrillation, though, the upper chambers beat much faster than the lower ones. So the ventricles don't fill completely and the heart has to work harder to get blood to the rest of the body."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "It's possible to have atrial fibrillation and not notice any symptoms. If you do have symptoms, you may first notice your pulse is irregular or hard to find because it's so weak. You also may feel tired and weak. And you may have the sensation you can feel your heart racing. But it's possible you may go for months before a doctor notices a problem during a physical exam. The longer it goes untreated, the more likely you are to notice symptoms of heart failure. These can include shortness of breath, swelling ankles, or a chronic cough with foamy mucus. Strokes are also a potential problem. So you may need to take blood thinners on a regular basis to prevent them. Often, the treatment to regulate the heartbeat works at first, but the fibrillation returns later."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "A half-million new cases of atrial fibrillation are diagnosed each year in the country"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment depends on how severe your symptoms are and whether or not you already have heart disease.\n\nIf there is something causing the fibrillation, the first step is to address it. This could mean making lifestyle changes such as cutting out alcohol or caffeine and eating a heart-healthy diet. It also could mean treating a medical condition such as an overactive thyroid.\n\nThe doctor may prescribe heart rhythm medications such as calcium channel blockers.\n\nYou may need to take a blood thinner such as warfarin to reduce your risk of stroke.\n\nIn some cases, doctors use electricity to shock the heart back into a normal rhythm, a process called cardioversion.\n\nSurgery may be an option if other treatments do not work."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Certain medications, hyperthyroidism, too much thyroid, too much caffeine, alcohol, and magnesium deficiency"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "If you notice a weak, irregular pulse and have been feeling tired and weak, see your doctor for an evaluation. Call the emergency services or emergency services if you have severe chest pain, have signs of a stroke, or feel faint and have an irregular heartbeat."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\t\t•\tDo I have heart failure?\n\t\t•\tWhat tests will I need to find the problem with my heart?\n\t\t•\tHow are the tests performed?\n\t\t•\tWhat are my treatment and medication options?\n\t\t•\tWill I need to take blood thinners?"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "Atrial fibrillation is often diagnosed with a physical exam and an electrocardiogram (EKG). Some patients' heartbeats may stay regular during an EKG. So they wear a Holter monitor that records the heart's rhythm over a 24-hour period. Others wear a monitor they can activate when they feel their heartbeat become irregular. Ultrasound, or echocardiogram, is sometimes used to look for conditions that may accompany atrial fibrillation."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "History of Graves' disease or hyperthyroidism, advanced age, alcoholism, family history of irregular heartbeats, coronary artery heart disease, abnormal heart valves"
		}
	],

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Barbiturates are a type of prescription sedative. They were once a common treatment for anxiety and insomnia. Doctors now prescribe barbiturates less often because of their risks. Abusing barbiturates -- such as amobarbital (Amytal), pentobarbital, phenobarbital, secobarbital (Seconal), or tuinal -- can have serious side effects. Anyone who has taken more barbiturates than prescribed needs to go to the emergency room. Even a slight overdose can cause coma or death. Barbiturates are a common method of committing suicide among older people. With prompt treatment, most people recover from barbiturate overdoses. People who chronically abuse barbiturates need long-term help for drug addiction."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "People may abuse a legal prescription of barbiturates or buy them illegally. Barbiturates can cause symptoms similar to those of alcohol. People using them may seem drunk and slur their words. Depending on the specific drug, the effects may last for minutes or days. People abusing barbiturates may suddenly have life-threatening problems -- they may lose consciousness and stop breathing. About 10% of barbiturate overdoses are fatal. Emergency care can be lifesaving. Barbiturates are addictive. Taking them for a month or more can lead to severe withdrawal symptoms when a person stops."
		},

Benzodiazepine abuse occurs when you often use the drug in higher doses or for reasons other than prescribed. You may even develop physical dependence after using these drugs for more than 2 to 4 weeks. Chronic overuse can cause quickly shifting moods, anxiety, insomnia, headaches, and weakness. People who abuse benzodiazepines should taper off the drugs with help from a doctor. Stopping the medication suddenly may cause withdrawal symptoms."

	"Chronic_kidney_disease": [{
			"heading": "Chronic Kidney Disease",
			"content": "Chronic renal failure, kidney failure, CKD, chronic kidney failure, chronic renal insufficiency"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tConfusion\n\t\t•\tDecreased urination\n\t\t•\tFatigue\n\t\t•\tNausea or vomiting\n\t\t•\tDrowsiness\n\t\t•\tSwelling\n\t\t•\tDifficulty sleeping\n\t\t•\tHeadache\n\t\t•\tWeight loss (unintentional)"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Chronic kidney disease is a serious illness that occurs when the kidneys slowly stop working over time. When the kidneys don't work properly, waste products and fluids build up in your body. Chronic kidney disease is most often caused by diabetes and high blood pressure, but can also happen for other reasons. Most people don't have any symptoms for many years. When symptoms do start, they can include high blood pressure, fatigue, weakness, frequent urination, swelling of the legs, puffy eyes, trouble sleeping, difficulty concentrating, lack of appetite, nausea, and headaches."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Most people with chronic kidney disease have few symptoms until the kidney disease is in its later stages when the kidneys are failing. This usually happens over many years. Over time, most people with chronic kidney disease develop end-stage renal disease. This means you need dialysis or a kidney transplant to remain alive. There is no cure for chronic kidney disease, but treatment can help treat symptoms and delay kidney failure."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Nearly 26 million people in the country have chronic kidney disease."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "You may be at higher risk for chronic kidney disease if you:\n\t\t•\tHave diabetes\n\t\t•\tHave high blood pressure\n\t\t•\tHave heart disease\n\t\t•\tHave high cholesterol\n\t\t•\tHave certain autoimmune diseases such as lupus\n\t\t•\tHave a kidney infection\n\t\t•\tHave blockages due to prostate disease or kidney stones\n\t\t•\tSmoke\n\t\t•\tAre obese\n\t\t•\tAre American Indian, African-American, or Asian-American\n\t\t•\tHave a family history of kidney disease\n\t\t•\tAre age 65 or older"
		},
		{

		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",

		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",

	"Dehydration_(Adult)": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tConfusion\n\t\t•\tDecreased urination\n\t\t•\tDry mouth\n\t\t•\tFeeling faint\n\t\t•\tPale skin\n\t\t•\tThick saliva or mucus\n\t\t•\tMuscle cramps or spasms (painful)\n\t\t•\tDecreased sweating\n\t\t•\tPounding heart (pulse)\n\t\t•\tSunken eyes\n\t\t•\tConstipation\n\t\t•\tDizziness\n\t\t•\tFatigue\n\t\t•\tIncreased thirst\n\t\t•\tRapid heart rate (pulse)\n\t\t•\tFainting\n\t\t•\tDrinking excessive fluids\n\t\t•\tLow blood pressure\n\t\t•\tSwollen tongue\n\t\t•\tWeakness (generalized)\n\t\t•\t"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Dehydration happens when your body loses more water than it takes in. You naturally lose water every day, though urine, sweat, and even breathing. Normally, the water in what you drink and eat makes up for the fluid you've lost. Dehydration becomes a problem when the loss becomes excessive – from vomiting or diarrhea, for example -- and you can't get enough fluid to replace it. Or it can happen because of excessive sweating from working out on a hot day without adequate access to water. Not getting enough fluid can cause low blood pressure, weakness, dizziness, fatigue, and even nausea. The larger the deficit of fluid, the greater the risk is for serious complications. Dehydration can lead to such problems as kidney failure, confusion, coma, or shock."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Your body needs between 2 liters and 3 liters of fluid every day. Not getting that much or needing more because of illness or increased physical activity can lead to mild dehydration. You can treat mild dehydration by sipping water or other beverages, or by sucking on ice cubes or frozen ice pops. If the loss of fluid is severe, and the person has not gotten or can't get enough fluid to replace it, they may need IV fluids."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Dehydration is common, even in hospital settings. The people most vulnerable to dehydration are children and people older than age 60."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for dehydration depends on the age of the person and how severe the dehydration is. The primary treatment is to replace the fluids that have been lost. With mild to moderate dehydration that often can be done by drinking more fluids. If the case is severe, it may be necessary to give IV fluids. If dehydration is the result of an illness, the doctor will also treat the illness or adjust medications to control the symptoms and reduce the amount of fluid that is being lost."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "For mild dehydration, sip water, suck ice chips, or drink sports drinks such as Gatorade. Taking medication to control diarrhea, vomiting, or fever will help slow the loss of fluid associated with an illness."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Working out, hot environment, lack of water, caffeine, alcohol, and diuretics"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "Call the doctor if:\n\t\t•\tYou have vomiting that has lasted more than 24 hours or diarrhea that's continued for more than 2 days\n\t\t•\tYou notice excessive urination\n\t\t•\tYou've produced little or no urine in 8 hours\n\t\t•\tYou have other symptoms of dehydration and have trouble getting or keeping down fluids\n\t\t•\tYou feel weak\n\t\t•\tYour fever is more than 101 degrees Fahrenheit\n\nSevere dehydration is life-threatening. Call the emergency services if you have any of these symptoms:\n\t\t•\tFever higher than 103 degrees Fahrenheit\n\t\t•\tConfusion, lethargy, or headaches\n\t\t•\tSeizures or fainting\n\t\t•\tChest or abdominal pains or difficulty breathing\n\t\t•\tNo urine in the last 12 hours"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",

		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "The doctor usually can diagnose dehydration based on the signs and symptoms such as low blood pressure, little or no urination, sunken eyes, and a lack of elasticity in the skin. The doctor may ask for other tests, such as a blood test or urine analysis. The doctor may also evaluate a person's mental status to help determine how severe the condition is."
		},

			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Hypothyroidism occurs when the thyroid gland can't produce enough thyroid hormone. The thyroid is a butterfly-shaped gland that wraps around the front of the windpipe. It controls how the body uses energy. Without enough thyroid hormone, your body functions slow down, making you gain weight and feel tired all the time. Women are more likely to get thyroid disease than men. Hypothyroidism is fairly common and easy to treat."

It controls how the body uses energy. Without enough thyroid hormone, your body functions slow down, making you gain weight and feel tired all the time. Women are more likely to get thyroid disease than men. Hypothyroidism is fairly common and easy to treat."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Early symptoms include sensitivity to cold, constipation, depression, tiredness and weight gain. Not everyone has the same symptoms, and people often think symptoms are just signs of aging. As the metabolism slows down, symptoms get worse and cause puffiness, slowed heart rate, and swelling in the legs. If not treated, hypothyroidism can lead to a rare, life-threatening coma. Taking thyroid hormone replacement returns levels to normal within a few weeks and symptoms disappear. Most people need to take thyroid medicine for the rest of their life."

	"Intracranial_hematoma": [{
			"heading": "Intracranial Hematoma",
			"content": "Brain injury, subdural hematoma, epidural hematoma, intracerebral hematoma"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tConfusion\n\t\t•\tHeadache\n\t\t•\tSlurred speech\n\t\t•\tLoss of consciousness\n\t\t•\tUnable to move arm\n\t\t•\tWeakness\n\t\t•\tNausea or vomiting\n\t\t•\tChange in vision\n\t\t•\tUnable to move leg"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "An intracranial hematoma happens when a head injury causes blood to collect within the brain or between your brain and skull. Acute subdural hematomas cause rapid bleeding in the brain. They are usually the result of a severe injury to the head. Subacute subdural hematomas can cause symptoms that appear days or weeks after an injury. Chronic subdural hematomas develop within the brain over weeks or months. They typically occur in alcoholics and among older people. An epidural hematoma happens when a blood vessel ruptures between your brain and skull, and usually causes immediate symptoms. Intracerebral hematomas occur within the brain. Any intracranial hematoma can be a potentially life-threatening condition and require emergency care."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "Intracranial epidural hematomas are the most serious complications of head injury. They require immediate diagnosis and treatment to prevent brain damage or death. If you or someone you are with has symptoms of intracranial hematoma or has had a head injury and lost consciousness, call the emergency services or go to an emergency room immediately."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Some intracranial hematomas can be minor and heal themselves. Others can be life-threatening and need emergency surgery. You should always see a doctor after a head injury. Prognosis depends on many things, including the extent of the injury, the size of the hematoma, your age, and your overall health. Recovery from serious intracranial hematomas may take many months."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Medications that thin the blood, including aspirin, can increase the risk of bleeding in the brain."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Drugs may be used to reduce pressure within the brain and to lower fever, as well as to prevent convulsions. You may need surgery to relieve the pressure caused by bleeding in the brain. This is done by creating a small hole in the skull to drain fluid. In some cases, part of the skull may have to be removed to ease pressure."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "To be safe, see a doctor after any head injury. Seek immediate medical care for the symptoms of intracranial hematoma or after a head injury that causes loss of consciousness."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\t\t•\tHow severe is the bleeding in my brain?\n\t\t•\tWill the pressure go away on its own?\n\t\t•\tHas my brain been damaged?\n\t\t•\tWhat kinds of drugs will help?\n\t\t•\tWill you need to operate?\n\t\t•\tWill I recover completely?\n\t\t•\tCan I do anything to avoid another intracranial hematoma?"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "CT and/or MRI scans are used to detect intracranial hematomas. Bloods tests also may be used to assess a person's condition."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Nearly 2% of people with head injuries have intracranial hematomas."
		},

			"content": "The risk of intracranial hematomas is higher in people who are taking aspirin or blood-thinners as well as elderly with fall risk. Intracranial hematomas are also more common in people at risk for strokes."

MS seems be an immune disorder -- for some reason, the body's own immune system attacks healthy nerves. MS is unpredictable. Most people have mild cases but it can be debilitating. Symptoms and severity depend on which nerves are affected. MS is more common in women. There is no cure but treatment can help. Remember that MS is rare and that many less serious conditions can cause similar symptoms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Doctors usually diagnose people with MS between their 20s and 50s. Many people first notice vision changes, muscle weakness, and problems with coordination. In some people, MS symptoms come and go. A person may have symptoms that flare up -- for days, weeks, and months -- and then disappear for a long time. In other people, MS steadily gets worse. Medications can help slow down the disease and control the symptoms, improving quality of life. Many people with MS can keep working and most live a normal life span."

	"Acute_kidney_failure": [{
			"heading": "Acute Kidney Failure",
			"content": "Acute renal failure, acute kidney injury"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tConfusion\n\t\t•\tSwelling\n\t\t•\tDecreased urination\n\t\t•\tIncreased thirst\n\t\t•\tNausea or vomiting\n\t\t•\tDrowsiness\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tDecreased appetite\n\t\t•\tDry mouth\n\t\t•\tLightheadedness\n\t\t•\tRapid heart rate (pulse)"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Acute kidney failure occurs when the kidneys suddenly lose their ability to filter waste and water from the blood. It may occur with a major illness, trauma, or infection and can permanently damage the kidney it if it does not receive immediate intensive treatment. Usually this means treating the cause of the failure, but it can include dialysis to remove toxins and excess fluid from the body. You may have no symptoms of kidney failure or be quite ill. It can be fatal, but many people make a full recovery."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "If have any symptoms of acute kidney failure; such as dark urine, infrequent urination, nausea, muscle weakness or seizures, immediately see your doctor or go to a hospital emergency room."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Kidney failure is most common in people who already are hospitalized. The first symptom is often swelling in the ankles, feet, face, and hands. You also may have dark-colored urine or little urine, fatigue, confusion, or nausea. You may need a long hospital stay to care for acute kidney failure. Your doctors will treat the underlying illness or injury and give you medications to prevent complications from dehydration, accumulating wastes, or excess water in your body. Treating the underlying cause usually clears up the problem. If it doesn't, you'll need hemodialysis to take over kidney function while your kidneys heal. Probably a few times a week, you'll be hooked up to a dialysis machine that circulates your blood through an artificial kidney, which filters out waste and toxins and then returns the blood to your body. If your kidneys are too badly damaged to recover, you may have chronic kidney failure and need routine dialysis or a kidney transplant."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for acute kidney failure depends on the cause and may include:\n\t\t•\tTreating the underlying cause\n\t\t•\tStopping any medication related to the cause\n\t\t•\tIntravenous fluids for dehydration or to maintain adequate blood volume\n\t\t•\tRestricting diet\n\t\t•\tMedication for high blood levels of potassium or phosphate\n\t\t•\tA catheter or stent to treat obstruction\n\t\t•\tDialysis"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "If your doctor recommends it, avoid high-potassium or high-salt foods during your recovery from acute kidney failure."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "If you urinate less than 1 to 2 cups of urine a day and have been experiencing loss of appetite, nausea, fatigue, or foot or ankle swelling, see your doctor as soon as possible."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\t\t•\tDo I need dialysis or other treatments at this point?\n\t\t•\tIs there anything I can do to help heal?\n\t\t•\tHow advanced is my kidney failure, and do you think it will reverse?"
		},

		},
		{
			"heading": "Chagas Disease Overview",
			"content": "Chagas disease is caused by a tropical parasite called Trypanosoma cruzi. This parasite is found in microscopic feces left on the skin from blood-sucking insects native to Central and South America. The disease also can spread from mother to baby and through blood transfusions. The disease has two phases. The acute stage lasts a few weeks or months and may have few or mild symptoms, including fever, ill feeling, and swelling around one eye or near the insect bite. Once symptoms go away, it may be years before other, more serious health problems develop if the disease is not treated, including heart or intestinal problems. Treatment, especially at an early stage, can cure Chagas disease."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "During the acute stage, few or mild symptoms may develop. Eye swelling may occur from rubbing insect feces into the eye. Other symptoms such as fever, and muscle aches may last a few weeks or months. Once symptoms go away, it may be years before more serious health problems develop. Thirty percent of people with chronic disease develop heart problems such as heart failure or heart rhythm problems. Ten percent develop digestive or other problems. Treatment, especially at an early stage, can cure Chagas disease."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",

		},
		{
			"heading": "Prevention",
			"content": "There are no vaccines or drugs that can prevent Chagas disease. When traveling to countries where the disease occurs, sleep indoors in buildings with air conditioning or screens so bugs can't get in, use mosquito netting at night, wear protective clothing, and use insect repellant. Also use caution to avoid eating food or drinking beverages that might be contaminated with the parasite."
		},

			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Cyanide is a poison. When your body takes in too much of it at one time, you can get cyanide poisoning. Low levels of cyanide occur naturally in some foods, such as almonds, soy, spinach, and cassava. It is also found in cigarette smoke and other types of smoke and is created in certain industrial processes. Man-made cyanide has also been used as a chemical weapon. You can get cyanide poisoning from eating or drinking foods that contain it, touching water or soil that contains it, or breathing it in. Cyanide poisoning is a medical emergency. It can cause headache, weakness, confusion, nausea, difficulty breathing, and seizures. In severe cases, it can cause death."

If you are exposed to a large amount of cyanide, the symptoms usually start within a few minutes. Treatment for cyanide poisoning includes oxygen and antidotes to stop the effects of the poisoning. These treatments are most effective when given right away."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Lead poisoning is a serious condition that results from exposure to lead, a toxic metal that used to be common in paint and gasoline. Other sources of lead are pipes, soil and dust, storage batteries, and some toys, furniture, or cosmetics from other countries. Lead poisoning may cause trouble sleeping, abdominal cramping, or anemia. Lead can damage almost all parts of the body, and cause problems such as reduced IQ and slowed body growth. Young children are at increased risk for lead poisoning, because their nervous systems are more sensitive to lead. They also are more likely to put unwashed items into their mouths, and their small size leads to higher lead levels. The most important thing is to remove all sources of lead. In severe cases, chelation therapy can help remove lead from the body."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "Seek immediate medical care if you or your child has symptoms of high lead levels. This may include vomiting, staggering, muscle weakness, seizures, or coma."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "The more lead you have in your body and the longer it stays there, the more likely you will have long-term health problems. This may include decreased bone and muscle growth, speech and language problems, damage to the nervous system and kidneys, and developmental delays. If needed, treatment can help lower lead levels and minimize its effects. Depending on severity and length of exposure, recovery can take months to years."
		},

			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Removing lead-based paint the wrong way"
		},

			"content": "Treatment for lead poisoning depends on blood levels of lead. Removing the source of lead is the most important step. Then, treatment may involve use of a chelating agent that binds with lead so the body can get rid of it. For very high levels of lead, hospitalization is needed. Increasing iron and calcium intake can help."
		},

Just a few ounces are enough to kill an adult. Methanol poisoning needs emergency treatment in a hospital. 			"heading": "Typhoid Fever",
			"content": "Enteric fever"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tConfusion\n\t\t•\tJoint aches\n\t\t•\tDiarrhea\n\t\t•\tFever\n\t\t•\tDisorientation\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tDecreased appetite\n\t\t•\tFatigue\n\t\t•\tHeadache"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Typhoid fever is a life-threatening illness caused by Salmonella bacteria. Fever, general aches and pains, headache, weakness, and lack of appetite are common symptoms. Until typhoid fever is treated, it is highly contagious. You can get it from contaminated food or water or close contact with someone who has it. It occurs most often in developing countries with poor sanitation. It is rare in the country Most cases are due to international travel. Untreated, typhoid fever can be fatal. Antibiotics clear it up, but a small number of people become carriers and need further treatment. A vaccine can also help prevent typhoid fever."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "You'll begin to have typhoid fever symptoms one or two weeks after the Salmonella typhi bacterium enters your body. You'll probably have a fever as high as 104 degrees Fahrenheit for several days. You may also feel achy, have severe headaches and abdominal pain, and have constipation or diarrhea. Loss of appetite, lethargy, and a rash of flat, rose-colored spots may also occur. If you don't receive treatment, you could develop intestinal bleeding or perforation after two or three weeks, the fever could continue for months, and you could die. With antibiotics, your symptoms will probably improve within a couple of days and you'll recover within a week to 10 days. If the illness subsides but you become a carrier, you may need to continue taking antibiotics. And if you work handling food or with small children, you probably won't be able to go back to work until you no longer carry the disease. Rarely, carriers need surgery to remove the gall bladder where Salmonella bacteria multiply."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",

Endocarditis happens when certain bacteria from another part of your body get into the bloodstream. People with damaged heart valves, artificial heart valves, or other heart problems are most at risk for endocarditis, which can cause congestive heart failure and stroke. Antibiotics and, in severe cases, surgery, are used treat endocarditis. Detecting and treating it early can save your life."

You may have flu-like symptoms, such as low fever and fatigue, or develop rashes, shortness of breath, or sudden weakness in your face, arms, or legs. If you know you are at risk for endocarditis, don't wait out mild symptoms. You will probably need IV antibiotics, at first in the hospital and then after you go home. If there is damage to a heart valve, you have an artificial heart valve, or the infection is caused by fungus, you may need surgery to repair or replace the heart valve."
