	"Pica": [{
			"heading": "Pica",
			"content": "Eating disorder"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tCraving to eat ice, dirt or paper\n\t\t•\tFood cravings"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Pica is an eating disorder that involves eating non-food items such as paper or dirt. It typically occurs in young children and sometimes in pregnant women. Young children normally explore and put things in their mouth, such as crayons. However, pica occurs when a child or an adult is compelled to eat non-food repeatedly for at least a month. Children with developmental disabilities such as mental retardation or autism are more likely to develop the condition. Not getting enough iron or other nutrients also may cause pica. People with pica may crave and eat non-food items such as dirt, feces, string, paint chips, laundry detergent, and coffee grounds. Pica can be harmless or quite serious. Bowel obstruction, lead poisoning, parasite infection, or viral illness can occur, depending on what items are eaten. The condition often goes away on its own in a few months. In some people, pica can be a lifelong problem, especially if it occurs along with a developmental disability. Treatment may involve behavioral therapy, medication, and teaching parents how to prevent non-food eating in children."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Children or adults who crave or eat non-food items should see a doctor. Children older than 18 to 24 months who eat non-food repeatedly for more than a month likely have pica. Parents can learn how to manage the condition and children may benefit from behavioral therapy. Sometimes medication is helpful. Often, the condition goes away on its own in a few months. However, it can be serious, depending on what is eaten. Symptoms usually disappear in pregnant women after giving birth."

		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Anemia occurs when your body has fewer red blood cells than it needs. Red blood cells carry oxygen to body tissues. Your body uses iron to build red blood cells. Low iron levels due to blood loss, not enough iron in the diet, or poor iron absorption commonly causes anemia. Blood loss from menstruation puts women at risk for low iron levels. Intestinal bleeding also commonly causes low iron levels. With treatment, most people recover from anemia in a few months."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Anemia develops slowly as the body's iron stores get used up. People with mild anemia often don't have any symptoms. As anemia progresses, most people feel very tired and may have trouble concentrating at work or at school. Depending on the cause and severity, other symptoms can occur. Treatment for anemia includes identifying and treating the cause and increasing iron levels in the body."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Anemia is common in women and children. 12% of women aged 12 to 49 have iron deficient anemia. 7% of children aged 1 to 2 have anemia."

	"Head_lice": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tCrawling sensation\n\t\t•\tSkin irritation\n\t\t•\tBald spots (hair)\n\t\t•\tScratching\n\t\t•\tWhite specks on scalp or hair\n\t\t•\tItching or burning\n\t\t•\tHair loss\n\t\t•\tVisible bugs or parasites\n\t\t•\tFeeling something moving on scalp"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Head lice are tiny insects that infest the hair and scalp. Less often, they may latch onto eyebrows and eye lashes. Lice dig into the skin and feed on blood, causing intense itching and skin irritation. Lice are most common in children and spread easily from person to person from close contact. They can also be spread by using combs, brushes, bedding, or towels from an infected person. While they're small, you can see white lice eggs, called nits, in the hair around the neck and ears. Nits look like dandruff but stay firmly attached to the hair. Lice are harder to spot unless there are a lot of them. Over-the-counter or prescription shampoos and combing hair with a special nit comb will treat head lice."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Some people can have lice and not know it. For others, itching and irritation occur quickly. Usually, the small, white eggs can easily be seen around the neck and ears by parting the hair. Adult lice are harder to spot. Lice can live for up to 40 days on a human but will die in 1 to 2 days if they fall off. Eggs last for 2 weeks, and once they hatch, the cycle can start again. So it's important to treat head lice as soon as it's spotted. Having lice does not mean that a person has poor hygiene or lives in poverty. Lice don't discriminate and will infect any one regardless of social or economic status. Using OTC or prescription shampoos or lotions, removing nits by hand, and cleaning bedding and clothing will cure head lice."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Close contact with someone with lice; sharing brushes, combs, hats, towels, bedding, clothes, pillows, upholstery"

			"content": "Every year, an estimated 6 million to 12 million children aged 3 to 11 in the country get head lice."

			"heading": "Prevention",
			"content": "Take these steps to prevent head lice from spreading:\n\t\t•\tDon't use pillows, combs, brushes, towels, hats, or hair ribbons from an infected person.\n\t\t•\tDon't sit on couches or lie on beds or carpets recently used by someone with head lice.\n\t\t•\tFor a school infestation, don't let your child return until the space and other children are clear of lice.\n\nTreat head lice immediately, and don't let a child with head lice return to school or daycare until all the lice and nits are gone."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for head lice includes:\n\t\t•\tUsing prescription lotions or shampoos; these remedies should not be used on children younger than 2 years old.\n\t\t•\tRemoving lice and lice eggs with a nit comb."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Self care for head lice includes:\n\t\t•\tUsing an OTC medicated lotion or shampoo to kill lice; these remedies should not be used on children younger than 2 years old.\n\t\t•\tRemoving lice eggs with a nit comb.\n\t\t•\tWashing all clothes, bedding, and towels used by the infected person in hot water and drying on high heat.\n\t\t•\tVacuuming in living and bedroom areas.\n\t\t•\tPutting anything that can't be washed into a sealed plastic bag for 2 weeks. Dry cleaning items can also kill lice."

	"Porphyria": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tDelusions\n\t\t•\tBody aches or pains\n\t\t•\tDepressed mood\n\t\t•\tNumbness or tingling\n\t\t•\tSkin rash\n\t\t•\tSkin bumps\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tConstipation\n\t\t•\tNausea or vomiting\n\t\t•\tPersonality changes\n\t\t•\tSkin blisters\n\t\t•\tDark colored (brown) urine"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Porphyria is a rare genetic condition that can affect the nerves and skin. Sunlight may make people with porphyria burn easily, blister, and scar. Severe attacks may cause pain in the abdomen, seizures, and confusion. In people with porphyria, low enzyme levels prevent the body from making an important protein in red blood cells. Chemicals build up in the blood, causing damage. Porphyria is a chronic condition. Treatment -- often with lifestyle changes and medication -- can reduce flares and manage symptoms. Acute attacks of porphyria are medical emergencies."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Usually, porphyria is passed down through families. Infections, drugs and alcohol, smoking, and hormones can cause one type of porphyria. Some cases are quite severe while others are mild. Porphyria tends to come and go. Many people notice sunlight, alcohol, or medications can trigger flares. Acute attacks may develop over hours or days and last for weeks. Treatment depends on the type of porphyria. Some people just need to avoid triggers. Others need medical treatment. Severe attacks of porphyria can be life threatening. They may cause dangerously low blood pressure, shock, and breathing problems."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "An estimated 200,000 people in the country have porphyria, according to the American Porphyria Foundation."

You may need to eat a high-carb diet. If blistering is a problem, always wear sunscreen and sun-protective clothing when outside."

	"Syphilis_(female)": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "Syphilis is a sexually-transmitted disease caused by a type of bacteria. Pregnant women who have syphilis can pass it on to their baby. Syphilis goes through three stages: primary syphilis, secondary syphilis, and tertiary syphilis. There may be no symptoms or mild symptoms in the first stages. But if syphilis is not treated, it can cause irreversible damage to the brain, nerves, and heart."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Syphilis is a sexually-transmitted disease caused by a type of bacteria. Pregnant women who have syphilis can pass it on to their baby. Syphilis goes through three stages: primary syphilis, secondary syphilis, and tertiary syphilis. There may be no symptoms or mild symptoms in the first stages. But if syphilis is not treated, it can cause irreversible damage to the brain, nerves, and heart."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "In the first stage, syphilis causes a painless sore on the genital area. This sore appears about two to three weeks after infection and clears up in few weeks on its own. About two to eight weeks later, the second stage of syphilis may cause a rash all over the body, achy muscles and joints, headache, or flu-like symptoms. If not treated in the first two stages, syphilis may spread to the brain, heart, and nervous system and cause severe health problems. It can take many years for syphilis to move into the third stage. Syphilis can be treated at all stages with antibiotics. But if it is not treated until the third stage, it may cause long-term health problems."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "You may be at higher risk for syphilis if you have sex with many partners, have HIV, or have unprotected sex. Using a condom protects against syphilis."

		},

			"heading": "Lupus",
			"content": "Systemic Lupus Erythematosus, SLE"

		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tDepressed mood\n\t\t•\tSwelling\n\t\t•\tStiffness or decreased movement\n\t\t•\tBody aches or pains\n\t\t•\tFever\n\t\t•\tSkin rash\n\t\t•\tMuscle weakness\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tJoint aches\n\t\t•\tBleeding gums\n\t\t•\tEasy bleeding\n\t\t•\tHeadache\n\t\t•\tJoint pain\n\t\t•\tHair loss"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Lupus is a chronic autoimmune disease. For reasons doctors don't understand, the body begins to attack healthy tissue. There are several types. The most common is systemic lupus erythematosus or SLE-- it's often simply called lupus. It may affect the skin, joints, kidneys, heart, and other organs. It's more common in women, African-Americans, and Asian-Americans. Other types of lupus -- such as cutaneous lupus erythematosus -- only affect the skin. Occasionally, medications can trigger temporary lupus. Good treatment is crucial. Keep in mind that more common and much less serious conditions can cause many of the same symptoms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "SLE usually appears between the ages of 10 and 50. Symptoms vary depending on what areas of the body are affected. Many people start with severe exhaustion, joint pain, and a\"butterfly rash\" on the cheeks and the bridge of the nose. Lupus can be hard to diagnose. Many people have mild symptoms. Some develop life-threatening disease that affects the kidneys and other organs. Lupus tends to wax and wane. Symptoms may flare up and then go away for months or years. Medications and other treatments can't cure the disease, but they will relieve the symptoms and help prevent flares."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Lupus is relatively uncommon. Doctors diagnose about 2 to 8 people out of every 100,000 in the country with systemic lupus erythematosus each year."

		},

To reduce stress, learn relaxation techniques, such as breathing exercises or meditation."

Doctors aren't sure what causes some people to have it. People who have PTSD may have flashbacks or bad dreams about the event, difficulty sleeping, be easily startled, or feel tense, guilty, depressed, or emotionally numb. They may also avoid people or things that remind them of the event."

Treatment is often most effective when started soon after the symptoms begin."

	"Premenstrual_dysphoric_disorder_(PMDD)": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tDepressed mood\n\t\t•\tFits of rage"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD) is a severe form of premenstrual syndrome, or PMS. It occurs just prior to menstruation and goes away during your period. It causes mood swings such as depression, anger, irritability, and tension that are significant enough to interfere with work, school, relationships, and social life. PMDD affects a small percentage of women. The causes are not fully known, but stress, hormonal changes, vulnerability in brain chemistry, and fluctuation of the brain chemical serotonin may play a part. Medications, counseling, nutritional strategies, and lifestyle changes can help improve symptoms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Premenstrual dysphoric disorder involves a worsening of mood that disrupts your daily life. During the days before your period, you may have anger that seems out of control or you feel overwhelmed or hopeless. You may lose interest in social activities or work and have trouble concentrating. Physical symptoms such as bloating and headache may also occur. When your period starts, the symptoms begin to decrease. If the symptoms appear during other times in your cycle, PMMD is probably not the cause. If your PMDD is mild, you may be able to manage it with regular exercise, stress-reduction techniques, and changes in diet. If your symptoms don't improve or if you have severe symptoms, your doctor may suggest an antidepressant, usually a serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI). Psychological counseling and other medications, including hormonal therapies, can also ease PMDD symptoms. Give your treatment two or three menstrual cycles to see if your symptoms improve before talking with your doctor about a different approach."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Premenstrual dysphoric disorder affects between 2% and 10% of women during their reproductive years."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for premenstrual dysphoric disorder may include:\n\t\t•\tDietary changes, such as eating frequent, small meals rich in complex carbohydrates and low in salt, fat, and caffeine\n\t\t•\tLimiting alcohol\n\t\t•\tQuitting smoking\n\t\t•\tRegular exercise and sleep\n\t\t•\tNutritional supplements such as B6, E, calcium, and magnesium\n\t\t•\tStress management, such as learning stress-reduction techniques\n\t\t•\t\"Talk therapy,\" such as cognitive behavioral therapy or interpersonal psychotherapy\n\t\t•\tAntidepressants, usually SSRIs, taken during all or part of the month, to help emotional and physical symptoms\n\t\t•\tHormonal therapy, including birth control pills in some cases\n\t\t•\tMedications to treat symptoms such as headaches and water retention"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "These self-care strategies may help premenstrual dysphoric disorder:\n\t\t•\tExercise at least 3 times a week.\n\t\t•\tEat a balanced diet, especially fruits, vegetables, and whole grains.\n\t\t•\tGet plenty of rest.\n\t\t•\tDuring your PMDD days, keep your schedule light and ask for extra help with tasks such as housekeeping and childcare.\n\t\t•\tTo relax, try yoga, meditation, massage, or stress-reduction exercises.\n\t\t•\tTake an over-the-counter medication such as ibuprofen for PMDD pain or headache.\n\t\t•\tLimit sugar, salt, alcohol, and caffeine in your diet.\n\t\t•\tKeep a journal of your symptoms for 2 months or more. If they don't improve with lifestyle changes, the record can help your doctor devise another treatment plan."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Stress"
		},

			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "See your doctor if you have monthly symptoms of PMDD or if your symptoms don't improve with lifestyle changes. Call the emergency services if you feel that you might hurt someone or hurt yourself."
		},

			"heading": "Premenstrual Syndrome (PMS)",
			"content": "Premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD)"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "PMS is a common condition that affects many women during the two weeks prior to their period. Symptoms vary from woman to woman. Generally, they include such things as bloating, irritability, fatigue, breast swelling and tenderness, and depressed mood. Water retention, which can cause up to 3 pounds of weight gain, and migraines are both common symptoms. It isn't clear what causes PMS. But one factor seems to be changes in hormones that occur during the menstrual cycle. A severe form of PMS, marked by such symptoms as major depression and angry outbursts at oneself or at others, is called\"premenstrual dysphoric disorder\" or PMDD."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "PMS symptoms usually start 10-14 days before the next period starts. Then they gradually increase until your period begins. It may take a few days after the start of your period for the mood changes and breast swelling to go away. But within four days, most symptoms, including water retention and headaches, have disappeared."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "At least 85% of women of childbearing age have one or more symptoms of PMS during their monthly cycle."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Aspirin, ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin), and other anti-inflammatory pain relievers may help relieve headaches, backaches, cramping, and breast tenderness. If anti-inflammatories are used on a regular basis, follow the label directions and be sure to take them with food. Making lifestyle changes also can help. The doctor may also prescribe medications that include:\n\t\t•\tBirth control pills\n\t\t•\tAntidepressants\n\t\t•\tAnti-anxiety drugs\n\t\t•\tDiuretics (water pills) to reduce water retention"
		},

	"Seasonal_depression_(SAD)": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "Depressed mood"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Seasonal depression, or SAD, is depression that occurs every year during a certain season. SAD can cause problems ranging from sadness and sleep problems to anxiety and moodiness. SAD is most common in fall and winter, with symptoms usually improving in spring and summer. In rare cases, people have SAD in spring and summer and their symptoms improve in the fall. Doctors aren't exactly sure what causes SAD, but they think it may have to do with light, hormones, and body temperature. More women than men have SAD, and the symptoms usually begin during the teen or young adult years. SAD is treated with light therapy, antidepressants, and psychotherapy."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "In most cases, the symptoms of SAD happen between September and April. The symptoms are often most severe from December to February. People with SAD have symptoms every year, and the symptoms usually go away when the seasons change. Treatment for SAD includes antidepressants, light therapy, and counseling."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Six percent of the country population, primarily in northern climates, is affected by SAD in its clinical form. Another 14 percent of adults in the country suffers from a milder form of SAD."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for seasonal depression may include:\n\t\t•\tAntidepressant medications\n\t\t•\tLight therapy, using a special light box that mimics sunlight\n\t\t•\tSpending time outside when it is light\n\t\t•\tPsychotherapy"
		},

	"Substance-induced_mood_disorder": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "Depressed mood"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Substance-induced mood disorder occurs when a person's mental health is affected by drinking alcohol or taking certain drugs, including some prescription drugs and illegal drugs. A person with substance-induced mood disorder may feel depressed, elated, or a combination of these feelings. These feelings can occur while someone is taking the drug or during withdrawal. The symptoms are the same as depression or mania: depressed mood, lack of interest in activities, fatigue, feelings of worthlessness, sleep problems, talkativeness, distractedness, or suicidal thoughts."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "People who have a substance-induced mood disorder usually find that their symptoms go away within 4 weeks of stopping the drug that is causing them. It's important to talk to your doctor if you think a prescription medication is causing a problem -- your doctor may be able to switch medications, or in some cases, you may need to taper off a medication rather than stop abruptly. Sometimes, it is hard to know if a drug is causing the mood disorder. Many people who have a mood disorder, such as depression or mania, also use alcohol or drugs. If your symptoms don't stop after a month of abstaining from alcohol or drugs, you may have another type of mood disorder."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "In one study, about 202,000 people in the country had a mood disorder that was caused by using alcohol or drugs."

	"Sleep_apnea": [{
			"heading": "Sleep Apnea",
			"content": "Obstructive sleep apnea, central sleep apnea, cheyne-stokes breathing, sleep-disordered breathing"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tDifficult to wake from sleep\n\t\t•\tHeadache\n\t\t•\tProlonged breathing pauses\n\t\t•\tDisorientation\n\t\t•\tDifficulty staying asleep\n\t\t•\tRestless (tossing and turning) sleep\n\t\t•\tEpisodes of not breathing during sleep\n\t\t•\tFatigue\n\t\t•\tMemory problems\n\t\t•\tSnoring\n\t\t•\tDrowsiness\n\t\t•\tDifficulty staying awake during day\n\t\t•\tOverweight"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "People with sleep apnea stop and restart breathing multiple times while sleeping. Episodes of not breathing can last a few seconds to a few minutes. It may happen 5 to 30 times or more an hour. In most cases, breathing stops when the airway collapses, blocking the flow of air into and out of the lungs. In a rarer form, the episodes result from a problem with how the brain controls breathing. Sleep apnea causes you to wake frequently throughout the night, even though you may have no memory in the morning of being restless. Although it can be managed with proper treatment, sleep apnea often goes undetected. When not treated, it raises the risk of heart disease and other serious health problems."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Sleep apnea develops slowly. People may have it for years before it's even suspected. Some may notice symptoms such as being tired, but a person's bed partner is often the first to raise concerns. Your partner may already have remarked on your snoring or\"funny\" breathing and urged you to see a doctor. Because obesity is a major risk factor, your doctor may want you to lose weight along with making other lifestyle changes. Sleep apnea increases the risk for high blood pressure, heart failure, diabetes, and heart rhythm problems. It can make asthma worse, lead to pregnancy complications, and contribute to eye problems such as glaucoma. You'll need regular screenings and will have to work closely with your doctor to manage your health. Once the apnea improves, though, you should see positive improvements in the overall quality of your life."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "More than 12 million people in the country have sleep apnea."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for sleep apnea may include:\n\t\t•\tLifestyle changes such as losing weight, not smoking, avoiding alcohol and certain medications, improving sleeping habits\n\t\t•\tContinuous positive air pressure, which uses a small device and a face mask to provide a steady stream of air to keep your throat open while you sleep\n\t\t•\tDental devices that either hold the lower jaw in place so it doesn't block the air flow or hold the tongue in place to keep it from blocking the airway\n\t\t•\tMedication to treat the sleepiness symptom\n\t\t•\tSurgery to remove tissue and widen the airway"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "You can find some relief from symptoms by doing any or all of the following:\n\t\t•\tLosing weight\n\t\t•\tNot smoking\n\t\t•\tNot drinking alcohol\n\t\t•\tExercising regularly\n\t\t•\tSleeping on your side"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Smoking, drinking alcohol, weight gain, allergies that cause nasal congestion, certain medications like sleeping pills or sedatives -- especially before bed"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "See your doctor if you have any symptoms of sleep apnea, including daytime sleepiness, fatigue, depression, mood swings, and trouble concentrating. Also see your doctor if your partner expresses concern about your snoring or tells you there are times at night when you don't breathe."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",

		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "Your doctor will take a medical and sleep history and do a physical exam to determine if something else might be causing your symptoms. However, the doctor will not be able to diagnose sleep apnea without a sleep study. You'll likely be referred to an overnight sleep center where your sleep will be monitored electronically."

			"content": "Overweight, older age, smoking, family history of sleep apnea, diabetes, high blood pressure, GERD polycystic ovary syndrome"

	"Sleep_deprivation": [{
			"heading": "Sleep Deprivation",
			"content": "Chronic insomnia, sleep disorder"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tDifficult to wake from sleep\n\t\t•\tFeeling faint\n\t\t•\tRestless or irritability\n\t\t•\tPuffy eyelids\n\t\t•\tDifficulty staying awake during day\n\t\t•\tSlow thinking\n\t\t•\tWeakness (generalized)\n\t\t•\tFatigue\n\t\t•\tRed (bloodshot) eyes\n\t\t•\tDifficulty concentrating\n\t\t•\tDrowsiness\n\t\t•\tReduced productivity at work\n\t\t•\tDifficulty solving problems"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Sleep deprivation occurs when the lack of restful sleep is severe enough to compromise basic body functions and thinking. Different people need different amounts of sleep. But on average, adults need 7 to 9 hours each night to avoid sleep deprivation. People become sleep deprived for many reasons. Some have sleep apnea, restless leg syndrome, or insomnia. Others work night shifts, and others simply try to get by on little sleep. Whatever the reason, sleep deprivation can cause daytime sleepiness, fatigue, lack of concentration, irritability, erection problems, and depression. It also is linked to weight gain and may increase the risk of heart disease."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "One night of inadequate sleep usually causes only fatigue and spaciness. If you go 24 to 48 hours without sleep, job performance and other mental functions quickly deteriorate. In such cases, driving and running machinery is risky because there may be mental lapses. Falling asleep suddenly is a sign of sleep deprivation and can be very dangerous. Chronic sleep deprivation can cause depression and other long-term problems such as erectile dysfunction and high blood pressure and may contribute to heart disease."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "An estimated 50 to 70 million Americans regularly don't get enough sleep."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Good sleep habits can help you avoid sleep deprivation. See tips in the Self-Care section below. If you have a specific sleep problem, the doctor may recommend:\n\t\t•\tMedications to ease your sleep problem -- certain drugs treat insomnia, others treat restless leg syndrome, and others treat narcolepsy\n\t\t•\tFor sleep apnea, a CPAP machine to deliver a constant flow of air into your nostrils while you sleep\n\t\t•\tSurgery to repair a deviated septum and other structural problems that interfere with breathing while you sleep"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "If you are not getting enough sleep, these tips can help improve your sleep:\n\t\t•\tGo to bed and get up at the same time every day.\n\t\t•\tDon't use alcohol, caffeine, or nicotine before going to bed.\n\t\t•\tUse the bedroom just for sleeping and sex.\n\t\t•\tDon't take daytime naps.\n\t\t•\tMake sure your bedroom is not too hot or too cold and that it's dark, quiet, and relaxing."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Certain medications, excess alcohol, smoking, too much caffeine, drug abuse"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "Talk with your doctor if you routinely feel tired or fatigued during the day or regularly have trouble sleeping at night. Also call the doctor if your bed partner tells you that you snore and routinely stop breathing while you sleep."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\t\t•\tHow can I get a good night's sleep?\n\t\t•\tAre there treatment options that can help me sleep better?\n\t\t•\tAre there any tests that I need?\n\t\t•\tAre there any natural remedies I might use to help me sleep better?"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "Your doctor will take a medical history, do a physical exam, and ask you questions about your sleeping patterns and habits. The doctor also may refer you to a sleep study done at a sleep center. For a sleep study, a technician will monitor your sleep pattern, including any breathing problems, how often you wake up during the night, and how your legs move during sleep. The results will be analyzed by a specialist to see if you have a medical problem such as sleep apnea or restless leg syndrome."

	"Hypersomnia_disorder": [{
			"heading": "Hypersomnia",
			"content": "Excessive sleeping"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "Difficult to wake from sleep"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Hypersomnia is a rare condition that makes people sleep much more than normal. People with hypersomnia may sleep longer than average at night and still need to take naps, sometimes at inappropriate times, like at work, in the middle of a meal, during a conversation, or while driving. They may sleep for up to 18 hours a day without feeling refreshed afterward, and have trouble waking up from a long sleep. Sometimes, hypersomnia has no clear cause. Drug and alcohol abuse and conditions such as sleep apnea, restless legs syndrome, and depression are also associated with hypersomnia. Medications and lifestyle changes can help."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Often, doctors can't find a cause for hypersomnia. It tends to first appear in teens and young adults. It may develop slowly with symptoms lasting for months or years. Hypersomnia may be treated with medications including stimulants, antidepressants, and other drugs. If hypersomnia is caused by another condition, such as sleep apnea, symptoms may come and go. In that case, treating the underlying condition may clear up the symptoms. Hypersomnia is not dangerous itself, but it can have a severe impact on a person's life. It also increases the risks of auto accidents."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Hypersomnia is rare. Up to 5% of people in the country complain of daytime sleepiness. Only a fraction of that number has true hypersomnia."

	"Postconcussive_syndrome": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tDifficulty concentrating\n\t\t•\tMemory problems\n\t\t•\tHeadache"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Postconcussive syndrome occurs when the symptoms of a concussion or other traumatic brain injury continue to occur. Headaches, dizziness, anxiety, irritability, mood swings, trouble concentrating or remembering, and other symptoms may show up right away or not for days or weeks after the injury. What causes the condition is unclear, but it happens more often after concussions from car accidents and assaults than from sports. There is no specific treatment for postconcussive syndrome, so doctors generally treat the symptoms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Some symptoms of postconcussive syndrome may go away quickly and others – like fatigue – may be more difficult to clear up. It's a good idea to see a neurologist for postconcussive syndrome, because the condition may be difficult to diagnose. How you treat it depends on your symptoms. Your doctor may prescribe medication to relieve headaches. Biofeedback can improve attention and memory. For anxiety, depression, or other emotional problems caused by the condition, it may help to take an antidepressant or see a therapist who is experienced with brain injuries. About half of people with postconcussive syndrome have symptoms for up to three months, and about one in 10 people still have symptoms at one year."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Each year, about 1.4 million people in the country suffer traumatic brain injury, and about 40% of those develop postconcussive syndrome."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Depending on your symptoms, treatment may include:\n\t\t•\tMedication\n\t\t•\tPsychological treatment\n\t\t•\tVocational treatment\n\t\t•\tBiofeedback\n\t\t•\tSurgery"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "No one with postconcussive syndrome should participate in contact sports until symptoms have resolved. Depending on the nature and severity of your symptoms, it may help to:\n\t\t•\tLimit physical and mental activity\n\t\t•\tDevelop good sleep hygiene habits\n\t\t•\tTalk to your doctor about when to return to work\n\t\t•\tTake measures to prevent falls\n\t\t•\tTalk to your doctor about safe exercise\n\t\t•\tGradually increase reading if you have concentration problems\n\t\t•\tMake lists if you have memory loss"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Exertion, stress, alcohol"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "If you have any concussion symptoms for more than a week, see your doctor. If symptoms of postconcussive syndrome are severe, go to a hospital emergency room."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\t\t•\tDo you think I am suffering from postconcussive syndrome?\n\t\t•\tWhat treatment options are there?\n\t\t•\tAre there any other tests that are needed?\n\t\t•\tHow long will the symptoms last?"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "The doctor will take a medical history and do a physical exam, and may do a CT scan, MRI, or electroencephalogram (EEG), which evaluates electrical brain activity."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "You're more likely to have postconcussive syndrome if your brain injury was due to a car accident or assault, you're depressed, you lack social support, or you are middle-aged, older, or very young."

	"Anemia": [{
			"heading": "Anemia",
			"content": "Red blood cell deficiency"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tDifficulty concentrating\n\t\t•\tDizziness\n\t\t•\tLightheadedness\n\t\t•\tShortness of breath\n\t\t•\tFainting\n\t\t•\tTires quickly\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tFatigue\n\t\t•\tPale skin\n\t\t•\tWeight loss (unintentional)\n\t\t•\tLoss of consciousness\n\t\t•\tWeakness (generalized)"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Anemia is a condition in which the body doesn't have enough red blood cells to carry oxygen to the tissues. Anemia can cause fatigue, pale skin, weakness, dizziness, headache, chest pain, and shortness of breath. There are many types of anemia and many causes, including blood loss and vitamin deficiencies. Pregnancy, chronic diseases, cancer, and autoimmune disorders can also cause anemia. Depending on the type of anemia you have, there are several different treatments."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "The type of anemia symptoms you have and how severe your symptoms are depends on the cause of your anemia. Iron-deficiency anemia is the most common type of anemia. It is more common in women, caused by blood loss during menstrual periods. Blood loss because of cancer or ulcers can also cause this type of anemia. Vitamin-deficiency anemia is another type caused by low levels of B-12 and folate vitamins. This type causes muscle weakness, dizziness, shortness of breath, and diarrhea. The symptoms may increase as the vitamin deficiency gets worse. Aplastic anemia is a type of anemia that occurs when bone marrow can't produce new red blood cells. Almost all types of anemia get better with treatment."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Anemia caused by iron deficiency is common in women and children. Twelve percent of women aged 12 to 49 have iron deficiency anemia. Seven percent of children aged 1 to 2 have it."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "The treatment for anemia depends on what's causing the anemia. Iron-deficiency anemia and vitamin-deficiency anemia are usually treated with iron and vitamin supplements and changes in the diet. You may need blood transfusions, surgery, or medications for other types of anemia."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "If your anemia is caused by an iron or vitamin deficiency, eating a healthy diet rich in iron and vitamins can help improve symptoms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Eating a poor diet, pregnancy, heavy menstrual bleeding, taking antacids, taking aspirin or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications (NSAIDS) for a long time, donating blood"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "See your doctor if you have any unusual bleeding or any symptoms of anemia."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\t\t•\tHow severe is my anemia?\n\t\t•\tWhat treatments do I need?\n\t\t•\tWhat caused my anemia?\n\t\t•\tWhat can I do to feel better?\n\t\t•\tWhat can I do to prevent anemia in the future?"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "To diagnose anemia, your doctor will take medical history and do a physical exam. You may also need blood tests that will include a red blood cell count, a gastrointestinal intestinal exam, or a bone marrow biopsy."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Eating a poor diet, being pregnant, being a woman, having an intestinal disorder, having a family history of anemia, being on certain medications such as blood thinners or certain chemotherapy drugs"
		}

	"Anemia_(chronic_disease)": [{
			"heading": "Anemia of Chronic Disease",
			"content": "Acd, anemia of inflammation, anemia of inflammatory response"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tDifficulty concentrating\n\t\t•\tDizziness\n\t\t•\tHeadache\n\t\t•\tPale skin\n\t\t•\tShortness of breath\n\t\t•\tTires quickly\n\t\t•\tDifficulty sleeping\n\t\t•\tFatigue\n\t\t•\tLightheadedness\n\t\t•\tRapid heart rate (pulse)\n\t\t•\tMuscle cramps or spasms (painful)"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Anemia occurs when a person has too few red blood cells. These cells carry oxygen and other nutrients throughout the body. Signs of anemia can include weakness, tiredness, difficulty breathing, dizziness, and other symptoms. Anemia of chronic disease (ACD) is caused by certain inflammatory or infectious diseases, such as autoimmune disorders, cancer, kidney disease, cirrhosis, and long-term infections such as HIV and hepatitis B. ACD is likely a protective reaction the body has to the underlying disease. All living cells, including bacteria and even cancer cells, need iron. ACD limits the amount of iron that's available for whatever agent is causing the disease. Treatment for ACD consists of treating the underlying condition that is causing it."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Anemia of chronic disease develops slowly in response to a chronic inflammatory or infectious disease or cancer. When symptoms appear, they are usually mild. The condition usually does not get worse. Severe cases requiring transfusion or other treatments are very rare. ACD usually improves or goes away on its own when the disease that's causing it is treated."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Anemia of chronic disease is the second most common form of anemia and the most common form of anemia in patients in the hospital."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Anemia of chronic disease is usually mild and the disease generally requires no treatment. When the underlying condition that's causing it is treated, ACD usually improves or goes away on its own. A very severe case may require a blood transfusion, but that is rare. Iron supplements and vitamins, which may be used to treat other types of anemia, are not effective. In fact, taking iron supplements could cause life-threatening complications."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "For ACD it's important to follow the treatment plan for the condition that is causing it. Trying to treat the anemia on your own with iron supplements could be dangerous. Do not take any over-the-counter supplements without discussing it with your doctor first."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "See your doctor if you have an infectious or inflammatory disease and develop any symptoms of anemia. Symptoms of anemia can include pale complexion, dizziness, fatigue, rapid heartbeat, headache, and shortness of breath. It's also important to keep all your doctor appointments for treating the underlying disease.\n\nIf you have ACD accompanied by chest pain, call the emergency services or seek immediate medical attention."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\t\t•\tHow severe is my anemia?\n\t\t•\tDo I need any treatment for it?\n\t\t•\tUnder what circumstances might I need a transfusion?\n\t\t•\tWhat caused this anemia?\n\t\t•\tAre there any other things I should be doing to get better?\n\t\t•\tWhat can I do to prevent anemia in the future?"

	"Insomnia": [{
			"heading": "Insomnia",
			"content": "Difficulty sleeping, sleeplessness"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tDifficulty concentrating\n\t\t•\tDifficulty falling asleep\n\t\t•\tDifficulty staying awake during day\n\t\t•\tDifficulty sleeping\n\t\t•\tDifficulty staying asleep"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Insomnia is the inability to get to sleep or stay asleep at night. Anyone at any age can experience insomnia. Drinking alcohol or caffeine, stress, medications, an uncomfortable sleep environment, and work schedule changes can lead to short-term insomnia. Chronic insomnia often results from mental health problems and can be a sign of depression. Medical conditions such as COPD or sleep apnea can also cause chronic sleep problems. Most of the time, good sleep habits, such as keeping a regular sleep schedule and not consuming caffeine before bed, can resolve the problem. Treating underlying medical conditions can also improve sleep."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Many people have insomnia for a short while due to stress, jet lag, medication side-effects, pain from an injury, or some other problem. But some people suffer from chronic insomnia, which may be harder to treat. If a medical condition, such as COPD or heart failure, makes sleeping difficult, talk with your doctor about ways to ease night-time symptoms so you can get enough sleep. Sleep problems are often associated with certain types of mental illness, including depression, anxiety, and bipolar disorder. If lack of sleep makes it hard to function during the day or if insomnia lasts for longer than 3 or 4 weeks, see your doctor to determine the cause and get treatment. Making changes to your sleep habits, such as keeping a regular sleep schedule and avoiding caffeine and alcohol at night, can help both short-term and chronic insomnia. If needed, taking sleeping pills can also help improve sleep, but medications should not be used as the only therapy."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 30% to 50% of people in the U.S have insomnia at some point in their life."
		},

		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Take these steps to improve your sleep:\n\t\t•\tGo to bed and get up at the same time each day.\n\t\t•\tAvoid alcohol, caffeine, and heavy meals before bedtime.\n\t\t•\tDon't smoke.\n\t\t•\tGet regular exercise; but avoid exercise 3 to 5 hours before bedtime.\n\t\t•\tMake your bed and bedroom comfortable for sleeping.\n\t\t•\tUse your bed for sleep and sex only; don't read, watch TV, or eat in bed.\n\t\t•\tTry relaxation techniques such as breathing exercises or meditation.\n\t\t•\tIf you can't sleep after 30 minutes, get up and try relaxing in another room."
		},
		{

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Lyme disease is a bacterial infection spread through tick bites. A tick may feed on a mouse or deer with the bacteria and then bite a person, spreading the disease. Lyme disease may cause a rash and flu-like symptoms. Prompt treatment with antibiotics can prevent complications such as joint and nerve problems. Keep in mind that the majority of tick bites don't result in Lyme disease -- or any other disease. Other more common conditions can cause symptoms similar to those of Lyme disease."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Ticks that spread Lyme disease are so small that many people never notice the bite. Lyme disease can be hard to diagnose. While it often causes a distinct symptom within a month of the bite -- a red, ringed rash that looks like a bulls-eye -- many people with Lyme disease never develop it. Instead, they may have vague flu-like symptoms and fatigue. As long as a person starts treatment quickly, antibiotics usually cure the infection without other problems. Without treatment, Lyme disease can progress and cause painful joints. Rarely, it can cause memory problems, mood changes, heart rhythm problems, and other issues. For some people, these symptoms linger even after treatment."
		},

			"heading": "How Common",

			"content": "Lyme disease always needs medical treatment. Your doctor may suggest over-the-counter NSAIDs -- such as ibuprofen, ketoprofen, and naproxen -- for joint pain and swelling. 	"Nicotine_withdrawal/cessation_of_smoking": [{
			"heading": "Nicotine Withdrawal (Cessation of Smoking)",
			"content": "Quitting smoking"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "Difficulty concentrating"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Nicotine is an addictive substance in tobacco that affects a person's mood. People who smoke, chew, or inhale tobacco regularly develop a dependence on nicotine. Trying to cut down or quit will trigger nicotine withdrawal. The body reacts when the supply of nicotine is cut off. It causes an intense desire for nicotine, irritable mood, headaches, and anxiety. Nicotine withdrawal can be difficult and unpleasant, but it is not harmful. It often subsides within a few weeks as the body adjusts. Treatment can help people resist the desire to use tobacco again during nicotine withdrawal. The effects of nicotine withdrawal are temporary. The benefits of quitting tobacco use will last the rest of a person's life."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Just a few hours after a person last used tobacco, nicotine withdrawal symptoms may start. They tend to get worse over the following hours and peak after two or three days. Symptoms tend to be most severe in people who were heavy users or used tobacco for many years. Nicotine withdrawal can trigger symptoms in people who have previously had depression or other psychological conditions. Nicotine withdrawal symptoms should go away within a few weeks. Taking nicotine supplements -- such as skin patches, gum, inhalers, and nasal sprays -- will reduce withdrawal symptoms and may make it easier to quit. People who quit may still have intense desires for tobacco weeks, months, or years later, especially during situations in which they used to smoke. This is not a sign of nicotine withdrawal but a psychological craving."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "80% to 90% of people who smoke are addicted to nicotine. They will have nicotine withdrawal if they try to quit."
		},

		},

	"Acute_stress_reaction": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tDifficulty falling asleep\n\t\t•\tGiddiness\n\t\t•\tNervousness\n\t\t•\tRapid heart rate (pulse)\n\t\t•\tTrembling\n\t\t•\tMood swings\n\t\t•\tExcessive mouth watering\n\t\t•\tHyperventilating (rapid/deep breathing)\n\t\t•\tHigh blood pressure\n\t\t•\tJumpiness or easily startled\n\t\t•\tReduced productivity at work\n\t\t•\tShaking\n\t\t•\tFatigue\n\t\t•\tHeadache\n\t\t•\tPalpitations (fluttering in chest)\n\t\t•\tThroat tightness\n\t\t•\tHyperactive behavior\n\t\t•\tRapid breathing\n\t\t•\tFlushed skin\n\t\t•\tShaking hands or tremor\n\t\t•\tPounding heart (pulse)\n\t\t•\tGrinding teeth\n\t\t•\tRestless (tossing and turning) sleep"

		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Acute stress reaction, or acute stress disorder, is a physical and psychological reaction to a stressful situation. It can cause shortness of breath, rapid heartbeat, increased blood pressure, anxiety, and a sense of impending doom. These reactions can be normal after an unusually severe and stressful event such as the death of a loved one, a natural disaster, or physical violence."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "An acute stress reaction usually occurs right after or during the stressful event, but it can be delayed as long as 4 weeks. While some people may have obvious signs of a reaction, others may keep their stress response hidden -- even from themselves. If that happens, a person may become depressed or have trouble sleeping well after the event. Usually, stress reactions get progressively better over a day or two. However, many people go on to develop post-traumatic stress disorder."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "There are millions of acute stress reactions of varying degrees in the country every year."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for an acute stress reaction may include:\n\t\t•\tAnti-anxiety medication\n\t\t•\tAntidepressants\n\t\t•\tCognitive Behavioral Therapy"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Remaining in the stressful situation or experiencing stress from a different situation"
		},

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Restless legs syndrome causes intense discomfort in your legs and an overpowering urge to move them. You may feel itching or crawling. The feeling gets worse when you rest and better when you move. Usually, restless legs syndrome has no clear cause, although pregnancy, some health conditions, and medicines can trigger it. While not dangerous, restless legs syndrome can keep you awake at night. Treatments can't cure restless legs syndrome, but they can ease the symptoms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Restless legs syndrome tends to be worse at night, and when you're sitting or lying down. Moving your legs will make them feel better temporarily. Many people have mild cases. Others have such bad restless legs that it's difficult to sleep through the night, leading to exhaustion and trouble thinking clearly. Restless legs syndrome may come and go over the months and years."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 1 in 20 people in the country have restless legs syndrome."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatments for restless legs syndrome can relax the muscles and help you rest. They include:\n\t\t•\tReducing stress\n\t\t•\tMoist heat (such as warm baths)\n\t\t•\tStretching and massage\n\t\t•\tMedicines to help you sleep\n\t\t•\tOther drugs (which include medicines for Parkinson's disease, epilepsy, anxiety, and pain)\n\nIf an underlying condition or drug side effect is causing restless legs, treating the problem or using a different medicine may clear up the symptoms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Reducing stress can help. Try breathing exercises, yoga, or meditation. Relax the muscles with stretching exercises, massage, and hot baths. Cut down on -- or cut out -- caffeine, alcohol, and tobacco."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Resting or lying down, sitting still, stress, caffeine, alcohol, stimulants, and smoking"
		},

			"content": "If you have restless legs at night -- or suffer from sleep problems -- see the doctor."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\t\t•\tHow can I relieve the symptoms of restless legs syndrome?\n\t\t•\tCould drug side effects be causing it?\n\t\t•\tDo you recommend medicines to help me sleep?\n\t\t•\tCould another condition be causing my restless legs syndrome?"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "Your doctor will examine you and ask about your symptoms. You may need tests to rule out other causes."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Risk factors for restless legs syndrome include stress, menopause, pregnancy, and a family history of restless legs syndrome. Side effects from medicines -- such as antidepressants, allergy drugs, anti-nausea drugs, sedatives, and others -- can also cause restless legs syndrome. Restless legs syndrome sometimes develops in people with other medical conditions, such as iron deficiency, sleep disorders, nerve damage, fibromyalgia, kidney disease, and Parkinson's disease."

	"Brain_aneurysm": [{
			"heading": "Brain Aneurysm",
			"content": "Cerebral aneurysm, intracranial aneurysm, intracerebral aneurysm"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tDifficulty finding words\n\t\t•\tHeadache\n\t\t•\tSensitive to light\n\t\t•\tFainting\n\t\t•\tHeadache (worst ever)\n\t\t•\tDifficulty talking\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tNausea or vomiting\n\t\t•\tSlurred speech\n\t\t•\tLoss of consciousness\n\t\t•\tSeizures (uncontrollable jerking of limbs)"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "A brain aneurysm is a weak spot in a blood vessel in the brain that balloons and fills with blood. If it bursts, it can cause bleeding, known as a brain hemorrhage. One of the symptoms is often described as\"the worst headache of your life.\" A ruptured brain aneurysm can lead to stroke or death and is a medical emergency. Unless it ruptures, however, a brain aneurysm may cause no symptoms. If you smoke or have high blood pressure, atherosclerosis, or other risk factors, you should get screened. Detecting a brain aneurysm early makes it much easier to treat. Monitoring and surgery are the usual treatments."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "If you have symptoms of a ruptured brain aneurysm, such as a sudden and extremely severe headache, stiff neck, nausea and vomiting, blurred or double vision, trouble walking or dizziness, loss of consciousness, sensitivity to light, and seizures, call the emergency services."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Many aneurysms remain small and don't produce any symptoms. One that is growing may cause pain around the eye, vision problems, and partial facial paralysis as it gets larger. If it hemorrhages, you may have a sudden, severe headache, double vision, and vomiting or faint. If the brain aneurysm is small, your doctor may watch it over time to see if it grows or starts causing symptoms. If it does, you may need either surgery to cut off blood flow to the aneurysm or a non-surgical procedure that\"packs\" the aneurysm with small coils or a balloon. You'll be in the hospital for one to three days and recovery may take up to six weeks. If the aneurysm has ruptured, you'll receive emergency surgery and may be hospitalized for three or four weeks to be monitored or treated for complications."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Smoking, high blood pressure"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Depending on factors such as the size and location of the aneurysm, risk of rupture, and your health, treatment may include:\n\t\t•\tMonitoring\n\t\t•\tSurgery, including microvascular clipping (putting a clip on the neck of the aneurysm to stop blood supply) or occlusion (clamping off the artery that leads to the aneurysm)\n\t\t•\tEndovascular embolization (releasing coils or a balloon into the aneurysm to clot the blood and destroy the aneurysm)\n\t\t•\tTreatment for underlying conditions, such as high blood pressure\n\t\t•\tAnticonvulsants to prevent seizures\n\t\t•\tPain medication for headache\n\t\t•\tTreatment for complications\n\t\t•\tSpeech, rehabilitative, and occupational therapy if hemorrhage causes permanent disability"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "These self-care strategies may help if you have been diagnosed with a brain aneurysm:\n\t\t•\tControl your blood pressure.\n\t\t•\tDon't smoke.\n\t\t•\tDon't use cocaine or other stimulant drugs.\n\t\t•\tTalk to your doctor about using birth control pills."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "If you are at risk for a brain aneurysm, make an appointment with your doctor to get screened. Symptoms of an unruptured brain aneurysm may include pain above and behind the eye, headache, blurred or double vision, dilated pupils, progressive weakness or numbness, paralysis on one side of the face, and trouble speaking. If you have symptoms of an unruptured brain aneurysm, see your doctor promptly or go to a hospital emergency room. If you have symptoms of a brain hemorrhage, call the emergency services."
		},

	"Asthma_(teen_and_adult)": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tDifficulty sleeping\n\t\t•\tNighttime wheezing\n\t\t•\tFeeling of not being able to get enough air\n\t\t•\tNoisy breathing\n\t\t•\tShortness of breath\n\t\t•\tWheezing\n\t\t•\tLabored breathing\n\t\t•\tDifficulty talking\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tCough\n\t\t•\tNew onset asthma\n\t\t•\tPressure or heaviness\n\t\t•\tTightness\n\t\t•\tRapid breathing\n\t\t•\tDifficulty staying asleep"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Asthma is a lung condition that causes airways to swell and become inflamed. Asthma makes it hard to breathe. Some people may have minor symptoms, but others may have severe symptoms that interfere with daily life. Having severe asthma may put you at risk for a life-threatening asthma attack. Symptoms of an asthma attack include wheezing, chest tightness, coughing, and shortness of breath. Doctors don't know exactly what causes asthma, but genetic and environmental factors may play a role. Triggers such as smoking, air pollution, allergies, exercise, stress, GERD, and colds can bring on asthma attacks. Asthma is a lifelong condition that can be managed but not cured. Avoiding asthma triggers and taking medication help most people avoid attacks and keep symptoms under control."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Being exposed to pet dander, pollen, air pollution, or smoke can trigger an asthma attack. Having a cold or flu can also trigger attacks. Asthma attacks may come on suddenly or build slowly over several hours or days. Common symptoms include wheezing, shortness of breath, chest tightness, and coughing. Asthma symptoms can vary, and not everyone has the same symptoms all the time. Symptoms may be mild and barely noticeable, or they may interfere with daily life. Severe asthma attacks are a medical emergency. Taking daily medications, called controller medications, can help prevent asthma attacks. Once an attack has started, rescue medications help relax and open airways. Most people need both types of medication to control asthma."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "24 million people in the country have asthma."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for asthma includes an asthma action plan that has in writing when to take certain medications based on your symptoms. Medications include both those for long-term control and for quick relief:\n\t\t•\tLong-term control medications include inhaled corticosteroids, leukotriene modifiers, long-acting beta agonists, combination inhalers, omalizumab (Xolair).\n\t\t•\tQuick-relief or rescue medications include short-acting bronchodilators and oral corticosteroids.\n\t\t•\tAllergy treatment, if your asthma is triggered by allergies."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Learning to identify and avoid triggers can help prevent asthma attacks. Most people manage their asthma at home with the help of an asthma action plan that explains what type and how much asthma medication to use. It also includes when to call the doctor or go to an emergency room. Specific steps that may help include:\n\t\t•\tRunning your air conditioner\n\t\t•\tAvoiding pet dander\n\t\t•\tWearing a mask when cleaning (or having someone clean house for you)\n\t\t•\tEncasing pillows, mattresses, and box springs in dust-proof covers\n\t\t•\tChoosing hardwood floors instead of carpeting and blinds instead of drapes\n\t\t•\tGetting regular exercise (wearing a face mask when it's cold)\n\t\t•\tStaying at a healthy weight\n\t\t•\tEating a healthy diet with lots of fruits and vegetables"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Exposure to asthma triggers, stress"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "If you have never been diagnosed with asthma but are wheezing and having other mild symptoms, call your doctor. If you are taking asthma medication, but still having frequent attacks, call your doctor. You may need to change your treatment plan. If rescue medications aren't helping to control symptoms of an asthma attack and you can't reach your doctor, get immediate medical help. If you have blue lips, extreme difficulty breathing, or other symptoms of a severe attack, call the emergency services right away."
		},
		{

		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Emphysema is a chronic lung condition in which the small sacs in your lungs are slowly destroyed. This makes it hard for your body to get the oxygen it needs. It is one of the two types of COPD (chronic obstructive pulmonary disease). Smoking is the most common cause of emphysema. It takes many years to develop. People who have emphysema have shortness of breath, a chronic cough, wheezing, fatigue, and chest tightness."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Emphysema usually develops over many years. Shortness of breath or cough are often the first symptoms that people notice. These symptoms gradually get worse, until just walking across a room causes you to be out of breath. You also may notice that you feel too tired to do the things you used to do. There is no cure for emphysema, but treatment can help you feel better and help keep the condition from getting worse."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 20 in every 1,000 people in the country have emphysema."

	"Periodic_limb_movement_disorder": [{
			"heading": "Periodic Limb Movement Disorder",
			"content": "PLMD"

		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tDifficulty sleeping\n\t\t•\tRestless (tossing and turning) sleep\n\t\t•\tMuscle twitching (painless)"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Periodic limb movement disorder is a type of sleep disorder that causes the legs to move repetitively during sleep. The movements usually occur about every 20 to 40 seconds and last about 2 seconds. PLMD often occurs in people who have restless legs syndrome, but it is not the same thing.  PLMD may be caused by another sleep disorder or medical condition, such as diabetes, spinal cord injury, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, or anemia. Some medications such as antidepressants, antinausea drugs, or anticonvulsants can cause it in some people. In some cases, it has no cause. PLMD can disrupt your sleep and make you feel tired during the day. It can also cause insomnia."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "The symptoms of PLMD only occur while you are sleeping. You may not know that you have the condition unless your spouse says your legs are kicking during sleep. PLMD is usually treated with medications to help reduce the movement or to help you sleep through the movement. Sometimes, PLMD gets better when you treat the medical condition that's causing it."

	"Pinworms": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tDifficulty sleeping\n\t\t•\tWorms in stool\n\t\t•\tItching or burning"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Pinworms are small worms that infect the intestines, and they are highly contagious. They cause intense itching around the anus, where pinworms lay their eggs. Pinworms also can enter the vagina, where they cause itching. Pinworm infection occurs most often in children between ages 5 and 10. They are easy to treat with medications, and usually are not dangerous. But often, the whole family needs to be treated to avoid the spread of pinworms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Pinworm infections are treated easily with a single dose of one of two commonly used antiparasitic drugs. Because the eggs can survive for up to two weeks, a follow-up dose is given usually two weeks later. Pinworms are highly contagious, so members of the same household should be treated, as well. Recurrences are common. They can be prevented with careful hygiene."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Although pinworm infections can occur at any age, they are most common in school-aged children."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "More than 40 million cases of pinworm infection occur in the country each year."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Prevention",
			"content": "Good hygiene can help prevent the spread of pinworms, although once a family member is infected it's difficult to contain pinworms. Teach everyone in the family to wash hands before eating or preparing meals. Keep children's fingernails short and clean, and avoid biting fingernails. Don't scratch the anal area. Wash all bedding and pajamas regularly and change underwear every day. Vacuum the children's play area often."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "The most common treatment is a single dose of either mebendazole or albendazole. These medications are available over-the-counter and by prescription. The medications kill pinworms but not their eggs, so a follow-up dose is usually give after two weeks. Your doctor is likely to recommend that members of the household also be treated, since pinworms are so contagious."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "It is very important to prevent re-infection with pinworms. Clean toilet seats frequently. Because the eggs can be picked up when children scratch themselves and then be spread to others, keep your children's fingernails short and clean. Wash sheets and pillowcases twice a week. Encourage everyone in the family to wash hands before meals and after using the bathroom."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "Call for an appointment if:\n\t\t•\tYou or your child has symptoms of pinworm infection.\n\t\t•\tYou have seen pinworms on your child."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\t\t•\tHow will we know if the treatment has eliminated all the worms?\n\t\t•\tShould other members of the family be treated?\n\t\t•\tHow can we prevent a recurrence of pinworms?"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "Pinworms are large enough to be seen with the naked eye. Less than 1-inch long, they are yellowish white and as thin as thread. They usually appear in the anal area at night, when they lay their eggs. Pinworms can sometimes be seen in a child's stool, as well. To confirm the diagnosis, doctors often recommend a tape test, which can be done at home. The test involves pressing a piece of cellophane tape against the skin around the anus and then removing it. The best time is first thing in the morning. Your doctor will then look at the tape under a microscope to see if pinworm eggs are present."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "The intense itching caused by the worm can lead to scratching, leaving skin irritated or infected. Inadequate hygiene can allow the worm's eggs to spread."
		}

		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Pregnancy starts when the sperm and egg join and form an embryo. This takes place in the fallopian tube. Over the next few days, the embryo travels through the tube to the womb. Once there, it implants in the lining of the uterus and begins to grow. A normal pregnancy lasts nine months. During that time, the fetus gets oxygen and nutrients from the mother through the placenta. While a woman is pregnant, her body produces a special\"pregnancy hormone\" called hCG. Pregnancies are confirmed by testing for the presence of that hormone."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "When a woman is pregnant, she should expect to see her doctor or midwife regularly. That would mean once a month for the first seven months of a normal pregnancy and more often during the last two months. During these visits the doctor or midwife will check on the health of the mother and the fetus. They'll also provide direction the mother can use to keep herself and her baby well. Weight gain is normal during pregnancy. It's also normal for the belly to get large as the uterus expands to hold the fetus. Some spotting is normal, but there should be no heavy bleeding from the vagina."

	"Heartburn/GERD": [{
			"heading": "Heartburn/GERD",
			"content": "Chronic heartburn, dyspepsia, gastroesophageal reflux or irritation, peptic esophagitis, reflux esophagitis"

		{

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Heartburn happens when stomach acid backs up into your esophagus, irritating the lining of the esophagus. Usually when you swallow, a muscle around the bottom of the esophagus opens to let food go through and then closes. When it gets weak or doesn't close right, it lets stomach acid flow back into your esophagus. Heartburn causes a burning sensation in your mouth or chest or a sour taste in your mouth. Mild, occasional heartburn usually isn't a problem. Heartburn that happens frequently is called gastroesophageal reflux disorder, or GERD.  It is also possible to have GERD without symptoms of discomfort in your chest.  GERD without symptoms has been linked to causing ear infections, sinus infection, excessive mucus in the throat. Over time, GERD can wear away at your esophagus and increase your risk for esophageal cancer and other problems."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Most people have heartburn at one time or another. Mild heartburn usually gets better in a few hours. Many people can treat heartburn on their own with over-the-counter antacids and other medications. Avoiding foods that make your heartburn worse can also help. If you have heartburn more than twice a week or symptoms really bother you, you may have GERD. You may need prescription medications or surgery to treat GERD."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 1 in 20 people in the country have chronic acid reflux, or GERD."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for heartburn and GERD usually begins with over-the-counter antacids and medications to help reduce stomach acid. You also may want to avoid the foods and drinks that make your symptoms worse. If these treatments don't relieve symptoms, you may need prescription medications, surgery, or other procedures."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "You may be able to ease the symptoms of heartburn or GERD by avoiding the foods and drinks that make your symptoms worse. You also can eat smaller meals, lose weight, quit smoking, reduce stress, and avoid lying down for two to three hours after a meal."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Alcohol; caffeine; chocolate; fried, spicy, or fatty foods; eating large meals; lying down after a meal; smoking; stress; certain medications; wearing tight fitting clothing or belts"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "See your doctor if you use over-the-counter medications for heartburn more than twice a week or if you have frequent or severe GERD symptoms.\n\nIf you have chest pain, particularly along with shortness or breath or pain in your arm or jaw, dial the emergency services and seek emergency care. These could be signs of a heart attack."

	"Peripheral_neuropathy": [{
			"heading": "Peripheral Neuropathy",
			"content": "Peripheral neuritis, neuropathy, nerve damage, nerve pain"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tDifficulty staying asleep\n\t\t•\tWeakness\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tNumbness or tingling"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Peripheral neuropathy is a long-term condition in which the nerves in the arms, legs, hands, and feet are damaged and don't work properly. Diabetes is the most common cause, but other conditions, injuries, infections, and medications also can cause peripheral neuropathy. Peripheral neuropathy may not have a cause. People with peripheral neuropathy often have numbness and tingling in the hands and feet, nerve pain, and lack of coordination. It also can cause difficulty moving and decreased sensation. Peripheral neuropathy can cause diarrhea, dizziness, blurred vision, impotence, and weight loss."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "The first symptoms of peripheral neuropathy are often numbness, weakness, or tingling in the hands or feet. Over time, it also may affect other nerves and cause other symptoms. The symptoms of peripheral neuropathy can vary from person to person depending on which nerves are affected. Doctors usually treat peripheral neuropathy by managing the condition that is causing it. Other treatments can help reduce pain and nerve damage."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 60% to 70% of people with diabetes in the country have some nerve damage."

	"Night_eating_syndrome": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "Difficulty staying asleep"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Night eating syndrome (NES) is compulsive eating during the night. People with it may eat half or more of their daily food after dinner. Many people develop it around age 30, most often after a stressful event, such as a job loss, difficult pregnancy, or illness in the family. It is more common in people who are obese, have other eating disorders, or are substance abusers. Unlike eating disorders such as anorexia and bulimia, it affects women and men almost equally. It also tends to run in families. People with NES are fully conscious when they eat, unlike people with sleep-related eating disorder, who may eat while sleepwalking. Medication and counseling can help deal with it."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Night eating syndrome affects your eating, sleep, and mood. If you have it, you may feel that you need to eat after dinner until bedtime or you won't fall asleep. About two hours after you fall asleep, you may wake up feeling that you need to eat more to go back to sleep. If you don't eat, you may feel restless and agitated. You may end up eating a few small meals during the night, but no breakfast. You may delay your first meal of the day for several hours. Some people with NES diet during the day. Many people with NES are ashamed of their eating disorder or depressed, and depression in people with NES often worsens as the day goes on. Because it is not fully understood, there is no standard treatment for NES. Your doctor may suggest medication or a program of exercise and help to establish normal daytime eating patterns. Stress management, counseling, and limiting alcohol and caffeine may also be advised."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 1.5% of people have night eating syndrome."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Obesity, substance abuse, stress, family members who have night eating syndrome"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for night eating syndrome may include:\n\t\t•\tA program of regular exercise and counseling to help establish normal eating patterns\n\t\t•\tStress-reduction techniques\n\t\t•\tPsychological therapy for stress, anxiety, or depression\n\t\t•\tLimiting alcohol and caffeine\n\t\t•\tTaking a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor to help regulate both eating and sleep patterns"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "These self-care strategies may help you deal with night eating syndrome:\n\t\t•\tKeep a food diary, recording the time you go to bed and awaken during the night, what you eat, and your thoughts about eating. Discuss it with your doctor.\n\t\t•\tIf you have conditions that disrupt your sleep, such as snoring, get help for them.\n\t\t•\tDon't keep food in your room at night.\n\t\t•\tTry to eat fewer calories at each nighttime eating session.\n\t\t•\tEstablish a regular exercise program."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",

			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Caffeine is a stimulant. If you drink caffeinated drinks such as coffee, tea, or cola every day, your body gets used to the caffeine. If you suddenly stop, you may get withdrawal symptoms, such as headache, fatigue, and bad mood. These problems will fade within a week or so. You can usually avoid caffeine withdrawal by cutting down on caffeine gradually."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "After you quit caffeine, your body goes into withdrawal. Symptoms usually start 12 to 24 hours later. They are usually worse in the first day or two. All symptoms clear up in 2 to 9 days. The more caffeinated drinks you have each day, the worse your caffeine withdrawal may be. But even people who drink just one small cup of coffee a day find they have caffeine withdrawal."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Treatment"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "The best immediate treatment for caffeine withdrawal is simple: have some coffee or tea. A little caffeine will reduce your symptoms. If you want to prevent caffeine withdrawal, slowly reduce the amount of caffeine you take in over the course of a few days. Once your body adjusts, even quitting caffeine completely shouldn't cause withdrawal symptoms."
