	"Narcolepsy": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "Difficulty staying awake during day"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Narcolepsy is a brain disorder that makes people abnormally sleepy at times during the day. They may unintentionally fall asleep for periods lasting from a few seconds to several minutes, sometimes right in the middle of an activity. Narcolepsy also disrupts night-time sleep patterns, causing poor sleep. Symptoms typically appear between ages 10 and 25. But narcolepsy can be diagnosed at almost any age. Medication can help treat excessive daytime sleepiness and promote more normal sleep at night."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "You may fall asleep unintentionally during the day, sometimes in the middle of performing a task. You may also suffer sudden, temporary loss of muscle tone. It can be as minor as a drooping eyelid or severe enough to cause physical collapse. Some people also have hallucinations and temporary paralysis while falling asleep. There is no cure for narcolepsy. But treatment with medications, naps, and good sleep habits allow most people with narcolepsy to lead normal and productive lives."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About one in 2,000 people in the country have narcolepsy."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Family history slightly increases the risk of narcolepsy."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "There is no cure for narcolepsy. But drugs can treat the most troublesome symptoms of the disorder. Medications include:\n\t\t•\tStimulants, which help people with narcolepsy stay awake during the day\n\t\t•\tSelective serotonin or norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors, which can help prevent cataplexy (sudden muscle weakness) and excessive sleepiness during the day\n\t\t•\tSodium oxybate, a medication that is often prescribed for severe episodes of muscle weakness"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "\t\t•\tTake regularly scheduled naps.\n\t\t•\tArrange your work or school schedule so that you do the most demanding tasks when you're most alert.\n\t\t•\tMaintain a regular sleep schedule.\n\t\t•\tAvoid alcohol and caffeinated beverages close to bedtime.\n\t\t•\tExercise at least 20 minutes a day, but not close to bedtime.\n\t\t•\tMake your bedroom as comfortable and quiet as possible.\n\t\t•\tFind a support group for people with narcolepsy."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\t\t•\tDo you think I may have narcolepsy?\n\t\t•\tWhat tests are used to diagnose this condition?\n\t\t•\tWhat treatment do you recommend?\n\t\t•\tWhat do drugs for narcolepsy do to prevent symptoms?\n\t\t•\tDo they have side effects?\n\t\t•\tCan I safely drive or do other activities?\n\t\t•\tWill I always have narcolepsy and require treatment?\n\t\t•\tWould it be useful for me to find a support group for people with narcolepsy?"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "A complete physical exam and medical history will alert your doctor to symptoms of narcolepsy. Your doctor may recommend a polysomnogram, which evaluates sleep patterns at night. Another test that is often performed is a multiple sleep latency test, which measures your tendency to fall asleep during the day."

			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Heavy meals, alcohol"

	"Amphetamine_withdrawal": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "Difficulty staying awake during day"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Amphetamines are stimulant medications that increase energy, alertness, and attention. They are used to treat some medical conditions, such as narcolepsy, ADHD, and depression. Some people also take amphetamines illegally without a prescription. If you take amphetamines often, stopping them suddenly can cause depression, fatigue, increased appetite, and sleep problems. It's more likely that you'll have these side effects if you are taking amphetamines illegally."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Amphetamines are addictive drugs that your body gets used to over time. In most cases, it's best to stop using amphetamines slowly. This will help prevent withdrawal symptoms. If you're taking amphetamines under your doctor's orders, your doctor can help you stop over time. If you are taking amphetamines without a prescription, you may need to seek help from a drug treatment center. Some people may need counseling to help stop taking amphetamines."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 15.4% of high school seniors report using amphetamines without a prescription."

	"Concussion": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tDisorientation\n\t\t•\tBlurred vision\n\t\t•\tDizziness\n\t\t•\tLightheadedness\n\t\t•\tMemory problems\n\t\t•\tRinging in ears\n\t\t•\tLoss of consciousness\n\t\t•\tAbnormal gait (walking)\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tConfusion\n\t\t•\tHeadache\n\t\t•\tLoss of balance\n\t\t•\tNausea or vomiting\n\t\t•\tSlurred speech\n\t\t•\tLoss of coordination"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "A concussion is an injury to the brain, usually caused by a blow to the head or an intense jolt. Concussions may cause nausea, confusion, or unconsciousness. For most concussions, rest is the main treatment. The brain needs time to heal. Full recovery can take days, weeks, or months. Most  concussions don't cause lasting problems but a severe head injury cold trigger swelling and/or bleeding in the brain which is life-threatening. A concussion is always serious and needs medical attention."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "Anyone with a possible concussion should see a doctor. If a person has major concussion symptoms such as loss of consciousness, confusion, frequent vomiting, blood or fluid leaking from the ears or nose, slurred speech, difficulty walking, muscle weakness, seizures, and pupils of different sizes, go to the emergency room or call the emergency services. Babies who are crying uncontrollably or won't eat after a possible concussion should also go to the emergency room."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Some concussion symptoms may occur right after the injury. Others may not appear until hours or days later. Watch people with a possible concussion for 24 to 48 hours. When they go to bed, wake them every two to three hours to check on their symptoms. Some people find that while they're recovering from a concussion, they have mild headaches, mood changes, problems with memory, and difficulty tolerating noise. These symptoms usually go away as they heal. The doctor may suggest avoiding sports, vigorous activity, tasks that require heavy concentration, and driving until a person is completely healed."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Not resting, vigorous activity, returning to work or school too quickly, alcohol, drugs that increase the risk of bleeding including blood thinners, aspirin, and NSAIDs such as ibuprofen, ketoprofen, and naproxen"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatments for concussions include:\n\t\t•\tRest\n\t\t•\tOver-the-counter acetaminophen for pain\n\t\t•\tAvoiding exercise, physical activity, and heavy concentration\n\t\t•\tHospitalization\n\t\t•\tSurgery, for severe concussions"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Anyone with a possible concussion should see a doctor. After a concussion, your doctor may tell you to take it easy. Don't go back to work or school, play sports, or engage in any strenuous mental or physical activity until your doctor says it's safe. Limit video games and computer time. Avoid alcohol. Take acetaminophen -- not aspirin, ibuprofen, ketoprofen, or naproxen -- for pain. If people with a possible concussion go to sleep, wake them up every two to three hours to make sure they're not getting worse. Always wear appropriate safety gear when playing sports."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "Anyone with a possible concussion should see a doctor."
		},

Some may experience inhalant intoxication accidentally when using chemicals in a confined space. Inhalant intoxication can be dangerous and sometimes deadly, even after a first exposure. Chronic use can cause severe organ damage."

Anyone who is exposed to fumes and notices symptoms should get fresh air right away. Someone with severe symptoms -- such as extreme confusion or unconsciousness -- needs emergency help."

			"heading": "Cat Scratch Disease",
			"content": "Cat scratch fever"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tDisorientation\n\t\t•\tBody aches or pains\n\t\t•\tEnlarged or swollen glands\n\t\t•\tFever\n\t\t•\tUnable to blink or close eyelid\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tDecreased appetite\n\t\t•\tFatigue\n\t\t•\tTender glands"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Cat scratch disease is a bacterial infection caused by a cat scratch or bite or cat saliva. Infected cats have no symptoms, so you can't tell that they have the disease. Fleas pass the disease between cats, but don't spread it to humans. Symptoms in humans include a blister or bump at the bite area, swollen lymph glands near the injury, fatigue, headache, sore throat, fever, and a general feeling of being ill. More serious, but less common symptoms include draining lymph nodes, enlarged spleen, eye infection, and liver, bone, joint, or lung infection. Cat scratch disease is usually mild and goes away on its own in two to four months. People with severe symptoms or a weak immune system may need antibiotics to help treat the disease."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Often a blister or bump forms at the site of the scratch or bite in about three to 10 days. After one to four weeks, swollen lymph nodes and other symptoms may occur. The blister usually heals in a few days. Lymph nodes can remain swollen for as long as two to four months. Most people don't need medical treatment, as the condition will go away on its own. People with more severe symptoms or those with a weak immune system may need antibiotics."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Being bitten or scratched by a cat or being exposed to cat saliva"

		},

		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Most of the time, cat scratch disease goes away on its own without treatment. People with a weak immune system or more serious symptoms may need antibiotics."
		},

			"heading": "Self Care",

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "A middle ear infection is the most common type of childhood bacterial infection, but it can also affect adults. These ear infections are often triggered by allergies, colds, and sinus infections. When the tubes leading from the middle ear to the back of the throat become swollen and blocked, bacteria or viruses can grow. This causes fluid buildup, which puts pressure on the eardrum, causing pain and, sometimes, hearing loss."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Most ear infections develop over a few days, causing pain and discomfort. Infants with an ear infection will fuss, cry, and have trouble sleeping. Young children will complain about ear pain. Both infants and children may run a mild fever. Many ear infections clear up in two to three days without treatment. If symptoms continue or get worse, the doctor will prescribe antibiotics, usually for 10 days. Even after treatment, fluid may remain in the ear for three to six weeks, causing temporary hearing loss until it is gone. Chronic ear infections can damage the ear drum and lead to permanent hearing loss."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "There are many millions of middle ear infections in the country every year."

		},
		{

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Labyrinthitis is an infection and swelling in the inner ear. Usually, viruses cause labyrinthitis. Labyrinthitis may cause vertigo -- dizziness, loss of balance, nausea, vomiting -- and sometimes hearing loss. An inner ear infection is different from common childhood ear infections. Those are typically caused by bacteria in the middle ear."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Labyrinthitis commonly occurs after a viral illness such as a cold or the flu. Symptoms range from mild dizziness to vertigo, an intense spinning sensation that makes it difficult to stand without falling over. You may also have nausea and vomiting. Changing your head position makes symptoms worse. Labyrinthitis gradually improves over one to three weeks. Most people recover completely within a few months. However, some people may have persistent problems with dizziness if the virus caused nerve damage."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 17% of people with chronic ear infections develop labyrinthitis. And about one in 10,000 people seek treatment for sudden labyrinthitis, often after a cold or flu."

		},

	"Benign_paroxysmal_positional_vertigo_(BPPV)": [{
			"heading": "Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo",
			"content": "Inner ear vertigo, bppv, labyrinthitis"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "BPPV (benign paroxysmal positional vertigo) is usually a temporary condition that affects balance and your sense of position. It's brought on by changes of head position that cause a sudden sense of spinning, known as vertigo. The dizziness comes from shifts in calcium crystals in the inner ear that normally help the brain know where you are in relation to things around you. Normally, these crystals send signals to the brain that help you balance. But with BPPV the signals are exaggerated. The result is a sensation that either you or the room is spinning. BPPV may be due to labyrinthitis, an inflammation or viral infection in parts of the inner ear. Most often, its cause is unknown. Along with the sensation of spinning, or vertigo, BPPV may cause nausea and sometimes vomiting."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "BPPV becomes more common with aging. It can come on for no apparent reason. Or it can occur after a viral infection, such as a cold or flu. When it happens, you get a sudden sense of spinning. The feeling is similar to spinning in a swivel chair or being on a ride at the amusement park. Changing your head position can bring it on or make the symptoms worse. Some people experience the feeling on waking, rolling over, or getting out of bed. During an episode, driving or operating machinery can be dangerous. Often, the BPPV improves on its own with no treatment over a period of a few weeks to a few months. Treating it with medications used for motion sickness can help relieve the symptoms. Slow rotational head movements and other exercises that you can learn from a physical therapist or other health professional can also be effective in controlling symptoms. After an initial episode, BPPV may go away, only to return months or years later."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "BPPV affects about  64 of every 100,000 people in the US. It is most common among people over age 50 and is rarely seen in people younger than 3."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Vertigo of the inner ear often clears up without any treatment. Your doctor may prescribe medications to reduce dizziness and nausea. Your doctor may also refer you to a physical therapist or other health professional, such as an ear, nose, and throat specialist. Professionals with special training can lead you through a series of head maneuvers that can shake the calcium crystals out of the inner ear canals. These maneuvers, known as Epley maneuvers, can often effectively cure vertigo of the inner ear."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "BPPV can be treated at home by waiting it out and using motion sickness medications. Have a doctor evaluate your symptoms of vertigo, especially if it lasts more than a week or the symptoms are severe."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Smoking, movement, alcohol"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "Contact your doctor if symptoms don’t improve. Also, call your doctor right away if you have vertigo and a fever, stiff neck, or sensitivity to light. Those symptoms could signal a serious viral infection such as meningitis.\n\nVertigo accompanied by problems with hearing and ringing in the ears could indicate a benign tumor in the inner ear. These symptoms should be evaluated by a doctor. Do not drive yourself to see the doctor. Vertigo makes driving risky.\n\nCall the emergency services or get immediate medical attention if the sensation of vertigo is accompanied by any symptoms of stroke, such as:\n\t\t•\tWeakness or numbness on one side of the body\n\t\t•\tLoss of vision\n\t\t•\tDifficulty speaking"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\t\t•\tHow long should I expect my symptoms to last?\n\t\t•\tWhat can I do to decrease the dizziness?\n\t\t•\tAre there any other treatments that might help me feel better more quickly?\n\t\t•\tWhat can I do to prevent this from coming back?\n\t\t•\tCould this be something more serious than BPPV?"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "Your doctor will do a physical exam, including an ear exam, and ask you questions about your symptoms and your medical history. To rule out other more serious conditions, the doctor may ask for other tests, such as blood tests, CT or MRI scans, and tests to assess your hearing."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Older age, having minor head injuries or viral infections, having ear surgery, making repetitive head movements such as you might make when working on a computer"
		}

	"Diabetes_(type_2)": [{
			"heading": "Diabetes, Type 2",
			"content": "Adult onset diabetes, non-insulin dependent diabetes"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tDizziness\n\t\t•\tDouble vision (without one eye covered)\n\t\t•\tFrequent urination\n\t\t•\tIncreased thirst\n\t\t•\tDrinking excessive fluids\n\t\t•\tOverweight\n\t\t•\tBlurred vision\n\t\t•\tFatigue\n\t\t•\tHeadache\n\t\t•\tWeight gain\n\t\t•\tFrequent infections\n\t\t•\tWeakness (generalized)"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Type 2 diabetes occurs when the body does not make enough insulin or does not use it as it should. When we eat food, our body breaks down the sugars and starches into glucose, which our cells need for energy. Insulin moves glucose from the blood to the cells. If there is not enough insulin, or if cells do not respond to the insulin, glucose can build up in the blood, which can cause complications, organ damage, and coma.\n\nBeing overweight increases your risk for type 2 diabetes, but not everyone who is overweight will develop the disease. Type 2 diabetes also affects people who are not overweight. Eating too much sugar won't cause diabetes, although a diet high in fat and calories will lead to weight gain."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "At first, type 2 diabetes often has no symptoms, so you can have it and not know it. The condition starts as prediabetes. This means that your glucose levels are higher than normal, with fasting blood sugars between 100 and 125. Once your fasting blood sugars are over 126, you have type 2 diabetes. You can help prevent or delay getting diabetes by losing weight, eating healthy food, and exercising more. Once you have type 2 diabetes, you need to manage it with those same lifestyle changes and medication. By keeping your glucose at a healthy level, you can lower your risk for serious health problems, including eye disease, kidney damage, nerve damage, heart disease, and stroke."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Approximately 1 in 17 people have type 2 diabetes."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Type 2 diabetes needs to be treated and monitored closely by a doctor. However, you can help manage type 2 diabetes by getting regular exercise and eating healthy foods such as vegetables, fruit, lean meats, and whole grains."

		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Vasovagal syncope is the most common reason that people faint. It happens when your body overreacts to emotional or physical stress such as seeing something unpleasant or standing for too long. This reaction causes your blood pressure to drop and less blood to flow to your brain, which makes you faint. Vomiting, coughing, defecating and urinating are also forms of vasovagal syncope."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "If symptoms do not improve, call your doctor or go to the emergency room. If you are pregnant and faint, call the emergency services."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Most fainting symptoms last only for a few minutes. In most cases, you will feel better when you lie down. Vasovagal syncope doesn't usually cause any other problems or need any treatment. But you can get hurt if you hit something when you faint. Sometimes people faint because there's an underlying problem such as low blood sugar, low blood pressure, or an irregular heartbeat. If you faint, see a doctor to make sure you don't have an underlying problem."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Standing, wearing tight clothing, or getting overheated"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Vasovagal syncope usually doesn't need any treatment. But if you faint often, your doctor may recommend one of the following treatments:\n\t\t•\tMedications\n\t\t•\tLeg exercises or special elastic stockings\n\t\t•\tA pacemaker"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",

	"Heart_rhythm_disorder": [{
			"heading": "Heart Rhythm Disorder",
			"content": "Heart arrhythmia, cardiac ectopy, dysrrhythmia"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tDizziness\n\t\t•\tFatigue\n\t\t•\tIrregular heartbeat\n\t\t•\tNervousness\n\t\t•\tPressure or heaviness\n\t\t•\tShortness of breath\n\t\t•\tFainting\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tFeeling faint\n\t\t•\tLightheadedness\n\t\t•\tPalpitations (fluttering in chest)\n\t\t•\tRapid heart rate (pulse)\n\t\t•\tSlow heart rate (pulse)\n\t\t•\tWeakness (generalized)"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Heart rhythm disorder – heart arrhythmia -- happens when the electrical impulses that control your heartbeat don't work correctly. Your heart may beat too slowly, too quickly, or have an irregular beat. Many heart rhythm problems are harmless. But some long-lasting heart rhythm disorders can cause a fluttering in the chest, shortness of breath, chest pain, or dizziness. Atrial fibrillation, when the upper chambers of the heart beat fast and out of rhythm, is a common heart rhythm disorder. It can be dangerous over time. Another type of problem, ventricular fibrillation, can cause death within minutes. It causes the lower chambers of the heart to quiver, so the heart can't pump any blood. Ventricular fibrillation is an emergency and needs to be treated with an electrical shock (defibrillator) to keep the heart working."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "You may not know you have a heart rhythm disorder unless your doctor finds a problem during an exam. And not all heart arrhythmias need treatment. It depends on the type of symptoms you have, how often they happen, and what type of heart rhythm problem you have. Most can be treated with medication, pacemakers, surgery, or other procedures."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 2.2 million Americans have atrial fibrillation, including 3% to 5% of people over 65."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for heart rhythm disorders varies depending on the type of disorder you have. Some of these treatments include:\n\t\t•\tMedications to stop the arrhythmia\n\t\t•\tA pacemaker or implanted cardiac defibrillator (ICD)\n\t\t•\tCardioversion, a shock to reset your heart\n\t\t•\tAblation therapy, which destroys tissue to stop the abnormal heartbeat\n\t\t•\tSurgery"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Having heart disease puts you at risk for heart rhythm disorders. Keeping your heart healthy may be helpful in preventing some heart rhythm disorders. Here's what you can do:\n\t\t•\tStop smoking.\n\t\t•\tEat a heart-healthy diet.\n\t\t•\tGet regular exercise.\n\t\t•\tLimit alcohol and caffeine.\n\t\t•\tControl stress.\n\t\t•\tDon't take medications that contain stimulants, such as some over-the-counter drugs for colds."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Stress, infection, fever, alcohol, caffeine, methamphetamines, cocaine, some medications"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "See your doctor if you have any symptoms of a heart rhythm disorder, including a racing heart, a slow heartbeat, shortness of breath, weakness, dizziness, chest pain, or fainting. Get medical treatment immediately if you have any sudden or severe symptoms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\t\t•\tWhat is causing my condition?\n\t\t•\tDo I need to take any medications?\n\t\t•\tWhat symptoms should I watch for?\n\t\t•\tWhen should my symptoms improve?\n\t\t•\tDo I need any other diagnostic tests?"

	"Aortic_regurgitation": [{
			"heading": "Aortic Regurgitation",
			"content": "Aortic insufficiency, aortic incompetence"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tDizziness\n\t\t•\tSwelling\n\t\t•\tIrregular heartbeat\n\t\t•\tPalpitations (fluttering in chest)\n\t\t•\tFainting\n\t\t•\tWeakness (generalized)\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tFatigue\n\t\t•\tLightheadedness\n\t\t•\tShortness of breath\n\t\t•\tVisible pulsations"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "The aortic valve normally opens and closes as the heart beats, letting blood flow from the heart into the body's main artery. With aortic regurgitation, the valve doesn't close completely, and some blood leaks back into the heart. This makes the heart work harder to get blood to all parts of the body. Eventually, this can lead to heart failure. Leaky valves develop with age. Most people over 80 have some degree of aortic regurgitation. A leaky aortic valve can also be caused by infection, calcium deposits on the valve, or a bicuspid valve. Symptoms of aortic regurgitation typically develop over time. In rare cases, they can come on suddenly and without warning. This could be the result of an infection, dissection of the thoracic aorta, or a trauma to the valve or artery. When it happens, it can be life-threatening."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Aortic regurgitation can be present for years with little or no symptoms other than a heart murmur that can be heard with a stethoscope. At a certain point, the heart muscle cannot keep up and symptoms of heart failure develop. These include shortness of breath, a headache from high blood pressure, a whooshing sound in the chest, swelling in the feet, and an increased risk for fainting. With mild regurgitation, you'll need to see your doctor regularly so the condition can be monitored. Eventually, you may take medications to control the symptoms. At some point as the condition worsens, you may need surgery to repair or replace the valve. For many people, symptoms dramatically improve once the valve is replaced."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Millions of people in the country have some degree of aortic regurgitation."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "If the aortic regurgitation is mild, the doctor may recommend healthy lifestyle changes and monitor your heart.\n\nAs symptoms develop, the doctor may prescribe medications to control symptoms such as swelling and high blood pressure.\n\nOver time, you may need surgery to repair or replace the leaky heart valve.\n\t\t•\tIf your symptoms are severe, especially if they came on suddenly, you may need surgery to replace the valve right away."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "It's important that you work closely with your doctor and maintain a healthy lifestyle. Eat a healthy diet, stay physically active, and don't smoke."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Certain medications, excess weight, magnesium deficiency, water overload (drinking too much water and eating too much salt), high blood pressure"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "If you notice a weak irregular pulse and have been feeling tired and weak, or if you notice other symptoms of heart failure, see your doctor for an evaluation. Symptoms of heart failure include: fainting, dizziness, fatigue, weakness, shortness of breath, foot and ankle swelling and increased cough. The sudden occurrence of severe symptoms of heart failure can be life-threatening. If that happens, you need to contact your doctor right away or call the emergency services."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\t\t•\tDo I have heart failure?\n\t\t•\tI understand that some tests, such as an echocardiogram, are needed to see how the heart is performing. What tests will I need?\n\t\t•\tWhat are my treatment and medication options?\n\t\t•\tIs there something I can do to keep this from progressing?"
		},
		{

			"content": "The doctor will take a medical history, ask about your symptoms, and do a physical exam. Aortic regurgitation can often be diagnosed on the basis of the physical, but the doctor may ask for other tests such as X-rays and an echocardiogram to see an image of the heart."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Having a bicuspid aortic valve, advanced age, abnormal heart rhythms, bacterial endocarditis"
		}

	"Aortic_stenosis": [{
			"heading": "Aortic Stenosis",
			"content": "Aortic valve stenosis"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tDizziness\n\t\t•\tIrregular heartbeat\n\t\t•\tShortness of breath\n\t\t•\tLoss of consciousness\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tRapid heart rate (pulse)\n\t\t•\tFainting\n\t\t•\tJoint pain"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Aortic stenosis is a narrowing of the aortic valve in the heart that stops it from fully opening. This means less blood flows into the main artery, or aorta, and through the rest of your body. Your heart needs to work harder to pump blood, which wears it down. Rheumatic fever, calcium buildups that come with age, and heart defects cause it. Unless you were born with a valve defect, you're most likely to have it when you're over 65 years old. You may feel shortness of breath, dizziness, or chest pain. It can lead to heart failure, and most people eventually need surgery to repair or replace the valve."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "You can have mild aortic stenosis for years without feeling any symptoms. Aortic stenosis may never become severe. But if you have it, your doctor will want to monitor your heart valve closely and may prescribe cholesterol, blood pressure, or other medication. You'll also be at risk for bacterial endocarditis, a heart infection. If aortic stenosis worsens, you may feel shortness of breath or just\"out of shape\" when you're active physically. You may need to avoid strenuous activity. Eventually, you may feel chest pain, lightheadedness, fainting, and abnormal heart rhythms. You will probably need open heart surgery to replace the valve if the condition becomes severe."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Aortic stenosis affects five in 10,000 people."
		},

	"Cryptococcosis": [{
			"heading": "Cryptococcus",
			"content": "Cryptococcosis, Cryptococcus infection"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tDizziness\n\t\t•\tBlurred vision\n\t\t•\tFever\n\t\t•\tStiff neck\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tCough\n\t\t•\tHeadache"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Cryptococcus is a fungus found in soil or bird droppings. When inhaled, it can infect the lungs, causing a disease called cryptococcosis. Most healthy people can fight off the infection; many never even have symptoms. However, cryptococcosis can be dangerous for those with weak immune systems. People with HIV and Hodgkin's disease -- and people getting chemotherapy or immunosuppressant drugs-- have a greater risk. In them, cryptococcosis is more likely to spread, causing life-threatening lung infections and meningitis. Prompt treatment with antifungal drugs is crucial."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Cryptococcus neoformans is the most common cause of this disease. Rarely, another type of fungus --Cryptococcus gattii -- can trigger it, too. Symptoms may start with a cough or fever. If it spreads to the brain, cryptococcosis can cause meningitis, which can be fatal if not treated in time. Antifungal medications can help treat and cure the infection. Anyone with cryptococcosis will need regular checkups for a year or so to make sure the condition hasn't spread. Healthy people may have no symptoms and need no treatment."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Cryptococcus neoformans infects about 1 million people in the country each year."
		},
		{

		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Doctors prescribe antifungal medications to treat cryptococcosis."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Not getting prompt treatment"
		},
		{

This causes sugars to build up in the blood, which can lead to serious complications, including damage to the heart, nerves, eyes, feet, and kidneys. Doctors aren't exactly sure what causes diabetes type 1, but they think it might have to do with a virus. People can get type diabetes 1 at any age, but it is most commonly diagnosed in children and young adults. Having diabetes type 1 can make you feel hungry, tired, or thirsty. You may also urinate more than normal, have blurry vision, or lose weight without trying."
		},

			"heading": "What to Expect",

Sometimes the symptoms can happen quickly and make you feel very sick. If you have diabetes type 1, you will need to take insulin every day. You will also need to learn to control your blood sugar levels. Your doctor will show you how to test your blood sugar on your own. Over time, diabetes can cause serious problems with the heart, eyes, feet, kidneys, nerves, and blood vessels. There is no cure for diabetes type 1, but you can help prevent complications by keeping your blood sugar under tight control."

			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Heat exhaustion develops when your body can't keep itself cool. You may get it after a tough workout in the sun. Or you may develop it gradually over days if it's hot and you're not drinking enough fluids. Young children, older adults, and people with health conditions such as high blood pressure or heart disease have a higher risk. Cooling down is the treatment. Act quickly. If you don't treat heat exhaustion, you could develop heatstroke, which is more severe and sometimes deadly."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "In many cases, you can treat heat exhaustion on your own by cooling off in an air-conditioned room or cold shower. If symptoms don't get better within half an hour, call your doctor. 	"High_blood_pressure_(hypertension)": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tDizziness\n\t\t•\tLightheadedness\n\t\t•\tFlushed skin\n\t\t•\tHeadache\n\t\t•\tChange in vision\n\t\t•\tHigh blood pressure"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "High blood pressure is a condition in which blood pressure stays above a healthy range and puts too much force against artery walls. Blood pressure is measured by two numbers, for example, 140/90. The top number is called systolic pressure and measures the pressure when the heart beats. The bottom number is called diastolic pressure and measures the pressure as the heart rests between beats. A person has high blood pressure if the top number is 140 or higher or if the bottom number is 90 or higher. In most cases, there's no one cause of primary high blood pressure. High blood pressure often happens with age. Other risk factors are being overweight, having a family history, heavy drinking, lack of exercise, poor diet, and other factors. Primary hypertension often develops over years. Secondary hypertension is caused by an underlying condition such as kidney problems, some medications, and tumors on the adrenal glands. Left untreated, high blood pressure can damage the heart, arteries, and kidneys and greatly increase the risk for stroke and heart attack. Eating a healthy, low-salt diet, getting regular exercise, quitting smoking, staying at a healthy weight, and taking medication can lower blood pressure to a healthy range."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Because high blood pressure has no symptoms, it's important to have your blood pressure checked regularly, especially as you get older. If you are diagnosed with high blood pressure, you can keep it under control and lower your risk for serious health problems by making healthy lifestyle changes and taking blood pressure medications as directed."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "A third of adults in the country have high blood pressure."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "You may be able to lower blood pressure by making lifestyle changes. If those aren't enough, your doctor will prescribe medication. The type of medication depends on your condition and stage of high blood pressure, and can include:\n\t\t•\tThiazide diuretics, or water pills, to help your body get rid of excess water\n\t\t•\tAngiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors, which help relax blood vessels\n\t\t•\tAngiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs), which help relax blood vessels\n\t\t•\tBeta-blockers, which slow your heartbeat\n\t\t•\tCalcium-channel blockers, which relax the muscles of blood vessels\n\t\t•\tIf you're still having trouble getting your blood pressure under control, your doctor may prescribe other medications."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "You can help lower by blood pressure by:\n\t\t•\tEating a healthy, low-fat, high-fiber diet, such as the DASH diet\n\t\t•\tLimiting sodium (salt) to less than 1,500 milligrams a day, or less than 3/4 of a teaspoon\n\t\t•\tExercising at least 30 minutes a day, 5 days a week\n\t\t•\tStaying at a healthy weight\n\t\t•\tManaging stress\n\t\t•\tLimiting alcohol to no more than 2 drinks a day for men and 1 drink a day for women\n\t\t•\tQuitting smoking"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Heavy alcohol intake, smoking, poor diet, lack of exercise, stress, certain medications, high blood sugar and cholesterol"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "If you monitor your blood pressure at home and it stays high, call your doctor. Also, call your doctor if you notice medication side effects. Do not stop taking your medication without talking with your doctor.\n\nGet immediate medical attention if you have signs of heart attack or stroke, including:\n\t\t•\tPain, fullness, or squeezing in your chest\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort in the jaw, neck, back, stomach, or one or both arms\n\t\t•\tShortness of breath\n\t\t•\tLightheadedness\n\t\t•\tCold sweats\n\t\t•\tNausea\n\t\t•\tSudden confusion\n\t\t•\tDifficulty speaking\n\t\t•\tSudden numbness or weakness in the face, arm, or leg, especially on one side of the body\n\t\t•\tDifficulty seeing\n\t\t•\tSudden dizziness, loss of balance, or trouble walking\n\t\t•\tSudden, severe headache"
		},

	"Meniere's_disease": [{
			"heading": "Meniere's Disease",
			"content": "Inner ear vertigo, endolymphatic hydrops"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tDizziness\n\t\t•\tHearing loss\n\t\t•\tNausea or vomiting\n\t\t•\tSpinning sensation\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tLoss of balance\n\t\t•\tRinging in ears\n\t\t•\tEar ache"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Meniere's disease is a chronic inner ear condition that causes vertigo or extreme dizziness, loss of balance, ringing in the ears, and hearing loss. Attacks occur due to changes in the fluid in the inner ear, which affects balance. Meniere's usually occurs only in one ear, although 10%-20% of people have it in both ears. No one knows what causes the condition, although it tends to run in families. Eating a low-sodium diet and taking medication can help people cope with Meniere's disease."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "A Meniere's attack may start with a roaring or ringing sound called tinnitus and a feeling of fullness in the ear. Vertigo comes on suddenly, making it hard to walk or stand upright. Nausea and vomiting may occur with vertigo. Attacks can last from a few minutes to a few hours. Once vertigo has passed, most people feel fatigued and need to sleep. Most people have no symptoms between attacks, although some have lingering dizziness. Some people go long periods between attacks and others have several over a few days. A Meniere's attack can come on so suddenly that the person falls to the ground. These are called drop attacks. Over time, tinnitus occurs constantly and hearing loss becomes permanent. A low-sodium diet and diuretics can help prevent attacks."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 615,000 people in the country have Meniere's disease."
		},
		{

		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Self-care for a Meniere's attack involves waiting it out at home and taking anti-motion drugs. Sitting still and looking at one place can help control vertigo."
		},

	"Pulmonary_hypertension": [{
			"heading": "Pulmonary Hypertension",
			"content": "Pulmonary valve stenosis"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tDizziness\n\t\t•\tSwelling\n\t\t•\tFatigue\n\t\t•\tShortness of breath\n\t\t•\tWeakness (generalized)\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tBlue colored skin\n\t\t•\tIrregular heartbeat\n\t\t•\tFainting"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Pulmonary hypertension is high blood pressure in the blood vessels of the lungs. This makes the right side of your heart work harder to pump blood. It is a serious condition that can eventually lead to heart failure. Lung disease, heart disease, congenital heart defects, autoimmune disorders, HIV, and other conditions can all cause pulmonary hypertension. But sometimes it has no cause. People with pulmonary hypertension can have shortness of breath, a fast heart rate, or lightheadedness when doing activity. It can also cause swelling in the legs and ankles, chest pain, fatigue, bluish lips or skin, dizziness, and weakness."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "The symptoms of pulmonary hypertension usually start gradually and get worse over time. It can take several years for the symptoms to develop. The first symptoms you may notice are shortness of breath and feeling lightheaded when you're active. You may have days when you feel better and days when you feel worse. Over time, pulmonary hypertension can cause heart failure on the right side of the heart. Sometimes it can cause death. There is no cure for pulmonary hypertension, but treatments can help ease symptoms. You may need to try several different kinds of treatment to find one that works for you. If you have another condition that is causing the pulmonary hypertension, your doctor will usually treat that condition, too."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 10% to 30% of people with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease [COPD] have pulmonary hypertension. It is also more common in people who have heart failure or sleep apnea."

		},

		},

	"Supraventricular_tachycardia": [{
			"heading": "Supraventricular Tachycardia",
			"content": "SVT, atrial tachycardia, paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia, psvt"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tDizziness\n\t\t•\tFatigue\n\t\t•\tLightheadedness\n\t\t•\tRapid heart rate (pulse)\n\t\t•\tExcessive sweating\n\t\t•\tFainting\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tFrequent urination\n\t\t•\tPalpitations (fluttering in chest)\n\t\t•\tShortness of breath\n\t\t•\tThroat tightness\n\t\t•\tPounding heart (pulse)"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Supraventricular tachycardia, or SVT, is a type of fast heart rhythm that starts in one of the upper chambers of the heart. Another name for SVT is\"paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia.\" Paroxysmal means from time to time, meaning the faster heartbeat usually comes on suddenly and then goes away after a few minutes to a few hours. SVT can cause a variety of symptoms, including anxiety, palpitations, weakness, and dizziness. It may be caused by certain medications or Wolfe-Parkinson-White syndrome, an inherited condition. Smoking, alcohol use, drug use, or stress also can trigger it. Sometimes, it happens with no known cause. SVT is usually not dangerous. Very frequent episodes, though, may weaken the heart muscle and damage it over time."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "SVT comes on suddenly and may last from a few minutes to a few hours. Medication corrects it, although in most cases, SVT resolves on its own. In chronic cases, it may last until it is corrected by cardioversion, which shocks the heart back into a normal rhythm. You may also use a series of simple actions called vagal maneuvers to get the heart to return to its normal rhythm."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "SVT occurs in about 3 people out of every 1,000 in the country"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "SVT is normally treated with:\n\t\t•\tHeart rhythm medications, such as calcium-channel blockers and others\n\t\t•\tCardioversion, shocking the heart back into proper rhythm\n\t\t•\tA pacemaker, which may be used to control the heart's rhythm\n\t\t•\tSurgery"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "SVT may need no treatment and may simply stop on its own. You also can try to restore your normal heart rate by taking actions called vagal maneuvers. These involve holding your breath, immersing your face in cold water, coughing, and straining your abdominal muscles as though you were trying to have a bowel movement. Lying down to rest and taking deep breaths can also help restore a normal rhythm."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Certain medications, hyperthyroid (overactive thyroid), too much caffeine or alcohol, magnesium deficiency"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "Call the doctor if:\n\t\t•\tYou've never had an irregular heartbeat before and it lasts longer than a few seconds to a few minutes\n\t\t•\tYou recognize an irregular heartbeat, but it does not respond to self-care.\n\nGet emergency help if you have rapid heartbeat and:\n\t\t•\tFeel dizzy or faint\n\t\t•\tHave chest pain\n\t\t•\tAre short of breath\n\t\t•\tDo not try to drive yourself to the emergency room. Call the emergency services or have someone else drive you."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\t\t•\tWill this keep happening or was it just a one-time event?\n\t\t•\tWhat tests will I need?\n\t\t•\tWhat are my treatment and medication options?\n\t\t•\tAre there medications I can take to prevent this?\n\t\t•\tWhat can I do on my own to get the heart rhythm back to normal when I have an episode?"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "To diagnose SVT, the doctor will ask you about your symptoms, medical and surgical history, and lifestyle. The doctor may do a physical, focusing on your heart and other organs that may cause the symptoms, and order an ECG, echocardiogram (an ultrasound examination of your heart), or a stress test. Since SVT episodes come and go, the doctor may ask you to wear a heart monitor that will record your heart activity over a period of one to two days."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Digitalis use, history of Grave's disease or thyroiditis, advanced age, alcohol use, caffeine, smoking, inherited heart arrhythmias (irregular heartbeats that run in families)"
		}

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "The small bowel is the portion of intestines that links the stomach to the colon, or large intestine. Cancer of the small intestine is quite rare. Still, there are 5 different types of cancer that can grow in the wall of the small bowel. Early symptoms of small bowel cancer are typically vague and nonspecific. And because the cancer is deep within the abdominal cavity, it can be hard to detect. So the cancer often is not found until it's fairly advanced. As a result, it can be a very dangerous and hard to treat condition. In later stages, small intestine cancer can cause loss of appetite, watery diarrhea or constipation, internal bleeding, intestinal blockage, and weight loss. Keep in mind that other, less serious conditions can cause symptoms similar to small bowel cancer."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "The earlier cancer is found the better your odds of beating it. If the doctor suspects cancer, you'll need to have a number of tests, including X-rays, CT scans, endoscopies, and a biopsy to either confirm it or rule it out. If you do have cancer, the doctor will ask for it to be staged to see how far along it is. Your treatment will then depend on what stage your cancer is. You may need surgery to remove part of the bowel. You may also need radiation therapy and chemotherapy. The doctor may talk to you about taking part in a clinical trial that's studying newer types of treatment. While you are receiving treatment and after treatment is over, you'll need many of the same tests you had when the cancer was first diagnosed. That's to see how well the treatment is working and to watch to see if the cancer comes back."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Small intestine cancer is very rare. There are an estimated 7,000 new cases diagnosed in the country each year."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Smoking, overuse of alcohol, exposure to radiation, poor diet, celiac disease, Crohn's disease, being male, certain genetic traits, having had colon cancer"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for small bowel cancer commonly includes:\n\t\t•\tSurgical removal of the tumor\n\t\t•\tRadiation therapy to kill cancer cells or shrink the tumor\n\t\t•\tChemotherapy to kill cancer cells at the site of the tumor and elsewhere in the body\n\nYou might also take part in a clinical trial that is looking at newer treatments such as new anticancer drugs or biologic therapy that uses your own immune system to fight the cancer."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",

		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "An allergic reaction occurs when your immune system overreacts to an allergen, or normally harmless substance. Animal dander, pollen, dust, medications, insect bites, and foods such as peanuts and shellfish are common allergens. Most allergic reactions are mild, but others can be severe and life threatening. Severe reactions are called anaphylaxis. Anaphylaxis is a medical emergency because a person can die without fast treatment. Emergency care includes an injection with epinephrine, an adrenalin medication."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Anaphylaxis is a whole-body reaction. Symptoms include flushed or pale skin, rash, lip or joint swelling, sweating, panting, rapid pulse, faintness, wheezing, itchy mouth or throat, hoarseness, nausea, abdominal cramps, convulsions, confusion, and loss of consciousness. Symptoms of a mild allergic reaction include sneezing, stuffy, runny, or itchy nose, hives or itchy, red skin, and sinus swelling."

			"content": "About 150,000 cases of anaphylaxis occur in the country each year."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "If you have a mild allergic reaction, you can usually treat it by avoiding the trigger, taking oral antihistamines, icing the area, and using an anti-inflammatory steroid cream if you have a rash.\n\nIf you have anaphylaxis, these self-care strategies may help prevent future attacks:\n\t\t•\tAvoid the trigger.\n\t\t•\tKnow what to do if you are exposed to the trigger.\n\t\t•\tCarry epinephrine with you always if your doctor prescribes it.\n\t\t•\tTeach your family and friends how to deal with a reaction.\n\t\t•\tWear a medical bracelet."

	"Abscess": [{
			"heading": "Abscess",
			"content": "Skin abscess, boils, carbuncles, furuncles"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tDrainage or pus\n\t\t•\tChills\n\t\t•\tFever\n\t\t•\tSkin open sore\n\t\t•\tWarm to touch\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tEnlarged or swollen glands\n\t\t•\tLump or bulge\n\t\t•\tSkin redness\n\t\t•\tTenderness to touch"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "A skin abscess is an inflamed pocket of pus that develops below the skin surface. It causes swelling, pain, and tenderness on the skin. Also called boils, skin abscesses often show up in places where you sweat or there is friction, such as the armpits, groin, buttocks, face, or neck. Staphylococcus aureus and streptococci infections are the main cause. These bacteria can enter the skin through splinters, scrapes, and inflamed hair follicles. Some skin abscesses rupture and drain on their own and some need to be treated by a doctor. Bacteria from skin abscesses are dangerous if they spread to the bloodstream, lymph nodes, or deeper tissue."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "If a skin abscess is small (less than one-half inch), it may clear up if you apply warm compresses. If it\"comes to a head,\" however, you should see a doctor. Don't attempt to drain it by squeezing or lancing it on your own because it can cause infection to spread to tissue or the blood. Your doctor may make an incision, drain the pus, and wash out the pocket with a sterile salt solution. This relieves much of the pain right away, and the area usually heals within two weeks. Antibiotics generally aren't necessary if the abscess is completely drained, but you may need one if the infection has spread, you have a weakened immune system, the abscess is on the face, or you have recurring skin abscesses."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Abscesses are a very common reason why people see a doctor."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment may include:\n\t\t•\tWarm compresses or soaks\n\t\t•\tIncision and drainage by a doctor\n\t\t•\tAntibiotics"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "To help clear up a small skin abscess and prevent infection from any abscess:\n\t\t•\tApply warm compresses for about 30 minutes, four times a day.\n\t\t•\tAlways wash your hands before and after touching a skin abscess.\n\t\t•\tNever squeeze or stick a boil to drain it.\n\t\t•\tIf a boil ruptures on its own, apply an antibiotic ointment and keep the area around it clean.\n\t\t•\tKeep the abscess covered with a clean bandage.\n\t\t•\tGently wash the abscess twice a day with antibiotic soap.\n\t\t•\tWash clothing, sheets, towels and other materials that come into contact with the abscess in hot soapy water."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "ot treating an abscess, squeezing or lancing it at home, and not draining it properly."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "See a doctor if a skin abscess is larger than 1/2 inch across, doesn't heal, grows bigger, is in the rectal or groin area, or if there is a foreign material in a wound or under the skin. Also see a doctor if you have a fever of 100.4 degrees Fahrenheit or higher. People with chronic illness such as AIDS, diabetes, cancer, sickle cell disease, or peripheral vascular disease should see a doctor for any skin abscess.\n\nGo to a hospital emergency room if you have an abscess on your face that is wider than one-half inch, you see red streaks spreading from the abscess, you have a fever of 102 degrees Fahrenheit, or are vomiting. These symptoms are especially critical if you have a chronic disease or are on medication that compromises your immune system. If you have had a skin abscess removed, contact your doctor immediately if you have a fever or increased redness or pain in the area."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\t\t•\tWhy have I gotten an abscess?\n\t\t•\tWhat can I do to prevent a recurrence?\n\t\t•\tDo I need a procedure to drain the abscess?\n\t\t•\tHow long will I be on antibiotics?"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "The doctor will take a medical history and examine the abscess and tissue around it. The doctor also may feel for swollen lymph nodes or do a wound culture, blood tests, or imaging studies."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "A wound, injury, surgery, diabetes, chronic skin condition (such as acne or eczema), weakened immune system (from medication or a chronic disease), close contact with someone with a skin abscess, or carrying staphylococcus (especially in nasal passages) puts you at increased risk for skin abscesses."

	"Atrial_flutter": [{
			"heading": "Atrial Flutter",
			"content": "Arrhythmia, dysrhythmia, abnormal heartbeat"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tFainting\n\t\t•\tFeeling faint\n\t\t•\tPalpitations (fluttering in chest)\n\t\t•\tShortness of breath\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tLightheadedness\n\t\t•\tRapid heart rate (pulse)"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Atrial flutter is an abnormality of the heart's rhythm that causes rapid and sometimes irregular heartbeats. Blood doesn't pump efficiently when the heart is beating too fast, so vital organs, including the brain and the heart, may not get enough oxygen from blood. Atrial flutter may come and go. Most last for days to weeks. Untreated, atrial flutter can be dangerous. A variety of treatments can effectively control this condition."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "Seek immediate medical help if you are being treated for atrial flutter and experience chest pain, light-headedness, or severe shortness of breath. In emergency situations, doctors decrease the heart rate rapidly with IV medications and sometimes by using electrical currents to shock the heart back into a normal rhythm, a technique called defibrillation."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Some heart flutters go away on their own. In other cases, medications are used to ease the symptoms of atrial flutter. Sometimes, a procedure called radiofrequency catheter ablation must be performed. Atrial flutter can be well controlled in most people."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Excessive alcohol consumption, use of stimulants such as cocaine, amphetamines, cold medicine, caffeine"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Atrial flutter may go away on its own. Depending on your condition, your doctor may prescribe a variety of medications. Some reduce heart rate and maintain a normal heart rhythm. Others thin the blood and prevent clots. Some people need a procedure called radiofrequency catheter ablation, which destroys some abnormal tissue linked to abnormal heart rhythms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Taking good care of your heart by eating a healthy diet, exercising, and reducing stress will help prevent or control atrial flutter."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\t\t•\tHow serious is my atrial flutter?\n\t\t•\tWill it go away on its own?\n\t\t•\tAre my symptoms being caused by an underlying condition that needs to be treated?\n\t\t•\tCan medications control my symptoms?\n\t\t•\tWhat if medications aren't enough to treat my symptoms?\n\t\t•\tWhat can I do to keep this from happening?"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "Your doctor will listen to your heart and check your pulse rate. An electrocardiogram may be performed to record the electrical signals in your heart. Another test, called an echocardiogram, is sometimes done to create a picture of the inside of your heart while it's beating."

		{
			"heading": "How Common",

			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Heart disease, lung disease, high blood pressure, overactive thyroid, coronary artery disease, abnormal heart valves, use of stimulants such as alcohol or diet pills, stress and anxiety"

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Low blood pressure, or hypotension, can make you feel lightheaded and dizzy. Blood pressure is the force of your blood as it pushes against the walls of your arteries. If it's too low, your body may not get enough blood. Many people have occasional moments of low blood pressure after standing up suddenly or a tough workout. Dehydration, drug side effects, heart problems and other medical conditions can cause it. Low blood pressure can be dangerous if it makes you so dizzy that you fall, especially if you're older. If you need them, treatments will help."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "When you start feeling dizzy, sit or lie down and put your feet above your heart. Usually, the symptoms will pass in a few seconds or minutes. If they last longer, get emergency help. Your doctor will need to figure out what's causing your low blood pressure. Lots of different medications and health conditions can trigger low blood pressure. Treatment usually works well, although the best approach depends on the cause. Severe, untreated low blood pressure can damage the organs or cause shock."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Millions of people in the country have low blood pressure."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment depends on the cause of your low blood pressure. 		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "If you feel faint or lightheaded, sit or lie down. Raise your feet over your heart. Ask someone to get you a drink, such as a sports drink with minerals. After you feel better, see the doctor. If you suspect a prescription drug is causing your symptoms, don't stop taking it unless your doctor agrees. Avoid triggers, such as alcohol, dehydration, standing for a long time, or getting up suddenly."
		},
		{

	"Ectopic_pregnancy": [{
			"heading": "Ectopic Pregnancy",
			"content": "Tubal pregnancy"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tFainting\n\t\t•\tFatigue\n\t\t•\tNausea or vomiting\n\t\t•\tJoint pain\n\t\t•\tMissed or late menstrual period\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tLightheadedness\n\t\t•\tTenderness to touch\n\t\t•\tPain with sexual intercourse (female)\n\t\t•\tVaginal bleeding"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "An ectopic pregnancy happens when a fertilized egg implants somewhere outside of the uterus, usually in a fallopian tube. It can be life-threatening and requires immediate attention. The fallopian tube may rupture, which can cause major internal bleeding. If this happens, the pain may be so severe that you can't stand up or you faint. The fetus can't survive in an ectopic pregnancy. Medication or surgery are used to remove pregnancy tissue or, in some cases, the ovary or fallopian tube."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "A ruptured ectopic pregnancy is a medical emergency. Call the emergency services if you have severe pelvic pain, feel faint, lightheaded, or dizzy, or have a rapid heartbeat."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "An ectopic pregnancy usually occurs when an infection, inflammation, scar tissue, or an abnormality of the fallopian tube slows down or blocks a fertilized egg from traveling to the uterus. It's most often discovered by the eighth week of pregnancy. You may have no symptoms, regular pregnancy symptoms, or sharp, stabbing pain in the pelvis or abdomen, vaginal bleeding, or dizziness or weakness. If the ectopic pregnancy is very small, medication can stop the tissue from growing so your body can expel it. If it is large or outside of the fallopian tube, you have severe abdominal bleeding, or there is ovary or fallopian tube damage, you'll need surgery. Most women who have ectopic pregnancies go on to have normal pregnancies and births."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Rupturing of the fallopian tube makes an ectopic pregnancy a medical emergency."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Ectopic pregnancy treatment may include:\n\t\t•\tMethotrexate injection to stop pregnancy cells from growing\n\t\t•\tLaparoscopic surgery to remove tissue\n\t\t•\tEmergency surgery to stop bleeding if a fallopian tube is ruptured\n\t\t•\tSurgery to repair or remove a damaged fallopian tube or ovary"

	"Pulmonary_embolism": [{
			"heading": "Pulmonary Embolism",
			"content": "Blood clot in the lungs"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tFainting\n\t\t•\tSwelling\n\t\t•\tFeeling of not being able to get enough air\n\t\t•\tExcessive sweating\n\t\t•\tLabored breathing\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tCough\n\t\t•\tShortness of breath\n\t\t•\tTenderness to touch\n\t\t•\tSense of impending doom"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "A pulmonary embolism is a blood clot that forms in a vein, usually in the calf, travels to the lung, and lodges there. You may have shortness of breath, even while resting, or feel as if you're having a heart attack. It is an emergency, because one large pulmonary embolism or several small ones can be fatal. Blood-thinning medication is the standard treatment. Most people who are treated for pulmonary embolism survive. Those who are older, have an underlying illness, or do not get diagnosed promptly are at greater risk of dying."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "If you have unexplained shortness or breath, chest pain, or are coughing up blood, or if you have leg symptoms such as swelling or pain, get to a hospital emergency room."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Pulmonary embolism usually starts in veins in the deep muscles of the leg or pelvis, a condition known as deep vein thrombosis. Your only symptoms of deep vein thrombosis may be pain, swelling, or tenderness in the leg. When the clot reaches the lung, it can cause sudden shortness of breath, chest pain, or coughing. Your doctor or a vascular surgeon may give you medications to dissolve the clot, or insert a catheter to extract the clot. In life-threatening situations, they may try to remove the clot in surgery. After treatment, you'll probably need to take an anticoagulant drug such as warfarin for six months or more. If drug therapy isn't possible or your doctor doesn't think it will be enough to prevent future embolisms, you may need a metal filter in your main vein, the vena cava, to trap clots before they reach the lungs."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Chest pain may get worse with movement or deep breaths."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for pulmonary embolism may include:\n\t\t•\tAnticoagulant medication or thrombolytic medication to dissolve the clot\n\t\t•\tProcedures using a catheter to extract the clot\n\t\t•\tSurgery to remove the clot\n\t\t•\tVena cava filter, a metal filter in your main vein to trap future clots before they reach the lungs"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "These self-care strategies may help prevent pulmonary embolisms from recurring:\n\t\t•\tWear compression stockings to prevent deep vein thrombosis.\n\t\t•\tStay hydrated and walk or flex your legs every hour during a long trip.\n\t\t•\tGet out of bed and walk around as soon as you can after surgery or illness."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\t\t•\tHow soon do you think it will take my lungs to heal completely?\n\t\t•\tShould I be taking anticoagulants long term?\n\t\t•\tWhat should I do to prevent future blood clots in my legs and lungs?\n\t\t•\tPrior to and after surgery, what can I do to prevent or lessen my risk of pulmonary embolism?"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "Your doctor will take a medical history, do a physical exam, and may do an ultrasound, CT or lung scan, blood tests, electrocardiogram, pulmonary angiography (X-ray of blood in vessels in the lungs), venography (X-rays of leg veins), or a chest X-ray or MRI."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 350,000 to 600,000 patients develop deep vein thrombosis each year, resulting in at least 100,000 deaths per year from pulmonary embolism."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "You are at increased risk for pulmonary embolism or deep vein thrombosis if you have a family history of pulmonary embolism or blood-clotting disorders; have had a pulmonary embolism before; have been bedridden or have had recent surgery or a broken bone; have been sitting or standing for long periods of time (such as on an airplane flight); are pregnant; take birth control pills or hormone replacement therapy; are obese or smoke; or have had cancer, a heart attack, or stroke."

Doctors aren't sure what causes some babies to have this condition. If the hole is small, it may not cause any symptoms. But if the hole is large, it can cause shortness of breath, paleness, a bluish color to the skin, failure to gain weight, fast breathing, or a fast heartbeat."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Rabies is a deadly viral infection spread through the bite of an infected animal. The virus infects the brain and nervous system, causing anxiety, excitability, fever, loss of muscle control, muscle spasms, drooling, and convulsions. Once symptoms occur, the virus can't be cured, and the infected person usually dies in about 7 days. Prompt treatment with a rabies vaccine can prevent symptoms and treat the infection. Foxes, skunks, raccoons, bats, and coyotes commonly spread rabies. Domestic animals rarely spread the illness, because most pets get rabies vaccinations. Infected animals often drool, bite, and act either very aggressively or unusually friendly. If you think you have been bitten by an animal infected with rabies, get immediate medical help."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "Call your doctor right away if you have been bitten by a wild animal or unfamiliar domesticated animal. If your doctor is unavailable, seek emergency care."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "If you have been bitten by a wild animal or an unfamiliar domestic animal, seek immediate medical care. The doctor will ask you some questions to help determine whether the animal is rabid. If caught, wild animals will be killed and tested for rabies. Domestic animals will be isolated and observed for 10 days to see if they develop symptoms. If the rabies test is positive or the animal develops signs of rabies, you will be treated with a rabies vaccine. If not treated, rabies symptoms will occur about 3 to 7 weeks after infection. Early signs include flu-like symptoms such as fever, headache, and weakness. There may be a tingling or prickling sensation at the site of the bite. Soon, more serious symptoms develop, including anxiety, excitability, muscle spasms, drooling, and convulsions. Death occurs about 7 days after symptoms develop. Rabies is easily prevented by getting prompt medical treatment."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "ot getting medical help for an animal bite"

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Acute sinusitis is an inflammation of the sinuses caused by infection lasting less than 4 weeks. Sinusitis often develops when swelling, inflammation, and mucus from a cold block nasal passages. This makes it easier for bacteria to grow. Organisms can produce gas, and when your sinuses are not draining, pressure can quickly build and cause the infection to spread. Viruses are the most common cause of acute sinusitis, but bacteria, fungi, and allergies may also cause it. Sinus pain and tenderness are common, but severe pain may indicate an abscess or other complication."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Mild cases of acute sinusitis, usually viral, last just a few days, and often go away with home treatment. However, sinusitis can become a full-blown bacterial infection with fevers, chills, and severe sinus pain. Doctors often prescribe antibiotics to treat a bacterial infection. For severe cases, doctors may prescribe cortisone to help drain the sinuses. In rare cases, doctors surgically open the sinuses to get at a deep seated infection. With proper treatment, most sinus infections clear up in 1 to 2 weeks, but some require antibiotics. Many people develop chronic sinusitis."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 12% of people will develop sinusitis in a given year."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatments for acute sinusitis may include:\n\t\t•\tFlushing nasal passages with warm salt water (Neti pot) or saline nasal spray\n\t\t•\tWarm packs\n\t\t•\tAntibiotics for bacterial infections\n\t\t•\tCortisone and other nasal sprays for inflammation and allergy control\n\t\t•\tSinus drainage procedures\n\t\t•\tOral antihistamines and/or decongestants"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "At the first sign of sinus pain, you may be able to head off an infection by irrigating your sinuses at home using a nasal syringe or neti pot filled with sterile warm salt water. Avoid overusing antihistamines; they may dry your sinuses and cause irritation. You can use non-prescription decongestant sprays if your doctor says it's OK, but not for more than 1 to 3 days as they may cause rebound congestion. Natural remedies that may help some people include bromelain and steam inhalation. If you have bloody, discolored sinus drainage or severe pain, see your doctor as soon as possible."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Allergies, air pollution, wood stoves, smoking, upper respiratory infections, immune deficiencies, nasal polyps, snorting drugs up the nose."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "If you have sinus pain and tenderness for more than a few days or have bloody, thick, yellow nasal discharge, call your doctor for an appointment. If you are dizzy or lose your balance due to sinus pain and pressure and can't get in to see your regular doctor right away, you should go to urgent care or the emergency room."
		},

			"heading": "Influenza (Flu)",

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "The flu is a respiratory tract infection caused by the influenza virus. Flu symptoms include fever, sore throat, runny nose, headache, cough, muscle aches, and fatigue. The flu spreads easily from person to person. Most people recover at home with rest and over-the-counter medications, but for some people flu can be severe and even life-threatening. Young children, older adults, pregnant women, and people with health problems are at risk for complications from the flu, such as pneumonia. Prescription antiviral medication can lessen symptoms and help speed recovery. Getting a yearly flu vaccine is the best way to prevent the flu."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Symptoms are similar to the common cold, but they come on suddenly and can be severe. Most people recover fully in one to two weeks by resting at home. However, the flu can be life-threatening in elderly adults, young children, pregnant women, and people with certain chronic diseases such as asthma. Even healthy adults can have severe symptoms. Anyone concerned about their illness should call the doctor."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Smoking, having a weak immune system, being exposed to someone with the virus, having a job that involves contact with many people, such as a teacher or nurse"
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "In the country, about 5%-20% of people get the flu every year."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Prevention",
			"content": "The best way to prevent the flu is to get a yearly flu shot. The viruses that cause the flu change from year to year, so new flu vaccines are created every year. The flu spreads through direct contact with someone who is sick, or by touching objects they have touched such as telephones or computer keyboards. If you have the flu, you can spread it one day before symptoms develop and five to seven days after the illness starts. Here are other ways to help prevent the flu:\n\t\t•\tWash your hands often.\n\t\t•\tUse hand sanitizer if you will be around a person with the flu.\n\t\t•\tDon't share towels, drinking glasses, eating utensils, computer keyboards, or telephones with someone who has the flu.\n\t\t•\tCover your mouth when coughing or sneezing.\n\t\t•\tAvoid contact with people who are sick.\n\t\t•\tIf you are sick, stay home and rest so you don't infect other people at your workplace or school.\n\t\t•\tIf you get the flu, talk with your doctor about taking antiviral medication. They are most effective when taken in the first two days of symptoms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "The flu usually gets better on its own in one to two weeks with rest. Antihistamines, decongestants, pain relievers, drinking plenty of fluids, and inhaling steam may help ease symptoms. For people at risk for complications and those with severe symptoms, antiviral medications such as oseltamivir (Tamiflu) or zanamivir (Relenza) may help lessen symptoms, shorten the illness, and prevent complications if they are taken soon after symptoms appear."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Self care for the flu includes:\n\t\t•\tOver-the-counter medications to relieve fever and pain\n\t\t•\tAntihistamines and decongestants to open nasal passages\n\t\t•\tSaline nasal spray\n\t\t•\tGargling with warm salt water\n\t\t•\tDrinking warm liquids to soothe the throat\n\t\t•\tSucking on hard candies or throat lozenges\n\t\t•\tRest\n\t\t•\tNot smoking"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "Call your doctor if you are at risk for complications from the flu or if flu symptoms are severe or getting worse. 		},

			"content": "Bacterial pneumonia is a lung infection caused by bacteria. Pneumococcal bacteria are the most common cause, but pneumonia also may be caused by staph and other bacteria. These germs are spread from person to person, typically when an infected person coughs. People who have bacterial pneumonia often have a cough, fever, weakness, shortness of breath, headache, or chest pain. The symptoms of bacterial pneumonia can vary from person to person and can be mild or severe. In some cases, bacterial pneumonia can cause life-threatening complications, especially in people who are older or who have a chronic illness."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "The symptoms of bacterial pneumonia can start suddenly or begin more gradually. The symptoms can seem like those of a bad cold or the flu. Older adults and people with chronic illnesses may have milder symptoms. But people in these groups are more likely to have serious complications from pneumonia. Bacterial pneumonia is usually treated with antibiotics. Most people feel better in about two weeks. Sometimes, pneumonia can cause severe complications, including blood infection (sepsis), lung failure, and meningitis."
		},
