			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Gastroenteritis is irritation of the stomach and intestines. Viruses, bacteria, parasites, or food-borne illness can cause it. Gastroenteritis symptoms include abdominal pain and cramping, nausea, diarrhea, and vomiting. While sometimes called the\"stomach flu,\" the flu virus does not cause gastroenteritis. The illness usually spreads easily from contact with a sick person. Eating or drinking contaminated food or beverages also will spread the illness. Most people recover in a few days by drinking plenty of fluids and resting. Antibiotics treat gastroenteritis caused by bacteria or some parasites. Infants, older adults, and people with chronic illnesses are at higher risk for dehydration from gastroenteritis."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",

If nausea and vomiting make it difficult to drink fluids, call the doctor."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Most people have had sunburn – a reddened, irritated area of skin caused by overexposure to the sun's rays or other ultraviolet light. Sunburn can vary from mild to severe, depending partly on your skin type and how long you're in the sun. You can relieve mild sunburn symptoms at home with cold compresses and moisturizing lotions. A severe sunburn can cause fever, chills, and even shock. Some severe sunburns need treatment at a hospital. Chronic sunburns cause skin damage, which can lead to premature aging and severe wrinkling, and increase your risk for skin cancer. Preventing sunburn is the best protection. Children especially need protection, because most skin damage occurs in childhood."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Symptoms of sunburn can start within an hour of exposure and usually peak between 12 and 24 hours. Your skin may be red, warm, and irritated. A cool bath or compresses, moisturizers (without fragrance or anesthetics), plenty of fluids, and over-the-counter pain medication can help relieve discomfort. The sunburn should begin healing within several days. In some cases, sunburn may peel and itch after a few days. Peeled areas of skin are very sensitive to sunlight for several weeks, so you'll need to protect them carefully. Medical care may be necessary for sunburn in a baby, or if sunburn in a child or adult covers a large area or causes severe pain, blistering, or fever. You may need oral steroids, a prescription pain reliever, or an antibiotic for infection. If you have severe sunburn or complications such as dehydration or heat stress, you'll be given IV fluids and may be treated in a hospital burn unit. Complete healing from moderate sunburn usually takes several weeks."
		},

			"heading": "How Common",

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Urinary tract infections are common, especially among women. UTIs occur when bacteria in the digestive tract and around the anus get into the urethra, the tube that carries urine from the bladder. There the bacteria can cause an infection in the urethra, the bladder, or both. If not treated, UTIs can cause painful and dangerous kidney infections. UTIs usually are easy to detect, but some have no symptoms. If a UTI develops into a kidney infection, you may notice pain in your side or back, along with chills, fever, or vomiting."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "If you notice a UTI coming on and have only minor symptoms, drinking extra water with vitamin C or cranberry juice may help stop it. But most UTIs require antibiotics and then clear up quickly. If not treated, a UTI can progress to a kidney infection or cause severe bladder and urethral irritation."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "There are many millions of UTIs treated every year in the country UTIs are more common in females. UTIs in men under age 40 are rare."

			"content": "\t\t•\tAntibiotics\n\t\t•\tDrinking lots of water\n\nPhenazopyridine, a medication used to dull the pain in the urethra. Note that it colors the urine bright red/orange or brown and can stain clothing. It is available over the counter. It may help you feel better, but it can't cure the UTI."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "At the first sign of a bladder irritation, try drinking more water and/or cranberry juice. Cranberry juice helps prevent bacteria from sticking to the bladder lining. Take extra vitamin C and A. Wear loose-fitting pants. If your symptoms don't get better, see your doctor."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Aseptic meningitis, or viral meningitis, is an inflammation of the lining around the brain and spinal cord. It's usually caused by a virus. Less often, fungi, diseases spread by insects, and other conditions trigger it. Aseptic meningitis is usually not as serious as bacterial meningitis, which can be life-threatening. Symptoms include fever, headaches, neck pain and stiffness, nausea, fatigue, confusion, and sensitivity to light. Most often, aseptic meningitis goes away on its own with rest, fluids, and pain relievers. However, any signs of meningitis are always a medical emergency. The symptoms of aseptic meningitis are often the same as those of bacterial meningitis, which is life-threatening without treatment."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Symptoms start 3 to 7 days after exposure. They can come on slowly or quickly and often occur after a cold, diarrhea, or other infection. Headache, neck pain and stiffness, and sensitivity to light may develop. Most cases of aseptic meningitis go away completely in 5 to 14 days with rest, plenty of fluids, and over-the-counter pain and fever relievers."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",

	"Coxsackie_virus_infection": [{
			"heading": "Coxsackie Virus Infection",
			"content": "Hand, foot, and mouth disease"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tFever\n\t\t•\tHeadache\n\t\t•\tMouth sores\n\t\t•\tUnable to blink or close eyelid\n\t\t•\tBody aches or pains\n\t\t•\tSkin rash\n\t\t•\tGum sores"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Coxsackie virus infection is a common infection that easily spreads from person to person. Children under age 10 most often get this virus, but adults can get it, too. Half of those infected have no symptoms. Early on, the infection may feel similar to a cold, with a sore throat, runny nose, cough, headache, fever, muscle aches, nausea, and diarrhea. The virus can also cause blisters in the mouth and on the hands and feet. This is called hand, foot, and mouth disease. Eye pain and redness may also occur. Serious complications occur less often, but include infection of the heart, brain, chest muscles, or the membrane around the spine and brain. Newborns are more at risk for serious complications. Most people recover in one to five days with rest and self-care."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Symptoms start a few days after infection and include headache, fever, muscle aches, and sore throat. Other symptoms include blistering rash on the hands, feet, and mouth, and eye pain and redness. Symptoms usually go away in one to seven days. Most people are contagious during the first week of symptoms, but sometimes the virus can spread even a week after symptoms are gone."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Being under age 10, exposure to someone with the virus, having a weakened immune system"
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Every year, millions of people are infected with the coxsackie virus."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Prevention",
			"content": "Sneezing and coughing, contact with fluid from blisters, or touching objects contaminated with fecal matter can spread the virus. Here are ways to help prevent the virus from spreading:\n\t\t•\tWash your hands often if you have the virus, especially after blowing your nose, sneezing, coughing, or using the bathroom.\n\t\t•\tWash your hands carefully after changing diapers.\n\t\t•\tDon't share towels, drinking glasses, eating utensils, computer keyboards, or telephones with someone who has the virus.\n\t\t•\tCover your mouth when coughing or sneezing.\n\t\t•\tAvoid contact with people who are sick.\n\t\t•\tAnyone with the virus should stay home and rest so they don't infect other people at work or school."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "There is no medical treatment specifically for the coxsackie virus.\n\nAcetaminophen can ease fever and pain (never give aspirin to children or teens. Aspirin can cause Reye's syndrome, a rare but potentially fatal condition).\n\nRest and self-care at home will ease symptoms until the virus goes away."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Self-care for symptoms of a coxsackie virus infection includes:\n\t\t•\tRest\n\t\t•\tAcetaminophen to relieve fever and pain\n\t\t•\tDrinking plenty of fluids\n\t\t•\tGargling with warm salt water\n\t\t•\tEating or drinking warm or cold foods or beverages to soothe the throat\n\t\t•\tSucking on hard candies or throat lozenges\n\t\t•\tTrying not to scratch or break the skin if the rash is itchy\n\t\t•\t"
		},

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Bronchial adenomas are cancers that arise in glands and ducts of the windpipe or large airways of the lungs. Most of them grow and spread very slowly. Still, bronchial adenomas can pose a threat. Standard treatment is to remove them surgically. The prognosis for people with this type of cancer is excellent. Anyone with symptoms such as a persistent cough, fever, or shortness of breath needs to see a doctor. Keep in mind that more common and less worrisome conditions can cause the same symptoms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Some kinds of bronchial adenoma are benign. Those that pose a threat usually can be removed surgically. These cancers very rarely come back. As a result, nearly 96% of people with bronchial adenoma are alive five years after diagnosis. Some bronchial adenomas, called neuroendocrine tumors, can secrete hormones. Any symptoms that may result depend on what hormone is secreted."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Tumors of the trachea, or windpipe, are uncommon. They account for only 1% to 3% of all pulmonary cancers."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Bronchial adenomas typically show up in people younger than age 50. The median age at diagnosis is age 43. Smoking does not seem to be linked to bronchial adenomas."
		},

Surgery may be done:\n\t\t•\tThrough an open incision\n\t\t•\tThrough a bronchoscope, a narrow, flexible tube passed through the nose into the airways\n\t\t•\tUsing video-assisted thoracic surgery, another form of minimally invasive surgery"
		},

		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",

Doctors often follow up with a CT scan or MRI to get a more detailed look at the tumor, where it's located, and whether it may be spreading to lymph nodes. A bronchoscopy -- inserting a thin, flexible tube with a camera into the nose and down into the windpipe and lungs -- also may be done. During a bronchoscopy, your doctor may take a small sample of cells to examine under a microscope. Blood tests also may be performed."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Crohn's disease is a chronic condition in which a person's own immune system attacks healthy tissue in the digestive tract, usually in the small intestine. It causes swelling, cramping, chronic diarrhea, nutritional problems, and bleeding. Crohn's disease is serious and has no cure. Treatment with medication and surgery can help get it under control. Keep in mind that less severe conditions -- such as irritable bowel syndrome -- can cause many of the same symptoms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "While Crohn's disease usually causes damage in the small intestine, it can trigger symptoms anywhere in the digestive tract -- from the mouth to the colon. Crohn's disease often first appears in people between the ages of 15 and 30. The symptoms tend to come and go over the months and years. Although evidence is not clear, many people say that certain foods and stress can trigger disease flares. Complications, such as bowel perforations, blockages, and infections, can be serious. Ongoing drug treatment often helps control symptoms. Most people with Crohn's disease eventually need surgery to remove damaged areas of the intestines. Unfortunately, the disease may return after surgery. Since Crohn's disease increases the risk of intestinal cancer, people who have it need regular checkups."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About one out of 14,000 people in the country have Crohn's disease."

Avoid any drinks or foods that seem to trigger symptoms. People with lactose intolerance should cut out dairy products. Eat small meals. Try to reduce stress with relaxation techniques. Use breathing exercises or meditation."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",

	"Epiglottitis": [{
			"heading": "Epiglottitis",
			"content": "Enlarged epiglottis, supraglottitis"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tFever\n\t\t•\tDrooling\n\t\t•\tNoisy breathing\n\t\t•\tSore throat\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tMuffled voice\n\t\t•\tShortness of breath\n\t\t•\tDifficulty swallowing"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Epiglottitis is a rare, life-threatening illness that keeps air from getting to the lungs. The epiglottis is a small piece of cartilage at the back of the tongue. It keeps food out of your windpipe when you swallow. Infection or injury can make it swell and cause it to cover the windpipe. This keeps air from getting to the lungs and can result in death. The usual cause is infection with bacteria called Haemophilus influenza type B, or HIB. Infection with HIB is much more likely in children than adults. But since the mid-1980s, the HIB vaccine has made infections very rare. Other bacteria and viruses, though, can cause epiglottitis. So can an injury, such as being hit in the neck or swallowing a too hot liquid. If you suspect epiglottitis, it's important to get emergency treatment right away."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Epiglottitis can come on suddenly and lead to breathing problems within hours. If you suspect epiglottitis, do not try to examine your throat yourself. Doing so can cause serious problems, including sudden death. Instead, call the emergency services or go to the nearest emergency room. The first thing the medical team will do is make sure the airway is open and breathing is controlled. This may involve inserting a breathing tube through the nose or mouth. In severe cases it may be necessary to surgically open the airway. Once breathing is controlled, the doctor will examine the throat and start treatment with antibiotics. The doctor also may use steroid medication to reduce the swelling. It may take up to 24 hours before the disease stops progressing. And a full recovery can take several days."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Epiglottitis is very rare in the country, affecting 10 to 40 out of every million people."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Risk factors include:\n\t\t•\tBeing male\n\t\t•\tA weakened immune system\n\t\t•\tDelayed or missed vaccinations"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "The first goal of treatment is to open the airway and control the breathing. Once that's done, the doctor will use antibiotics given through an IV to stop the infection. The doctor also may use steroid medications to help reduce the swelling."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "The most important step in self-care is to prevent the infection. And the best way to do that is to make sure children have the recommended vaccinations. Check with the doctor about any vaccinations you or your children might need."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Trying to examine the throat at home with a tongue depressor or in some other way can make the condition suddenly worse."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "Call the emergency services or the local emergency number if you or someone in your family has symptoms of epiglottitis such as:\n\t\t•\tTrouble breathing\n\t\t•\tExcessive drooling\n\t\t•\tIrritability\n\t\t•\tTrouble speaking"
		},

	"Hepatitis_A": [{
			"heading": "Hepatitis A",
			"content": "Infectious Hepatitis, food-borne hepatitis"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tFever\n\t\t•\tFatigue\n\t\t•\tYellow skin\n\t\t•\tDark colored (brown) urine\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tNausea or vomiting\n\t\t•\tTenderness to touch\n\t\t•\tYellow eyes"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Hepatitis A is an inflammation of the liver by the hepatitis A virus. Hepatitis A is the mildest of the three most common hepatitis viruses. Symptoms include fever, fatigue, yellowing of the skin and eyes, dark urine, pale stools, liver pain, nausea, and vomiting. Many people have no symptoms. The virus is found in the stool of an infected person. It spreads through eating or drinking contaminated water or food, having close contact with someone infected with the disease, and oral-anal sex. The illness goes away on its own in about three months with rest, and nearly everyone recovers completely. Once a person recovers from hepatitis A, they can't get it again."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Hepatitis A symptoms usually appear two to six weeks after infection and are usually mild. Some people have no symptoms, but can still spread the illness. Diarrhea, vomiting, nausea, fatigue, jaundice, and other symptoms usually pass in two months, but may linger as long as six months or so. In very rare cases, hepatitis A can cause liver failure and death in people with liver disease or in older adults. Once symptoms have passed you are immune from getting hepatitis A again. However, you can still get other types of hepatitis. If you have been exposed to hepatitis A, you can stop the infection by getting a vaccine within two weeks."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Travelers to countries where hepatitis A is common, people who use illegal drugs, men who have sex with men, people who live with or have sex with an infected person, people who engage in anal-oral sex."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "early 20,000 people in the country get hepatitis A every year."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Prevention",
			"content": "Here are ways to protect yourself and help prevent the spread of hepatitis A:\n\t\t•\tWash your hands often, especially after using the bathroom, changing a diaper, or coming into contact with someone with hepatitis A.\n\t\t•\tWash your hands thoroughly before preparing food.\n\t\t•\tDon't eat raw or undercooked seafood harvested from water contaminated with raw sewage.\n\t\t•\tTake precautions when traveling to developing countries, such as only drinking bottled water and not eating uncooked food.\n\t\t•\tAvoid brushing your teeth or making ice or drinks from contaminated water.\n\t\t•\tAvoid oral-anal contact during sex.\n\t\t•\tIf you are at risk for hepatitis A, get vaccinated.\n\t\t•\tIf you have been exposed to hepatitis A, ask your doctor about getting treatment with immune globulin, which may help protect you from infection."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "There is no specific medical treatment for hepatitis A. It usually gets better on its own. Your doctor may recommend:\n\t\t•\tAnti-nausea medications and other treatments to help relieve symptoms.\n\t\t•\tAvoiding certain medications, including over-the-counter drugs, that are processed by the liver.\n\t\t•\tNot drinking alcohol.\n\t\t•\tGetting vaccinated or treated with immune globulin if you have been exposed within the past 2 weeks."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Self-care for hepatitis A includes:\n\t\t•\tGetting plenty of rest\n\t\t•\tNot smoking or drinking alcohol\n\t\t•\tAvoiding fatty foods\n\t\t•\tAvoiding acetaminophen (Tylenol) and other medications that can harm the liver"

	"Hepatitis_B": [{
			"heading": "Hepatitis B",
			"content": "Serum Hepatitis"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tFever\n\t\t•\tDecreased appetite\n\t\t•\tNausea or vomiting\n\t\t•\tTenderness to touch\n\t\t•\tYellow eyes\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tFatigue\n\t\t•\tYellow skin\n\t\t•\tDark colored (brown) urine"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Hepatitis B is an inflammation of the liver that may cause fever, fatigue, yellowing of the skin and eyes, dark urine, pale stools, liver pain, nausea, and vomiting. Many people, however, have no symptoms. The inflammation is caused by the hepatitis B virus, one of the three most common hepatitis viruses (the others are hepatitis A and C). The disease spreads through blood, vaginal fluid, semen, and other body fluids of an infected person. The virus can be passed by sharing drug needles, having sex with an infected person, and sharing personal items such as toothbrushes or razors. A mother can pass the disease to her child at birth. Most people who get the hepatitis B virus fight it off in six months with rest and close monitoring by a doctor. Some people go on to develop chronic hepatitis B, a more serious form of the disease. Treatment with antiviral medication helps prevent liver damage in people with chronic hepatitis B. The hepatitis B vaccine offers lifelong immunity against this infection."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Symptoms may begin about one to four months after infection, although some people have no symptoms at all. Diarrhea, vomiting, nausea, fatigue, jaundice, and other symptoms usually pass in a few weeks or months. Most people are able to fight off the virus completely during the acute stage. Those who fully recover cannot get it again. People who can't fight off the virus completely develop chronic hepatitis. Chronic hepatitis may have no symptoms but can slowly cause liver damage over time. Children are more likely to develop chronic hepatitis B than adults. Antiviral medication can help prevent liver damage in people with chronic hepatitis B. People with severe chronic hepatitis B may need a liver transplant."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "People who use illegal drugs, men who have sex with men, people who have multiple sex partners, anyone with a sexually transmitted disease, people with chronic liver or kidney disease, people with HIV, people who travel to countries where the disease is more common, health care workers and others exposed to blood"
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "early 40,000 people in the country get hepatitis B every year."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Prevention",
			"content": "The best way to protect yourself is to get vaccinated against hepatitis B. If you are already infected, you can help prevent the spread hepatitis B:\n\t\t•\tUse latex condoms whenever you have sex.\n\t\t•\tDon't share razors, toothbrushes, or other objects that may have blood on them.\n\t\t•\tDo not share drug needles.\n\t\t•\tWear gloves if you have to touch someone else's blood.\n\t\t•\tIf you are getting a tattoo or piercing, make sure the shop or person uses sterile equipment.\n\t\t•\tIf you are at risk for hepatitis B, get vaccinated.\n\t\t•\tDon't donate blood if you have hepatitis B."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Anti-nausea medications and other treatments help relieve symptoms in people with acute hepatitis B. Your doctor may suggest avoiding certain medications that are toxic to the liver while you are recovering. If you develop chronic hepatitis B, your doctor will monitor your liver and determine if and when you need treatment with antiviral medications."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Self-care for hepatitis B includes:\n\t\t•\tGetting plenty of rest\n\t\t•\tDrinking plenty of fluids\n\t\t•\tNot overexerting yourself\n\t\t•\tEating a healthy diet\n\t\t•\tAvoiding alcohol\n\t\t•\tAvoiding acetaminophen (Tylenol, for example) and other medications that may harm the liver"
		},

		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Kidney infection is a bacterial infection of one or both kidneys. An untreated bladder infection, usually from Escherichia coli bacteria, causes most kidney infections. Other bacteria such as Staphylococcus saprophyticus, also can pass through the bloodstream to the kidneys and cause infection. Kidney infections are common, especially in women, especially during pregnancy. You may experience back pain, chills, fever, nausea, and vomiting. Antibiotics usually clear it up if treated early. If not, it can do permanent kidney damage or cause blood poisoning, a life-threatening condition. People with diabetes or weakened immune systems are more likely to have severe kidney infections."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "If you have kidney infection symptoms along with blood in your urine, fever, and nausea, immediately see a doctor, get to a hospital emergency room, or call the emergency services."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "See your doctor right away if you have symptoms of a kidney infection. If the doctor suspects a kidney infection, you'll start antibiotics immediately. When the results of lab tests are available, you may be switched to a different dosage or antibiotic. Usually, taking antibiotics for a week or two, getting plenty of fluid, and resting can clear up a kidney infection. Your symptoms probably will get better after a few days, but it's important to finish the antibiotic to make sure the infection is cleared completely. Men may have to take medication for up to six weeks because the condition is more difficult to treat in men. If you have a severe infection, a high fever, dehydration, or significant vomiting or pain, you may need to be hospitalized for a few days and receive antibiotics and fluids intravenously. If the infection doesn't get better or if you have recurrent kidney infections, you may need further tests and surgery to determine if you have a structural abnormality, obstruction, or kidney stones."
		},
		{

		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Mononucleosis, often called the kissing disease, is a common infection usually caused by the Epstein-Barr virus. Symptoms include extreme fatigue, sore throat, fever, rash, loss of appetite, muscle aches, and swollen lymph nodes and spleen. Many people have the Epstein-Barr virus but don't have any symptoms of mono. The illness can last anywhere from 10 days to three months. The virus spreads through saliva and is commonly diagnosed in teens. There is no medical treatment for mono. The illness goes away on its own with plenty of rest."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Mononucleosis symptoms start gradually four to six weeks after a person has been exposed to the virus. Sore throat symptoms are most painful about five to seven days into the illness and gradually get better over the next week or so. Swelling in lymph nodes goes away in about three weeks. People with mono should not play contact sports for four months. Physical contact can easily injure an enlarged spleen. Tiredness can last for months after other symptoms have gone away."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Being a high school or college student and being exposed to someone with the virus"

		},
		{
			"heading": "Prevention",
			"content": "Preventing mononucleosis is difficult. Healthy people can have the virus and spread it without knowing it. People who have had the virus can spread it even after their symptoms are gone. Avoiding people who have symptoms can help but won't guarantee that you won't get mono at some point. Try these tips: Carefully wash your hands before contact with people if you are sick and after seeing people if they are sick. Don't share eating utensils or glasses. Cover your mouth when sneezing or coughing. If your partner is not sick and you are, sleep separately until symptoms are gone."

		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Mumps is a contagious viral disease that causes painful swelling of the glands that produce saliva. The virus also causes headaches, face pain, fever, muscle aches, and sore throat. Sometimes, mumps can cause swelling and pain of the testicles in adolescent and adult men. While more common in children, anyone who has not been vaccinated or who has not had mumps before can get the disease. Treatment includes pain relievers, ice packs to relieve swelling, and rest. Children and teenagers should not take aspirin, which is associated with a rare but serious illness called Reyes syndrome. Because the disease can spread quickly, the CDC recommends that anyone with mumps be isolated for 5 days after swelling begins. Most people recover fully from the mumps and are immune from it for the rest of their lives. Because of routine vaccination, mumps now rarely occurs in the country"
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Symptoms may occur anywhere from 12 to 25 days after infection. Half of those infected have mild symptoms and may not know they have the mumps. Often, fever and headache develop followed by swelling of the salivary glands that gets worse over 1 to 3 days. The CDC recommends isolation for 5 days after swelling has started to help prevent mumps from spreading. Adolescent and adult males may have swelling and pain in one or both testicles along with fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, and headache. Symptoms usually go away in 3 to 7 days. Most people recover fully from the mumps with rest. Rare complications include sterility in men, inflammation of the brain or the membrane covering the brain and spinal cord, inflammation of the breasts or ovaries in women, and deafness."

Blowing your nose and touching objects such as pens, telephones, and computer keyboards can also spread the virus. Here are ways to help prevent spreading mumps:\n\t\t•\tIf you have the mumps, avoid all contact with the public for 5 days.\n\t\t•\tWash your hands often, especially after blowing your nose, sneezing, or coughing.\n\t\t•\tDon't share towels, drinking glasses, eating utensils, computer keyboards, or telephones with someone who has the mumps.\n\t\t•\tCover your mouth when coughing or sneezing.\n\t\t•\tAvoid contact with people who have the mumps."

		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Osteomyelitis is an infection of a bone that causes pain, swelling, and redness. The infection may get to the bone through the blood, through nearby tissues, or through an injury -- such as surgery or a puncture wound. It's most common in children. While osteomyelitis is serious, treatment -- with antibiotics and sometimes surgery -- usually cures the condition. Getting medical attention quickly is key. Less serious conditions can cause many of the same symptoms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "In children, osteomyelitis is more common in the long bones, such as the ones in the legs or arms. In adults, it's more common in the hips and smaller bones in the feet or back. Acute osteomyelitis may appear suddenly, sometimes after an injury or surgery. Most people need four to six weeks of antibiotics, often intravenously. Some need surgery to remove damaged areas of bone. Treatment usually works well. Untreated acute osteomyelitis is more likely to become chronic, which is harder to cure. In some cases of chronic osteomyelitis, amputation is the best option."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",

	"Pericarditis": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tFever\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Pericarditis is sudden or chronic inflammation of the pericardium, the sac that holds the heart in place and helps it work smoothly. Inflammation can make the layers of the pericardium rub against the heart, causing chest pain. With acute pericarditis, you may feel like you're having a heart attack. Men between ages 20 and 50 are most likely to get pericarditis. Viruses and infection, especially respiratory infection, commonly cause it. Pericarditis usually clears up on its own with rest and minor treatment. In severe cases, surgery is required. Severe untreated pericarditis can lead to fatal complications."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "Call the emergency services if you have sudden chest pain. This could also be a sign of a heart attack."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Pericarditis is usually acute, or sudden. You'll likely have sharp, stabbing chest pain that may worsen when you cough, swallow, breathe deeply, or lie down. It may ease up when you sit up and lean forward. You may also have a fever. Your doctor will probably treat you in a hospital with rest, over-the-counter anti-inflammatory medications, and close monitoring for complications. Usually, the condition goes away within a few days or weeks, and you can return to normal activity.\n\nChronic constrictive pericarditis develops if the layers of the pericardium thicken and stick together, constricting the heart's normal movements. A portion of the pericardium may need to be removed surgically. Chronic pericarditis can last several months and you'll probably need to take prescription medication for years."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Coughing, swallowing, deep breathing, lying flat on your back, not getting treatment"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for pericarditis may include:\n\t\t•\tRest\n\t\t•\tOver-the-counter or prescription anti-inflammatory medication for pain and inflammation\n\t\t•\tCorticosteroid medication to reduce inflammation\n\t\t•\tAntibiotics or anti-fungal medication\n\t\t•\tNarcotic pain medication\n\t\t•\tPericardiocentesis -- insertion of a needle or catheter in the chest wall to remove excess fluid in the pericardium\n\t\t•\tPericardiectomy -- surgery to remove the pericardium\n\t\t•\tTreatment for underlying conditions such as kidney failure or cancer"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "These self-care strategies may reduce your chance of complications or a recurrence of pericarditis:\n\t\t•\tGet prompt treatment.\n\t\t•\tGet plenty of rest.\n\t\t•\tAvoid strenuous activity that is not approved by your doctor.\n\t\t•\tFollow your treatment plan.\n\t\t•\tWatch for signs of complications or recurrence, especially shortness of breath."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "See your doctor if you develop symptoms of chronic constrictive pericarditis -- such as shortness of breath, heart palpitations, or swelling in your legs, feet, or abdomen -- or if you have unexplained chest pain."

	"Phlebitis": [{
			"heading": "Phlebitis",
			"content": "Thrombophlebitis, blood clots, deep vein thrombosis, superficial phlebitis"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tFever\n\t\t•\tSwelling\n\t\t•\tBulging veins\n\t\t•\tSkin rash\n\t\t•\tSkin redness\n\t\t•\tTenderness to touch\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tBruising or discoloration\n\t\t•\tItching or burning\n\t\t•\tSkin open sore\n\t\t•\tWarm to touch"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Phlebitis means inflammation of the veins, usually caused by injury or a blood clot. Phlebitis can occur in the veins on the surface of the skin (superficial phlebitis) or deep in larger blood vessels. Deep vein thrombosis in the legs causes dangerous blood clots. When a clot breaks off and travels into the lungs, it can cause a life-threatening condition called pulmonary embolism."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Superficial phlebitis can occur at the site of an IV needle. It may not cause any symptoms, or you may notice a red area that runs along the veins near the skin. This can become hard, tender, itchy, warm, and swollen. The condition is rarely serious and usually goes away in 1 to 2 weeks with treatment.\n\nDeep vein thrombosis also may not have any symptoms at first. It usually takes a week or two for a clot to develop, although it can occur rapidly. Redness, warmth, and hard swelling develop, often in the calf, and may extend up the leg, where a clot is more dangerous. A clot will dissolve slowly. It can take 6 weeks or more to disappear. Even after the clot has gone, the vein may remain hard, sometimes permanently."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "300,000 to 600,000 people have deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism related to phlebitis each year."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Depending on whether you have superficial phlebitis or deep vein thrombosis, treatment may include:\n\t\t•\tNSAIDs and aspirin to relieve inflammation and pain\n\t\t•\tAntibiotics (if needed) for an infection\n\t\t•\tBlood thinners such as warfarin and heparin to thin the blood and help keep new clots from forming\n\t\t•\tHeat packs"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Using moist heat and elevating the limb can help reduce swelling and pain. Your doctor may also recommend that you wear support stockings."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Smoking, inactivity, obesity"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "If you have sudden pain, swelling, or redness in your calf, or it moves up your leg to the deep veins in your inner thigh, or if you have symptoms along with chest pain or shortness of breath, go to the emergency room immediately. Time is of the essence if a pulmonary embolus occurs."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",

	"Rheumatic_fever": [{
			"heading": "Rheumatic Fever",
			"content": "Rheumatic heart disease"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tFever\n\t\t•\tSwelling\n\t\t•\tJoint pain\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tSkin rash\n\t\t•\tMuscle twitching (painless)"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Rheumatic fever is an inflammatory disease that affects the heart and other organs. It can develop after an infection by streptococcal bacteria, which causes strep throat or scarlet fever, especially if that infection is not fully treated with antibiotics. Children ages 6 to 15 are most likely to get rheumatic fever, though people of all ages can get it. Rheumatic fever usually causes fever, joint pain, abdominal pain, rash, fatigue, shortness of breath, and chest pain."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Symptoms of rheumatic fever usually start about 20 days after having strep throat or scarlet fever. Symptoms can vary from person to person. The symptoms can also change during the illness. Rheumatic fever can cause inflammation in the heart, skin, joints, and brain. In some cases, the inflammation can last weeks or months. Sometimes the inflammation can cause long-term heart problems. Most cases of rheumatic fever are treated with antibiotics."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "History of strep throat or scarlet fever, family history of rheumatic fever, having a certain type of strep bacteria that is more likely to cause rheumatic fever, living in a crowded area, living in an area with poor sanitation"
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Rheumatic fever is rare in the country"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Prevention",
			"content": "You can help prevent rheumatic fever by getting prompt treatment for strep throat and scarlet fever and by taking antibiotics exactly as directed. To prevent spreading streptococcal bacteria to others:\n\t\t•\tCarefully wash your hands BEFORE contact with people if you are sick and AFTER seeing people who are sick.\n\t\t•\tIf you are ill, keep your own drinking and eating utensils separate until they are washed.\n\t\t•\tDo not share glasses or utensils.\n\t\t•\tCover your mouth when sneezing or coughing.\n\t\t•\tIf your partner is not sick and you are, you might want to sleep separately until your sore throat is gone."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Rheumatic fever usually is treated with antibiotics and over-the-counter anti-inflammatory drugs. In severe cases, rheumatic fever may require cortisone or other medications to decrease inflammation in the joints and heart. If you've developed rheumatic heart disease, surgery may be needed to repair or replace damaged heart valves."
		},

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune disease that causes your own body to attack your joints, which causes pain, swelling, and joint damage. It also can cause fever, fatigue, swollen glands, weight loss, morning stiffness, and red hands. RA can cause swelling in other organs, including the eyes, lungs, and heart. Doctors don't know what triggers the autoimmune response that causes RA, but the disease is more common in women than men. There is no cure, but medications can stop joint damage and symptoms and put the disease into remission."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "The symptoms of RA may start slowly. You may first notice pain or swelling in the smaller joints of your hands, wrists, feet, or ankles. As it spreads, it can affect the joints in your jaw, neck, hips, knees, shoulders, and elbows. RA usually affects the joints on both sides of your body. Symptoms may come and go, sometimes clearing up for a while. But RA is a chronic disease, so it never goes away completely. After one to two years, RA can start to destroy the joints and make them look deformed. There is no cure for RA, but treatments can help relieve symptoms and stop destruction of the joints. Treatment is more effective when it is started early."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About three people in 10,000 in the world have rheumatoid arthritis."

		},

It most often affects the lungs, but sarcoidosis can affect the eyes, liver, skin, heart, and brain. No one knows what causes it. While sarcoidosis is serious, many people who have it never get very sick. Most gradually recover without treatment. Severe cases can damage the lungs and other organs and may need medications and other treatments. Sarcoidosis is more common in African-Americans and women."

Symptoms may go away slowly over years. Treatment -- with steroids or drugs that suppress the immune system -- can help control severe cases, which can be life threatening. Some people need lifelong treatment."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Scarlet fever is a red rash on the body caused by streptococcal bacteria, the same type of bacteria that cause strep throat. Scarlet fever usually develops as a result of a strep throat infection. The strep bacteria make a type of toxin that causes the rash in some people. Not everyone has a reaction to the bacteria and not everyone with strep throat will get scarlet fever. Scarlet fever may cause a red, itchy rash on the neck and face that moves down the body. Tiny bumps that feel rough, like sandpaper, appear on the skin. It also can cause a red and swollen tongue, white patches on throat, sore throat, trouble swallowing, swollen lymph glands, and fever. If not treated, scarlet fever can lead to serious health problems such as rheumatic fever, kidney problems, middle ear infections, meningitis, and throat abscess. Antibiotics treat strep throat and scarlet fever and help prevent these rare but serious conditions."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Strep throat symptoms usually start suddenly with a sore throat 1 to 5 days after exposure to the bacteria. If scarlet fever develops, a rash appears on the neck and chest and spreads to the rest of the body. With antibiotic treatment, strep throat symptoms usually go away in about a week. The rash fades in about a week, and the skin may peel on the fingers, toes, and groin. The rash can take up to three weeks to go away completely."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Young age, being exposed to someone with strep throat"

		},

			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Antibiotics shorten the disease and prevent potentially serious complications. Antibiotics also make you less contagious after 24 hours of treatment."

Aspirin can cause Reye's syndrome, a rare but fatal condition.\n\t\t•\tDrinking plenty of fluids\n\t\t•\tEating or drinking warm or cold foods or beverages to soothe the throat\n\t\t•\tSucking on hard candies or throat lozenges\n\t\t•\tTrying not to scratch or break the skin if the rash is itchy\n\t\t•\tRest"

		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Thalassemia is a rare group of genetic blood disorders. They cause problems with the red blood cells that carry oxygen, which leads to anemia. There are two major types -- alpha and beta thalassemia -- with minor and major subtypes. Symptoms often appear at birth or during early childhood. Thalassemia can be life threatening, especially if it's not treated. People with thalassemia may need blood transfusions and other treatments."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "A child will have thalassemia only if both parents carry the genetic trait. Thalassemia minor may cause no symptoms or mild anemia; people with this condition may not need treatment. Thalassemia major can lead to life-threatening heart or liver problems and infections. Babies with severe thalassemia may die before birth. People with more severe thalassemia may need regular blood transfusions to stay healthy. However, blood transfusions can lead to dangerously high iron levels in the blood. Chelation -- using a drug to remove excess iron -- will help. Bone marrow or stem cell transplants have cured some people with thalassemia."
		},

		},

	"Tuberculosis": [{
			"heading": "Tuberculosis",
			"content": "TB, consumption"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tFever\n\t\t•\tChills\n\t\t•\tDecreased appetite\n\t\t•\tFatigue\n\t\t•\tTender glands\n\t\t•\tYellow skin\n\t\t•\tYellow eyes\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tCough\n\t\t•\tEnlarged or swollen glands\n\t\t•\tShortness of breath\n\t\t•\tWeight loss (unintentional)\n\t\t•\tNight sweats\n\t\t•\tWeakness (generalized)"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Tuberculosis, or TB, is a chronic disease caused by the Mycobacterium tuberculosis bacterium. It usually infects the lungs, but it can also affect other areas such as the spine, brain, kidneys, and intestines. TB spreads when an infected person coughs, sneezes, speaks, or sings, which releases droplets into the air that other people can breathe in. If not treated, the disease can be serious and even fatal. TB causes a bad cough, coughing up blood, chest pain, fever, chills, and fatigue. Some people are infected with TB bacteria but don't have any symptoms and are not contagious. However, the disease can become active later and make them sick. People with a weak immune system, such as from HIV, are at higher risk for TB infection. Living in unsanitary conditions, abusing alcohol or drugs, and working with people who have TB also increases the risk. Taking several medications over a period of months will cure most cases of TB unless it's caused by a drug resistant version of the bacterium. Not taking medication correctly increases the risk of developing treatment-resistant TB."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "If you get a TB infection and your immune system fights it off, you won't have any symptoms and can't spread the disease to other people. However, you will still test positive for TB. This is called a latent TB infection. If your immune system becomes weaker at some point, the disease can become active and you will become sick. Some people with TB never get sick at all, some develop symptoms a few weeks after infection, and others develop the illness years later. Once the disease becomes active, symptoms such as fatigue, fever, weight loss, and cough may develop. Without treatment, symptoms can get worse or the infection may spread to other parts of the body. Everyone who has a TB infection needs treatment, either to prevent TB from becoming active, or to treat active TB. People with active TB may need to be separated from friends and family for a few weeks during treatment to prevent the disease from spreading."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Living in crowded or unsanitary conditions, being homeless, being around someone with TB, being an alcoholic or drug user, having HIV or another medical condition that weakens the immune system"
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 11,500 people in the country get TB every year."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Prevention",
			"content": "TB bacteria are spread through coughing, sneezing, talking, and singing. The bacteria remain suspended in the air for hours where other people can breathe them in. Kissing, sharing eating utensils or glasses, or shaking hands won't spread TB. If you have TB, it's important to tell the people close to you that you have it so they can also be tested. For the first few weeks of treatment, you need to stay away from others so you don't spread the TB bacteria. Your doctor may recommend that you wear a mask around other people. Also, always cover your mouth when you cough. Always take your medication exactly as directed. If you don't, you can spread the disease to others, stay sick, or develop drug-resistant TB, which is harder to treat."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "TB treatment may include:\n\t\t•\tMedication taken for 9 months to kill TB bacteria and prevent the active disease in people with latent TB.\n\t\t•\tSeveral medications taken from 6 months to a year to kill TB bacteria in people with active TB and prevent the disease from spreading."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "It's very important to take your medication exactly as directed. If you don't, TB can come back and be harder to treat. People who have a hard time taking their medication can meet with a health care worker for treatment."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "Call your doctor if you have been exposed to someone with TB, if you have symptoms of TB, or if you are being treated for TB and your symptoms get worse or you develop new symptoms. Get immediate medical care if you have a high fever, aching joints, aching or tingling in your fingers or toes, tingling or numbness around your mouth, blurred vision, ringing in your ears, dizziness, bruising, or yellow skin or eyes."

It's common in the desert areas of the Southwest country and in Central and South America. Most people have mild, if any, flu-like symptoms and usually get better without treatment. If the infection doesn't clear up, it could become a more serious, life-threatening form of the disease. Antifungal medications can treat valley fever."

Most people recover completely within six months. Very rarely, valley fever can progress to chronic or disseminated coccidioidomycosis with more severe symptoms. In that case, you may need medication or surgery and it may take up to a year to recover fully."

	"Viral_pneumonia": [{
			"heading": "Viral Pneumonia",
			"content": "Aseptic pneumonia"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tFever\n\t\t•\tBody aches or pains\n\t\t•\tFatigue\n\t\t•\tLabored breathing\n\t\t•\tJoint aches\n\t\t•\tCough\n\t\t•\tShortness of breath\n\t\t•\tDifficulty talking"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Viral pneumonia is a lung infection caused by viruses. Children and older adults more commonly get viral pneumonia. Bacteria cause most cases of pneumonia in adults. Viral pneumonia symptoms can be mild or life-threatening and include cough, shortness of breath, wheezing, chest pain, fever, and chills. Older adults, young children, people with a weak immune system, and those with chronic medical conditions are more at risk for complications from pneumonia. Treatment for pneumonia may include rest and self-care at home, or hospitalization and oxygen therapy, depending on the severity of symptoms. Antiviral medications can treat pneumonia caused by the influenza virus. Most people recover from viral pneumonia in about 1 to 3 weeks."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Viral pneumonia symptoms may be mild and come on slowly. The illness may start with a cough that brings up mucus, fever, chills, and shortness of breath. Other symptoms may include sweating, fatigue, and sharp or stabbing chest pain. Most people recover at home within 1 to 3 weeks with rest. Antibiotics work against bacterial pneumonia, but won't treat viral pneumonia. Antiviral medication can treat pneumonia caused by the influenza virus. People with more serious symptoms may need to be hospitalized to help replace fluids and make breathing easier."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",

Here are steps you can take to prevent viruses from spreading:\n\t\t•\tWash your hands often if you have a cold, especially after blowing your nose, sneezing, or coughing.\n\t\t•\tUse hand sanitizer or wash your hands often if you will be around a person with a cold.\n\t\t•\tDon't share towels, drinking glasses, eating utensils, computer keyboards, or telephones with someone who has a cold.\n\t\t•\tCover your mouth when coughing or sneezing.\n\t\t•\tAvoid contact with people who are sick.\n\t\t•\tIf you are sick, stay home and rest so you get better and don't infect other people at your workplace or school.\n\t\t•\tDon't smoke."

		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Histoplasmosis is a fungal infection you can get by breathing it into your lungs. It is caused by the Histoplasma capsulatum fungus and is often found in soil, especially dirt that has bat or bird droppings. It is most often found in the mid-Atlantic, southeastern, and central regions of the country Histoplasmosis can range from mild to life-threatening. It most often affects your lungs, but in severe cases it can spread to your whole body. It can cause muscle aches, fever, headache, chills, chest pain, cough, sweating, shortness of breath, weight loss, pneumonia, stiff neck, and mouth ulcers. Sometimes it causes no symptoms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "The symptoms of histoplasmosis can vary widely from person to person. The severity of your illness depends on how much of the fungus you inhaled and your general health. Some people have no symptoms. If you do have symptoms, it is most common to have flu-like symptoms and symptoms that affect the lungs. About 10% of people can have swelling in the bones, skin, joints, or lining of the heart. A small number of people have a life-threatening form of histoplasmosis that spreads to the blood and other organs. This can cause fever, stiff neck, weight loss, pneumonia, and mouth ulcers. Young children, older adults, and those with weakened immune systems are more likely to have this serious type of illness. Histoplasmosis is usually treated with antifungal medications. Many people with a mild form of the illness don't need any treatment."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 250,000 people in the country have histoplasmosis each year."

			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Chronic histoplasmosis is usually treated with antifungal medications taken orally, or if the condition is severe, by IV. Treatment for acute histoplasmosis is typically unnecessary."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Sickle cell disease is a group of lifelong genetic disorders that often begin in early childhood. The most common type is sickle cell anemia. Sickle cell disease turns red blood cells into a distorted crescent shape. This makes blood cells break down rapidly, blocking blood flow. This deprives tissues of oxygen and sometimes causes organ damage. Sickle cell disease causes pain, repeated infections, shortness of breath and fatigue. The course of the disease varies greatly from person to person. Some have mild symptoms. Others often need hospitalization for more serious problems. Treatment may involve pain medication, blood transfusions, penicillin and/or other antibiotics, hydroxyurea, or bone marrow transplant."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "The course of sickle cell disease varies greatly from person to person. Some have mild symptoms. Many have painful crises. Some need hospitalization for serious complications. These range from strokes to lung blockage to kidney damage. Improved treatments allow people to live into their 50s or longer. The only cure is a bone marrow transplant."
		},

			"heading": "How Common",

		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Most tick bites are harmless, especially if the tick is removed soon after attaching. However, ticks can transmit bacteria, viruses, and other parasites to the person or animal they bite. The most common tick-related illness is Lyme disease, which is caused by bacteria from an infected tick. The first sign may be a rash, fever, chills, and other flu like symptoms. Later it can cause severe and chronic arthritis as well as fatigue and other problems. Lyme disease is primarily found in the Northeast. But it has been reported in every state except Hawaii. Some other tick-borne diseases include Rocky Mountain spotted fever, tularemia, and ehrlichiosis."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "If there is no infection, a tick bite will heal quickly once the tick has been removed. It's important to remove a tick quickly to help prevent infection. Make sure you get the entire tick by grasping it as close to the head as possible with a pair of tweezers and pulling upward with a slow steady motion. Keep the tick in a plastic bag in the freezer in case signs of illness appear. A rash around the site of the bite is often the first sign. Other signs include fever and chills, aches and pain, and fatigue. Tick-borne illnesses usually respond well to treatment with antibiotics. Treating them early is key to avoiding serious complications later."
		},
		{

			"content": "Tick bites don't require treatment unless an illness develops. Antibiotics are used to treat most illnesses that result from tick bites."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Remove a tick as soon as you see it. Grasp it as close to the head as possible with a pair of tweezers and pull upward with a slow, steady motion. Don't jerk or twist. After the tick has been removed, watch for any symptoms that could indicate a related illness. The earlier treatment starts, the easier the illness will be to treat."
		},

	"Dengue_fever": [{
			"heading": "Dengue Fever",
			"content": "Break-bone fever, dandy fever"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tFever\n\t\t•\tBody aches or pains\n\t\t•\tDiarrhea\n\t\t•\tHeadache\n\t\t•\tSkin rash\n\t\t•\tJoint aches\n\t\t•\tChills\n\t\t•\tFatigue\n\t\t•\tNausea or vomiting"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Dengue fever is a flu-like illness that is passed between people via bites from the Aedes mosquito. Dengue hemorrhagic fever, a severe form of the illness, can be fatal if not treated early in a hospital. High fever, rash, joint pain, and bleeding from the nose or gums are some symptoms of dengue fever. There is no cure for the illness, so treatment addresses the symptoms. People who live in or travel to tropical or subtropical areas are most likely to get it, and most people recover. Anyone who has symptoms of dengue fever should see a doctor. Keep in mind that other, less serious health conditions can cause the same symptoms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "Go to a hospital emergency room if you have any signs of dengue hemorrhagic fever. Call the emergency services if you have signs of dengue shock syndrome."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "If you have mild dengue fever, you'll start getting symptoms within four to seven days of being bitten by an infected mosquito. You may have a fever of up to 105º F, skin rash, pain behind the eyes, nausea, chills, and severe head, muscle, and joint pain. These symptoms may subside and then return with another skin rash everywhere but your face. Dengue hemorrhagic fever starts off with similar symptoms. But when the fever goes down, you may have persistent vomiting, severe abdominal pain, and trouble breathing. You may bleed from the nose or gums or under the skin, which will show up as purplish bruises. In the most severe form of the illness, dengue shock syndrome, symptoms include massive bleeding and shock. Blood vessel, liver, and neurological damage and death can occur with severe dengue fever. To treat mild dengue fever symptoms, your doctor will probably advise rest, fluids, and an over-the-counter acetaminophen. You'll likely recover within a couple of weeks and feel weak for a couple more. If you get infected again, however, complications are more likely. For more severe dengue fever, emergency treatment with intravenous fluids and electrolyte replacement can be lifesaving. You'll probably be hospitalized and may need intensive care treatment such as a blood transfusion and blood pressure monitoring and support. Still, the vast majority of people with dengue hemorrhagic fever or dengue shock syndrome survive with prompt hospital care."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Previous dengue fever"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for dengue fever may include: Getting plenty of bed rest Drinking plenty of fluids to prevent dehydration Taking over-the-counter acetaminophen for pain and fever Avoiding drugs containing ibuprofen, Naproxen, or aspirin because of the risk of hemorrhage Intravenous fluids, blood and platelet transfusion, blood pressure support (for severe dengue fever)"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "To prevent dengue infection while traveling:\n\t\t•\tIf possible, avoid travel to areas during peak dengue transmission season or when an outbreak is occurring. Check the CDC Travelers' Health web page.\n\t\t•\tEspecially during the day, when Aedes mosquitoes bite, wear a long-sleeved shirt, long pants, socks, and shoes and use a mosquito repellant with DEET on your skin and clothes.\n\t\t•\tTry to spend your time in places with good screens or air conditioning.\n\t\t•\tKeep unscreened windows and doors closed.\n\t\t•\tGet rid of mosquito-breeding areas, such as standing water in flowerpots."

			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Legionnaires' disease is a severe type of pneumonia caused by bacteria called Legionella. The bacteria usually grow in warm water, such as in whirlpools, mist sprayers, and the air conditioning systems of large buildings. Legionella also causes a milder type of illness called Pontiac fever. You can get Legionnaires' disease or Pontiac fever if you breathe the bacteria into your lungs in a vapor or mist, but it isn't contagious. Legionnaires' disease can cause a headache, chills, high fever, a cough, muscle pains, chest pain, fatigue, and loss of appetite. Pontiac fever can cause headache, fever, and muscle aches. Pontiac fever often gets better on its own, but Legionnaires' disease can be life-threatening. Antibiotics usually cure Legionnaires' disease."

Pontiac fever usually goes away on its own in 2 to 5 days with no treatment."

			"heading": "Malaria",
			"content": "Plasmodium, Biduoterian fever, Blackwater fever"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tFever\n\t\t•\tChills\n\t\t•\tNausea or vomiting\n\t\t•\tDark colored (brown) urine\n\t\t•\tBody aches or pains\n\t\t•\tHeadache\n\t\t•\tExcessive sweating\n\t\t•\tWeakness (generalized)"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Malaria is a dangerous disease spread by mosquitoes. In rare cases, it's spread by blood transfusions. Malaria causes severe fever, chills, headache, and anemia. Malaria is extremely rare in the country, but common in warmer areas of the world, especially Africa and South Asia. It's also found in parts of the Middle East, Southeast Asia, Central and South America, and the Caribbean. Malaria is especially dangerous for pregnant women and their unborn babies. Untreated, the disease can be fatal, but the majority of people who get prompt treatment are cured. If you are traveling to a warm country, you can reduce your risk of getting malaria by taking preventive medicine in advance."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Malaria symptoms usually appear between 10 days and four weeks after infection, but may take months to develop. Doctors may misdiagnose malaria at first because it's so rare in the country It may seem like a bad flu. Anyone with signs of malaria should tell a doctor about travel to areas with malaria anytime in the last year. People with malaria usually stay in the hospital. Many need IV fluids. Medications will destroy the parasite. Occasionally, some people with malaria have lasting neurological problems. Certain types of malaria have become resistant to medication and are harder to treat. Relapses of malaria symptoms may occur months or years after the original infection."
		},

			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Whooping cough is a contagious respiratory infection that is spread from one person to another from coughing or sneezing. It's caused by the bacterium Bordetella pertussis, and can be prevented by the pertussis vaccine, given in the first six months of a baby's life. Whooping cough causes a runny nose, a mild fever, and a severe cough. Sometimes the coughing can cause vomiting. Whooping cough can cause severe, sometimes life-threatening, illness in babies and children. Whooping cough used to be a common childhood illness, but the pertussis vaccine has made it much less common."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "The symptoms of whooping cough often start off like cold. After about a week to 10 days, severe episodes of coughing start. In some cases, the coughing is so bad that it's hard to take a breath. When your child tries to inhale, you may notice a “whooping” sound. Infants may have just a mild cough or no cough at all, even if their condition is serious. Adults and older children with whooping cough are usually treated at home. Infants and young children may need antibiotics or treatment in the hospital. The infection usually lasts about 6 weeks."
		},

	"Aortic_aneurysm_(abdomen)": [{
			"heading": "Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm",
			"content": "aortic aneurysm, AAA"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tFever\n\t\t•\tBlue colored skin\n\t\t•\tPulsating sensation\n\t\t•\tCold feet\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tWeight loss (unintentional)\n\t\t•\tBlack colored stools"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "An abdominal aortic aneurysm happens when the wall of the aorta, the main artery that carries blood to the body, weakens and swells like a balloon in your abdomen. Smoking, high blood pressure, and atherosclerosis (hardening of the arteries) can cause it. If an aneurysm is not diagnosed and treated, the aorta can burst and cause life-threatening bleeding. You may feel sudden pain, lose consciousness, or go into shock. If the aorta hasn't burst, you may have no symptoms. Screening can discover an abdominal aneurysm early, when it's curable. Treatment may include surgery or observation."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "If you feel sudden, severe chest or back pain, immediately go to a hospital emergency room. Emergency treatment can be life-saving for a ruptured aneurysm as well as other conditions that cause chest pain."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Because abdominal aortic aneurysms often have no symptoms, most are detected through tests for other medical problems. If an aneurysm is small, developing slowly, and causing no symptoms, your doctor may monitor its development with an ultrasound exam once or twice year. If the aorta wall starts to leak, you may feel pain in your back, abdomen, or groin. Aneurysms that leak, grow rapidly, cause symptoms, or are large require immediate treatment. Open surgical repair is most common and very successful if the aneurysm has not ruptured, but recovery is lengthy. In a newer, less invasive procedure, endovascular repair, a graft is inserted into the aorta to reinforce it. Most people do not survive a ruptured aneurysm. If you are at risk for an abdominal aortic aneurysm, getting screened and treated will lower the chance of a rupture."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Exertion, high blood pressure, stress,"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for an abdominal aneurysm may include:\n\t\t•\tObservation, with regular CT scans or ultrasounds\n\t\t•\tOpen surgery to replace the aorta\n\t\t•\tEndovascular repair (inserting a stent-graft to reinforce the weakened part of the blood vessel and create a new channel for blood flow)"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "These self-care strategies may help when you have an abdominal aortic aneurysm:\n\t\t•\tDon't smoke.\n\t\t•\tWork with your doctor to control your blood pressure.\n\t\t•\tAsk your doctor about exercising 30 minutes a day.\n\t\t•\tEat a low-fat, low-cholesterol diet.\n\t\t•\tGet regular ultrasound exams as recommended."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",

		},

			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "A pilonidal cyst forms under the skin at the tailbone, and usually contains skin debris and hair. These cysts typically form in the teens or the 20s and are rare after age 40. They also are more common in males than in females. Experts believe they are usually caused by an ingrown hair in the crease between the buttocks. When a hair penetrates the skin, they believe, a natural reaction of the body is to form a cyst around it. However, it's possible to have a cyst without a hair. Cysts that have come to the surface may be small or be as large as golf balls. Although they are completely benign, pilonidal cysts can be irritating, unsightly, and painful. A cyst on the surface may erupt, become infected, and form an abscess, which requires immediate medical attention."
		},

			"content": "A pilonidal cyst may cause mild discomfort before seeming to clear up on its own. But some of these cysts become inflamed and form a large painful lump or break open on the skin, resembling an ulcer. Cysts can be drained and then removed with minor surgery. In close to half the cases, though, a cyst will come back."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Measles is a highly contagious viral infection that is most common in children. Globally, it is one of the leading causes of death in children, but it is uncommon in the country because of widespread immunization. Pneumonia, blindness, and brain infection are rare but serious complications, so vaccination is strongly recommended. Anyone who is exposed to measles or has symptoms such as body rash and fever should see a doctor. Keep in mind that other conditions can cause the same symptoms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "After a 7- to 14-day incubation period, the first symptom of measles is usually a high fever, which may last for several days. You may also have a barky cough, runny nose, watery eyes, and white spots inside your cheeks. A red rash will appear on your face and neck and spread down to your hands and feet. Measles must run its course -- usually two weeks or less -- but rest, sponge baths with lukewarm water, and acetaminophen or ibuprofen can help relieve symptoms. Complications are most common in adults and children under age five. About 1 in 10 children develops ear infections, and 1 in 20 develops pneumonia, which is especially serious in infants. Encephalitis (swelling of the brain) is very rare. Most people completely recover, and once you've had measles, you are immune for life."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Being an unvaccinated young child, or at any age not being vaccinated, or having not had the measles before"
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "In 2016, 70 cases of measles were reported in the country, down from 188 the year before and 667 cases in 2014. Worldwide, there are about 20 million cases a year."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Prevention",
			"content": "The best prevention for measles is the MMR (measles, mumps, and rubella) vaccine. Children get one vaccine at 12 to 15 months of age and another at four or five years old. If your child is not immunized, you can still prevent measles by getting a vaccine within three days of exposure to the virus. If you are not immunized and were born in 1957 or after, you should get at least one dose of the MMR vaccine. College students, people who work with children or in healthcare, and international travelers should get two doses. If you are pregnant or have leukemia, lymphoma, or a depressed immune system, you should not get immunized."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "There is no treatment for measles. But you can treat symptoms:\n\t\t•\tAcetaminophen or ibuprofen may relieve pain and fever symptoms. Do not give aspirin to children or teenagers.\n\t\t•\tA humidifier or vaporizer may ease a cough."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "These self-care strategies can make you more comfortable when you have measles:\n\t\t•\tGet plenty of rest.\n\t\t•\tDrink plenty of fluids to avoid dehydration.\n\t\t•\tSponge baths with warm water may ease fever discomfort.\n\t\t•\tAcetaminophen or ibuprofen may relive pain and fever symptoms. Do not give aspirin to children or teenagers.\n\t\t•\tA humidifier or vaporizer may ease a cough.\n\t\t•\tAsk your doctor about vitamin A supplements if you have a vitamin A deficiency or a weakened immune system."
		},

		},
		{
			"heading": "Plague Overview",
			"content": "Plague is a rare bacterial infection caused by the bacterium Yersinia pestis. It is spread most often to humans through fleas that have bitten infected rodents. In rare cases, you can get plague by handling an infected animal. Pneumonic plague (a lung infection) is spread easily between people by coughing. It can cause a high fever, difficulty breathing, seizures, severe headache, abdominal pain, diarrhea, vomiting, organ failure, and bleeding. Plague was a huge problem in the Middle Ages, killing millions of people, but now it is confined mostly to certain parts of the Southwest country where rodents carry the disease.\n\nBubonic plague (confined to the lymph nodes), which also killed million of people in the Middle Ages, is difficult to pass to others."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Symptoms of plague usually start about two to 10 days after you are exposed to the bacteria. But in some cases, symptoms can start just a few hours after you are exposed. People who have plague need to be treated right away with antibiotics. Treatment is most effective when it's started within 24 hours of the first symptoms. Without prompt treatment, plague often causes death."
		},

			"content": "The best way to prevent plague is to limit your exposure to wild rodents in areas that have plague. People who have plague are kept isolated in the hospital to prevent spreading the illness."

	"Shingles_(herpes_zoster)": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tFever\n\t\t•\tHeadache\n\t\t•\tSkin blisters\n\t\t•\tSore throat\n\t\t•\tUnable to blink or close eyelid\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tSkin rash\n\t\t•\tSkin bumps\n\t\t•\tJoint pain"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Shingles is a painful, blistering, skin rash typically found on the back and sides of the chest (but can occur anywhere on the body, including the scalp and genitalia). It is caused by the herpes zoster virus, the same virus that causes chicken pox. After a chicken pox infection, the virus becomes inactive but remains in nerve tissue. Years later, the virus may reactivate as shingles. Stress, cancer, or other medical problems can trigger an outbreak. In some cases, shingles pain may linger after the rash has cleared up. This is called post-herpetic neuralgia, a long-lasting, sometimes disabling condition."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Shingles usually starts as itching and pain on the skin that develops into blisters. The full rash forms in about a week or so. Blisters break open and form scabs that sometimes leave scars after healing. The whole process takes 2 to 3 weeks. For some people, the rash barely develops. It's unclear why some people have worse symptoms or develop post-herpetic pain, but age and stress may be factors. Cancer or other immune deficiencies increase the risk for widespread zoster, which can be dangerous if it affects the airways."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Approximately 1 in 100 people get shingles in any given year. People over age 50 and those who never got the chicken pox vaccine are more likely to develop shingles. Shingles is also more common in people with cancer and those who take immunosuppressive drugs such as cortisone."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Anti-viral medications (acyclovir, famciclovir, valacyclovir) reduce the pain and duration of a shingles outbreak.\n\nZostavax (a shingles vaccine) reduces by half the risk of developing shingles.\n\nAntidepressants and pain medications can reduce post-shingles nerve pain.\n\nTopical corticosteroids are sometimes prescribed to reduce inflammation and pain."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "If you develop early symptoms of shingles (tingling, blistery rash) see your doctor. Treatment with anti-viral medications early on can reduce the spread of the rash and help prevent pain. If you can't see a doctor, treat the itching with calamine lotion, anti-itch creams, and antihistamines. Oatmeal baths may also help. Take acetaminophen or a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory such as ibuprofen (Advil)."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Scratching the blisters or sores, wearing tight clothing"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "Schedule a doctor visit as soon as you notice symptoms of shingles, such as tingling, itching, nerve pain and a rash, often wrapping around one side from the middle of the back to the front of the chest."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\t\t•\tHow can I reduce the itching?\n\t\t•\tAre anti-virus medications useful at this point?\n\t\t•\tWhen should I get the shingles vaccination?\n\t\t•\tWhen should I expect the pain to go away?\n\t\t•\tWhat if the blisters get weepy or spread?"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "Doctors diagnose shingles with a physical exam. The rash is distinctive and easy to spot. If the rash is widespread, a doctor may order other tests to rule out underlying diseases."
		}

		{
