		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Anthrax is a bacterial infection that typically attacks animals, such as sheep, cattle, and goats. In rare cases, people may develop anthrax from spores in the soil or infected animals. Anthrax can enter the lungs if a person breathes it in. Inhaled anthrax is often fatal. Anthrax is extremely rare in the country -- even in animals. It's more common in parts of Southern and Eastern Europe, South and Central America, Asia, Africa, the Middle East, and the Caribbean. Researchers have developed strains of anthrax as biological weapons. Five people died from inhaled anthrax after handling tainted letters in 2001. While there is an anthrax vaccine, it is only available to people at high risk, such as members of the military, certain lab workers, and others. Remember that anthrax infection is extremely uncommon. Much less serious conditions -- such as a cold or flu -- are more likely the cause of symptoms such as headache, fever, and cough."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "If you may have been exposed to anthrax or have any severe symptoms, call a doctor right away or go to the emergency room. Call the police if you come in contact with suspicious white powder that could be anthrax."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "People may get anthrax from the soil or infected animals. Inhaled anthrax symptoms may take between one to six weeks to appear. People may have cold or flu-like symptoms, such as fever, muscle aches, and sore throat. As it spreads in the lungs, inhaled anthrax will cause a cough, difficulty breathing, and chest pain. Immediate treatment with IV antibiotics is crucial after exposure. Most people don't suspect that they have inhaled anthrax until it's too late. People with advanced inhaled anthrax infection may go into shock and then die."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "People with eating disorders have extreme and dangerous eating habits. They may drastically reduce the amount they eat or overeat compulsively. They may become obsessed with eating -- or not eating -- and have a distorted view of their physical appearance. Binge eating disorder, anorexia nervosa, and bulimia nervosa are some of the more common eating disorders. While more frequent in girls and women, boys and men develop eating disorders, too. Eating disorders can be hard to control. They can have a severe impact on a person's health and need medical treatment. Therapy, medication, and behavior changes can help."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "People with anorexia severely restrict food. Bulimia causes people to purge after eating by making themselves throw up or using laxatives. People with binge eating disorder eat compulsively and excessively. Eating disorders usually start in teenagers or young adults. Some eating disorders are more common in people who are driven, successful in school, and perfectionists. For some, it's a brief phase. For others, it becomes a life-long problem. A therapist can help people understand the problem and change their behaviors. Family support is crucial. Even after successful treatment, eating disorders can come back."
		},

			"content": "\t\t•\tFood cravings\n\t\t•\tWeight loss (unintentional)\n\t\t•\tHunger\n\t\t•\tFatigue\n\t\t•\tSlow growth (failure to thrive)"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Malnutrition occurs when your body isn't getting enough nutrients. It can be caused by eating an unbalanced diet or not getting enough of a single nutrient. It also can be caused by not eating enough food or not properly digesting or absorbing the food you do eat. Infants and small children, along with the elderly, may be at higher risk for malnutrition. Alcoholism and certain medical conditions also can contribute to malnutrition. In mild cases, there are no symptoms. However, sometimes the condition is life-threatening or can cause permanent damage to your body."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "If you are malnourished, your symptoms will continue to get worse without treatment. You can do permanent damage to your body if you don't get the nutrients you need. Most of the symptoms of mild malnutrition can be reversed with dietary changes and nutritional supplements. In more serious cases, the person may need to be hospitalized and fed through a tube. If an underlying condition is responsible for the malnutrition, they will need treatment for that condition."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Less than 1% of all children in the country have chronic malnutrition."

		},

	"Hair_loss_(female)": [{
			"heading": "Hair Loss, Female",
			"content": "Alopecia, hair loss in women, female pattern baldness"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "Hair loss"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Alopecia means hair loss. Everyone's hair thins as they age. But some women have female pattern baldness, called androgenetic alopecia, which runs in families. Unlike male baldness, female pattern baldness usually causes thinning on the top of the head but not complete baldness. Other forms of alopecia can occur after a serious illness or other physical trauma or as a result of underlying conditions such as lupus or some forms of cancer. In some cases, hair grows back. If not, medications can slow or reverse some forms of alopecia."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Some forms of alopecia go away on their own and hair regrows. Other forms are permanent. Medications can sometimes be used to regrow hair. If you're bothered by thin areas, you may also want to change your hairstyle to make thinning less obvious or wear hair extensions or a wig."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 13% of premenopausal women have some hair loss. After menopause, thinning increases dramatically. By the age of 65, one in four women has alopecia."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Some forms of alopecia are temporary and hair grows back on its own. Others involve inflammation of the hair follicles that can be treated with drugs that suppress inflammation. For some forms of alopecia, a medication called monoxidil can help slow or reverse hair loss."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Since some hair thinning is a normal part of aging, it only becomes a problem if it bothers you. Many women adapt to hair loss by choosing a different hair style that masks thin areas, wearing hair extensions or a wig, or wearing hats can hide thin areas."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Overly vigorous brushing, harsh hair care chemicals, nutritional deficiencies"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "See your doctor if you suddenly notice unusual hair loss."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "Your doctor can usually diagnose alopecia by asking about your medical history and examining your scalp. In some cases a “pull test” is done, which involves firmly tugging a cluster of several dozen hairs to see how many come out. Your doctor may recommend a scalp biopsy to determine the kind of alopecia you have. Other tests may be ordered to rule out underlying conditions."

	"Malocclusion_(bite_out_of_alignment)": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tHeadache\n\t\t•\tTeeth do not fit like they used to\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Malocclusion is misalignment of the teeth such as underbites, overbites, and crossbites. Hereditary factors including the shape of your face or having different sized jaws and habits such as extended thumb sucking can cause malocclusions. The teeth may look crowded, jut out, or be out of place. Malocclusions can cause problems with speech, eating, and tooth care, and lead to other dental problems. Braces can treat malocclusion, but for adults, oral surgery also may be necessary."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Malocclusion is easier to treat earlier in life. If your child has mild malocclusion, it may improve as the jaw grows. If braces are recommended, your child will probably begin wearing them between 9 years and 14 years old. Sometimes it's also necessary to remove a tooth to make room for others that are growing in. Adults can wear less-noticeable braces than children to correct malocclusion. Braces may have clear plastic wires instead of silver, attach to the back of teeth, or be removable. To fully correct a jaw-related problem, however, an adult may need surgery. Braces are generally worn for one to three years, followed by a retainer full time for six months and then only during sleep."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 4 million children and 1 million adults wear braces in the country"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment may include:\n\t\t•\tFixed or removable mouth appliances (braces, retainer, spacers)\n\t\t•\tTooth extraction\n\t\t•\tJaw surgery"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "\t\t•\tAvoid gum, sticky foods, popcorn, and nuts while wearing braces or other mouth appliances.\n\t\t•\tBrush and floss teeth regularly.\n\t\t•\tClean removable mouth appliances regularly.\n\t\t•\tWear a retainer as instructed.\n\t\t•\tSee the dentist twice a year for regular dental care.\n\t\t•\tTake over-the-counter pain relief when braces are tightened."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Malocclusion symptoms can get worse as a person ages."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "See an orthodontist for a malocclusion evaluation by the time your child is 7 years old. When wearing a dental appliance such as braces, see your orthodontist for loose brackets or bands, wires that stick out, or pain that isn't relieved by over-the-counter medication."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\t\t•\tHow likely is it that my child will have malocclusion?\n\t\t•\tWhat can I do to prevent malocclusion?\n\t\t•\tHow long will treatment take?\n\t\t•\tIs jaw surgery necessary?\n\t\t•\tWhat are the advantages of different types of braces?"
		},
		{

			"content": "Family history of malocclusion, thumb sucking past age 5, very small space between baby teeth, and tooth loss (due to injury or tooth decay caused by habits such as sucking on a baby bottle during sleep) increase risk of malocclusion."

	"Migraine_headache_(adult)": [{
			"heading": "Migraine Headache",
			"content": "Migraine, cephalgia, vascular headache"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tHeadache\n\t\t•\tNumbness or tingling\n\t\t•\tSensitive to noise\n\t\t•\tFlickering lights in vision\n\t\t•\tNausea or vomiting\n\t\t•\tSensitive to light\n\t\t•\tFlickering uncolored zig-zag line in vision\n\t\t•\tDifficulty talking"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Migraines are a common type of headache that can cause severe pain. They can last for a few hours or a few days and may cause throbbing, sensitivity to sound or light, nausea, or vomiting. Migraines are caused by abnormal brain activity that is triggered by certain foods, stress, or other factors. Some people have an aura before a migraine, which can have symptoms that include temporary vision loss, seeing stars or flashes, or a tingling in an arm or leg. There is no cure for migraines, but medications can help reduce pain or stop migraines from occurring."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Most migraines usually last 4-72 hours, but this varies from person to person. A migraine can start with an aura or other sensations, such as seeing wavy lines in one eye, a sense of elation, irritability, or a craving for sweets. Auras can happen just a few minutes before the migraine or up to a day before it. Migraines are more common in women, and tend to run in families. Although there is no cure for migraines, there are many treatments. Treating migraine symptoms right away can help make the headache less severe. Some medications help relieve the pain of migraines; others help prevent migraines."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 1 in 10 people have migraine headaches."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Some migraines can be treated at home with over-the-counter pain relievers.\n\nSevere migraines are usually treated with prescription medicines called triptans, anti-nausea medicine, or sedatives. Pain-relieving medications usually work best when taken at the first sign of a migraine.\n\nFrequent migraines can sometimes be prevented by taking medications such as beta-blockers, antidepressants, antiseizure drugs, or by getting a Botox injection in the muscles of the forehead and neck."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Once a migraine strikes, try these tips:\n\t\t•\tRest in a dark, quiet room\n\t\t•\tDrink water, especially if you have vomited\n\t\t•\tPut a cool cloth on your forehead"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Movement, bright lights and loud sounds, smoking, and alcohol."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "Seek medical care right away if you:\n\t\t•\tHave a sudden headache that feels like a thunderclap\n\t\t•\tHave a headache with a fever, weakness, stiff neck, double vision, or confusion\n\t\t•\tYour headache feels worse after coughing, sudden movement, or straining\n\t\t•\tYou develop headaches after age 50"
		},

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "earsightedness is a common eye problem that affects distance vision. It occurs when the shape of the eyeball or cornea -- the clear layer that covers your eye -- does not refract incoming light rays correctly. You may be able to clearly make out the words in a book in front of you but not those on a sign in the distance. Eyeglasses, contact lenses, or eye surgery can solve the problem. Sometimes, diabetes or a developing cataract causes nearsightedness."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Children between ages 8 and 12 years are most likely to be diagnosed with nearsightedness. It usually worsens during the teen years and then stabilizes at around age 20. But nearsightedness from visual strain may develop in adults and get worse with age. Depending on how nearsighted you are, you may need to wear glasses for some activities or all the time."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About one in four people in the country are nearsighted."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Getting a pair of eyeglasses is the simplest treatment for nearsightedness. 		},

			"content": "Eye strain may make nearsightedness worse."

You have chronic sinusitis when your symptoms last longer than 12 weeks."

In severe cases, you may need cortisone to reduce inflammation. In some cases, doctors use surgery to drain and clean the sinuses."

When the lens or the cornea -- the clear layer that covers your eye -- has slight imperfections, it may not refract light correctly. You could have trouble seeing fine details, both nearby and in the distance. A pair of glasses or contacts usually solves the problem."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Most people with astigmatism were born with it. However, a doctor may not diagnose it until a child starts school and has trouble reading the blackboard. Less often, astigmatisms develop later in life. You might get it after an injury or surgery for cataracts. Astigmatism may get better or worse as you get older. While astigmatism is different from nearsightedness and farsightedness, it can occur along with either condition."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tHeadache\n\t\t•\tNausea or vomiting\n\t\t•\tDrooping eyelid\n\t\t•\tBruising or discoloration\n\t\t•\tUnable to blink or close eyelid\n\t\t•\tBlank stare"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Botulinum toxin is produced by a type of bacteria that causes food poisoning. When injected in small doses, botulinum toxin relaxes muscles and does not cause illness. One type of botulinum toxin is used to temporarily remove wrinkles on the face. Other types treat severe neck and shoulder muscle spasms, uncontrollable blinking, misaligned eyes, excessive underarm sweating, and migraines. Botulinum toxin is usually safe, but it can cause side effects. These include pain and tenderness at the injection site, headache, nausea, dry mouth, dry eyes, tearing, and sensitivity to light. While rare, the drug can spread to other parts of the body and cause more serious side effects including unexpected muscle weakness, trouble talking, rash, itching, breathing difficulty, trouble swallowing, loss of bladder control, vision problems, and drooping eyelids. Call the emergency services If you notice serious side effects."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Botulinum toxin injections are generally safe when given by a doctor who has used the drug before to treat your condition. The doctor will inject small amounts of the botulinum toxin into specific muscles, and you may have more than one injection. It's normal to feel some mild pain. You may notice a little bruising and redness. Don't rub the injection site, as this may cause the toxin to spread to other areas. Depending on the condition it's used for, the drug starts to work in a few days to one or two weeks and lasts about three to six months. If you notice side effects such as headache, nausea, dry eyes and tearing that don't go away, call your doctor. Call the emergency services if you have more serious side effects such as trouble talking or breathing, vision problems, muscle weakness or loss of bladder control, or rash, itching and other signs of an allergic reaction."
		},

		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Cervical spondylosis is arthritis of the neck. It happens when the vertebrae in your cervical spine or neck break down, lose fluid, and get stiffer as you age. In some cases, bone spurs called osteophytes may form on the bones of your neck. These spurs can narrow the spinal column, causing a related condition call cervical spinal stenosis. Symptoms of cervical spondylosis include neck pain and stiffness, pain in the shoulder, arm, or chest, and a grinding sensation when turning your neck. It is usually treated with rest, medication, and physical therapy. In rare cases, you may need surgery."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Cervical spondylosis is usually chronic, meaning it lasts a long time and may get worse over time. It's most common in people older than age 50. In some cases, bone spurs and other spinal abnormalities may narrow the spinal column, putting pressure on the spinal cord or nerves."

			"content": "Migraine variant, cephalgia, vascular headaches"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tHeadache\n\t\t•\tRed eye (single)\n\t\t•\tNausea or vomiting\n\t\t•\tRunny nose\n\t\t•\tDrooping eyelid\n\t\t•\tSmall (constricted) pupils\n\t\t•\tAgitation\n\t\t•\tNasal symptoms and one red eye\n\t\t•\tRestless or irritability\n\t\t•\tWatery eyes\n\t\t•\tEarly morning waking"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Cluster headaches occur one to three times a day and last a few minutes to several hours. These daily headache clusters occur for several weeks and then go away for months or even years. Cluster headaches are the rarest and most severe type of headache. Men tend to get them more than women. Pain occurs behind one eye on one side of the head. The eye and nose on that side may become swollen, red, and runny. Attacks come at the same time every day and the intense pain makes it hard to sit still. Many people with cluster headaches pace restlessly or rock back and forth during an attack. Medication helps prevent headaches, lessen the pain, and shorten the duration of an attack. Cluster headaches aren't dangerous, but they make it difficult to work and do daily activities."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Pain comes on suddenly, often just after falling asleep. Early signs include droopy eyelid, red eye, runny nose, red face, sweating, and sensitivity to light. Pain becomes strongest 10 minutes or so after it starts and remains at that level for minutes to hours. Most headaches last about 30-90 minutes. Then the pain disappears completely, only to come back later in the day. Clusters of attacks last weeks or months and then go away for weeks, months, or years. About 20% of cluster headaches become chronic and never go away completely, returning almost every day. Medication helps most people cope with cluster headaches."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Fewer than 1 in 1,000 people have cluster headaches."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for cluster headaches includes:\n\t\t•\tMedications to help prevent headaches, such as beta blockers, anticonvulsants, antidepressants, calcium channel blockers, and corticosteroids\n\t\t•\tBreathing 100% oxygen at the start of a headache to lessen pain\n\t\t•\tMedications to relieve headache pain and shorten attacks, such as triptans, ergot alkaloids, and others\n\t\t•\tSurgery for some people if medications don't work"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Cluster headaches come on quickly and need to be treated at home. It's important to work with your doctor to develop a home treatment plan that works best for you."
		},

Allergies, asthma, sensitivity to aspirin, and chronic sinus infections raise the risk. Many nasal polyps don't need treatment. If they're causing problems, your doctor may suggest medication or surgery."

The condition causes the same symptoms as hay fever, except it is not triggered by pollen or other allergies. Stress, environmental irritants, infections, and some medications can trigger non-allergic rhinitis. But usually the underlying cause of this problem is unknown. 	"Noroviruses_(Norwalk-like_viruses)": [{
			"heading": "Noroviruses",
			"content": "Norwalk viruses, viral gastroenteritis, acute gastroenteritis, stomach flu, food poisoning"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tHeadache\n\t\t•\tNausea or vomiting\n\t\t•\tFever"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Noroviruses are a group of viruses that cause inflammation of the stomach and intestines. Severe diarrhea, vomiting, and stomach pain are the most common symptoms. Most people know norovirus infection as\"stomach flu,\" although it's not caused by a flu virus. Noroviruses are contagious and often cause outbreaks among people who live, work, or eat in close quarters. That's because they are easily spread through contaminated food or water, by touching a contaminated surface, or from person to person. There's no specific treatment for noroviruses, although it's important to get enough fluids. Infants, older adults, and people with chronic illnesses are at higher risk for dehydration from noroviruses and may need medical care."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Norovirus infection symptoms usually come on suddenly within 24 to 48 hours of exposure. But you're contagious from the moment you start feeling ill until at least 3 days -- and up to 2 weeks -- after you recover. You're likely to feel very sick and have diarrhea or vomit many times a day, but symptoms usually clear up in 1 to 3 days. It's important to drink fluids to prevent dehydration from vomiting and diarrhea. Elderly people, young children, and people who have a chronic illness or can't take care of themselves are especially prone to dehydration. In some cases, intravenous fluids or hospitalization may be necessary."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Exposure to a contaminated water supply, such as a recreational lake; eating contaminated food or drink; touching a contaminated surface; taking care of a person infected with the virus; living, eating, or working in close quarters, such as a nursing home, daycare center, school, cruise ship, hospital, hotel (especially as a housecleaner), or restaurant"
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 23 million people are infected with noroviruses in the country each year, resulting in 50,000 hospitalizations."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Prevention",
			"content": "These strategies can help prevent getting a norovirus infection:\n\t\t•\tWash your hands well with soap and warm water after using the toilet or changing diapers and especially before preparing or eating food.\n\t\t•\tWash fruits and vegetables.\n\t\t•\tCook fish and shellfish thoroughly.\n\t\t•\tDisinfect surfaces contaminated by diarrhea or vomiting with bleach.\n\t\t•\tImmediately wash and machine dry clothes or linens contaminated with norovirus germs.\n\nTo prevent passing on the virus if you are infected:\n\t\t•\tStay home from work while ill.\n\t\t•\tDon't prepare food for others while you have symptoms or for three days after.\n\t\t•\tIf you work in a nursing home taking care of patients or handling food, stay out of work for at least 48 to 72 hours after symptoms end."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for norovirus infection may include:\n\t\t•\tDrinking plenty of liquids\n\t\t•\tIV medication to stop vomiting\n\t\t•\tIV fluids with electrolytes, if dehydration develops\n\t\t•\tHospitalization in cases of severe dehydration until electrolytes and fluids are replaced"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "These self-care strategies may help if you have a norovirus infection:\n\t\t•\tGet plenty of rest.\n\t\t•\tTo rehydrate, drink plenty of clear fluids such as water, watered-down juice, oral rehydration solutions, or broth.\n\t\t•\tDon't drink liquids with caffeine or alcohol.\n\t\t•\tGive children an oral rehydration solution such as Pedialyte, Enfalyte, or Pediatric Electrolyte.\n\t\t•\tDo not take over-the-counter anti-diarrheal medication, which may prolong the infection or cause complications.\n\t\t•\tTo ease back into solid foods, eat bland foods and drink clear liquids."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "See your doctor if you have a norovirus infection and can't drink liquids or have extensive vomiting or diarrhea. Immediately see your doctor or go to a hospital emergency room if you have signs of dehydration, such as decreased or dark colored urine, dry mouth or throat, or lightheadedness. A child with dehydration may cry without tears or be unusually fussy or sleepy."

	"Ocular_migraine": [{
			"heading": "Ocular Migraine",
			"content": "Retinal migraine, ophthalmic migraines"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tHeadache\n\t\t•\tChange in vision\n\t\t•\tFlickering lights in vision\n\t\t•\tBlurred vision\n\t\t•\tPartial vision loss\n\t\t•\tBlindness"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Ocular migraine usually refers to retinal migraines, a type of migraine that can cause temporary blindness in one eye. You may or may not have other symptoms such as headache. Although alarming, ocular migraines are usually harmless. But because the symptoms are similar to those of more serious conditions, such as stroke, it's important to get medical attention. Some people use the term\"ocular migraine\" to describe a typical migraine aura. But a migraine aura typically distorts vision in both eyes, while a true ocular migraine affects one eye."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "The symptoms usually last minutes but may linger for up to an hour. Although they go away on their own, you're likely to have ocular migraines again. Rarely, optical migraines can damage the vision. Some migraine treatments can help. However, the symptoms usually disappear before treatment would have time to take effect. Exercise, changes in position, and birth control pills can trigger ocular migraines.\n\nIf you do not have a true ocular migraine, but instead have a migraine aura, here's what to expect: A migraine aura often begins as some wavy lines in the eye, or a hole in your vision. It usually occurs a few minutes before you feel migraine pain, and the aura typically lasts 10-30 minutes."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 29 million Americans get migraines, but most of these headaches are not ocular (retinal) migraines. Experts believe that retinal migraines are rare."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "If you have symptoms and have never had an ocular migraine, go to the emergency room right away. You need to make sure you don't have a more serious problem, such as a stroke.\n\nOcular migraines are usually over so quickly that treatment won't have time to work. Treatments to prevent ocular migraines include:\n\t\t•\tCalcium channel blockers, such as verapamil and nifedipine, which relax tightened blood vessels\n\t\t•\tPropranolol, a blood pressure medicine\n\t\t•\tDaily aspirin\n\t\t•\tStopping birth control pills\n\t\t•\tAvoiding migraine triggers, such as bright lights, chocolate, and not getting enough sleep\n\t\t•\tStress reduction"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "To reduce the chances of ocular migraines, don't smoke and reduce stress in your life. Try meditation or breathing exercises. Be careful to avoid your migraine triggers. A daily aspirin may help prevent ocular migraines."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Exercise, changes in position, birth control medication, and smoking"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "If you have vision loss in one eye and this has not happened before, get medical help right away."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\t\t•\tHave you ruled out other causes besides ocular migraine?\n\t\t•\tWill treatment help?\n\t\t•\tWhat should I do if I get these symptoms again?"

	"Sporotrichosis": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tHeadache\n\t\t•\tEnlarged or swollen glands\n\t\t•\tSkin bumps\n\t\t•\tJoint pain\n\t\t•\tSwelling\n\t\t•\tSkin blisters\n\t\t•\tSkin open sore\n\t\t•\tDrainage or pus"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Sporotrichosis is an infection caused by a fungus found in sphagnum moss, roses, hay and other plant material, and in soil. The fungus enters the skin through a puncture wound or cut when handling infected plant material or soil. The fungus can also be inhaled. Sporotrichosis can cause painless bumps on the fingers, hands, and arms that break open and slowly heal. If not treated, the condition can become chronic. Usually the fungus only infects the skin, but it can affect other body parts. People with a weak immune system are more likely to develop more serious health problems, including pneumonia, bone infection, arthritis, and meningitis. Antifungal medications taken for several months treat and cure the fungal infection in most people."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Symptoms start days or months after infection. First, a small red, pink, or purple bump appears. The bump looks like a boil, which eventually opens and drains clear fluid. Other bumps soon follow. Often the infection develops along lymph nodes, forming a line of bumps along the arm or leg. If not treated, the condition may become chronic. People with a weak immune system can develop life-threatening health problems such as pneumonia, bone infection, arthritis, and meningitis. Antifungal medications treat the condition and clear up skin problems in most people. Severe symptoms can be harder to treat."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Sporotrichosis is rare. About 200 to 250 people in the country get sporotrichosis every year."

		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Constipation is having less than three bowel movements a week. You also may have hard, dry stools that are difficult to pass. Everyone has constipation at one time or another. It's usually nothing to worry about. The foods you eat, how often you exercise, and other factors affect how often you have bowel movements. Many people expect to have one bowel movement a day, but most people aren't that regular. A normal range is anywhere from three to 21 bowel movements a week. However, prolonged constipation can lead to hemorrhoids. If you have constipation, understanding what causes it can help you avoid it."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "For most people, eating a high-fiber diet, getting regular exercise, and drinking enough fluids solves any problem with constipation. However, chronic constipation can be a sign of other medical conditions, such as irritable bowel syndrome or low thyroid. Some medications, such as some antidepressants and narcotic pain relievers, also cause constipation. In most cases, treating the underlying health problem, changing medications or dosage, or taking a stool softener medicine relieves constipation."
		},

	"Pseudohypoparathyroidism": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tHeadache\n\t\t•\tStiffness or decreased movement\n\t\t•\tFatigue\n\t\t•\tSensitive to light\n\t\t•\tTires quickly\n\t\t•\tUnusually short fourth fingers\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tBlurred vision\n\t\t•\tPalpitations (fluttering in chest)\n\t\t•\tMuscle cramps or spasms (painful)\n\t\t•\tWeakness (generalized)\n\t\t•\tAbnormally round face"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Pseudohypoparathyroidism is a very rare inherited condition similar to hypoparathyroidism. It causes low calcium and high phosphorus levels in the blood, which can lead to cramps, muscle spasms, delayed growth and development in children, and other problems. Hypoparathyroidism causes problems, because the body doesn't have enough parathyroid hormone. In pseudohypoparathyroidism, the body has enough of the hormone but can't use it correctly. Treatment includes daily dietary supplements."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Doctors may diagnose pseudohypoparathyroidism in children because of growth and developmental delays. Adults with pseudohypoparathyroidism may have other hormone issues that may cause weight gain, low energy, and low sex drive. A rare genetic disorder called Albright's hereditary osteodystrophy causes one type of pseudohypoparathyroidism. Symptoms include a round face, small hand bones, shortened ring fingers, and short height. Pseudohypoparathyroidism usually has milder symptoms than hypoparathyroidism. Severely low calcium levels can be life threatening. Treatment usually controls the symptoms. In children, growth and development may still be affected, even with treatment."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Pseudohypoparathyroidism is quite rare. Studies suggest that about 1 out of 300,000 people have it."
		},

		},

		},
		{

			"content": "Not getting enough calcium or getting too much phosphorus in the diet"
		},

Children may be small and have developmental delays. Severely low calcium levels can cause heart problems. If you have seizures or changes in heart rhythm, go to the emergency room."

	"Radiation_sickness": [{
			"heading": "Radiation Sickness",
			"content": "Acute radiation syndrome (ARS)"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tHeadache\n\t\t•\tCough\n\t\t•\tFatigue\n\t\t•\tShortness of breath\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tDiarrhea\n\t\t•\tSkin rash"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Radiation sickness occurs when your body gets a high dose of radiation, usually in a short time. It can be fatal, so requires immediate medical attention. Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and skin damage are early symptoms. Generally, the greater the radiation exposure, the more severe the symptoms. Radiation sickness is not caused by exposure to low-dose radiation, such as X-rays and CT scans. Accidents at nuclear power plants, such as that at Fukushima Daiichi plant in Japan in 2011, are usually the cause."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "Go to a hospital emergency room immediately if you have been exposed to a high dose of radiation in a short time, such as in a nuclear emergency."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Within minutes of radiation exposure, you may have vomiting, nausea, and diarrhea. This could last for minutes or come and go for several days. Within a few hours, your skin may be red and swollen, as if you had a bad sunburn, and some of your hair may fall out. Your skin may heal and you may feel healthy for a short time before the early symptoms return, along with fever, lack of appetite, and possibly seizures and coma. This can last for a few hours or several months. The prognosis for radiation sickness depends on the amount of radiation exposure. In severe cases, people usually die within weeks or months. For survivors, it may take up to two years to recover and up to three years for the skin to heal."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Higher doses of radiation and closer and longer exposure"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for radiation sickness may include:\n\t\t•\tRemoving radioactive materials on your body\n\t\t•\tWashing with soap and lukewarm water\n\t\t•\tMonitoring your radiation levels\n\t\t•\tTaking potassium iodide to prevent your thyroid from absorbing radioactive iodine, which can lead to thyroid cancer\n\t\t•\tTaking Prussian blue, a dye that traps radioactive particles in the intestines and keeps them from being re-absorbed by the body\n\t\t•\tInjections of DPTA (diethylenetriamine pentaacetic acid), which binds to radioactive material or poisons, helping them pass out of the body through urine\n\t\t•\tInjections of Neupogen, which stimulates white blood cell growth, to heal bone marrow damage"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "In a radiation emergency, get inside and stay inside an undamaged building. Then, if possible:\n\t\t•\tTake off clothing, shoes, and accessories and seal them in a plastic bag. Store the bag in a safe place until you can put it outside.\n\t\t•\tShower, washing your body thoroughly with soap and water.\n\t\t•\tPut on clean clothes."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "If you think you have been exposed to high-level radiation, go to the emergency room."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",

	"Seborrheic_dermatitis": [{
			"heading": "Seborrheic Dermatitis",
			"content": "Dandruff, seborrheic eczema, cradle cap"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tItching or burning\n\t\t•\tWhite specks on scalp or hair\n\t\t•\tSkin rash"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Seborrheic dermatitis is a chronic skin condition that most often affects the scalp. It causes scaly, itchy, red skin. Sometimes it also affects other areas of the skin, including the eyebrows, eyelids, nose creases, ears, and skin folds on the stomach. Doctors aren't sure what causes seborrheic dermatitis, but they think it might be caused by yeast, stress, or certain medical conditions. Seborrheic dermatitis is a chronic condition that can be treated and controlled with medication. In babies, it is called cradle cap and is a common, harmless condition."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Seborrheic dermatitis is a chronic condition. The symptoms may flare up occasionally. For many people, symptoms tend to improve in the summer and get worse in the winter. Seborrheic dermatitis on the scalp is usually treated with special shampoos. Seborrheic dermatitis on other parts of the body is treated with medications. Cradle cap in children usually clears up by age 3."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Seborrheic dermatitis affects 1% to 5% of the overall adult population."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Seborrheic dermatitis usually is treated with shampoos, cortisone creams, or antifungal medications. Severe cradle cap in babies may be treated with prescription creams."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "You can treat seborrheic dermatitis at home by shampooing daily, using over-the-counter antifungal or 1% hydrocortisone cream, avoiding harsh soaps, and shaving facial hair if it makes symptoms worse. You can treat your baby's cradle cap by massaging the scalp gently, using gentle shampoo daily, and brushing your baby's hair with a soft brush several times a day."

	"Contact_dermatitis": [{
			"heading": "Contact Dermatitis",
			"content": "Allergic dermatitis, skin allergies, dermatitis"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tItching or burning\n\t\t•\tHives\n\t\t•\tSkin irritation\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tSkin rash"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Contact dermatitis is a rash on the skin that can be itchy, painful, or tender. Sometimes it can cause blisters or swelling. Contact dermatitis is caused either by a substance that irritates the skin, or a substance that causes an allergy on the skin. Some substances that can cause contact dermatitis include soaps, perfumes, poison ivy, poison oak, rubber products, cosmetics, jewelry, and medications. In some cases, the substance causes a reaction only when the skin is exposed to sunlight. Most cases of contact dermatitis are treated with creams or oral medications."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Contact dermatitis usually happens soon after you have had contact with the substance that causes the reaction. If it is caused by an allergic reaction, the rash may take 24-48 hours to appear. You usually need to be exposed to an allergen several times before you develop contact dermatitis. This is often the case with poison ivy and poison oak. But once you develop an allergy, even a little bit of exposure will cause a reaction. In most cases, contact dermatitis clears up in about two to three weeks. You usually can avoid further contact dermatitis by avoiding the substance that causes it."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "There are millions of cases of contact dermatitis in the country every year."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Most contact dermatitis is treated with corticosteroid skin creams or other skin creams or ointments. If the rash is severe, your doctor may suggest oral medications. Some cases of contact dermatitis need no treatment."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "You can treat many cases of contact dermatitis at home with over-the-counter medications such as 1% cortisone cream and an oral antihistamine. Applying wet, cool compresses to the area or taking a cool bath can also help ease symptoms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Scratching the rash, rough clothing, and continued contact with the irritant or allergen can make the rash worse."
		},

			"content": "See your doctor if the rash does not clear up with treatment, if your rash is so uncomfortable that you can't sleep, or if you think your rash may be infected."

			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "You might be at higher risk for contact dermatitis if you often use strong detergents, solvents, or other chemicals."

			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Bee or wasp stings are a common problem, especially during the summer. Bee or wasp stings are painful but not serious for the vast majority of people. People who are allergic may have severe reactions. Very rarely, they can be fatal. Swarms of wasps or bees can be dangerous. Even in people without an allergy, the amount of venom from a very large number of stings can be life threatening."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "If you have symptoms of an allergic reaction after a sting -- such as hives, trouble breathing, or swelling of the face, tongue, lips, or throat -- or have been stung many times by a swarm, call the emergency services. If you have a prescribed dose of epinephrine for a bee or wasp allergy, use it and then seek emergency medical care."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "After stinging, honeybees leave their stingers in the body. Bumble bees and wasps, including hornets and yellow jackets, do not. Most people will have pain, swelling, or redness at the site of the sting. The symptoms usually clear up within a week. People with allergic reactions may have more severe symptoms, such as difficulty breathing, swelling in the face, and hives. They need emergency medical help."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Most people treat wasp or bee stings at home. If a bee has left its stinger in the skin, remove it. Scraping the area with a butter knife or credit card should work. Don't pinch the venom sack, since this will squeeze more venom into the body. Otherwise, treat wasp and bee stings the same way. Wash the area with soap and water. Alternate between icing the area for 10 minutes and taking the ice off for 10 minutes. Take diphenhydramine (Benadryl) antihistamine for itching. But if you have an allergy to bee or wasp venom, always carry an emergency kit with epinephrine -- use it and then get emergency medical help."

	"Dermatitis": [{
			"heading": "Dermatitis",
			"content": "Eczema"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tItching or burning\n\t\t•\tSkin redness\n\t\t•\tSkin rash"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Dermatitis is any inflammation of the skin that causes a rash. There are different kinds of dermatitis, and the rash can come from a variety of things. For instance, many illnesses, such as lupus, or some viral infections produce a rash. So can drug reactions. With contact dermatitis, the rash results from skin making contact with a substance that causes an allergic reaction, such as poison oak or ivy. Contact dermatitis may occur the first time you come in contact with a substance. It's also possible that the rash won't develop until after repeated episodes of handling what causes it."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "What you can expect depends on what causes your dermatitis. If it comes from a drug reaction, it usually will not get better until the drug has been stopped for at least a few days. Contact dermatitis can develop shortly after contact with a substance or be delayed up to 24 to 48 hours. It can be mild or severe. And in some cases it can last for weeks. If you know what causes the reaction and can avoid it, the rash will usually go away within a few days of treatment. However, if there is continued or intermittent contact with what causes it, dermatitis will continue to flare. You may have had years of contact with whatever causes it without any reaction. Then you may suddenly have a surprisingly severe reaction."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "There are millions of cases of dermatitis in the country every year."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment consists of:\n\t\t•\tDeveloping strategies to avoid whatever might be causing the dermatitis\n\t\t•\tApplying a hydrocortisone cream or some other soothing lotion to the rash several times a day\n\t\t•\tTaking an antihistamine to relieve itching\n\t\t•\tIf symptoms are severe or persist despite treatment, the doctor may prescribe oral or intravenous steroids to stop the inflammation."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "You sometimes can treat mild dermatitis yourself by using an over-the-counter cortisone cream and over-the-counter antihistamine. It also will be important to avoid contact with whatever is causing the rash. You should still discuss your condition with your doctor to be sure that the dermatitis is not being caused by a reaction to medication or some other serious problem. Don't stop taking medication on your own without talking with your doctor first."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Scratching or irritating the rash, continued contact with whatever causes the rash, or continued use of a drug or medication that might be causing it"

	"Poison_ivy/oak/sumac": [{
			"heading": "Poison Ivy, Poison Oak, Sumac",
			"content": "Rhus allergies, contact dermatitis, delayed hypersensitivity reaction"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tItching or burning\n\t\t•\tSkin rash\n\t\t•\tSkin irritation\n\t\t•\tSwelling\n\t\t•\tSkin blisters\n\t\t•\tSkin redness"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "The sap of poison ivy, poison oak and poison sumac contains a toxin called urushiol. This toxin causes an itchy, allergic rash with raised welts and blisters. While intensely uncomfortable, the rash usually clears up on its own in one to three weeks. Treatment helps relieve the symptoms. Any exposure to the oily sap -- even if it's on clothing, shoes, garden tools, sports equipment, or pets -- will cause a reaction. The rash itself, however, isn't contagious. Another person cannot get it by touching your skin."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Once you've touched poison ivy, oak, or sumac, the rash may not appear for 12 to 72 hours. It takes time for the body to react to the oil. As long as you've washed off the sap, scratching won't make the rash spread. Scratching does increase the risk of infection, so try to resist. The rash will probably be worst within the first four to seven days. It should disappear within three weeks. Rarely, poison ivy, oak, or sumac can sometimes cause a dangerous allergic reaction. Get medical help right away if you have swelling or trouble breathing."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Millions of people in the country get rashes from poison ivy, oak, and sumac every year."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "If you think you've been exposed to the sap, wash the area with soap and water right away. If you act quickly -- ideally within 30 minutes -- you might prevent the rash. Remember to wash clothing in hot, soapy water. Clean off garden tools or sports equipment with alcohol or water mixed with bleach.\n\nIf the rash develops, at-home treatments such as oatmeal baths, cool compresses, calamine lotion, cortisone and antihistamine creams, and oral antihistamines will relieve itching. To reduce the risk of infection, try not to scratch."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Scratching the rash increases the risk of infection."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "While the rash can usually be treated at home, see the doctor if blisters appear on the face, the genitals, or large areas of the body. Medical treatment will help prevent scarring. Any signs of infection -- such as pus -- should be checked out, too. If you have swelling or trouble breathing after exposure to poison ivy, oak, or sumac, get medical help right away. Anyone who has inhaled smoke from the burning plant should also get medical attention."

	"Epilepsy_(tonic_clonic_or_grand_mal_seizures)": [{
			"heading": "Epilepsy (Tonic-Clonic or Grand Mal Seizures)",
			"content": "Generalized tonic-clonic seizure, generalized seizure"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tLoss of consciousness\n\t\t•\tStool leaking (incontinence)\n\t\t•\tProlonged breathing pauses\n\t\t•\tRepetitive behaviors\n\t\t•\tBlackouts (memory time loss)\n\t\t•\tEyes rolling back\n\t\t•\tConfusion\n\t\t•\tUrine leaking (incontinence)\n\t\t•\tDisorientation\n\t\t•\tSeizures (uncontrollable jerking of limbs)\n\t\t•\tComa"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Epilepsy is a disorder of the brain. Nerve cells create unusual electrical signals that result in seizures, or convulsions. There are over 32 different kinds of seizures. But the one most people think of is the tonic-clonic seizure, also known as a grand mal seizure. It causes body rigidity and jerking. Having two or more seizures is considered epilepsy. Both epilepsy and tonic-clonic seizures can strike at any age. You can inherit epilepsy or it can be the result of brain disorders, trauma to the head, exposure to toxins, and even not sleeping enough. Medication and surgery can control most seizures."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "If you have seizures, you may need to avoid certain activities and jobs, such as driving, flying a plane, and playing contact sports. After being seizure-free after many years, some people can stop taking seizure drugs. Other people need to take them all their life. Seizures increase your risk for difficulty learning and for injuries due to falling or wounding yourself during a seizure. Pregnant women who take some anti-seizure medications may be at higher risk of having a baby with a birth defect. If you are being treated for epilepsy, it's important to let your doctor know if you are trying to get pregnant."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "More than 2 million people in the country have epilepsy or have had a seizure for an unknown reason."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatments for epilepsy include:\n\t\t•\tFixing what is causing the seizures (treating an infection, for example)\n\t\t•\tMedicines (anticonvulsants)\n\t\t•\tBrain surgery\n\t\t•\tVagal nerve stimulator (a pacemaker-like device placed in the chest to lessen the frequency of seizures)\n\t\t•\tKetogenic diet (a high-fat, low-carbohydrate diet mostly recommended for children) or a diet low in carbohydrates for adults"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "You can better manage epilepsy with these self-care tips:\n\t\t•\tTake your medicines exactly as your doctor prescribes.\n\t\t•\tGet enough rest.\n\t\t•\tAvoid anxiety.\n\t\t•\tSee your doctor regularly.\n\t\t•\tWear a medical ID bracelet so people will know how to help you if you have a seizure."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Stress, illness or infection, too little sleep, excess alcohol, taking recreational drugs, some prescription medications, being pregnant, missing doses of your epilepsy medication"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "Contact your doctor if you have epilepsy and you experience any new symptoms. They grow slowly and are filled with an oily or cheesy-looking material made of a protein called keratin. These cysts often develop in a damaged hair follicle or by a serious skin injury. Epidermal cysts are harmless, but they can be irritating and painful if they become infected."

If necessary, your doctor can easily drain the cyst or remove it surgically."

		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Lipomas are a harmless collection of fatty cells that form a lump under the skin. They are the most common soft tissue tumor and usually grow on the shoulders, back, trunk, and arms. Lipomas can occur at any age, but usually appear in people ages 40 to 60. No one knows what causes them, but they often run in families. Lipomas are almost always benign, so you don't need to have a lipoma removed unless it bothers you."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Lipomas grow slowly, so by the time you notice one, it's probably been growing for years. Most people have more than one lipoma. Lipomas that grow near a joint or over muscles can interfere with movement and cause soreness. If a lipoma causes discomfort or you don't like the way it looks, your doctor can remove it. However, most of the time, they can be left alone."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 1% of the population has at least one lipoma."

	"Marijuana_(cannibis)_use": [{
			"heading": "Marijuana (Cannibis) Use",
			"content": "Weed, herb, mary jane, mj, pot, grass, 420, ganja"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "Memory problems"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Marijuana is the dried leaves, stems, buds, or flowers of the Cannibus sativa hemp plant. It is most often smoked, but sometimes it is put into foods or brewed as tea. Most people use marijuana illegally, but some people have a prescription to use marijuana to help ease certain medical conditions. Also, the recreational use of marijuana has now been made legal in some states. Marijuana can cause feelings of euphoria, relaxation, memory problems, impaired coordination and balance, problems with sleep, and difficulty thinking. Over time, it can lead to addiction."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "If you smoke marijuana, the effects usually happen right away. If you eat the marijuana in food, it can take up to an hour to cause effects. The effects of marijuana usually last from one to three hours. In large doses, it can cause psychosis, hallucinations, and delusions. Most of the symptoms stop once the effects have worn off, but it can cause longer-term problems with memory and learning with chronic use. Although the effects of marijuana wear off after a few hours, the drug is detectable in your urine or blood for several weeks. Marijuana addiction is usually treated in a drug treatment program."
		},
		{

	"Falls_or_injury": [{
			"heading": "Falls or Injury",
			"content": "Fractures"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "Multiple bruises of different ages"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Falls can happen to anyone, but they are more common -- and more dangerous -- in older adults. Older adults tend to have weaker bones, so a minor fall can more easily cause a major injury, such as a broken hip. In fact, most fractures in older adults result from falls. Fractures most commonly occur in the hand, forearm, spine, pelvis, hip, leg, and ankle. Weak leg muscles, poor balance, slower reflexes, vision problems, alcohol use, dizziness from medication or illness, low blood pressure, foot problems, and poor footwear can lead to falls in older adults. Falls are a leading cause of injury in children, as well, and can lead to bumps, bruises, cuts, sprains, concussions, and fractures."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "Get immediate medical help if you fall from more than your height, hit your head hard enough to cause bleeding or loss of consciousness, have a severe headache, are vomiting, feel very drowsy, don't recall what happened, keep repeating yourself after hitting your head, have a bone sticking out of the skin, or are bleeding heavily. If you think you may have injured your spine, don't move, and have someone call the emergency services."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "No one expects to fall, and when you do it can be upsetting. After a fall, stay still for a few moments to catch your breath, then check to see whether you are injured. If you are not injured, roll over onto your side, and wait for a few seconds to let your blood pressure adjust. Then if you can, crawl on your hands and knees over to a sturdy chair. Once you get into the chair, make sure any dizziness has gone away before trying to stand up. If you think you've been injured, you've hit your head and briefly lost consciousness, or you can't move, call someone for help or contact the emergency services if you can reach a phone. If a child falls, hits his or her head and has lost consciousness even for a few seconds, get immediate medical help. Minor bumps, bruises, cuts, and scrapes from a fall can be treated at home."
		},

	"Burn_(heat_or_fire)": [{
			"heading": "Burn",
			"content": "Thermal burn"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tNumbness or tingling\n\t\t•\tSwelling\n\t\t•\tSkin blisters\n\t\t•\tSkin thickening\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tSkin rash\n\t\t•\tSkin redness"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Burns caused by heat are called thermal burns. Hot metals, scalding liquids, steam, and fire cause thermal burns. If you are burned, you may have pain, swelling, and blistering. In severe cases, you may go into shock or develop a serious infection or other complications. A deep or extensive burn or a burn on a critical area such as your face or hands is a medical emergency and usually requires hospital care. Most minor burns can be treated at home. Scalding causes most burns in children, while open flames cause most burns in adults."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "Call the emergency services or go to the emergency room for immediate treatment of extensive second- or third-degree burns. Also get emergency care for difficulty breathing, smoke inhalation, or loss of consciousness."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "The least severe burn is a superficial or first-degree burn, such as a mild sunburn. It penetrates only the top layer of skin and may be red, painful, and swollen but doesn't develop blisters. A partial thickness or second-degree burn penetrates two layers of skin. You may have the same symptoms along with blisters that ooze clear fluid. Quick immersion in cool (not cold) water, antibiotic cream, and protection with a sterile dressing may be enough to heal many first- and second-degree burns. Minor burns can take a few days or a few weeks to heal and don't cause scarring. Deep second-degree burns may take three weeks or longer to heal and usually cause scarring. The most severe burn is a full thickness or third-degree burn. It destroys all three layers of skin and may damage underlying muscles, tendons, and bones. Third-degree burns require hospital care, and sometimes surgery or physical therapy if scar tissue from the burn interferes with movement."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Putting butter, oil, ice, or ice water on a burn"
		},

		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "These self-care strategies can help heal a minor burn:\n\t\t•\tImmerse it in cool water for 15 minutes or until the pain subsides.\n\t\t•\tDo not put butter, ice, ice water, or oil on the burn or break blisters.\n\t\t•\tApply an over-the-counter or prescription antibiotic cream.\n\t\t•\tCover the burn with a nonstick dressing held in place with gauze or tape.\n\t\t•\tGet a tetanus shot if you are not up to date.\n\t\t•\tTake acetaminophen for pain.\n\t\t•\tClean the burn, apply antibiotic cream, and re-cover every day while healing.\n\t\t•\tDon't scratch the burn.\n\t\t•\tCheck every day for signs of infection. See your doctor if the burn becomes infected."

Doctors don't know exactly what causes RBD, but in some people it is connected to Parkinson's disease or other neurologic disorders. Alcohol or other drug or medication use can sometimes cause it. RBD is most common in men over age 50. People who have RBD may yell, swear, kick, punch, leap, or jump while sleeping. This behavior often causes injury to the person with RBD or the person's bed partner."

	"Tourette_syndrome": [{
			"heading": "Tourette's Syndrome",
			"content": "Tourette's disorder"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tRepetitive behaviors\n\t\t•\tBlinking eyes\n\t\t•\tMuscle twitching (painless)\n\t\t•\tUncontrollable verbal outbursts"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Tourette's syndrome is a nervous system disorder that causes a person to make involuntary movements or sounds called tics. For example, a person might move his head in a certain way repeatedly, or click his tongue over and over again. People with Tourette's syndrome can't stop themselves from having tics. Tics can be complex, involving several parts of the body, such as tilting the head, swinging an arm, and jumping up. Or a tic can be simple and more subtle, like sniffing repeatedly. In addition to movements, tics can also include vocalizations, such as grunting. Rarely, a person with Tourette's syndrome may shout out swear words or repeat something another person has said. Stress or certain triggers, such as a tight collar or hearing someone sniff, can make tics worse. This syndrome usually begins in childhood, and boys are affected three times more often than girls. Symptoms often improve in adolescence and early adulthood. Most people with Tourette's syndrome learn to live with their tics, but some people take medication to help control more severe symptoms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Tics often first occur in the neck or head and tend to start at age 5 to 10. Physical tics usually start before vocal tics. Severity of symptoms can vary over time. Tics may occur in different locations and in different numbers of repetitions. Tic severity usually peaks in adolescence and tends to improve in late teens and early adulthood. Many people outgrow the condition, but about 10% of people continue to have Tourette's syndrome as adults."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "3 out of every 1,000 children ages 6 to 17 in the country are diagnosed with Tourette's syndrome."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Having a parent with Tourette's syndrome"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Many people with Tourette's syndrome find ways to manage their tics and don't need treatment. When needed, treatment may include:\n\t\t•\tMedication to help suppress severe tics\n\t\t•\tBehavioral therapy and other types of therapy\n\t\t•\tTreatment for co-existing conditions such as OCD, ADHD, or depression"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Self-care for Tourette's syndrome may include:\n\t\t•\tUnderstanding your triggers\n\t\t•\tLearning how to hide, manage, or suppress tics as needed"
		},

			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",

			"heading": "Tetanus",
			"content": "Lockjaw"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tSeizures (uncontrollable jerking of limbs)\n\t\t•\tShortness of breath\n\t\t•\tMuscle cramps or spasms (painful)\n\t\t•\tJaw locking\n\t\t•\tDifficulty opening mouth\n\t\t•\tStiffness or decreased movement\n\t\t•\tDifficulty swallowing\n\t\t•\tUnable to blink or close eyelid\n\t\t•\tUnable to open mouth (jaw)\n\t\t•\tMuscle stiffness (rigidity)"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Tetanus is a potentially fatal infection caused by a toxin made by the bacterium Clostridium tetani. It's also called\"lockjaw\" because the muscles around the jaw can tighten shut, making it impossible to open your mouth or swallow. Tetanus bacteria live in soil and can enter your body through an open wound caused by a splinter, insect bite, puncture wound, or self-piercing. In the country, tetanus mostly affects older people who are not vaccinated or have not gotten booster shots. It can be treated in the hospital, but up to one in 10 people who get it die. There is no cure for tetanus, so the best treatment is prevention through vaccination."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "If you have an open wound and have never been vaccinated or haven't received a booster in the last 10 years:\n\t\t•\tGo to a hospital emergency room if the wound is large, crushed, or heavily contaminated.\n\t\t•\tGo to a hospital emergency room if you start to experience tetanus symptoms such as muscle cramps or spasms or have trouble swallowing.\n\t\t•\tAsk your doctor whether you should go to a hospital emergency room for treatment if the wound is minor."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Symptoms of the most common tetanus, generalized tetanus, usually start in the face and move down as the effect of the toxin spreads. You may first experience a stiff jaw, then stiffness in the neck, trouble swallowing, and rigid abdominal muscles. Spasms in your body muscles may last for several minutes and continue for up to four weeks, and you may develop fever and a rapid heartbeat. Tetanus convulsions can break your spine or bones. You probably will need to spend several weeks in the intensive care unit of a hospital to treat tetanus. The wound will be cleaned and you may get antibiotics, a tetanus vaccine, IV rehydration, pain medication, and sedatives. You may need a ventilator to help you breathe. Most people recover from tetanus, but complete recovery takes several months."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Tetanus gets worse without prompt treatment."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for tetanus may include:\n\t\t•\tWound cleaning and care\n\t\t•\tA tetanus and diphtheria shot (Td or Tdap) or booster\n\t\t•\tOral or IV antibiotics\n\t\t•\tTetanus antitoxin to neutralize any toxin that hasn't bonded to nerve endings\n\t\t•\tPain medication\n\t\t•\tSedatives to control muscle spasms\n\t\t•\tVentilator to help with breathing\n\t\t•\tIV rehydration"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",

	"Anaphylactic_shock": [{
			"heading": "Anaphylactic Shock",
			"content": "Anaphylaxis, serious allergic reaction"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tSense of impending doom\n\t\t•\tFeeling of not being able to get enough air\n\t\t•\tShortness of breath\n\t\t•\tWheezing\n\t\t•\tSwelling\n\t\t•\tRapid heart rate (pulse)\n\t\t•\tThroat tightness\n\t\t•\tRapid breathing"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Anaphylactic shock is a severe allergic reaction that happens quickly after exposure to a trigger (allergen) such as certain foods, medications, insect stings, or latex. It can be fatal without immediate treatment. Call the emergency services or seek immediate medical care as soon as a reaction begins. Signs of anaphylactic shock -- such as breathing troubles, hives, throat tightness, dizziness, vomiting, and lack of consciousness -- may occur within minutes to a few hours of exposure to the allergen. A shot of epinephrine (adrenaline) can stop the reaction. A doctor also may give other medications such as antihistamines or steroids. If you have anaphylaxis, the doctor may suggest that you carry an emergency kit with you to treat future attacks."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "Anaphylactic shock is an emergency. If you have severe symptoms, especially after eating, taking medication, or an insect sting, call the emergency services or go to an emergency room right away. This is critical if you have trouble breathing, low blood pressure, or have lost consciousness."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Symptoms of anaphylactic shock can begin within minutes to two hours of exposure to a trigger. They can get worse over several hours. Or they can go away and come back within a few hours. Don't wait for symptoms to get better. If you get treatment right away, you should recover completely. The doctor may give you a shot of epinephrine (adrenaline) to relieve any breathing issues or other serious problems. You may need other medications, too. Have someone stay with you for 24 hours after an attack. Your doctor may refer you to an allergist for follow-up care and to identify what triggered your reaction."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "If you have had a serious allergic reaction, the doctor will likely prescribe auto-injectable epinephrine (EpiPen or Twinject) you can give yourself in an emergency. You should carry this with you at all times. You may also need allergy shots (immunotherapy) to further reduce your risk. Make sure all your doctors and dentists know you have had anaphylactic shock."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Avoid your triggers. Don't eat or handle foods you are allergic to. Wear protective clothing and insect repellent if you are allergic to insects. If the doctor has prescribed epinephrine, always carry it with you, know how to use it, and keep it up to date. You may need to wear special jewelry that identifies your allergy."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "See an allergist (a specialist) if you have had any symptoms of allergies, especially if you have had a severe reaction."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\t\t•\tHow can I know whether or not I'm having a severe allergic reaction?\n\t\t•\tWhat can I do to prevent another attack?\n\t\t•\tShould I carry auto-injectable epinephrine with me at all times?\n\t\t•\tHow do I use my auto-injectable epinephrine?\n\t\t•\tShould I teach my friends how to use it?"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "Anaphylaxis is diagnosed by a physical exam and an evaluation of vital signs. To identify the trigger, an allergist will take blood and/or skin tests to determine the cause of the allergic reaction. You will also be asked for foods that you've eaten, medications you've taken, and about possible contact with insects and rubber products."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 50 out of 100,000 people in the country go to the emergency room for anaphylaxis each year."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Previous anaphylactic shock, family history of allergic conditions such as asthma, eczema, or hay fever, food allergies, medication allergies, insect sting allergies, latex allergy, asthma"
		}

	"Severe_allergic_reaction_(anaphylactic_shock)": [{
			"heading": "Severe Allergic Reaction (Anaphylactic Shock)",
			"content": "Anaphylaxis, anaphylactic shock"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tSense of impending doom\n\t\t•\tFeeling of not being able to get enough air\n\t\t•\tShortness of breath\n\t\t•\tWheezing\n\t\t•\tSwelling\n\t\t•\tRapid heart rate (pulse)\n\t\t•\tThroat tightness\n\t\t•\tRapid breathing"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Severe allergic reactions -- such as anaphylactic shock -- can be life threatening. In people with allergies to certain foods, medications, insect stings, latex, or other substances, the body overreacts after contact with the allergen. A severe allergic reaction may quickly cause difficulty breathing, dizziness, vomiting, and unconsciousness. Severe allergic reactions are medical emergencies -- they can be fatal without prompt treatment. Injected epinephrine can stop a severe allergic reaction. Antihistamines and steroids may also help."
		},
		{

In most cases, they are not dangerous and you can treat them at home. But some stings can cause anaphylaxis, a severe, whole-body allergic reaction that can be life- threatening and requires emergency treatment. Insect bites and stings can become infected and some can cause illnesses such as West Nile virus, malaria, and typhoid."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "How sensitive you are to an insect's venom usually determines how you respond to its bite. In many cases, you may experience pain, swelling, redness, or itching for a day or so. A wasp or yellow jacket sting is more likely to cause severe pain and infection. Cleaning and icing the area, taking over-the-counter medication, and avoiding scratching usually provide relief. But see a doctor if a bite or sting becomes infected (often from scratching), is on the tongue, or is an open wound. Also see a doctor if you don't know what bit you -- it may be from a poisonous spider. If you start to have a severe allergic reaction, such as hives, wheezing, or shortness of breath, call the emergency services. Anaphylactic shock can be fatal within 10 minutes."

			"heading": "Subconjunctival Hemorrhage (Bleeding in Eye)",
			"content": "red eye, bleeding in the eye"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tBleeding in eye\n\t\t•\tRed (bloodshot) eyes"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "A subconjunctival hemorrhage is a bright red patch in the white of the eye. It occurs when blood vessels break and bleed just below the surface of the eye. Sneezing, coughing, straining, high blood pressure, certain medications, eye injury, bleeding disorders, and even rubbing your eye can cause blood vessels to rupture. Often, there is no cause. The condition causes no pain or discharge, and you may first notice it when looking in a mirror. Most of the time, the red patch goes away within two weeks and requires no treatment."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "Get immediate medical help if you have a subconjunctival hemorrhage along with eye pain, you notice vision changes such as blurred vision, you have an eye injury, or you have a history of high blood pressure or a bleeding disorder."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "The red patch may appear to get bigger in the first 24 hours. Then it will slowly get smaller as the blood is absorbed by the body. Similar to a bruise, a subconjunctival hemorrhage changes colors -- red to orange to yellow -- as it heals. The hemorrhage should disappear completely within two weeks."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Dry eyes"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment is not needed for this condition."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Self-care includes using artificial tears to avoid irritation and avoiding aspirin and ibuprofen, which can thin the blood and cause more bleeding."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "Call your doctor if you have more than one subconjunctival hemorrhage, the condition doesn't get better in two weeks, or if you have other bleeding at the same time, such as bleeding gums or bruising."

	"Diabetic_eye_disease": [{
			"heading": "Diabetic Eye Disease",
			"content": "Diabetic retinopathy"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tBlind spot in vision\n\t\t•\tBlurred vision\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tFloating spots or strings in vision"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "People with diabetes may develop diabetic eye disease, a term for a group of eye problems. All can cause vision loss and even blindness. The most common one, diabetic retinopathy, involves damage to the blood vessels in the retina. First, blood vessels may swell and leak, although usually there is no vision loss. Eventually, in some people, abnormal blood vessels may grow on the retina and leak blood into the center of the eye, blocking vision and sometimes causing the retina to detach. People with diabetes also are more likely to have cataracts and glaucoma. Keeping your blood sugar under control and having an annual eye exam can help prevent diabetic eye disease."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Most people don't notice symptoms of diabetic retinopathy in the early stages. And sometimes even people in the late stages don't have symptoms until it is too late to treat them. Or you may have gradual vision loss and blind spots as the blood vessels in your eyes bleed and block vision. In the early stages, you may not need any treatment for diabetic retinopathy. But you may need to have eye exams more often so your doctor can track your condition and start treatment if needed. In some cases, you may need laser treatment or surgery to protect your vision."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 29% of people with diabetes who are age 40 or older have diabetic retinopathy."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "You usually can treat diabetic retinopathy by keeping your blood sugar levels under control. If your retinopathy is severe, you may need laser treatments or surgery."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "You can help keep your eyes healthy by keeping your blood sugar levels under control. Watching your cholesterol and blood pressure levels may also help."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Not controlling your blood sugar, having high blood pressure, and having high cholesterol"
