	"Glaucoma": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tBlind spot in vision\n\t\t•\tBlurred vision\n\t\t•\tNausea or vomiting\n\t\t•\tChange in vision\n\t\t•\tVisual halos around lights\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tLoss of side vision\n\t\t•\tRed (bloodshot) eyes\n\t\t•\tPartial vision loss"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Glaucoma is an eye disease that can cause vision loss. If fluid gets trapped and builds up in the eye, the pressure can damage the optic nerve. There are several types. Open-angle glaucoma is the most common; it develops slowly over years, starting with darkness at the edges of your vision. Health problems, medications, and inherited genetic conditions can cause glaucoma. For any type of glaucoma, good treatment will help prevent further vision loss."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "If you have open-angle glaucoma, you may not have symptoms for years. You may start to notice darkness on the edge of your vision that slowly gets worse over time. Treatment with eyedrops, medications, or surgery usually can stop glaucoma from progressing. Catching glaucoma early -- ideally before you have symptoms -- is key. You can't restore any vision that you've lost. Most people need ongoing treatment to prevent problems. Acute angle-closure glaucoma is a rare type of glaucoma. It has very different symptoms, such as sudden pain, blurry vision, and nausea. Without prompt treatment, it can cause blindness within days."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 4 million people in the country have glaucoma."
		},
		{

		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "If you notice any vision changes, see a doctor, and have regular checkups to detect glaucoma without symptoms. Acute angle-closure glaucoma is an emergency. If you have symptoms such as intense pain in the eye, cloudy vision, and vomiting, get to a hospital right away."

	"Optic_neuritis": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tBlind spot in vision\n\t\t•\tPain when moving eyes\n\t\t•\tPartial vision loss\n\t\t•\tVision fading of colors\n\t\t•\tTrouble distinguishing color shades\n\t\t•\tBlindness"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Optic neuritis is an inflammation of the optic nerve, which sends images from your eyes to your brain. Symptoms include eye pain, blurred vision (usually in one eye), headaches, and loss of color vision. Optic neuritis can happen on its own or it can be a symptom of multiple sclerosis or another autoimmune disease. It is most common in young people. In most cases, the symptoms go away, although some loss of vision may occur. Because optic neuritis can be associated with serious underlying conditions, it is important to see your doctor immediately."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "Call your doctor or go to an emergency room immediately if you have sudden loss of vision in one eye or any other sudden significant change in vision. This can be a symptom of a serious illness that needs immediate attention."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "If your symptoms are not associated with an underlying condition such as multiple sclerosis, you have an excellent chance of recovering completely. Vision usually returns to normal within two to three weeks. If you have an underlying condition, your prognosis depends on how well it can be controlled. Three-fourths of the people have nearly complete return of central vision. But some people may have some residual haziness."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",

			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Retinal detachment occurs when the retina pulls away from the layer of tissue in the back of the eye that supports it. This can cut the retina off from oxygen and may cause permanent vision loss if not treated. A detached retina can cause bright flashes of light in your peripheral vision, blurred vision, and floaters in the eye. Many conditions can cause retinal detachment, including an eye injury, eye surgery, diabetes, or an inflammatory disorder. Sometimes it occurs for no apparent cause."

	"Normal-tension_glaucoma": [{
			"heading": "Glaucoma (Normal Tension)",
			"content": "Low-tension glaucoma, normal pressure glaucoma"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tBlindness\n\t\t•\tChange in vision"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Glaucoma is a group of eye conditions in which fluid builds up in your eye, putting pressure on it. This eye pressure causes damage to the optic nerve, the main nerve behind the eye, and gradual vision loss. With normal-tension glaucoma, optic nerve damage and vision loss occur even though eye pressure is normal. An unusually fragile optic nerve or decreased blood flow to the optic nerve may be the cause. Normal-tension glaucoma is most common in people older than age 60. Medication, laser treatment, and conventional surgery can't cure it or restore eyesight to normal, but they can help preserve your vision."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "In the early and middle stages of normal-pressure glaucoma, you have no symptoms. After several years, you may notice small blind spots at the edge of your vision. If it is untreated, you may lose your side vision, so it will appear as if you are looking through a tunnel. Over time you could lose your straight-ahead vision and become blind, although this is rare with normal-tension glaucoma. The first treatment is usually medicated eye drops to lower eye pressure, preventing further nerve damage and vision loss. If this doesn't lower pressure enough, your ophthalmologist may suggest laser treatments, which can help reduce eye pressure for three to five years. In severe cases, you may need surgery to create an alternative channel to drain eye fluid."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Did you know?",
			"content": "\t\t•\tWomen get normal-tension glaucoma more often than men.\n\t\t•\tNormal-tension glaucoma is prevalent in Japan.\n\t\t•\tAfrican-Americans are 5 times more likely to have glaucoma than white Americans.\n\t\t•\tAbout 9 in 10 people with glaucoma are diagnosed by their eye doctors after routine eye tests."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Up to one-third of people with glaucoma have normal-pressure glaucoma."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Family history of normal-pressure glaucoma, Japanese ancestry, personal history of systemic heart disease, such as irregular heartbeat"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for normal-tension glaucoma may include:\n\t\t•\tMedicated eye drops to reduce pressure\n\t\t•\tTrabeculoplasty -- a laser treatment that allows fluid to flow better out of the eye\n\t\t•\tTrabeculectomy -- surgery to create a drainage channel to help fluid out of the eye"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Get regular eye exams with an ophthalmologist to prevent or detect glaucoma:\n\t\t•\tHave at least 1 complete eye exam between ages 20 and 29.\n\t\t•\tHave at least 2 complete eye exams between ages 30 and 39.\n\t\t•\tGet a baseline eye disease screening at age 40 and then schedule visits according to your ophthalmologist's recommendation.\n\t\t•\tGet regular eye exams every 1 or 2 years after age 65.\n\nIf you have a family history of eye problems, are an African-American older than age 40, or have diabetes or a history of eye injury, you may need eye exams more often."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "See your doctor if you have any signs of worsening vision. Otherwise, regular eye exams with an ophthalmologist can help detect normal-tension glaucoma early."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Pinkeye is redness and swelling of the membrane that lines the eyelid, called the conjunctiva. Pinkeye is usually caused by a virus. Less common causes include allergies, fungus, bacteria, certain diseases, chemicals, contact lenses, and chlamydia. Pinkeye caused by viruses or bacteria is very contagious. So it's important to wash your hands often and avoid touching your eyes. Viral pinkeye goes away on its own, usually within two weeks. Eye drops or ointment helps reduce redness and swelling as the eye heals. Antibiotic eye drops treat pinkeye caused by bacteria."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Redness, swelling, and other symptoms develop in one eye and often spread to the other eye. Symptoms are worse three to five days after first appearing. Pinkeye usually goes away in about one to two weeks. Children who have viral pinkeye may be contagious for a week. Ask your doctor when a child with pinkeye can go back to school."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Viral or bacterial infection; dry eyes from lack of tears or exposure to wind and sun; exposure to chemicals, fumes, or smoke; allergies"
		},

			"content": "Most people will have pinkeye at least once in their lifetime."

Use tissues to wipe away any discharge.\n\t\t•\tDon't share towels, wash cloths, and pillows with anyone else.\n\t\t•\tChange your pillow case every day until the infection is gone.\n\t\t•\tDon't wear eye makeup, and don't share makeup.\n\t\t•\tAsk your doctor when a child can go back to school or when you can go back to work."

			"content": "Viral pinkeye usually goes away on its own without treatment in two to three weeks. Allergy medications ease pinkeye symptoms that are due to allergies."
		},

Do not share eye drops.\n\t\t•\tNot wearing contact lenses until the infection is gone.\n\t\t•\tNot wearing a patch over your eye. Doing so can worsen the infection.\n\t\t•\tPeople with infectious pinkeye should not go to school or day care or go to work until symptoms improve."

Acute angle-closure glaucoma can cause sudden pain, redness, cloudy vision, and nausea. Most types of glaucoma are painless and develop over years. Acute angle-closure glaucoma develops within hours. Some medications and health conditions increase the risk. If you don't get treatment, you could have permanent vision loss within a day or two. Prompt treatment -- with medication and surgery -- can stop the damage."

		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Many people get foreign objects -- such as dirt, sand, or eyelashes -- in their eyes every day. Usually, these objects are small and the problem isn't serious. The eye will blink and tear up, flushing the object out on its own. Sometimes, a foreign object in the eye is an emergency. A person working in a machine shop or hammering a nail could get a metal fragment shot into the eye. This could cause permanent damage, especially if it isn't treated right away. If you have concerns about something in your eye or a child's eye, get help."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "If you have severe pain, bleeding, blurry vision, or a foreign object that is large or embedded in the eye, go to the emergency room or see an ophthalmologist immediately."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Usually, people can remove a foreign object from the eye at home. Flushing it out with water or saline solution often works. Even after it's gone, you may still have a lingering scratchy or irritated feeling. If this continues, see a doctor. If you have a large or sharp object in the eye, something actually stuck in the eye, severe pain, or blood or fluid leaking from the eye, go to the emergency room. Children who have something in their eye should always see a doctor. An expert can remove the object. Some people will need antibiotic treatments or surgery. Recovery depends on the type of injury. Scratches on the cornea usually heal quickly. More severe injuries can cause permanent vision problems."
		},

		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Look at your eye in a mirror in a well-lit room. If the foreign object is small, try flushing out the eye with water. Use a tissue or cotton swab to gently touch the object and lift it away. Don't rub or touch the eye itself. If the object is larger or stuck in the eye, don't try to move it. Bandage the eye gently -- or tape a paper cup over the eye to protect it without putting any pressure on it -- and go to the emergency room. To protect yourself, always wear safety goggles when you're at risk of getting debris in your eye."

	"Keratoconus": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tBrownish-Yellowish ring around the color of eye\n\t\t•\tDistortion of part of visual field\n\t\t•\tChange in vision\n\t\t•\tDouble vision (with one eye covered)\n\t\t•\tBlurred vision\n\t\t•\tSudden flash of lights\n\t\t•\tVisual halos around lights"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Keratoconus is an eye disease that affects the cornea -- the clear, rounded surface of the front of the eye, over the iris. It happens when the cornea gets too thin and bulges out into a cone shape. This can make your sight blurry and distorted. Glasses or contact lenses can most likely correct your vision with early to moderate keratoconus. The condition is often mild, and if so it usually stops getting worse after a while."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Experts don’t know the cause of keratoconus, but it is linked with allergies, constant eye rubbing, some diseases, and conditions like Down syndrome. It usually happens in both eyes and gets worse slowly, over 10 or 20 years. At first, you may have mildly blurred vision, or the shapes of objects may look wrong. This can be worse at night. You may also see streaks or halos around lights. Over time, you are likely to have more trouble seeing things far away. You may also get astigmatism, which can make objects look blurry and drawn out. In rare cases, your cornea may swell and become scarred."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Keratoconus is not common. About 1 in every 2,000 people get it."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Severe allergies, chronic eye rubbing, Down syndrome"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "If you have mild keratoconus, you might only need to wear glasses or soft contact lenses. If it gets worse, you may need hard, gas-permeable lenses. For most people, corrected eyesight is enough. Small plastic implants that flatten or stiffen the cornea are also an option. And a process called collagen cross-linking looks promising, too. It uses UV light and eyedrops to make the cornea stronger and to flatten it. If your cornea is scarred or you can’t wear contact lenses, you may need a corneal transplant. Your eye doctor replaces part or all of your cornea with a healthy one from a donor. Only 1 to 2 in 10 people need a transplant, and it works more than 90% of the time. With any of these treatments, you may still need eyeglasses or contact lenses."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Frequent eye checkups are a good idea. If you have allergies, ask your doctor about eyedrops to control itching."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "If your vision isn't 20/20 with eyeglasses or you need to change eyeglass prescriptions often"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tCould there be another cause for my symptoms?\n\t\t•\tDo I have keratoconus in both eyes?\n\t\t•\tDo I need treatment?\n\t\t•\tIs keratoconus treatment the same for both eyes?\n\t\t•\tDoes keratoconus always get worse?"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "Your eye doctor may diagnose keratoconus during a routine exam using a slit lamp or other equipment. A keratometer can shine light on the cornea to measure its shape. Corneal mapping uses photos to create a 3-D image of the cornea."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Rubbing your eyes, laser surgery such as LASIK"
		}

		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "A black eye usually results from a blow to the face. It's not an injury to the eye itself. Blood vessels in the skin break and the blood pools around the eye, causing swelling, pain, and red, yellow, purple, or brown bruising. While black eyes may look severe, they are common and rarely a sign of serious problem. Like any bruise, they usually heal on their own in a few days or a week. Black eyes may occur along with more serious injuries that need medical attention. Anyone with a black eye and vision changes or eye bleeding needs help right away."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "A person doesn't need to be hit on the eye socket to develop a black eye. A blow to the forehead or nose could cause a black eye, because gravity pulls the blood down to the skin around the eye. A black eye may start out looking red but will gradually turn into a darker bruise. Ice will reduce swelling. Acetaminophen may help with pain. Anyone with an injury to the eye should be seen by a doctor as soon as possible.\"Raccoon eyes\" -- two black eyes – that occur after being hit on the back of the head may signal a very serious skull fracture, and should be checked out right away by a doctor."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Black eyes are extremely common. The good news is that about 90% of all eye injuries can be prevented."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatments for black eyes include:\n\t\t•\tApplying cold compresses or ice wrapped in a cloth on and off for 24 to 48 hours\n\t\t•\tAcetaminophen for pain.\n\t\t•\tAvoid aspirin and NSAID's, such as ibuprofen, because they can increase bleeding.\n\t\t•\tRest"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "People can usually treat a black eye at home with cold compresses or ice wrapped in a cloth. Be careful not to press on the eye itself. Over-the-counter acetaminophen may help with any pain. Don't use aspirin, since it could increase the risk of bleeding. Prop your head up when you lie down to prevent blood from pooling around the eye."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Not icing the area after the injury, blood thinners, aspirin"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "If you have a black eye or head injury, it's a good idea to see a doctor to be checked out as soon as possible. If you have a black eye with a fever, call a doctor right away. Anyone with a black eye and vision problems, vision loss, confusion, difficulty moving the eye, fluid or blood draining from the ears or nose, bleeding in the eye, or severe pain or headache needs to go to the emergency room."
		},

	"Cataracts": [{
			"heading": "Cataracts",
			"content": "Lens opacity"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "Change in vision\n\t\t•\tVision fading of colors\n\t\t•\tDecreased night vision\n\t\t•\tVisual halos around lights\n\t\t•\tCloudy vision\n\t\t•\tFrequent changes in eye glass prescription\n\t\t•\tSensitive to light\n\t\t•\tDouble vision (with one eye covered)"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "A cataract is a cloudy area in the lens of the eye. It can cause blurry or dim vision. Cataracts are a common problem, especially in people over age 55. Less often, they can occur in younger people. Very rarely, babies are born with cataracts. A number of conditions increase the risk of cataracts, including eye injuries, glaucoma, and diabetes. Most people with cataracts have them in both eyes, although one is often worse than the other. Worldwide, cataracts are a frequent cause of blindness. Surgery for cataracts works well and improves vision in the vast majority of people."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Most people develop cataracts slowly after middle age. They may have a patch of cloudy vision that expands over years or decades. In some cases, the lens takes on a yellow or brown tint. Since the vision worsens so slowly, people may not notice cataracts for years. Cataracts only need treatment if they are interfering with vision. New glasses may help with mild cataracts. The most common treatment for cataracts is surgery to remove the cloudy lens and, usually, replace it with an artificial lens. Surgery improves vision in 90% of people."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 20.5 million people over age 40 in the U.S. have cataracts."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",

		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatments for cataracts include:\n\t\t•\tNew eyeglasses that magnify vision or cut down on glare\n\t\t•\tSurgery to remove the cloudy lens and, in most cases, replace it with an artificial lens"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Home treatments won't cure cataracts. Wearing sunglasses and a wide-brimmed hat can help delay or prevent cataracts. Eating a healthy diet with lots of leafy green vegetables may help reduce the risk of developing cataracts."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Botulism is a serious but rare illness caused by a bacterium called Clostridium botulinum. You can get it in an open wound or from eating foods that are not preserved properly. Infants under age 1 can get it by eating raw honey or corn syrup. The most common causes of food-borne botulism in adults are home-canned vegetables, cured ham, and raw or smoked fish. Botulism can cause abdominal cramps, difficulty breathing, dry mouth, nausea, difficulty swallowing, blurred vision, and weakness in adults. In infants, botulism can cause weakness, constipation, poor feeding, loss of muscle tone, and a weak cry."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "Seek emergency care if you have any symptoms of botulism poisoning."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "The symptoms of botulism poisoning usually begin about 8 to 36 hours after eating contaminated food. Botulism poisoning is a medical emergency and needs treatment right away to prevent serious complications and death. It is usually treated with an antitoxin to stop the spread of the toxin in the body. The earlier this treatment is given, the more effective it is. Other treatments may include IV fluids, a breathing tube, or a breathing machine. Even with treatment, botulism poisoning can cause breathing complications and paralysis that need medical treatment for several months."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Dry eye syndrome happens when the eye can't make tears to coat itself or when tears aren't the right consistency and dry too fast. The eye's surface may also become swollen. Dry eye syndrome can be the result of some medicines, pregnancy, allergies, and conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis. You can develop dry eye syndrome even if you're healthy, and you're more likely to have it as you get older because you make fewer tears as you age. Dry eye syndrome can cause pain, blurred vision, redness, light sensitivity, and often makes reading unpleasant. It can be either temporary or long-term. Eyedrops or medications may ease dry eye syndrome. In severe cases, doctors may suggest surgery. Without proper care, dry eye syndrome can cause eye damage and vision loss."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Many people find that dry eye syndrome is mostly annoying, making watching TV, looking at a computer screen, and driving uncomfortable. In severe cases, you can get an infection if the surface of your eye becomes very dry. You usually can ease symptoms with eyedrops. Without treatment, there may be scarring or injury to the eye, possibly leading to blindness."

			"heading": "Symptoms",

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Sjogren's syndrome is an autoimmune disorder -- meaning your immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue -- that most often causes dry eyes and dry mouth. It also can cause vaginal dryness, joint pain, skin rashes, and fatigue. It is an autoimmune disorder in which the immune system attacks the tear and saliva ducts. Women over age 40 and people who have rheumatoid arthritis, scleroderma, or lupus are more likely to have Sjogren's syndrome."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Sjogren's syndrome first affects the moisture-producing glands of your mouth and eyes. Most people with Sjogren's syndrome have symptoms that just affect their eyes and mouth. This can lead to problems with vision and dental health. People with Sjogren's are more prone to get cavities. But in some cases, Sjogren's syndrome can affect other organs, including the lungs, liver, kidneys, blood, nerves, and brain. In rare cases, this can cause more serious infections and complications. There is no cure for Sjogren's syndrome. It usually is treated by replacing moisture in the areas affected. Some people need to take medication or have surgery."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "1 to 4 million people in the U.S. have Sjogren's syndrome."

			"content": "Adie's pupil is a rare disorder that occurs when the pupil does not widen and contract normally, causing blurry or distorted vision in the eye. The condition usually affects just one eye, although there are cases when both pupils are abnormal. It often makes one pupil appear larger than the other. People with Adie's pupil also may have impaired reflexes in their knees and ankles."
		},

			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Wearing contact lenses can be a convenient alternative to eyeglasses, but sometimes they can cause eye discomfort, irritation, or infection. Contact lenses are more likely to cause problems if you don't care for them properly, wear them too much, or are sensitive to saline solution. Often you can relieve eye discomfort by using prescription eyedrops or taking a break from wearing your lenses. Getting regular eye exams and practicing good hygiene habits can help prevent eye trouble in the first place."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Sometimes simply taking out your contact lenses and rinsing them with solution before putting them back in may help your eyes feel better. But if your eyes keep bothering you, it could also be a sign of a more serious condition, such as an eye infection. That could lead to open sores in the cornea (corneal ulcers). Other complications include scratches on the cornea; inflammation of the conjunctiva, a clear membrane that lies over the white portion of the eye (conjunctivitis); and blindness. Always see your eye doctor if eye irritation is severe or lasts for several days after you have taken out your contact lenses."

This causes nasal congestion, itchy eyes, runny nose, and other symptoms. Hay fever occurs most often in spring. Symptoms tend to last a few weeks but may continue into summer or fall if you have other allergies, such as grass pollen or leaf mold. Medications to reduce swelling and inflammation and keep nasal passages clear relieve hay fever symptoms and may help prevent sinus infections."

		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Hay fever usually comes on in early spring and may continue through the fall or longer, depending on the type of allergy. Trees flower in the spring, grass pollinates in spring and summer, and weeds release pollen in late summer and fall. Symptoms improve once the plant stops pollinating. Runny nose, itchiness, congestion, tiredness, and other allergy symptoms interfere with daily life. Ongoing symptoms can lead to health problems such as sinus infections, nasal polyps, and ear infections in children. Using antihistamines, decongestants, and nasal sprays helps relieve hay fever."

	"Dry_eyes": [{
			"heading": "Dry Eyes",
			"content": "Dry eye syndrome"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tEye irritation\n\t\t•\tDischarge or mucus in eyes\n\t\t•\tGritty or scratchy eyes\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tItching or burning"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Dry eyes occur when the eye either doesn't produce enough tears or the tears lack the right balance of oil, water, and mucus -- the combination of components that help nourish and lubricate the eye. The condition may cause a gritty sensation, pain, light sensitivity, burning, and stinging. Age, certain medications, medical conditions, dry air, smoking, and hormonal changes in women can all lead to dry eyes. If you have dry eyes most of the time, it's called\"dry eye syndrome.\" You can relieve dry eyes by using artificial tears or eye ointments, not smoking, blinking more often, and using a humidifier. If these approaches don't work, prescription eyedrops or having a procedure to block the tear ducts can effectively treat dry eyes."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Dry eyes can cause grittiness, eye redness, burning, pain, and light sensitivity. Having dry eyes makes it uncomfortable to wear contacts. Left untreated, dry eyes can cause tiny abrasions on the front of the eye and make it hard to see. Some people with dry eyes actually have excess tears. This happens when your eyes don't make enough oil and mucus, allowing the water from tears to drain from the eyes. You can help relieve your symptoms by using artificial tears or eye ointments, remembering to blink more often, not smoking, and using a humidifier. For more serious cases of dry eyes, prescription medications can help the eyes produce more tears. Another treatment involves placing a plug in the tear duct to help keep tears in the eye longer."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 10% to 30% of people in the U.S. have dry eyes.\n\nAn estimated 25 million to 30 million people in the U.S. have dry eye syndrome."

		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Blepharitis is an inflammation of the eyelids, usually where the eyelashes are. Symptoms include redness, irritation, itchy eyelids, and crustiness on the eyelids. Bacteria, scalp dandruff, and rosacea can cause blepharitis. It is not contagious and usually doesn't cause vision problems. Carefully washing your eyelids with warm water and a baby shampoo may be enough to treat the symptoms. If your doctor suspects a bacterial infection, he may recommend a topical antibiotic. For stubborn cases, your doctor may prescribe anti-inflammatory eyedrops."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Treating blepharitis involves careful hygiene to keep eyelids clean. Good hygiene is often enough to make the symptoms go away. Blepharitis seldom goes away completely, however. Even with successful treatment, it can return from time to time."

Using a clean cloth for each eyelid, rub the solution back and forth over your closed eyelid and eyelashes. Rinse with cold water. If the inflammation persists, see your doctor."

Eye allergies often appear along with nasal allergies, or hay fever. While they're generally not a serious medical problem, eye allergies can be frustrating and uncomfortable. Treatment with eye drops and oral medications will help."

Treatment with eyedrops and oral medications will ease the symptoms or help stop the underlying allergic reaction. Allergy shots may cut down on symptoms over time. Try to reduce contact with possible allergens if you can. If you have eye allergy symptoms and haven't had allergies before, see a doctor. You may have an infection that needs treatment."

	"Lazy_eye": [{
			"heading": "Lazy Eye",
			"content": "Amblyopia"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tEyes do not track together\n\t\t•\tDrooping eyelid\n\t\t•\tFrequent squinting\n\t\t•\tTilts head to look at something"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Lazy eye occurs when the brain favors one eye over the other. Although both eyes are healthy, the brain begins to pay attention to information from just one. The condition can occur when a child's eyes are crossed or when one eye has much sharper vision than the other. It typically shows up before age 8. The sooner the problem is diagnosed, the easier it is to treat. Treatment consists of blocking the good eye from seeing, so the brain is forced to use the weaker eye."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Most children recover vision in the weak eye and see normally. In some cases, treatment may have to be repeated if the brain again begins to favor one eye over the other."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Lazy eye affects about two to three out of every 100 children."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Crossed eyes, poor vision in one eye, being born prematurely, and having a family history of lazy eye"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "The goal of treatment is to strengthen the lazy eye by forcing the brain to use it. To do this, your doctor may recommend that your child wear an eye patch over the good eye, or that you use eye drops to blur vision from the good eye. Before treatment, your doctor may correct poor vision in the lazy eye by prescribing glasses. In some cases, eye exercises are used to teach the two eyes to work together. If your child has lazy eye because of crossed eyes, surgery may be necessary to straighten the eyes."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Young children may be uncomfortable with having to wear a patch over one eye. But the success of treatment depends on forcing the weak eye to see. As a parent, the most important thing you can do is try to help your child follow your eye doctor's instructions."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tDoes my child have lazy eye?\n\t\t•\tIs there an underlying cause?\n\t\t•\tWhat treatment do you recommend to strengthen the lazy eye?\n\t\t•\tWhat can I do to make sure the treatment is effective?\n\t\t•\tHow long will it take before my child sees normally again?\n\t\t•\tHow often should my child's vision be checked?\n\t\t•\tWill my child recover full and normal vision?"
		},

			"heading": "Diagnosed By",

	"Wernicke_syndrome": [{
			"heading": "Wernicke's syndrome",
			"content": "Wernicke's encephalopathy, Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tEyes do not track together\n\t\t•\tNumbness or tingling"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Wernicke's encephalopathy is a serious brain condition caused by long-term thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency. It most often occurs in alcoholics, but more rarely it can also happen to those who have chemotherapy treatment, chronic vomiting, an eating disorder, or bariatric surgery. Wernicke's encephalopathy can cause confusion, lack of muscle coordination, and vision problems. It usually leads to another chronic condition, called Korsakoff syndrome, which causes memory loss. When the two happen together, it's called Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Wernicke's encephalopathy causes damage to the thalamus and hypothalamus in the brain. You can often slow or reverse this brain damage if you get early treatment. Wernicke's encephalopathy usually leads to another condition called Korsakoff syndrome, which can cause chronic memory problems. Some people are able to regain their memory loss when they are treated promptly. Without treatment, these conditions get worse and can cause death. Wernicke's encephalopathy and Korsakoff syndrome are both treated with thiamine (vitamin B1). Some people need treatment in the hospital."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 1% to 3% of people have Wernicke's encephalopathy."

	"Diabetic_neuropathy": [{
			"heading": "Diabetic Neuropathy",
			"content": "Peripheral neuropathy (nerve damage of the feet and hands)"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tEyes do not track together\n\t\t•\tNumbness or tingling\n\t\t•\tDifficulty walking"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Diabetic neuropathy is nerve damage caused by high blood sugar levels. It is a common condition in people who have diabetes. The nerve damage can cause the muscles in your arms and legs to feel weak or numb. This numbness may lead to falls, injuries, and clumsiness. People with diabetes also can have nerve damage in other organs, including the heart, stomach, eyes, sex organs, and intestines. This can cause bladder problems, constipation, diarrhea, indigestion, increased heart rate, sexual problems, and vision problems."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Diabetic neuropathy usually develops over many years. The type of symptoms you have depends on what nerves are damaged. The first symptom is often tingling, numbness, or pain in the feet. If you have nerve damage in your digestive system, you may have constipation, diarrhea, or vomiting. If the nerve damage is in your bladder or sex organs, you may have difficulty with urination or sexual function. When nerves in your eyes are damaged, you may have vision problems. There is no cure for diabetic neuropathy. But keeping your blood sugar levels under tight control and taking medications can help treat the symptoms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 50% of people with diabetes develop neuropathy."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "You may have a higher risk of diabetic neuropathy if you:\n\t\t•\tHave had diabetes for 25 years or longer\n\t\t•\tSmoke\n\t\t•\tHave not had good blood sugar control\n\t\t•\tHave kidney disease"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "The first treatment for neuropathy is to try to get your blood sugars under control. Other treatments may include:\n\t\t•\tMedications and other treatments to relieve nerve pain\n\t\t•\tAntidepressants\n\t\t•\tAntiseizure medications\n\t\t•\tTreatments for any specific symptoms you have"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "You can help keep your nerve damage from getting worse by keeping your blood sugar levels and blood pressure under control, getting exercise, and not smoking."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "See your doctor if you have any signs of diabetic eye disease, even if you have not been diagnosed with diabetes."

	"Myasthenia_gravis": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tEyes do not track together\n\t\t•\tFatigue\n\t\t•\tDifficulty swallowing\n\t\t•\tDrooping eyelid\n\t\t•\tUnusual facial expression\n\t\t•\tWeakness\n\t\t•\tShortness of breath\n\t\t•\tUnable to blink or close eyelid\n\t\t•\tDifficulty talking"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Myasthenia gravis is caused by abnormal immune responses that weaken muscles. Most commonly affected are the muscles that control the eyes and eyelids, facial expressions, and chewing and swallowing. Up to 20% of people with this disease will have an acute crisis, when muscle weakness makes it difficult for them to breathe. Fortunately, drugs can reduce muscle weakness and suppress abnormal immune responses in myasthenia gravis. Treatments can also remove abnormal antibodies from the blood. Most people diagnosed with myasthenia gravis go on to lead normal lives."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Many people have only mild or moderate symptoms. In some people, symptoms go away on their own, even without treatment. But as many as 20% of people with myasthenia gravis experience a myasthenic crisis, when muscle weakness suddenly makes it hard to breathe. This medical emergency typically occurs within the first two years of diagnosis. Thanks to current treatments, most people recover. Some people experience remissions and can stop taking medication for myasthenia gravis."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Approximately 20 out of 100,000 individuals in the U.S. are diagnosed with myasthenia gravis. The prevalence has increased over the past 20 years because people are living longer and the disease is diagnosed earlier."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Your doctor may prescribe a medication that improves nerve signals to muscles and increases muscle strength. Some patients also benefit from drugs that suppress the immune system's production of abnormal antibodies. Other treatments include:\n\t\t•\tSurgery to remove the thymus gland, called a thymectomy\n\t\t•\tPlasmapheresis, a procedure used to remove abnormal antibodies from the blood Intravenous immune globulin, which prevents the immune system from damaging nerves\n\nNearly 10% to 15% of people with myasthenia gravis symptoms have a tumor of the thymus gland, which is part of the immune system. The tumor should be removed to avoid malignancy."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "To help improve overall energy and muscle strength:\n\t\t•\tGet plenty of sleep.\n\t\t•\tTake rests during the day.\n\t\t•\tEat a healthy diet.\n\t\t•\tBudget your energy.\n\t\t•\t"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "Call your doctor if you develop any persistent muscle weakness or any of the specific symptoms of myasthenia gravis. Myasthenia gravis can be life-threatening when weakness suddenly disrupts the muscles that control breathing. This medical emergency is called a myasthenic crisis. It can be triggered by infection, fever, or a bad reaction to medication. Call emergency services immediately if you or someone you are with experiences severe difficulty breathing."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tHow do you tell if my symptoms are caused by myasthenia gravis?\n\t\t•\tCould a tumor in my thymus be causing the symptoms?\n\t\t•\tWhat medications do you recommend?\n\t\t•\tWould surgery to remove my thymus gland help?\n\t\t•\tHow long will I have to take medication?\n\t\t•\tWill my symptoms go away?"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "Doctors use several blood tests to diagnose myasthenia gravis. One test looks for acetylcholine receptor antibody, which is present in about 85% of patients. Another test looks for anti-MuSK antibody, which is present in the remaining 15% of myasthenia gravis patients. Your doctor also may perform tests to assess your muscle strength and nerve activity."
		},

			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Overdoing physical activity, becoming overly tired, and lack of sleep can make myasthenia gravis symptoms worse."

	"Benign_eye_floaters": [{
			"heading": "Benign Eye Floaters",
			"content": "Eye floaters, vitreous floaters"

			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tFloating spots or strings in vision"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Benign eye floaters are tiny floating specks or cobwebs in your vision. Most people have floaters as they age. Floaters are caused when the vitreous, a gel-like substance in the eye, starts to shrink. As it shrinks, the vitreous gets stringy. These stringy pieces can cast shadows on the retina, causing the floaters. In most cases, floaters are a normal part of aging."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Many people have floaters without even noticing them. You may notice them more when you're looking at something bright. Most floaters eventually settle to the lower part of the vitreous cavity where you don't see them. In most cases, floaters don't need any treatment."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Millions of people have eye floaters."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",

		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "A vitreous detachment can cause a lot of new floaters to suddenly appear. This is when a section of the vitreous pulls away from the retina. In most cases, this doesn't cause any problems with sight."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "See your doctor if you have a sudden increase in floaters. Seek medical care right away if you have an increase in floaters along with flashes of light or loss of your peripheral vision. This could be caused by a retinal detachment, which can lead to blindness if it is not treated."

Chronic exposure to dust at work such as dust from rock, wood, metal, coal, grain, silica, and asbestos can have serious health consequences."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "If you have allergies to particles in dust, reducing exposure and treatment with antihistamines and other allergy medications will help. While the body has natural defenses against dust, large quantities and chronic exposure will overwhelm them. People who inhale dust at work may be at higher risk for occupational asthma and interstitial lung disease. Miners and other workers can develop pneumoconiosis, such as black lung. To protect yourself, you may need a respirator or goggles. Some diseases such as histoplasmosis, psittacosis, and hantavirus are transmitted by inhaling dust."

		},

Use a Neti pot to flush out the nasal passages and remove allergens. Enclose your pillows and mattress in plastic or vinyl, which helps prevent dust mites. Use a dehumidifier. Masks or respirators may keep out allergens and other dust particles and may be useful while cleaning. Try to limit exposure to dust at work. If you smoke, quit."

	"Rosacea": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tItching or burning\n\t\t•\tSkin redness\n\t\t•\tSkin rash\n\t\t•\tFlushed skin"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Rosacea is a chronic skin condition that can cause redness, broken blood vessels, a rash similar to acne, or thickened skin on the face. It usually appears on the cheeks, nose, forehead, or eyelids. It's more common in women and in people between ages 30 and 50. Being fair-skinned increases the risk. Rosacea is not medically serious, but it can be frustrating and hurt a person's self-esteem. There is no cure, but treatments and avoiding triggers may help control the symptoms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Rosacea often starts with a tendency to blush. Some people develop only minor redness. Others have acne-like symptoms or bloodshot eyes. Symptoms may get worse over time or gradually fade. Topical creams and oral antibiotics can help control some symptoms. Avoiding triggers -- which vary from person to person but often include getting overheated, stress, alcohol, hot drinks, and spicy foods -- may reduce flares. Untreated rosacea is likely to get worse."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 16 million people in the U.S. have rosacea."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Being a woman, being fair-skinned, having a family member with rosacea, acne, eye problems such as keratitis and blepharitis, blushing easily"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatments for rosacea include:\n\t\t•\tAvoiding triggers\n\t\t•\tOral or topical antibiotics for acne-like symptoms\n\t\t•\tOther medications, such as isoretinol"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Since avoiding triggers is important, keep a symptom diary. You may notice a connection between your symptoms and certain foods, activities, and weather. Getting sweaty and hot is a common trigger. Try to exercise when it's cool or use a fan when working out inside. Wash your face with lukewarm water and a gentle facial cleanser. Use sunscreen with an SPF of 15 or higher whenever you're outside. Reduce stress with deep breathing exercises, yoga, or meditation. Many people use lotions and make-up to cover redness from rosacea."
		},

	"Chalazion": [{
			"heading": "Chalazion",
			"content": "Meibomian cyst, lump in eyelid, eyelid cyst"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tLump or bulge\n\t\t•\tSkin bumps"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "A chalazion is a lump in the eyelid, caused when the drainage duct of an oil gland gets blocked. The blockage creates a lump that can become red and painful. Usually chalazions go away on their own. If not, your doctor may prescribe antibiotics or drain the lump and reduce the swelling."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "A chalazion often goes away on its own. Warm compresses may help. If not, or if it comes back, your doctor may recommend antibiotics or an anti-inflammatory drug. Very stubborn chalazions can be drained or removed surgically. The simple operation is done through an incision on the inside of the lid, leaving no visible scar. If a chalazion comes back in the same place, your doctor may suggest a biopsy to rule out a more serious problem."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "There are no official statistics. But chalazions are considered common."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Your doctor may recommend applying warm compresses for five to 10 minutes, four to six times per day, to reduce swelling and encourage the gland to drain. You may be prescribed antibiotic eye drops or an ointment if a bacterial infection is suspected, or inject a steroid medication in the area of the lump to reduce inflammation. If these treatments don't help, an ophthalmologist can drain the chalazion or remove it through a tiny incision on the inside of your eyelid."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Warm compresses applied to the eyelid help reduce swelling and clear the blocked duct. A compress can be made from a washcloth immersed in warm water. Apply five to 10 minutes, four to six times a day. Lightly massaging the area also may help."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Trying to burst a chalazion or scratching it can make it redder and more painful."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",

This can happen from the sun or other strong sources of ultraviolet light, such as a sun lamp, a welder’s torch, flood lamps, or a halogen lamp. Corneal flash burns can cause pain, bloodshot eyes, tearing, blurry vision, sensitivity to light, or a feeling that there’s something in your eyes. In most cases, your eyes will heal in a few days if you protect them from any further damage."

The cornea usually gets better in 1 to 2 days."

An attack of iritis usually comes on quickly. It typically affects only one eye. Untreated, iritis can cause cataracts, glaucoma, and permanent vision loss. With prompt treatment, the symptoms clear up without affecting vision in most cases."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",

			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Most acute attacks of iritis go away in one to two weeks with proper treatment. Some cases may take much longer to heal. Relapses can occur, so your doctor will follow your condition closely. Once the inflammation goes away, your doctor may ask to see you on a regular basis. If you are at risk of having chronic iritis, you may be given steroid eyedrops to use at the first sign of a recurrence. Chronic iritis can cause permanent damage."

			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tPuffy eyelids\n\t\t•\tWeakness\n\t\t•\tSkin rash\n\t\t•\tJoint pain\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tStiffness or decreased movement\n\t\t•\tDifficulty swallowing"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Dermatomyositis is a rare condition that causes muscle swelling, muscle weakness, and a patchy, reddish-purple rash on the face, eyelids, and joints. It's most common in children between ages 5 and 15 and in adults between ages 40 and 60. Cancer, lupus, rheumatoid arthritis, and other conditions may increase the risk. There is no cure, but ongoing treatment usually helps control the symptoms. Dermatomyositis can be life-threatening. Not getting prompt treatment increases the risks. Keep in mind that more common and less serious conditions can cause some of the same symptoms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "The muscle weakness may come on suddenly or gradually. It may be hard to get up from a chair or lift your arms over your head. The reddish-purple rash may appear before, during, or after the muscle symptoms. Ongoing treatment with steroids and drugs that suppress the immune system should help. Some people have periods of remission when the symptoms go away. Dermatomyositis may lead to severe lung complications and is associated with cancer."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Dermatomyositis is rare, with an estimated 1 to 10 cases in a million for adults and 3.2 cases per million among children."

		},

			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Dermatomyositis always needs medical treatment. Your doctor may also recommend that you exercise regularly to keep your muscles strong. 			"heading": "Blepharitis",
			"content": "Eyelid infection or inflammation"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "Red (bloodshot) eyes\n\t\t•\tSkin redness\n\t\t•\tSkin rash\n\t\t•\tFlaking skin"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Blepharitis causes swollen, red, itchy, and crusty eyelids. Bacteria in the follicles of the eyelid -- where the eyelashes grow -- usually trigger it. Dandruff, pink eye, rosacea, cosmetics, allergies, lice, and problems with the eye's oil glands can cause it, too. Blepharitis is not contagious and rarely serious. However, blepharitis often becomes a chronic problem."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "If you have an infection, you may need antibiotics to get it under control. Blepharitis can cause styes or chalazia, lumps, or bumps on the eyelid. Some eyelashes may fall out. If left untreated, blepharitis increases the risk of eye damage. Many people have recurring blepharitis. Washing your eyelids daily can help stop blepharitis from coming back."

	"Atopic_dermatitis": [{
			"heading": "Atopic Dermatitis",
			"content": "Eczema"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tScaley skin on eyelids\n\t\t•\tSkin rash\n\t\t•\tSkin thickening\n\t\t•\tSkin hardening\n\t\t•\tItching or burning\n\t\t•\tSkin irritation\n\t\t•\tSkin darkening"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Atopic dermatitis is a common skin disease that appears most often during the first year of life. Though it can be a lifelong problem, it is uncommon for a person to develop it first as an adult. People who have asthma, hay fever, or atopic dermatitis often pass atopic dermatitis on to their children. Many children who have atopic dermatitis go on to develop hay fever and asthma. Atopic dermatitis shows up as red, scaly patches that are extremely itchy. Irritants and allergens can make it worse. Medications and lifestyle changes help make it better."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Atopic dermatitis may appear in children as early as 2 or 3 months of age. In some children, it gets better and then comes back in the teen or adult years. About half of kids go on to have it as an adult, though it is usually milder with age. If it goes away entirely, you may have extremely dry skin. How large an area it covers, how much you scratch it, and whether it becomes infected determine the severity of atopic dermatitis. You may be able to clear up a small patch of mild atopic dermatitis just with moisturizing. A large, very itchy, severe patch will need the care of a dermatologist. A skin patch can help determine if a specific allergen or irritant causes it to flare. Atopic dermatitis can go into remission for months or years. Treating it early may make it less severe. Atopic dermatitis may make children restless and irritable. Children may get a rash in the creases of elbows or knees, around the mouth, or on their wrists, neck, or ankles. They may lick their lips a lot if they have inflammation around the mouth, causing painful cracks. In adults, it also can appear in creases, on the face, or as a rash all over the body. Sensitivity to allergens like dust mites or foods or to irritants such as cigarette smoke, wool clothing, perfume, or chlorine can make it flare in adults. A child who has atopic dermatitis has about a 50% chance of having it as an adult, although it may get milder with age."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "As many as 20% of children and 3% of adults have atopic dermatitis."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment may include:\n\t\t•\tDeveloping a special skin care routine\n\t\t•\tReducing exposure to allergens\n\t\t•\tCorticosteroid cream or ointment\n\t\t•\tOral corticosteroids\n\t\t•\tAntibiotics (for infection)\n\t\t•\tAntihistamines\n\t\t•\tMedications to suppress the immune system\n\t\t•\tUltraviolet light therapy"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Self-care strategies include:\n\t\t•\tShowering or bathing in lukewarm water, using mild soap\n\t\t•\tMoisturizing the skin frequently, especially right after bath\n\t\t•\tKeeping fingernails short\n\t\t•\tWearing cotton clothing\n\t\t•\tAvoiding triggers\n\t\t•\tTaking an antihistamine at night to prevent scratching\n\t\t•\tTreating skin infections promptly\n\t\t•\tAvoiding getting overheated\n\t\t•\tAvoiding stress"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Emotional factors (such as stress, anger, or major life changes), skin irritants, exposure to allergens, humidity or dryness, and bacterial infections."

	"Synaesthesia": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tSee letters, numbers or musical notes as colors\n\t\t•\tTaste words when they are heard"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Synesthesia is a harmless condition in which the senses -- sight, hearing, touch, smell, and taste -- merge in unusual ways. A person with synesthesia may see letters in specific colors. A word may taste salty. A headache may smell like cheese. Synesthesia is unintentional and consistent. People with synesthesia don't consciously imagine these things -- they feel real. A person might see a certain color when they see a letter of the alphabet -- the color red in response in the letter\"A,\" for example. Most people with synesthesia have had it since birth, although it can sometimes develop after a brain injury or drug use."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Some people have one type of synesthesia. Others have more than one -- letters may have colors and words may have tastes. Synesthesia tends to run in families. Many people with the condition don't realize that they have it -- they don't realize that they perceive things differently. Although the condition is harmless, people may find the amount of sensory input exhausting. Some with synesthesia say they were teased as children when they talked about it. There is no treatment. However, experts say that most people with synesthesia would not want to lose it. Some describe it as a gift that enriches their perception, like an additional sense. Many artists with synesthesia have used their distinct perspective in their work."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Estimates vary widely. Some studies have found that 1 in 20 people have some degree of synesthesia. Others put the odds at 1 in 100,000."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Risk factors include a family history of synesthesia. Hallucinogenic drugs can cause temporary synesthesia. Strokes and epileptic seizures can sometimes cause simpler forms of synesthesia."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Synesthesia is not really a medical condition and there is no treatment. If it causes any problems, talking to a therapist may be helpful."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "If you have symptoms of synesthesia and they bother you, talk about them with a doctor. If you have any sudden changes in your perception or understanding, such as distortions, blind spots, and difficulty understanding, go to the emergency room."

			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "Your doctor will examine you and ask questions."
		}

It can be caused by injury to a nerve, injury to an artery in the brain, stroke, migraine headaches, aortic aneurysm, or a tumor, among other things. In rare cases, a baby can have it at birth. Horner syndrome can cause a drooping eyelid, decreased sweating, and a small pupil in the eye. It usually only occurs on one side of the face. Treatment is usually aimed at the underlying cause of Horner syndrome."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Smoke exposure can occur when you're around burning cigarettes, pipes, and cigars, as well wood-burning stoves and fires. Smoke exposure can cause coughing, burning eyes, chest pain, and shortness of breath. How long these issues last and how serious they are depends upon the length of exposure, your age, and your overall health."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "All smoke contains carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide, and particulate matter. Some smoke, including tobacco smoke, also contains chemicals. These ingredients can make breathing difficult, and irritate the eyes, nose, and throat. How much you are affected by smoke exposure depends on how much smoke you inhaled, what chemicals are in the smoke, your age, and whether you have any health problems. Children are more vulnerable because they are still developing, have higher breathing rates, and have less control over their environments. Elderly people are also vulnerable. If smoke exposure is brief, most symptoms will go away. If smoke exposure lasts, you are at greater risk for conditions such as asthma, cancer, and heart disease."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",

			"heading": "Blocked Tear Duct",
			"content": "Blocked nasolacrimal duct, dacryostenosis"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tTearing in one eye\n\t\t•\tEye irritation\n\t\t•\tGritty or scratchy eyes\n\t\t•\tDry eyes\n\t\t•\tRed spots inside lower eyelid\n\t\t•\tDischarge or mucus in eyes\n\t\t•\tRed eye (single)\n\t\t•\tWatery eyes\n\t\t•\tNosebleed"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Blocked Tear Duct Overview",
			"content": "A blocked tear duct keeps your tears from draining and causes your eye to be watery and irritated. Your eyes constantly make tears as a form of protection. They normally drain into a small opening in the corner of your eye close to your nose. When this tube gets blocked, they can't drain. Babies are often born with blocked tear ducts when the ducts' covering doesn't open correctly. Adults sometimes have the condition due to getting older, an injury, an infection, or a tumor. The ducts may unclog on their own, and gently washing the eye area may provide relief. In cases where the cause of the blockage is more serious, medications or surgery often helps."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "In babies, blocked tear ducts often open up by themselves within a year. These babies don't tend to have other problems with their eyes or vision. If an injury to your face blocked your ducts, your doctor may simply want you to wait a few months for them to open again. If waiting doesn't help, you may need surgery. Complications from blocked tear ducts include infection, but medicines such as antibiotics can help clear up the infection."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 6 out of 100 newborn babies have blocked tear ducts."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for blocked tear ducts depends on what's causing them. Treatment may include:\n\t\t•\tUsing eyedrops or ointment to treat an infection that is causing the blockage\n\t\t•\tUnblocking the duct by enlarging it with a tiny probe or balloon\n\t\t•\tKeeping the duct open with a tube\n\t\t•\tSurgery"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "You can help ease the symptoms of blocked tear ducts with these self-care tips:\n\t\t•\tClean the eyelids gently with a warm, damp washcloth. Keep using different parts of the cloth.\n\t\t•\tLightly massage the eye area two or three times daily to help open up the tear duct."
		},

			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",

	"Torticollis": [{
			"heading": "Torticollis",
			"content": "Wry neck, cervical dystonia"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tTilts head to look at something\n\t\t•\tStiff neck\n\t\t•\tInvoluntary head turning or twisting\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tMuscle cramps or spasms (painful)"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Torticollis causes spasms of the neck muscles that cause the neck to twist to one side, tilting the head one way and the chin the other. It can also cause the head to tilt forward and back. Heredity, injury to neck or head nerves or muscles, and certain medications, can cause torticollis. Most often, the cause is unknown. Most cases of torticollis show up in people ages 30 to 50, although some infants are born with the condition. Treatment includes medication to relax muscle spasms, pain relievers, braces, neck exercises, repositioning exercises, and botulinum toxin injections. Surgery may be used in some cases. Most adults who develop torticollis will have it for the rest of their life but can manage it with treatment."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Torticollis caused by an injury such as whiplash or concussion comes on suddenly and gets better as the injury improves. Symptoms can also be delayed, occurring months after head or neck injury. For torticollis caused by medication, stopping the drug will make symptoms go away. Torticollis that develops with no clear cause often starts slowly and comes and goes. Symptoms gradually progress, reach a certain peak, and stay at that level. Some people have a remission in symptoms, but often symptoms come back. Treatment with muscle relaxants, pain relievers, bracing, and botulinum toxin injections help control symptoms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 90,000 people in the U.S. have torticollis."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for torticollis may include:\n\t\t•\tHeat\n\t\t•\tRest\n\t\t•\tStretching\n\t\t•\tBracing\n\t\t•\tPhysical therapy\n\t\t•\tPain relievers\n\t\t•\tStopping certain medications\n\t\t•\tMedication to relax muscles\n\t\t•\tBotulinum toxin injections\n\t\t•\tDeep brain stimulation\n\t\t•\tSurgery"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Minor neck pain can be treated at home with rest, cold or hot packs, and pain relievers. If muscle stiffness makes it hard to move your head and lasts for more than a day, see your doctor."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Stress, sitting in certain positions, activities that stress neck muscles and cause pain"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "If you have symptoms of torticollis that are not caused by an injury or accident, call your doctor for an appointment. If you injure your head or neck, have trouble breathing or swallowing, have trouble speaking or walking, feel tingling or weakness in your arms or legs, or find it hard to urinate or have a bowl movement, seek immediate medical attention."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",

			"content": "Psychiatric medications, motor vehicle accidents and other trauma, family history"

	"Color_blindness": [{
			"heading": "Color Blindness",
			"content": "Color vision deficiency, color vision defect"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tTrouble distinguishing color shades"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Color blindness means a person cannot tell the difference between certain colors or shades of colors. The most common form is an inability to distinguish between red and green. Another kind of color blindness causes people to not be able to tell the difference between blue and yellow. A third but very rare kind of color blindness causes a person to see no colors except shades of gray. Most color blindness is genetic. It results from a problem in certain nerve cells that line the retina. Because these cells lack certain pigments, they can't react to certain colors. Some medications and some eye diseases can also cause color blindness. Color blindness mostly affects men, not women."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Symptoms are often subtle. Some people don't know they are color blind until it causes a problem. For example, you may not know your child is color blind until you see that an activity like working with color-coded learning material causes confusion. There is no treatment or cure for color blindness, which is a lifelong condition. Most people who have color blindness are able to adjust without problems or disability. Some people, though, are unable to take certain jobs that require an ability to recognize color."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Color blindness affects about one in 10 men. Very few women are color blind."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Being a male of Northern European descent, having a history of certain diseases such as diabetes, Parkinson's disease, or chronic alcoholism, taking some drugs used to treat heart problems, infections, or nervous disorders, getting older, being exposed to certain chemicals in the workplace"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "There is no treatment for color blindness. If your color blindness is related to a disease, sometimes treating that disease may help. Colored filters used over eyeglasses can sometimes help improve your ability to see contrast. But they won't improve your ability to tell the difference between colors."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Most people who are color blind adjust and aren't disabled. Examples of adjustments include memorizing the order of colored objects such as in traffic lights and labeling objects of the same color that need to match."
		},

			"content": "Call your eye doctor if you think you or your child may have difficulty distinguishing colors."

	"Normal_variation": [{
			"heading": "Normal Variation of the Pupil",
			"content": "Anisocoria"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tUnequal pupils (size)"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Normal variation, or anisocoria, is unequal pupil size. It is a common condition. This normal variation is not a problem and you don't need treatment. If it's larger, it can be life threatening. Strokes, lung tumors, aneurysms, damage to the iris, head trauma, migraine headaches, glaucoma, and medications can cause this. Treatment depends on the cause."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "On some days, your left pupil might be bigger than the right and on other days, the right is bigger than the left. If the difference in pupil size is less than .04 mm -- 16/100 of an inch -- it's a benign abnormality, physiologic anisocoria, that doesn't require treatment. If you have an abnormally large pupil that doesn't constrict in bright light, it may be caused by motion sickness patches, eye drops, other medication, or chemicals (such as those used in gardens). This is usually corrected soon after you stop taking the medication or are no longer exposed to the chemical. If you have a large pupil and difficulty focusing on close objects, you may have Adie pupil. In most cases, the cause is unknown and there is no treatment. Over time, you'll probably regain your ability to focus up close and the pupil may shrink, but it may never react well when exposed to direct light.\n\nIf you have an abnormally large pupil along with a droopy eyelid and muscle weakness in your eye, you could have an aneurysm. This is a medical emergency. If one pupil is abnormally small and the upper lid droops, you could have Horner syndrome. This condition doesn't damage the eye, but it may mean that there is damage somewhere along the nerve. Your doctor will do tests to find out what is causing the damage and where, because it could be a serious condition such as a stroke, lung tumor, or break in an artery wall."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 1 in 5 people in the U.S. has physiologic anisocoria."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "A small variation in the size of pupils is normal and doesn't need treatment. With a large variation, treatment depends on the cause."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Self-care depends on the cause of unequal pupil size. No care is needed for benign and minor unequal pupil size."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Certain medications or chemicals"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "See your doctor if you have persistent changes in pupil size. Get immediate medical help if you have different pupil sizes after an eye or head injury."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tCould anisocoria be causing my symptoms?\n\t\t•\tWhat tests do I need?\n\t\t•\tWhat is the cause?\n\t\t•\tDo I need treatment?\n\t\t•\tWhat's my prognosis?"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "Your doctor will examine your eyes in light and dark to determine which pupil is abnormal. You may be asked to bring a driver's license or old photo of yourself to help determine if the anisocoria is physiologic, which means that it is always present. The doctor will also do a physical exam, including a neurological exam, and may do an eye drop test, CT scan, MRI, or other tests to determine the cause."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Being a young adult woman puts you at risk for Adie pupil. Head or eye injury, aneurysm, brain tumor, high eye pressure (from glaucoma), seizures, tumor in upper chest, migraine headache, and certain medications or chemicals increase risk for other types of anisocoria."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Cataract surgery removes the lens in your eye and replaces it with an artificial lens, called an intraocular lens. It is done to treat vision problems -- like blurriness and cloudiness -- caused by cataracts. Cataract surgery is very common, especially in people older than age 60. Although cataract surgery is usually successful, in rare cases it can cause problems. These problems can range from vision problems to pain and infection. If you have any vision loss, light flashes, or an increase in floaters, call your doctor right away."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Cataract surgery usually lasts for less than an hour and it is nearly painless. You can expect to have blurry vision for a few days after cataract surgery. You also may have some itching, mild pain, or fluid discharge. These are all normal side effects of surgery. It usually takes about eight weeks to heal completely from surgery. You may have to use eyedrops for a few days to help with healing. You may have to wear sunglasses or an eye shield and avoid bending at the waist or lifting heavy objects for a few days. Talk with your doctor if you have any unusual symptoms or vision problems. The most serious complication of cataract surgery is a retinal detachment. Symptoms of retinal detachment include bright flashes of light, blurred vision, and floaters. If not treated within 24 hours, it can cause vision loss. Retinal detachment is treated with surgery, often using a laser."

In most cases, the surgeries very effectively correct vision. But they can also cause side effects such as vision loss, halos of light, glare, double vision, poor night vision, and dry eyes."

But if your symptoms get worse instead of better, or if you have any severe pain, tell your doctor right away. You may need eye drops, glasses, contact lenses, or more surgery to treat these problems."

	"Amyloidosis": [{
			"heading": "Amyloidosis",
			"content": "Amyloid"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tYellow eyes\n\t\t•\tYellow skin"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Amyloidosis is a group of rare conditions that can damage the organs and tissue. Proteins start to build up in the body, particularly affecting the heart, kidneys, intestines, nerves, muscles, and skin. The tissue gets stiff and the organs may gradually stop working normally. Amyloidosis is a serious disease. The prognosis depends on which parts of the body are affected. Keep in mind that more common and less serious conditions can cause many of the same symptoms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "There are a number of types of amyloidosis. Some people develop amyloidosis on its own, called primary amyloidosis. Others get it as a symptom of another disease, such as rheumatoid arthritis, tuberculosis, or osteomyelitis. If the disease only affects a specific area, symptoms may be minor. If the disease affects crucial organs such as the heart or kidneys or is systemic -- meaning it affects many parts of the body at once -- it may be fatal. One type, familial amyloidosis, can be cured with a liver transplant. The correct treatment depends on the type and severity of the disease."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 2,000 people in the U.S. each year are diagnosed with primary amyloidosis."
