	"Cirrhosis_(liver)": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tYellow eyes\n\t\t•\tBloody or red colored vomit\n\t\t•\tDecreased appetite\n\t\t•\tSkin redness\n\t\t•\tSwelling\n\t\t•\tBulging veins\n\t\t•\tEasy bruising\n\t\t•\tYellow skin"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "In cirrhosis, chronic scarring of the liver causes it to deteriorate and stop functioning normally. The leading causes of cirrhosis are excessive alcoholism and chronic hepatitis C virus infection. Scar tissue blocks the flow of blood through the liver, impairing its ability to remove toxins and bacteria from the body. The damage also interferes with the liver's ability to process nutrients, hormones, and some medications. Damage to the liver also can cause high blood pressure. Cirrhosis can't be cured. But it is possible to prevent further damage to this critically important organ."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "There is no cure for cirrhosis. Treatment consists of stopping further injury to the liver and treating complications of the condition. Alcoholism is the leading cause of cirrhosis. If people with alcoholic liver disease continue to drink alcohol, they usually die of the disease. If they stop, some damage may be reversed, and they are likely to live longer. It's important to tell your doctor about all drugs that you are taking, including over-the-counter medications and dietary supplements. Some may further damage your liver."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Cirrhosis is the ninth leading cause of death, accounting for 1.2% of all U.S. deaths. Nearly 30,000 Americans die of cirrhosis of the liver each year."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "In the U.S., excessive alcohol consumption and chronic hepatitis C are the most common causes of cirrhosis. Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, which is caused by obesity, diabetes and high cholesterol (rather than heavy alcohol use), has become a new leading risk factor. Chronic damage to the liver typically takes years to cause the symptoms of cirrhosis."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for cirrhosis depends on the cause of the disease and whether complications are present. The goals of treatment are to slow the progression of scar tissue in the liver and prevent or treat the complications of the disease.\n\t\t•\tIf alcohol caused your cirrhosis, the most important thing you can do is stop drinking.\n\t\t•\tAvoid medications that may be toxic to the liver, including over-the-counter drugs.\n\t\t•\tHospitalization may be necessary for cirrhosis with complications.\n\t\t•\tA liver transplant may be necessary if cirrhosis becomes advanced."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "If you have cirrhosis, there’s plenty you can do to slow the progression of the disease.\n\t\t•\tDo not drink any alcohol.\n\t\t•\tTalk with your doctor before taking any medications, including prescription and over-the-counter drugs, vitamins, and herbal supplements. Cirrhosis makes your liver sensitive to certain medications.\n\t\t•\tGet a hepatitis A and hepatitis B vaccine.\n\t\t•\tAvoid eating raw oysters or other raw shellfish, which can harbor bacteria that's dangerous to people with cirrhosis."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "Make an appointment to see your doctor if you experience any of the symptoms of cirrhosis."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tHow extensive is the damage to my liver?\n\t\t•\tWhat can I do to prevent further damage?\n\t\t•\tWhat complications do I have from cirrhosis?\n\t\t•\tCan those complications be treated and controlled?\n\t\t•\tWould I be a candidate for a liver transplant?\n\t\t•\tWhich medications should I avoid taking?"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "Diagnosis is based on a physical exam, a medical history, and a variety of tests, including blood tests that measure liver function. A CT scan, ultrasound, or other imaging test may be used to assess the condition of your liver. A liver biopsy, which uses a small needle to remove tissue from the liver, may be performed."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Drinking alcohol, and being obese can worsen liver damage. Also, a person with cirrhosis should not eat raw shellfish, which can contain a bacterium that causes serious liver infection."
		}
	],
	"Gallstones": [{
			"heading": "Gallstones",
			"content": "Gallbladder stones, bile stones"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tYellow eyes\n\t\t•\tBloating or fullness\n\t\t•\tYellow skin\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tNausea or vomiting\n\t\t•\tTenderness to touch"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Gallstones are small, hard stones that form from substances in the gall bladder. They can take years to develop and range in size from a grain of sand to golf-ball-size stones. Gallstones cause pain and other symptoms when they block the ducts that drain bile from the gallbladder into the small intestine. Many people have gallstones, but don't have any symptoms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Most people with gallstones have no symptoms and don't need treatment. However, if a gallstone blocks the bile duct, it can cause severe pain that can last from minutes to hours. If you've had just one attack, your doctor may wait to see if you have another before deciding on treatment. People who have frequent attacks need surgery to remove the gallbladder. Blockage of the bile duct can cause jaundice, or yellowing of the skin due to a buildup of bilirubin in the blood. In rare cases, the duct can become completely blocked and cause a dangerous infection of the gallbladder. Another dangerous complication is gallstone pancreatitis, which can occasionally be life-threatening if not treated quickly."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Approximately 1 in 20 people has gallstones. Gallstones are much more common in women, especially women over 40 who have had multiple births. Being overweight, losing a lot of weight quickly, or having a family history of gallstones also increase your risk."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tSurgery to remove the gallbladder, often done using a scope.\n\t\t•\tDissolving gallstones with medication (stones often return if not treated with surgery)\n\t\t•\tUsing ultrasound shock waves to break up gallstones"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Avoid fatty meals. If you have gallstone pain after eating a fatty meal, you may not need treatment. However you should see your doctor for an evaluation."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "If you have abdominal pain that doesn't go away or keeps coming back, see your doctor. If you are vomiting, have severe pain, and have yellow skin or dark urine, seek immediate medical attention."
		},

		},
		{

			"content": "The doctor will do a physical exam and may order X-rays and ultrasound to detect stones. If the patient has yellow skin, the doctor will order blood tests for bilirubin and jaundice."
		}

	"Hepatitis_C": [{
			"heading": "Hepatitis C",
			"content": "Hep C"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tYellow eyes\n\t\t•\tDecreased appetite\n\t\t•\tYellow skin\n\t\t•\tDark colored (brown) urine\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tFatigue\n\t\t•\tTenderness to touch"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Hepatitis C is a type of virus. It causes inflammation of the liver that can lead to liver disease, liver failure, and liver cancer. You get hepatitis C from contact with the blood of someone who has hepatitis C. Hepatitis C often causes no symptoms until it has caused liver damage. But it can cause some mild symptoms including a yellowing of the skin and eyes, tiredness, weakness, weight loss, nausea, and vomiting."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Acute infection with hepatitis C causes fatigue and loss of appetite, followed by pain and tenderness near the liver. But chronic infection with hepatitis C may not cause noticeable symptoms until you have liver damage. Hepatitis C usually is treated with antiviral medications. In severe cases, scarring of the liver leads to liver failure and requires a liver transplant. Having hepatitis C also raises your risk for liver cancer."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "You may be at higher risk for hepatitis C if you:\n\t\t•\tUse needles to inject illegal drugs\n\t\t•\tAre a health care worker who is exposed to blood\n\t\t•\tHave HIV Had a blood transfusion or organ transplant before 1992\n\t\t•\tReceived blood products before 1987\n\t\t•\tReceived dialysis treatments for a long period of time\n\t\t•\tWere born to a mother who has hepatitis C\n\t\t•\tHad a tattoo or piercing using an unsterile needle"
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 2.7 million people in the U.S. are infected with hepatitis C."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Prevention",
			"content": "You can prevent getting or spreading hepatitis C by: Not sharing needles Getting tattoos and body piercings only with sterilized needles Wearing gloves if you need to touch someone else's blood Always wear condoms during sex (although sexual spread of hepatitis C is quite rare) Not donating blood if you have hepatitis C Not sharing razors or toothbrushes with others"

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Pancreatic cancer strikes a small gland in the abdomen called the pancreas. Symptoms often don't appear until the cancer has advanced, making treatment difficult. Surgeons can sometimes remove early stage pancreatic cancer and cure the disease. But the large majority of pancreatic cancers are diagnosed after they have spread. Chemotherapy and radiation are the primary treatments at that point. Treatments have extended the survival time for pancreatic cancer, but it's rarely curable."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "If pancreatic cancer is caught very early, it can be removed surgically. In some cases, surgery cures the disease. Unfortunately, most cases of pancreatic cancer are diagnosed after the cancer has spread. In that case, a cure isn't possible. But treatments can slow the progress of the disease. About 5% of patients with later-stage disease are alive five years after diagnosis."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Each year in the United States, more than 43,000 people are diagnosed with cancer of the pancreas. Most are over age 65."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Your odds of getting pancreatic cancer are higher if you smoke, have diabetes, or are obese. Persistent inflammation of the pancreas, called chronic pancreatitis, also may increase your risk. Pancreatic cancer also runs in families. Having a mother, father, sister, or brother with the disease increases your risk of getting it."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Surgery is the first choice for treating pancreatic cancer. However, for many patients, surgery is not possible because of where the tumor is located or because it has spread beyond the pancreas. If surgery is not an option, your doctor may recommend chemotherapy (drugs that kill cancer cells) or radiation therapy. Even if you are a candidate for surgery, your doctor may recommend chemotherapy to kill any remaining cancer cells.\n\nYour doctor also can offer treatments to ease the consequences of pancreatic surgery, which include pain, digestion problems, and weight loss. Some patients develop blockages in the tubes that transport bile in the body. In that case, surgery can be performed to place a tiny metal stent in place to open up the tube. Because most cases of pancreatic cancer can't be cured, many doctors recommend participating in clinical trials that test new and promising treatments."
		},
		{

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Primary biliary cirrhosis, or PBC, is a long-term disease that makes the liver's bile ducts irritated and swollen, slowing down the flow of bile (a liquid that helps your body break down nutrients). This damages the cells of the liver, which leads to scarring or cirrhosis. The cause of PBC is unknown, but it may have to do with immune system problems. Women in middle age tend to develop PBC. Without proper care, a liver transplant may be needed. But many people live active lives for years after learning they have PBC and find relief with medicine and vitamins."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Taking medication early on may help slow liver damage but not stop it completely. Complications of primary biliary cirrhosis include dry eyes or mouth, arthritis, kidney problems, trouble with digestion, and soft bones that can eventually lead to broken bones. After 10 years, about a quarter of people with primary biliary cirrhosis will have liver failure."

Some people with ulcerative colitis eventually need surgery to remove all or part of the colon. This cures the disease. While usually just a temporary annoyance, chronic congestion can cause problems like sinus infections. In infants, congestion can make feeding difficult. In young children, hearing problems from ongoing congestion can interfere with speech and development."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "When a cold or other virus causes nasal congestion, the symptoms may go away within a few days. Other conditions, such as allergies, sinus infections, and nasal polyps, cause congestion that lasts longer. Treatment depends on the cause. Decongestants can help with symptoms while the body fights off a cold. Allergy medications blunt the body's allergic reaction, easing symptoms. Sinus infections may need antibiotics. Some people have harmless growths in the nose called nasal polyps. They can cause chronic congestion. Surgery to remove them can help."

Always follow the dosing instructions. In babies, use a nasal bulb to remove excess mucus. Kids with congestion may sleep easier if you prop up the head of their bed or mattress a few inches. Never use cold or cough medications in children under age 4 unless a doctor recommends it."

	"Anosmia": [{
			"heading": "Anosmia",
			"content": "Loss of smell"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tDecreased smell\n\t\t•\tDecreased appetite"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Anosmia is complete loss of smell. Aging, head trauma, sinusitis, and upper respiratory infections most commonly cause it. If the cause can be treated, such as some infections or blockage in the nasal passages, anosmia can be relieved. In other cases, particularly if it's caused by age, anosmia may be permanent. Anosmia is not life threatening, but it can affect the quality of your life. You may not be able to taste foods or enjoy pleasant scents. It can also be dangerous because you can't detect smoke, poisonous fumes, or spoiled food. Learning adaptive strategies can help you cope with permanent anosmia."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "At first, you may think the problem is with your taste buds. You may be able to distinguish salty, sweet, sour, or bitter tastes -- which don't rely on sense of smell -- but not other tastes. You may also notice that you can't smell common aromas -- coffee brewing, the onion you're chopping, flowers. Whether you can recover your sense of smell depends partly on the cause. If a nasal or sinus condition causes anosmia, oral or inhaled steroids, antibiotics, decongestants, and other medications may help.\n\nSurgery may clear up anosmia if a polyp or other obstruction in your nose is the cause. If anosmia is caused by a head injury or upper respiratory infection, treatment may not be effective. Permanent anosmia can cause psychological and safety issues. You may feel anxious or depressed or lose interest in eating, which can lead to nutrition problems. Your doctor can advise you on safety measures such as installing smoke and gas detectors. Learning strategies to enhance flavor and improve your enjoyment of eating may also help."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 2.7 million adults in the U.S. may have some loss of smell."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for anosmia may include:\n\t\t•\tDecongestants, antihistamines, or saline irrigation in nose\n\t\t•\tAntibiotics\n\t\t•\tNasal or systemic steroids\n\t\t•\tNasal surgery\n\t\t•\tHormones for endocrine disturbances\n\t\t•\tEliminating toxins, such as cigarette smoke or airborne pollutants\n\t\t•\tCounseling for adjustments in daily living\n\t\t•\tPsychological counseling"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "These self-care strategies may help if you have anosmia:\n\t\t•\tInstall smoke detectors throughout your home.\n\t\t•\tSwitch to electricity instead of gas, if possible. Otherwise, use a gas stove with an automatic pilot and install gas detectors where there could be gas leaks.\n\t\t•\tRead and follow instructions on labels of cleaning or other products that may include strong chemicals.\nFor example, a label may say to ventilate the area well when using the product.\n\t\t•\tBe careful about food spoiling. Read expiration dates on labels. When in doubt about a food, throw it out.\n\t\t•\tQuit smoking. Be careful not to add too much sugar or salt to food in an attempt to improve flavor.\n\t\t•\tMake meals interesting by combining different textures or cold and hot foods. Enhance tongue sensations with spicy foods."

	"Foreign_object_in_the_nose": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tDifficulty breathing through nose\n\t\t•\tRunny nose\n\t\t•\tNosebleed\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tDrainage or pus\n\t\t•\tNasal congestion"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Kids often put foreign objects in their nose out of curiosity. This can cause pain, a runny nose, nosebleeds, nasal congestion, nasal drainage, and difficulty breathing through the nose. Toddlers and children ages 1 to 8 are likely to pick up items such as food, tissues, small toys, beads, and crayon pieces and put them in their nose. Objects can also become stuck as a result of falling face first or being hit in the face. You may be able to remove the object from your child's nose at home, but if it's too deep a doctor may need to take it out. Most children don't have problems in the long run, but getting care quickly is important. The object could move into the throat and cause choking, which could be deadly."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "Bring your child to the emergency room if the object has gone down the throat and your child is choking or if your child swallowed the object. You should also bring your child to the emergency room if there is food in the nose, which can swell with moisture, or a battery, which can leak chemicals."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Your child may need a follow-up visit to the doctor after being treated. Most children don't have any long-term problems, but there can be complications from having a foreign object in the nose. This could include vomiting due to the blood from nosebleeds running down the throat. Another complication is the skin infection called impetigo. Impetigo often appears under the nose from repeatedly wiping away discharge. A sinus infection, often the result of part of a tissue left inside the nose, can be another problem. The most severe complication is choking, which is rare but can be fatal."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Using a tool to remove the object from the nose"
		},

			"content": "Children may not sit still while the doctor is treating them, so they may first need sedation, a drug to help them relax.\n\nTreatments for removing a foreign object from the nose include:\n\t\t•\tUsing long tweezers, tools with a hook or loop, or gentle suction\n\t\t•\tUsing a long magnetized tool to remove metal objects\n\t\t•\tSliding a catheter (tube) by the object and inflating a balloon to lift it out"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "These self-care tips may help remove a foreign object in the nose:\n\t\t•\tPress closed the nostril that the object isn't in and have your child blow gently.\n\t\t•\tDon't use any tools or cotton swabs to remove the object. That could push it farther in the nose or into the throat.\n\t\t•\tPut a towel over the end of the nose to stop any bleeding. See a doctor if the bleeding doesn't stop in a few minutes."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tItching or burning\n\t\t•\tNosebleed"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Nasal dryness is a common problem that can cause congestion, runny nose, and nosebleeds. Dry weather and medications such as antihistamines, decongestants, and blood pressure drugs can cause nasal dryness. The body may respond to a dry nose by producing more mucus, causing stuffiness. Dried out and crusty tissue in the nose can crack, causing a nosebleed. Dry nasal tissue is more prone to bacterial infection, which can lead to colds or sinus infections. Moisturizing the nasal passages and the air will help. Anyone with frequent nosebleeds should check in with a doctor to rule out other causes."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Nasal dryness is generally not a serious problem. Use a humidifier or vaporizer to moisten the air. Saline nasal sprays and Neti pots will help keep the nasal passages moist. So will rubbing a water-soluble jelly inside the nostrils. Try to drink more water in dry weather. Make sure not to overuse decongestants or antihistamines, which can make nasal dryness worse. Sinus infections or other complications of a dry nose will need other treatments."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Nasal dryness is very common. Millions of people have nasal dryness every day."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Nasal dryness can usually be treated at home. Use a saline spray, Neti pot, or water-soluble jelly to keep the nasal passages moist. Use a humidifier at home or the office to moisturize the air. Don't rub or pick at the nose. Stay hydrated with plenty of water."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Ricin is a dangerous poison in castor beans. It's possible to get ricin poisoning from eating castor beans, but people can also use ricin as a weapon. Ricin stops cells from making proteins, causing them to die. It can cause problems with breathing or digestion, and sometimes results in death. Ricin's dangers depend on whether you swallow, touch, inhale, or inject it. The poisoning is worse if ricin is inhaled or injected. There is no cure, so getting medical care right away is important to lessen damage to your body."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "Call emergency services or go to the emergency room if you think you have ricin poisoning."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "If you swallowed ricin, you may notice signs of poisoning within 6 to 12 hours or sooner and feel worse over the next day. It may feel like you have food poisoning. Complications may include internal bleeding and spleen and kidney damage. If you inhaled ricin, you may first see signs of poisoning within 4 to 6 hours and feel worse over the next day. Lung failure is a possibility. You may need to stay in the hospital if your symptoms are serious, but you're likely to recover if you survive 3 to 5 days after ricin poisoning."

Double bag the clothes, sealing both bags, and let emergency workers get rid of them.\n\t\t•\tWash your body immediately with a lot of soap and water.\n\t\t•\tRinse your eyes with water for 10 to 15 minutes if they burn or if you have blurry vision. 		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Millions of people take aspirin for pain, fever, and protection against heart attacks and strokes. Aspirin thins the blood and reduces clotting. However, even at low doses -- the amount in a baby aspirin -- it can cause side effects. Aspirin can upset the stomach or trigger bleeding. It can worsen asthma symptoms, especially if you have nasal polyps. Aspirin can cause nosebleeds and easy bruising. An overdose of aspirin can be fatal."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Most aspirin side effects are minor. In some people, aspirin can irritate the lining of the stomach, causing heartburn and pain. The damage could lead to bleeding, ulcers, or both. People with asthma and nasal polyps are more likely to be sensitive to aspirin; it can worsen symptoms, such as stuffiness and wheezing, or trigger an allergic reaction. If you have symptoms from occasional aspirin for pain relief, switch to a different drug. If your doctor has prescribed aspirin to prevent heart attacks or strokes, don't stop taking it until you talk it over with your doctor. Never give aspirin to children or teenagers -- it can trigger a serious condition called Reye's syndrome."

	"Blood_clotting_disorder": [{
			"heading": "Blood Clotting Disorder",
			"content": "Thrombophilia, abnormal blood clotting"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tNosebleed\n\t\t•\tBlood or red colored urine\n\t\t•\tBlack (tar) colored stools\n\t\t•\tProlonged bleeding\n\t\t•\tBleeding gums\n\t\t•\tBloody or red colored stools\n\t\t•\tHeavy menstrual bleeding"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Blood clotting disorders increase the risk that dangerous blood clots will form in the body. Normally, blood clots to stop bleeding after an injury. In people with clotting disorders, clots may form inside the body where they shouldn't. They can clog a vein or artery. Clots can trigger miscarriages, heart attacks, strokes, and pulmonary embolisms. Some blood-clotting disorders are inherited, such as Factor V Leiden. Conditions such as lupus, bone marrow disorders, and some cancers can cause a clotting disorder. Keep in mind that many people with clotting disorders never have a blood clot -- they just have a higher risk. Treatment with blood thinners make clots less likely to form."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Depending on where they appear, clots can cause deep vein thrombosis in the legs, strokes, heart attacks, and pulmonary embolisms -- a life-threatening blood clot in the lungs. People may not realize that they have a clotting disorder until after they have a clot. Doctors may treat clotting disorders with drugs that thin the blood. Some people need ongoing treatment. Others only need treatment at specific times of higher risk, such as during pregnancy or when recovering from surgery. A person who currently has a blood clot needs emergency treatment."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "5% to 8% of people in the U.S. have an inherited blood clotting disorder."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "A personal or family history of blood clots, inherited conditions such as Factor V Leiden, protein C or S deficiencies, antithrombin deficiency"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatments for clotting disorders include:\n\t\t•\tAspirin\n\t\t•\tBlood thinners, such as heparin and warfarin (Coumadin)\n\t\t•\tAntithrombin factor and protein C\n\t\t•\tTreatment of underlying conditions or risk factors, such as high blood pressure, diabetes, and heart problems\n\nA blood clot is always an emergency and needs specific treatment. A person may need drugs to break up the clot, surgery, or other treatments."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Clotting disorders always need treatment. Your doctor may also suggest that you improve your diet, exercise more, and lose weight if you need to. If you smoke, quit. Make sure to stretch and move around regularly when in a confined space, such as a plane."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "If you're concerned you may have a blood clotting disorder -- or have a family history of clotting disorders -- talk to your doctor. If you have signs of a heart attack, stroke, pulmonary embolism, or deep vein thrombosis -- such as chest pain, shortness of breath, changes in vision or understanding, severe unexplained leg pain, or difficulty breathing -- go to the emergency room."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",

		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Myelodysplastic syndromes are diseases that affect the bone marrow and blood. Having MDS means that the bone marrow in your body doesn't make enough healthy blood cells. Some people with MDS eventually may develop leukemia. There are many different kinds of MDS, but they are all a type of cancer. It is most common in people over age 60. MDS causes anemia, and can make you feel tired or short of breath. Keep in mind that other, less serious conditions can also cause these symptoms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Depending on the type of MDS you have, your symptoms may be mild or severe. Your condition depends on how many of your blood cells are affected by MDS. In mild cases, you may not need any treatment except for watching your blood cells. In more severe cases, you may need to have chemotherapy or blood transfusions. In some cases, bone marrow stem cell transplants may be done."

			"heading": "Hemophilia",
			"content": "Hemophilia A, Hemophilia B, Christmas Disease"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tNosebleed\n\t\t•\tBlood or red colored urine\n\t\t•\tBlack (tar) colored stools\n\t\t•\tEasy bleeding\n\t\t•\tHeavy menstrual bleeding\n\t\t•\tBleeding gums\n\t\t•\tBloody or red colored stools\n\t\t•\tBruising or discoloration\n\t\t•\tEasy bruising\n\t\t•\tProlonged bleeding"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Hemophilia is a rare disorder in which the blood lacks certain clotting factors -- substances that help the blood clot. Many cases are mild. Severe hemophilia can be dangerous. Even a minor injury can cause serious bleeding. There are different types, including hemophilia A and hemophilia B. Hemophilia runs in families and it generally affects only men. Treatment works well. With good care, most people with hemophilia lead generally healthy lives."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Doctors often detect hemophilia in children. People with mild hemophilia may not realize that they have it until adulthood, after surgery or an injury. Bleeding may be on the surface of the skin or internal. Bleeding in the joints is common. The joint may be painful, swollen, and hard to move. Bleeding in the brain can be life-threatening. People with mild hemophilia may only need medication. More serious hemophilia needs replacement therapy -- occasional or regular treatment with IV or injected clotting factors. Many can do replacement therapy at home on their own."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Hemophilia is rare. About 20,000 people in the U.S. have it."
		},

		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Hemophilia always needs medical treatment. Your doctor may suggest that you avoid alcohol and medications -- such as aspirin, ibuprofen, ketoprofen, and naproxen -- which could make hemophilia symptoms worse. Take extra precautions to protect children with hemophilia from injury."

		{

			"content": "\n\t\t•\tNosebleed\n\t\t•\tBleeding gums\n\t\t•\tBloody or red colored stools\n\t\t•\tDizziness\n\t\t•\tFatigue\n\t\t•\tLightheadedness\n\t\t•\tShortness of breath\n\t\t•\tDifficulty concentrating\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tBlood or red colored urine\n\t\t•\tBlack (tar) colored stools\n\t\t•\tEasy bruising\n\t\t•\tFever\n\t\t•\tPale skin\n\t\t•\tWeight loss (unintentional)\n\t\t•\tWeakness (generalized)"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Aplastic anemia occurs when the bone marrow can't make enough new blood cells. When your body doesn't have enough blood cells, you may have weakness, shortness of breath, fatigue, rapid heart rate, pale skin, bleeding gums, bruising, frequent infections, and nose bleeds. About half the time, there is no clear cause of the illness. Experts say that aplastic anemia occurs when the immune system mistakenly attacks healthy cells. Pregnancy, certain medications, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and birth disorders can also cause the condition. The disease greatly increases the risk for life-threatening infections. Severe aplastic anemia can cause death if not treated. Treatment includes blood transfusions, drugs that suppress the immune system, and bone marrow transplantation."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Aplastic anemia may develop slowly or come on suddenly. Sometimes mild cases get better without any treatment. Usually the condition becomes chronic and gets worse over time. Blood transfusions may help manage moderate cases of the disease. Treatment for severe aplastic anemia includes a bone marrow transplant or drugs that suppress the immune system. If not treated, severe aplastic anemia can eventually cause death."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Every year about six out of 1 million people in the U.S. get aplastic anemia."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Certain drugs, pregnancy, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, some birth disorders, certain toxins"

		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Aplastic anemia requires medical treatment. Because of the risk for life-threatening infections, you should avoid large crowds and people with colds and other illnesses, wash your hands regularly, avoid foods that may be contaminated with bacteria or viruses, and take other steps to avoid infection."

		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "The common cold is a short-lived viral infection of the upper respiratory tract, which includes the nose and sinuses, mouth, and throat. Symptoms may include sore throat, stuffy or runny nose, nasal drip, headache, and slight muscle aches. Because more than 200 viruses cause colds, and new ones develop all the time, the body can't build immunity to colds. Colds spread easily from person to person and are the most common illness in the world. Most colds go away within a few days and don't cause serious health problems."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Symptoms start about two to three days after exposure to the cold virus. Symptoms may come on gradually or suddenly and can last from two days to two weeks, although most people get better within a week."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Prevention",
			"content": "When an infected person coughs or sneezes, it can launch tiny droplets up to 12 feet in the air. The virus spreads when a healthy person inhales those tiny droplets. Blowing your nose and touching something such as pens, telephones, and computer keyboards can leave cold viruses on those objects for several hours. If someone else uses your pen and touches their nose, that person may catch your cold. Here are ways to help prevent spreading colds:\n\t\t•\tWash your hands often if you have a cold, especially after blowing your nose, sneezing, or coughing.\n\t\t•\tUse hand sanitizer if you will be around a person with a cold.\n\t\t•\tDon't share towels, drinking glasses, eating utensils, computer keyboards, or telephones with someone who has a cold.\n\t\t•\tCover your mouth when coughing or sneezing.\n\t\t•\tAvoid contact with people who are sick.\n\t\t•\tIf you are sick, stay home and rest so you don't infect other people at your workplace or school."

			"heading": "Drug Allergy",
			"content": "Allergic reaction"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tRunny nose\n\t\t•\tSwelling\n\t\t•\tHives\n\t\t•\tNausea or vomiting\n\t\t•\tShortness of breath\n\t\t•\tThroat tightness\n\t\t•\tSwollen tongue\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tCough\n\t\t•\tItching or burning\n\t\t•\tSkin rash\n\t\t•\tSkin blisters\n\t\t•\tWheezing\n\t\t•\tStomach cramps"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "A drug allergy is an allergic reaction to a medication. Penicillin, sulfa drugs, barbiturates, aspirin, nonsteroidal and antiseizure medications, and contrast dye materials commonly cause it. Injecting a drug is more likely to cause a reaction than taking it orally. The most severe allergic reaction is anaphylaxis, which involves the whole body. You may have difficulty breathing, rapid heartbeat, or lose consciousness. Anaphylaxis must be treated in an emergency room. Other drug allergy symptoms can range from mild itching and hives to fever and vomiting. Prescription or over-the-counter medication and stopping the offending medication can usually clear up a reaction."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "An anaphylactic reaction can escalate quickly. If you have symptoms of a severe allergic reaction such as throat tightening, difficulty breathing, or faintness, call emergency services. If you carry epinephrine, inject it immediately. If you have blisters or the upper layer of your skin is detaching, get medical help immediately."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "You're most likely to have a reaction to a drug that you've taken once before. Unlike most allergic reactions, which come on quickly, drug allergy symptoms can occur days or weeks after starting a medication. You may have hives, a rash, itchiness, congestion, lymph node swelling, or muscle and joint aches. Your doctor may switch you to a different medication and prescribe antihistamines or oral steroids. You'll probably feel much better in 48-72 hours. An anaphylactic reaction usually occurs within four hours of taking a drug and can occur within minutes. It is considered a medical emergency. Your blood pressure may drop, your throat may tighten up, and you may faint. At the emergency room, you'll likely receive intravenous fluids, oxygen, antihistamines, steroids, and epinephrine (adrenaline). You may need to be hospitalized."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Re-exposure to a medication that causes a reaction"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for a drug allergy includes:\n\t\t•\tStopping the medication\n\t\t•\tCool compresses\n\t\t•\tOver-the-counter topical medication to relieve itching\n\t\t•\tInhaled albuterol or epinephrine\n\t\t•\tAntihistamines\n\t\t•\tOral or injected steroids\n\t\t•\tCPR\n\t\t•\tOxygen\n\t\t•\tEpinephrine injection\n\t\t•\tTherapy to maintain blood pressure and breathing"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "These strategies can help relieve a mild drug allergy:\n\t\t•\tTake cool showers or apply cool compresses.\n\t\t•\tWear clothing that doesn't irritate your skin.\n\t\t•\tRestrict activity.\n\nAfter an allergic reaction, you should:\n\t\t•\tTell all your doctors about your drug allergy.\n\t\t•\tAvoid the medication that you are allergic to.\n\t\t•\tCarry an identification card or wear a medical alert bracelet with information about your reaction in case of an emergency."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",

Symptoms of a drug allergy include: skin rashes, hives, and itchy skin, congestion, and swelling of the lips, tongue or throat. Call emergency services if you have symptoms of a severe reaction. Symptoms of a severe reaction include: swelling and hives, lightheadedness and dizziness, wheezing and trouble breathing, blue skin, sudden drop in blood pressure, loss of consciousness, rapid pulse, and shock."

Mesenteric lymphadenitis usually gets better on its own and causes no complications."

	"Cushing's_syndrome": [{
			"heading": "Cushing's Syndrome",
			"content": "Hypercortisolism"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tAbnormally round face\n\t\t•\tOverweight\n\t\t•\tWeight gain"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Cushing's syndrome is a rare condition in which the body is exposed to high levels of a hormone called cortisol over time. Taking high doses of corticosteroids such as prednisone for rheumatoid arthritis or asthma for a long time can cause Cushing's syndrome. It can also happen when your adrenal glands make too much cortisol because of a tumor. Cushing's syndrome often affects people ages 20 to 50. Doctors may recommend slowly tapering off the medicine or removing the tumor that is causing Cushing's syndrome. A full recovery is usually possible."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Cushing's syndrome is often curable. If you are taking corticosteroids, your doctor will have you taper off. Stopping it suddenly can cause cortisol to drop too low. Surgery to remove tumors causing Cushing's syndrome is frequently successful, but there is a chance the tumors could return. If a tumor is on the pituitary gland and gets too big, it can cause vision problems. Other complications include diabetes and high blood pressure. Without treatment, Cushing's syndrome can be life threatening."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Each year about 10 to 15 of every million people develop Cushing's syndrome."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Taking a lot of corticosteroids for a long time"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment of Cushing's syndrome can include:\n\t\t•\tSlowly taking less of the medication that is causing Cushing’s syndrome, as directed by your doctor\n\t\t•\tSurgery to remove the tumor that is causing Cushing’s syndrome, followed by radiation in some cases\n\t\t•\tCortisol replacement therapy after surgery\n\t\t•\tMedicine to stop the body from making cortisol"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "You can ease some symptoms of Cushing's syndrome by eating healthy foods and talking with a dietitian about avoiding weight gain."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Not getting treatment"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "See your doctor if you have any symptoms of Cushing's syndrome."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tIs Cushing's syndrome causing my symptoms?\n\t\t•\tWhat is causing Cushing's syndrome?\n\t\t•\tWhich treatment is right for me?\n\t\t•\tHow long will it be until I see results?\n\t\t•\tWhat are possible complications from treatment?"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "The doctor will examine you and ask you questions about your symptoms. You may not need other tests if you are taking a medicine that can cause Cushing's syndrome. If medicine is not the cause, the doctor may order blood and urine tests and imaging scans to look for tumors."
		}

	"Bells_palsy": [{
			"heading": "Bell's Palsy",
			"content": "Bell palsy, facial nerve paralysis, seventh nerve paralysis"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tDrooping of one side of face\n\t\t•\tDecreased taste\n\t\t•\tDry mouth\n\t\t•\tSensitive to noise\n\t\t•\tUnable to blink or close eyelid\n\t\t•\tTearing in one eye\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tDrooling\n\t\t•\tGritty or scratchy eyes\n\t\t•\tDifficulty swallowing\n\t\t•\tDry eyes\n\t\t•\tEar ache"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Bell's palsy is a harmless but sometimes alarming condition that causes muscle weakness or paralysis in some facial muscles. One side of the face may droop. Smiling may look like a sneer. Bell's palsy happens when one of the nerves that control the facial muscles gets irritated and swollen. No one is sure why. It may be an unusual reaction to a common virus. While not medically serious, Bell's palsy can be upsetting and embarrassing. It usually clears up on its own within a few weeks or months. Treatment also may help. Anyone with symptoms should see a doctor immediately -- they can be hard to distinguish from a stroke."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Bell's palsy often starts suddenly. A person may wake up one morning with facial paralysis. Usually, Bell's palsy only affects one side of the face. Talking and eating may be difficult. Sometimes, the eye can become dry because a person can't blink normally. Symptoms are usually worst in the first two days. Mild cases may go away within a few weeks. Others may take months. Rarely, Bell's palsy symptoms last for years or become permanent. Steroids and other drugs help in some cases."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 40,000 people in the U.S. develop Bell's palsy each year."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Mild cases may not need treatment. Some people with Bell's palsy benefit from:\n\t\t•\tSteroids\n\t\t•\tAntiviral medicines\n\t\t•\tTreating an underlying cause, such as an infection\n\t\t•\tPain relievers, such as aspirin, acetaminophen (Tylenol), ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin), or naproxen (Aleve)\n\t\t•\tEye drops or gels\n\t\t•\tTaping the eye closed when sleeping\n\t\t•\tPhysical therapy"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Take any medications your doctor has prescribed. To protect your eye, try using re-wetting eye drops, artificial tears, or wearing an eye patch while you sleep. Moist heat on the affected muscles may be soothing. Reduce stress with relaxation exercises and deep breathing. Ask your doctor if you should do any facial muscle exercises at home."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Not getting treatment in severe cases"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "If you have any symptoms of Bell's palsy, see a doctor right away. If you have symptoms of Bell's palsy with weakness or paralysis elsewhere in the body, you may be having a stroke. Call emergency services or go to the emergency room."
		},

	"Tetany": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tMuscle cramps or spasms (painful)\n\t\t•\tUnable to open mouth (jaw)\n\t\t•\tNumbness or tingling\n\t\t•\tDifficulty relaxing muscles after contracting them"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Tetany is a mineral imbalance that can cause painful muscle cramps, twitches, and spasms in the hands, feet, face, and larynx, or voice box. Severely low levels of calcium in the blood, or severe hypocalcemia, usually cause it. Kidney failure, some blood disorders, low levels of vitamin D and magnesium, chemotherapy, alcoholism, some medications, and underactive parathyroid glands can cause hypocalcemia. Tetany is a medical emergency. If treated well, it is reversible. Calcium, given intravenously in a hospital, treats it."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "A small drop in blood calcium may cause no symptoms. But once levels fall substantially, tetany cramps may start in your hands and feet. You may have severe muscle spasms that give the appearance of seizures. If muscle spasms occur in your throat, you can have trouble breathing. At the hospital, you'll be given calcium intravenously and vitamin D supplements to help with its absorption. You should also be treated for the underlying problem that caused the drop in calcium."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for tetany may include:\n\t\t•\tIntravenous calcium and fluids\n\t\t•\tOral calcium supplements\n\t\t•\tVitamin D supplements\n\t\t•\tDiuretics to decrease kidney excretion of calcium\n\t\t•\tTreatment for the underlying cause"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "These self-care strategies can help if your blood calcium levels are low:\n\t\t•\tMake sure you are getting enough calcium in your diet. Dairy products, greens, sardines, salmon, red beans, tofu, and seaweed are good sources.\n\t\t•\tAsk your doctor if you should take calcium supplements.\n\t\t•\tTake vitamin D with calcium supplements for better absorption.\n\t\t•\tDrink orange juice fortified with calcium."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "If you have severe symptoms of tetany, such as muscle spasms, a seizure, or difficulty breathing, immediately see your doctor or go to a hospital emergency room."
		},

Facial tics can also take the form of movements or behaviors such as grimacing, wrinkling your nose, or sticking out your tongue. They are often associated with anxiety. Tics usually go away on their own. If they become a persistent problem, psychological counseling or medications can help ease the symptoms."
		},

			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tNumbness or tingling\n\t\t•\tChills\n\t\t•\tColor change\n\t\t•\tCold feet\n\t\t•\tBlue colored skin\n\t\t•\tShaking chills (rigors)\n\t\t•\tCold hands\n\t\t•\tShaking"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Mild exposure to cold usually does not cause a problem, but staying in the cold too long has health risks. Hypothermia, a life-threatening drop in body temperature, is the most dangerous. Frostbite can cause tissue damage, often in the fingers, toes, nose, and ears. Frostnip usually appears first, which causes numbness and stinging. Trench foot -- from walking in cold, damp shoes -- can cause stinging and blisters. Chilblains cause red, swollen skin."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "If you have symptoms of excessive cold exposure such as numbness or shivering, you need to warm up. Get inside. Most people will do well with basic treatments such as wrapping up in blankets and drinking warm drinks. Swing your arms to get blood circulation going. If you have signs of hypothermia -- low body temperature, shallow breathing, fatigue, drowsiness -- get medical help right away."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Millions of people in the U.S. suffer from excessive cold exposure each year."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatments include:\n\t\t•\tGetting warm inside\n\t\t•\tBlankets and electric blankets\n\t\t•\tNonalcoholic and noncaffeinated warm drinks\n\t\t•\tSkin-to-skin contact with another person\n\t\t•\tSoaking trench foot or areas with frostbite in warm (not hot) water\n\t\t•\tLotions to soothe skin affected by chilblains\n\t\t•\tGetting dry, if skin is wet"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "If you have only moderate cold exposure, you can treat it at home. Get inside and warm up. Take off any wet clothes. Cover yourself with blankets. Drink hot drinks -- just not any with alcohol or caffeine. If you have frostbite or trench foot and can't get to the doctor within an hour, soak the area in warm but not hot water. Remember that hypothermia is a medical emergency -- get help right away if you show symptoms, such as constant shivering or a temperature below 95 degrees Fahrenheit."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Staying in the cold despite symptoms, not wearing warm enough clothing, keeping the heat too low inside"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "If you have numbness after cold exposure, see your doctor right away.\n\nHypothermia is an emergency. If you have symptoms -- such as constant shivering or a body temperature below 95 degrees Fahrenheit -- get medical help immediately."

		},
		{

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "A dental abscess can begin with a chipped tooth, cavity, or gap between your tooth and gums. Bacteria invade the inner tooth, pus builds up, and an abscess forms. You may feel throbbing pain that gets worse until either the abscess bursts or you get it drained. In some cases, you'll have to have the tooth pulled. If untreated, the infection can spread to the head, neck, and other parts of the body and become life-threatening. The sooner you treat an abscess, the less likely you are to develop dangerous complications."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "First, you'll probably have a throbbing toothache that won't go away. It may get worse when you chew or the tooth is exposed to heat or cold. The infection may cause a visible swelling, or boil, on your gum. If untreated, it can spread to your cheek, throat, jaw, under your tongue, or to your neck. If the abscess breaks open, you'll have a rush of foul-tasting, foul-smelling fluid in your mouth. Even if this happens, you need treatment for the infection. If the abscess doesn't rupture, draining it via a root canal will relieve symptoms. Taking antibiotics fights the residual infection. If your tooth is very decayed, the infection too severe, or you've lost too much tissue or bone, the tooth will be pulled instead. If the infection has spread to the bottom of the mouth or neck, you may need treatment in a hospital."
		},

	"Toothache": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tSwelling"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "A toothache is any pain or soreness in or around a tooth. The most common causes are tooth decay, infection, cracked teeth, broken fillings, or an injury to the mouth or jaw. Pain can sometimes radiate from other parts of the body, causing the symptoms of a toothache. If a toothache persists, call your dentist. If the cause is tooth decay, quick treatment will limit the damage to your teeth. If the cause is not related to teeth or gums, your dentist may refer you to a physician."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "Go to an emergency room if tooth pain is caused by a serious injury to the mouth or jaw. Call your dentist immediately if you have lost or swallowed an adult tooth. Also call your dentist immediately if you have toothache pain accompanied by fever, which may be a sign of infection. If you've had a tooth extracted and develop severe pain several days later, call your dentist immediately. If you experience toothache or jaw pain and have recently been injured, have chest pain, rashes, or a history of heart disease, seek medical help immediately."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Toothaches caused by temporary problems such as food getting stuck between teeth go away on their own. A persistent toothache signals a problem that needs to be treated. Treatment and prognosis depend on the cause of the toothache. Almost all toothache pain can be eliminated with proper treatment."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Hot or cold foods, tapping on a damaged tooth"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment depends on the underlying cause of the toothache. Tooth decay can be removed and the cavity filled. Loose or broken fillings can be replaced. If the pulp has been damaged, you may need a root canal, in which the decayed pulp is removed and a new filling put in place. When a tooth is severely decayed or damaged, it may need to be removed. If the cause is gum disease, your doctor may give you an antibiotic and then talk to you about treating the underlying condition."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Over-the-counter pain relievers such as aspirin or ibuprofen can ease toothache pain. Some people get relief from holding a cotton ball soaked with oil of cloves (available at many drug stores) between their teeth. Avoid very hot or cold foods if your teeth are sensitive to temperature. If the pain persists, contact your dentist."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "Call your dentist if toothache pain persists for more than a day or recurs over several days. Call your dentist immediately if toothache pain is accompanied by fever, intense pain, or swelling."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",

It usually occurs only on one side of the face -- around the jaw and cheek or eye -- and may cause people to grimace -- like a tic. Trigeminal neuralgia often has no specific cause and is most common in people over age 50."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",

Touching the face, brushing the teeth, chewing, or shaving can trigger an attack. In most cases, the attacks get more frequent over time. Medications often can help treat the symptoms, but some people need surgery."

	"Salivary_duct_obstruction_(sialolithiasis)": [{
			"heading": "Sialolithiasis",
			"content": "Salivary duct stones"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tLump or bulge\n\t\t•\tSwelling"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Salivary duct obstruction occurs when small stones form in the salivary glands. These stones plug up the ducts, like a clog in a drain. The backed up saliva causes swelling and pain, often under the tongue or jaw. Salivary stones are uncomfortable but harmless.\n\nChronic bacterial infections and dry mouth -- from conditions like Sjögren's syndrome or medicines such as antidepressants, antihistamines, or antipsychotics -- can cause salivary stones."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "A salivary stone could take years to form, but you might not notice it until it's large enough to block the flow of saliva. The swelling and pain might be worst when you're eating, because chewing triggers saliva production. Once the stone passes through the duct -- or your doctor removes it -- the symptoms will go away. Sometimes, the blockage will cause a bacterial infection (sialadenitis), which might need antibiotics or surgery."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "An estimated 1 in 15,000 people have painful salivary duct stones, based on hospital admissions records."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Salivary stone treatments include:\n\t\t•\tGently pushing or massaging the duct to remove the stone\n\t\t•\tSurgery (for larger stones)\n\t\t•\tIf the blockage has caused a bacterial infection (sialadenitis), antibiotics typically will be prescribed."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "For small stones, drinking more fluids, using moist heat, and taking occasional NSAID painkillers (such as ibuprofen, ketoprofen, or naproxen) might help. Eating or drinking sour foods or drinks can increase saliva, which might help push out the stone."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Hard or chewy foods, dehydration, and medicines that cause dry mouth, such as some antidepressants, antipsychotics, and antihistamines"
		},
		{

			"content": "If you notice any chronic pain or swelling in your mouth or jaw, see a doctor."

	"Angioedema": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "Swelling"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Angioedema is swelling under the skin. It can be a sign of an allergic reaction, similar to hives. While hives are swollen welts on the skin's surface, angioedema is swelling beneath it. It often appears around eyes and lips. People may develop angioedema and hives in reaction to an insect sting, medications, pet dander, certain foods, sunlight, and other triggers. In most cases, people never figure out the cause. Some people have chronic angioedema. You can treat mild cases at home. Severe angioedema, which may cause difficulty breathing, can be life-threatening."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "If home treatment isn't helping or you have difficulty breathing such as shortness of breath, wheezing, or fainting, go to the emergency room. If you already have a prescribed medication for a severe allergic reaction such as an Epi-Pen or Twinject, use it."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "After coming in contact with a trigger, angioedema may cause swelling on the face, especially around the eyes and the mouth. Often, a person also will have hives -- itchy welts on the skin. It may get worse over several hours. Antihistamines may help control the reaction. Usually, the swelling will stop and go away within a few days. If it's severe, the airways may start to swell, too, making it hard to breathe. If you're wheezing or can't catch your breath -- or symptoms are still getting worse after taking antihistamines -- go to the emergency room."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Scratching, not getting treatment, and continuing to exposure yourself to the trigger"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for angioedema includes:\n\t\t•\tAntihistamines to control the allergic reaction\n\t\t•\tCorticosteroids to reduce swelling\n\t\t•\tEpinephrine to control a severe allergic reaction\n\t\t•\tOther medications\n\t\t•\tEmergency treatments to keep the airways open"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Over-the-counter antihistamines may control the reaction. Ice and cold compresses may help with swelling and itching. Scratching will make the welts worse. In the future, be careful to avoid allergens and other triggers. If you are having a severe reaction, follow the instructions for using your Epi-pen and have someone call emergency services."

	"Glomerulonephritis": [{
			"heading": "Glomerulonephritis",
			"content": "Glomerular disease"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tSwelling\n\t\t•\tDecreased urination\n\t\t•\tBlood or red colored urine\n\t\t•\tFatigue"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Glomerulonephritis is a serious type of kidney disease. It stops the kidneys from filtering blood normally. There are two types. Acute glomerulonephritis comes on suddenly, often after an infection with a virus such as strep. Chronic glomerulonephritis develops more slowly. Symptoms include dark, foamy, bubbly urine, swelling, and high blood pressure. Conditions such as diabetes and lupus can trigger glomerulonephritis. Glomerulonephritis may clear up with treatment or on its own. It may also get worse over time. Prompt treatment is key -- it can sometimes prevent permanent kidney damage."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "If you have symptoms of glomerulonephritis along with signs of severe high blood pressure, such as headache, vomiting, blurry vision, and seizures, go to the emergency room."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Acute glomerulonephritis causes symptoms that may get worse over days or weeks. You may notice brown urine or a puffy face in the morning. While acute glomerulonephritis may go away on its own, you need to get treatment. Drugs that suppress the immune system or treatments to filter the blood can help. Chronic glomerulonephritis may cause bubbly urine or swollen legs. It has no specific treatment. Working to lower blood pressure and reduce further damage to the kidneys may help. Some people with glomerulonephritis develop kidney failure and need dialysis or a transplant."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Not getting prompt treatment, eating a high-protein or high-salt diet, using NSAIDs such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin) or naproxen (Aleve)"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment depends on the type of glomerulonephritis. 		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "If high blood pressure is a problem, your doctor may recommend cutting down on protein, salt, and fluids in your diet. You may need to avoid NSAIDs, such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin), ketoprofen, and naproxen (Aleve)."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "If you have symptoms such as dark or foamy urine, call your doctor right away."
		},
		{

			"content": "\n\t\t•\tDry mouth\n\t\t•\tDifficulty swallowing\n\t\t•\tBad taste in mouth\n\t\t•\tBad breath\n\t\t•\tThick saliva or mucus"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Everybody has dry mouth occasionally, but people with dry mouth syndrome have a chronic feeling of dryness in their mouths. They may have less saliva than normal.  Consistent problems with dry mouth can lead to health problems such as tooth decay and oral infections. Medications are the most common cause. Hundreds of drugs -- for conditions such as allergies, colds, anxiety, diabetes, pain, high blood pressure, and depression -- cause dry mouth syndrome. So can dehydration, mouth breathing, alcohol, tobacco, chemotherapy, radiation, and a number of medical conditions such as Sjögren's syndrome, diabetes, rheumatoid arthritis, and HIV. Treating the symptoms and addressing the underlying problem will help."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "People with dry mouth syndrome may have a chronic sticky, dry mouth. Sometimes, a dentist or doctor is the first to notice it because of tooth decay or oral infections. Treatment depends on the cause. Often, dealing with an underlying condition, changing medication, or modifying lifestyle can clear up the symptoms. If not, treating the symptoms with medications and extra fluids will help. You may need more frequent dental check-ups if you have dry mouth syndrome."
		},

Avoid salty or spicy foods, which may make your mouth burn if you don't have enough saliva. Use a humidifier to moisturize the air. Make sure to brush your teeth at least twice a day, floss daily, and see your dentist two or three times a year."

			"content": "Fissured tongue is a harmless condition in which there are deep cracks or grooves (fissures) on the upper surface of the tongue. The size and depth of the grooves can vary and make the tongue look wrinkled. You can have a fissured tongue at birth, during childhood, or later, but it tends to appear more often and be more obvious with age. Fissured tongue is more common in men than women and runs in families. People with certain conditions such as Down syndrome may have fissured tongue. A poor diet and infection are other possible causes. Fissured tongue rarely results in any problems, so medical care is not usually necessary."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "You don't need any medication or therapy for fissured tongue, and there aren't any complications unless you have it with another condition. Fissured tongue can sometimes lead to bad breath. Some people with fissured tongue also have geographic tongue, which may cause slight pain when eating spicy foods. In the rare Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome, people have fissured tongue along with a swollen face or lips and some paralysis in the face."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tGum sores\n\t\t•\tItching or burning\n\t\t•\tSoreness or burning inside of mouth\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tMouth sores"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Canker sores are small ulcers inside your mouth. They usually appear on the tongue or cheeks, on the inside lips, at the base of the gums, or on the soft palate. You may have just one sore, or there may be several in a cluster. Canker sores can be painful. But they usually heal on their own and do not need medical treatment. No one knows for sure what causes canker sores, although physical and emotional stress are possible triggers. Canker sores are not cancer, and they do not turn into cancer. They also are not caused by the herpes virus. Good oral hygiene is important, though, to prevent infection."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Canker sores come on in a day or two and usually heal within one to three weeks. Large sores may take longer to heal -- typically two to four weeks. In people with cancer or HIV, it may take longer to heal. Occasionally, other symptoms may accompany the sores, such as a mild fever or a general feeling of being ill."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "There are millions of cases of canker sores in the U.S. every year."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "In general, canker sores do not need to be treated by a doctor. But if the sores come back frequently, or if they persist, a doctor can provide treatment to relieve symptoms.\n\nSilver nitrate or other chemical products can be applied to relieve pain and speed healing.\n\nA prescription mouthwash sometimes can be used to relieve pain and speed healing.\n\nFolic acid, iron, or vitamin B12 supplements sometimes can be effective if your canker sores are related to a deficiency of any of these nutrients.\n\nIn very severe cases, the doctor may prescribe steroid medications to speed healing."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tAvoid hot, spicy, or hard foods that can cause pain.\n\t\t•\tUse a soft bristle toothbrush to clean your teeth after every meal.\n\t\t•\tUse an over-the-counter antibacterial mouthwash or rinse with a mild saltwater solution several times a day for symptom relief.\n\t\t•\tApply a mixture of half hydrogen peroxide and half water directly to the sores. Then follow that with a small dab of milk of magnesia. Doing this three to four times a day can be soothing and may promote healing.\n\t\t•\tAsk your pharmacist about over-the-counter pain relievers that can work on canker sores."

			"heading": "Laryngitis",

			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tHoarse voice\n\t\t•\tLoss of voice\n\t\t•\tSore throat\n\t\t•\tCough\n\t\t•\tMuffled voice\n\t\t•\tDifficulty talking"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Laryngitis is an inflammation of the larynx, or voice box. Inside the larynx are the vocal cords. Swollen, irritated vocal chords cause hoarseness or loss of voice. Laryngitis is usually short-lived, but may be chronic. Cold or flu viruses and overusing your voice cause most cases of laryngitis. Other causes include heavy alcohol use, smoking, GERD, allergies, and rarely, bacteria or fungus. Resting your voice, breathing in humid air, drinking plenty of fluids, and not smoking allows vocal cords to heal. Treatment for chronic laryngitis may include vocal training or surgery."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Laryngitis often occurs along with a cold and may come on during or just after a sore throat. Symptoms of hoarseness and loss of voice last about seven to 10 days. Resting the voice, not smoking, and drinking plenty of fluids help reduce inflammation. Talking in a normal voice is better than whispering, which actually puts more strain on the vocal cords. If laryngitis continues longer than two weeks, see a doctor for an evaluation."
		},

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Esophageal cancer starts in the lining of the esophagus, the tube that carries food from the mouth to the stomach. Smoking and heavy alcohol use are the most common causes. But obesity and complications from long-term gastroesophageal reflux disease, or GERD, also can cause this cancer. Difficulty swallowing, the most common symptom, doesn't usually show up until the cancer has advanced. Survival rates are low, because it most often is diagnosed at a later stage, when it is more difficult to treat. Esophageal cancer is uncommon in the U.S."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "As an esophageal tumor grows, your symptoms may advance from trouble swallowing to choking on food and chest pain or burning. Eventually, you may have a hoarse voice, chronic cough, and persistent hiccups. If your cancer is diagnosed before it has spread to other organs, you'll probably need surgery, chemotherapy, and/or radiation therapy. About 37% of people with localized esophageal cancer survive five years or more. If you have aggressive heart or lung disease, or the cancer has advanced too far for treatment to be effective, your doctor may insert a tube into your esophagus to aid in swallowing and do other therapies to improve quality of life."
		},

			"heading": "Vocal Cord Polyp",

		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tHoarse voice"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "A vocal cord polyp is a non-cancerous swelling, bump, or growth that forms on one or sometimes both vocal cords. Doctors don't always know why it happens, although it is usually associated with long-term smoking or misuse of your voice such as too much yelling or singing improperly. It also can be linked to other conditions such as hypothyroidism, gastroesophageal reflux, or allergies. Vocal cord polyps make your voice sound hoarse. There are several ways to treat a vocal cord polyp including vocal therapy and surgery."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "With a vocal cord polyp, your voice slowly becomes hoarse and breathy. In some cases, you might have difficulty breathing and make a raspy noise when you inhale. Symptoms often can be relieved by lifestyle changes such as quitting smoking or taking care of your voice. In some cases, surgery is necessary. Sometimes, your voice still will be somewhat hoarse and won't completely return to normal after treatment."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Vocal cord polyps are one of the most common causes of voice problems."

		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "If you have too much exposure to heat, the first symptoms you might notice are heavy sweating, dizziness, or cramps in your muscles. Doing exercise or working outdoors can make these symptoms worse. Usually, getting out of the heat and cooling down will make you feel better. If you don't get out of the heat, your symptoms can quickly get worse. Eventually, heat exposure can lead to heatstroke, the most severe type of heat-related illness. If you have heatstroke, your body might stop sweating, and you might have a high fever, confusion, dizziness, nausea, vomiting, or a fast heartbeat. Heatstroke is a medical emergency and needs treatment at a hospital."

	"Strained_voice_(vocal_cords)": [{
			"heading": "Strained Voice (Vocal Chords)",
			"content": "Hoarseness, dysphonia, loss of voice"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tLoss of voice\n\t\t•\tMuffled voice\n\t\t•\tHoarse voice\n\t\t•\tDifficulty talking"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Strained vocal cords occur when a person talks, sings, or shouts too loudly or too long, or sings without proper technique. Cold or flu viruses, laryngitis, heavy alcohol use, smoking, coughing, gastroesophageal reflux (GERD), and allergies also can irritate vocal cords and cause loss of voice. More serious causes can include thyroid problems, trauma, and cancer. A strained voice causes hoarseness, raspiness, rawness, an achy throat, difficulty talking, or not being able to hit higher notes when singing. Vocal strain can happen to anyone, but smokers and people who use their voice a lot every day such as public speakers, singers, lawyers, teachers, and sales people are at greater risk for vocal strain. A strained voice usually heals on its own with self-care, such as not smoking, drinking plenty of fluids, resting your voice, breathing in humid air, and practicing good vocal techniques when talking or singing."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "You may notice hoarseness, raspy voice, and difficulty talking after cheering on a favorite sports team or after a cold or the flu. Resting your voice, not smoking, drinking plenty of fluids, and breathing humid air should ease symptoms in one or two weeks. If your hoarseness is caused by allergies or acid reflux (GERD), getting treatment for those problems should ease your strained voice."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 7.5 million people in the U.S. have voice disorders or diseases."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for a strained voice may include:\n\t\t•\tResting the voice\n\t\t•\tNot smoking and avoiding secondhand smoke\n\t\t•\tAvoiding spicy foods, alcohol, and caffeine\n\t\t•\tBreathing in humid air\n\t\t•\tDrinking plenty of fluids\n\t\t•\tSpeech or voice training\n\t\t•\tMedication for gastroesophageal reflux (GERD) if you have GERD"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Most people can treat a strained voice at home by vocal rest, breathing in humid air, drinking fluids, not smoking, and avoiding secondhand smoke."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Smoking, secondhand smoke, spicy foods, caffeine, alcohol, coughing, allergies, cold and flu, vocal cord polyps, speaking loudly, shouting, singing without proper technique"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "If symptoms of a strained voice last longer than two weeks, see your doctor. If you have difficulty breathing or swallowing, feel a lump on your neck, or are coughing up blood, get immediate medical help."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tIs vocal strain causing my symptoms?\n\t\t•\tWhat can I do to ease my symptoms?\n\t\t•\tHow long should I rest my voice?\n\t\t•\tHow can I prevent vocal strain?"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",

Switching to a different form of antibiotic will often stop the reaction you are experiencing."

	"Poisoning": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tMetallic taste in mouth"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Poisoning can be mild or life threatening. Possible poisons include medications, illicit drugs, supplements, carbon monoxide, household cleaners, and other chemicals. Even over-the-counter medications -- such as the painkiller acetaminophen -- can be lethal in high doses. Poisons can be swallowed, breathed in, or absorbed through the skin. Poisoning is always an emergency. Any child or adult who has been exposed to poison -- or who might have been exposed to a poison -- needs medical help."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "If you or another person has been exposed to poison -- or may have been exposed -- call your local poison control center. Follow the instructions. Call emergency services or go to the emergency room if the representative suggests it. Getting treatment quickly can be lifesaving. If you can, bring the poison with you to show the doctors."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Symptoms depend on the type of poison. They may include nausea, vomiting, breathing changes, and unconsciousness. Don't wait for symptoms to appear before getting help. A child or adult may seem fine after poison exposure. It may take hours, days, or months for symptoms to appear, depending on the poison. Don't try to treat poisoning on your own. Don't make the person vomit with syrup of ipecac. Instead, call a poison control center."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",

		},
