	"Esophagitis": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tMouth sores\n\t\t•\tBloody or red colored vomit\n\t\t•\tNausea or vomiting\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tHeartburn\n\t\t•\tDifficulty swallowing"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Esophagitis is inflammation of the lining of the esophagus, the tube that carries food from the mouth to the stomach. Acid reflux from heartburn and GERD most commonly cause esophagitis. People with it may feel chest pain behind the breastbone, nausea, and have difficult or painful swallowing. Esophagitis also can be caused by medications that get stuck in the esophagus. Bacteria, viruses, or fungus are other causes, usually in people with weakened immune systems from HIV. Diabetes and leukemia may also be causes, along with chemotherapy and radiation therapy. The treatment varies, depending on what's causing the esophagitis."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Mild esophagitis may get better on its own in a day or two. Taking antacids or other treatments to soothe and coat the esophagus can help ease the pain. Symptoms that last longer indicate damage to the surface lining of the esophagus or a possible infection. With treatment, the symptoms usually ease in a few days. But they may take several weeks to completely go away."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment depends on what's causing your symptoms:\n\nFor acid reflux, the doctor may prescribe acid-blocking or acid-reducing medications. The doctor also may suggest making certain lifestyle changes, including dietary changes, quitting smoking if you do smoke, avoiding alcohol, and cutting back on caffeine.\n\nFor medication-induced esophagitis, the doctor may take you off the drug that is causing the problem until the esophagus heals. Or the doctor may prescribe the medication in liquid or different form.\n\nInfections affecting the esophagus can be treated with antibiotics. While the esophagus heals, the doctor may prescribe pain relievers to reduce your symptoms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Certain lifestyle changes can reduce the frequency of esophagitis. 		},

		},

		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "The doctor will diagnose esophagitis based on your symptoms. The doctor may request an endoscopy or an upper GI series to see the damage done to the esophagus. In an endoscopy, a doctor will use a camera attached to the end of a long, flexible tube to see the lining of your esophagus. An upper GI involves a series of X-rays taken after you swallow a solution containing barium. The barium coats the wall of the esophagus to make it visible and shows any damage. The doctor also may ask for other tests to rule out other possible causes of chest pain."

It's an autoimmune disease, meaning the body mistakenly starts to attack healthy tissue. There are several types. No one knows what causes it, although it's more common in older people, Eastern European Jews, and people from countries around the Mediterranean. It is not contagious. Treatment is crucial. Untreated pemphigus can be life threatening."

Corticosteroids are the typical treatment, although they can have serious side effects. The earlier a person starts treatment, the better the outcome. 		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Oral herpes is a common, very contagious viral infection. It causes cold sores or fever blisters, usually around the mouth. They may also appear on the tongue, face, or other area of skin. Oral herpes is not the same thing as genital herpes or canker sores. People usually get oral herpes as an infant or child from close contact with an adult or by sharing items such as lip balm or silverware. The infection can spread, even if the person does not have symptoms. Often, you don't need treatment for oral herpes. But cream or ointment can help relieve discomfort. Antiviral pills can shorten outbreaks and make them less severe. There is no cure for oral herpes. The virus stays in your body for life. It may or may not cause future outbreaks."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Although it can be mild, the first outbreak of oral herpes is usually the worst. Tingling, itching, or burning usually occur before one or more painful blisters appears. These break open, ooze, and form a crust. Sores often heal without treatment within two weeks. But once you are infected, the virus moves from the skin to nerve cells and stays in your body for life. It can just stay\"quiet\" or something can make it active again. Over time, outbreaks tend to be milder and less frequent."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Contact with someone who has simplex virus type 1. Once you have the virus, risk factors for flare-ups include stress, fatigue, illness, fever, sun exposure, menstrual periods, pregnancy, cuts, or surgery."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "By age 50, as many as nine out of 10 people have the oral herpes virus."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Prevention",
			"content": "If you or your child has tingling, itching, burning, or sores on your face, do not kiss or share silverware, cups, towels, or lip balms. Wash towels in hot water. Do not have oral sex. Prevent spread to other parts of your body such as eyes: Wash hands after touching sores. Use a cotton swab to apply medicine to cold sores. To help prevent new outbreaks, apply sunblock and lip balm with zinc oxide."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "If needed, treatment may include topical creams or ointments. You can take over-the-counter pain relievers such as ibuprofen or acetaminophen. 		},

			"content": "Erythema multiforme is a rare and potentially serious skin condition. It causes a rash and blisters. There are two types. Viruses such as herpes usually cause erythema multiforme minor, which is less severe. Allergic reactions to drugs usually cause erythema multiforme major, which can be life threatening. It's sometimes called Stevens-Johnson syndrome. Many medications can trigger it, such as some antibiotics, sedatives, and NSAID pain relievers."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Erythema multiforme minor usually clears up in two to six weeks, although it may come back. Treatment focuses on relieving itchiness and pain. Erythema multiforme major is much more serious. It usually starts with flu-like symptoms such as fever and achiness followed by a rash on the body, and sores in the mouth and on the genitals. Most people with erythema multiforme major need treatment in the hospital. It can damage the organs, and infections are a serious risk. If a drug caused erythema multiforme, taking the medication again will cause the condition to come back."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",

Common medications such as some sedatives, antibiotics, and seizure drugs can trigger erythema multiforme. So can conditions such as herpes or mycoplasma pneumonia. It's more common in people with AIDS and other conditions that suppress the immune system."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "The esophagus is a long tube that carries food from the mouth to the stomach. An esophageal stricture is a spot where the esophagus becomes too narrow. Food can get stuck. Swallowing can be difficult and painful. Chronic acid reflux, scar tissue, and injuries can lead to strictures. Although rare, more serious conditions such as autoimmune diseases and tumors cause them, as well. Treatments can widen the esophagus and control the underlying cause."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Untreated strictures tend to get worse over time. At first, you may feel discomfort when swallowing. Eventually, the esophagus could become completely blocked. Swallowing food -- or even liquids -- might become impossible. People with esophageal strictures can accidentally inhale food or drink, causing lung infections. Treatment can widen the esophagus. Medicine for acid reflux often helps with esophageal strictures. Most people don't need surgery. Even after successful treatment, some esophageal strictures will come back."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 10% of people with chronic acid reflux or GERD develop an esophageal stricture."

	"Glycogen_Storage_Disease_Type_II": [{
			"heading": "Glycogen Storage Disease Type 2",
			"content": "GSDII, Pompe disease, acid maltase deficiency"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Glycogen storage disease type 2 is a rare but serious genetic disorder. It causes life-threatening muscle weakness in the heart and in the muscles that help you breathe. People with GSD type 2 don't have enough of an enzyme that breaks down a natural type of sugar, called glycogen. As a result, glycogen builds up in the body, damaging the muscles. Thanks to recent treatment breakthroughs, people are living longer with GSD type 2."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "GSD type 2 is also called Pompe disease. There are two kinds. Early-onset Pompe disease affects babies younger than 6 months old. It gets worse quickly, damaging the heart. Without treatment, it's usually fatal in the first year. Late-onset Pompe disease affects children and adults up to their 60s. It tends to develop more slowly and doesn't usually affect the heart. Instead, it causes muscle weakness, often in the muscles at your hips and shoulders, and in the muscles that help you breathe. While late-onset Pompe disease usually shortens a person's life, many people live for decades after their diagnosis. With both kinds of GSD type 2, treatments can help ease symptoms and slow down the disease."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "One out of 40,000 people has glycogen storage disease type 2."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Family history of GSD type 2 or Pompe disease."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "The main treatment for GSD type 2 is called enzyme replacement therapy. Your doctor will give you medicines that take the place of the missing enzyme. Treatment can help slow down the disease, protecting your muscles from more damage. You get the drug by IV, usually every other week. One drug is FDA-approved for babies. Another is approved for older kids and adults. Depending on your symptoms, you may need the help of many experts -- like cardiologists, respiratory therapists, physical therapists, and others. It depends on how the disease develops.\n\nGSD type 2 is a genetic disorder. You could pass it on to your children -- but only if your partner also carries the same gene. Talk to your doctor or a genetic counselor about the risks. If you're pregnant, you can get a test to see if your baby has GSD type 2."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "GSD type 2 needs medical treatment."

			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tSnoring\n\t\t•\tFeeling of not being able to get enough air\n\t\t•\tShortness of breath\n\t\t•\tBlue colored skin\n\t\t•\tNoisy breathing\n\t\t•\tLabored breathing"

			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "An upper airway obstruction occurs when something blocks the trachea, the larynx, or the throat, making it difficult or impossible to breath. Upper airway obstruction is a medical emergency. A number of things can block the upper airway, including food or foreign objects, burns from chemicals or smoke, severe allergic reactions that cause swelling, viral or bacterial infections, abscesses, cancer, or injury. Symptoms include difficulty breathing, wheezing, agitation, gasping for air, panic, and unconsciousness. Performing the Heimlich maneuver can help clear the airway in people choking on food or other objects. If you don't know what's causing the blockage, call emergency services immediately."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "If you or someone around you shows signs of choking on food or another object, use the Heimlich maneuver to remove it. For other causes of upper airway obstruction, call emergency services immediately."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Immediate treatment will clear the blockage for most people. However, the condition can be fatal, depending on the cause and amount of time it takes to get treatment."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Not getting immediate medical treatment"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment depends on the cause and may include:\n\t\t•\tDoing the Heimlich maneuver\n\t\t•\tSurgically removing a foreign object Inserting a tube down the airway to assist breathing\n\t\t•\tDoing a tracheostomy\n\t\t•\tMedications to reduce swelling"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Heimlich maneuver"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "For any airway obstruction, get medical help right away. If a severe allergic reaction or other medical condition caused the airway obstruction, make a follow-up appointment to see your doctor."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tWhat caused the upper airway obstruction?\n\t\t•\tDo I need ongoing treatment?\n\t\t•\tWhat can I do to prevent this condition from recurring?"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "A doctor or emergency medical technician can diagnose an upper airway obstruction by doing a quick physical evaluation. Other tests may include a chest X-ray or performing a laryngoscopy, viewing the airway with a lighted scope."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 18,000 children in the U.S. each year suffer injuries due to suffocation."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Being age 4 or younger, gulping food, and having severe allergies put a person at higher risk of choking and suffocation.  Some medications, such as ACE inhibitors, can cause blockage of the airway as a result of swelling in the mouth and throat. ACE (angiotensin-converting enzyme) inhibitors are used to treat hypertension."

	"Esophageal_spasm": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tTaste of acid in mouth\n\t\t•\tHeartburn\n\t\t•\tFood getting stuck (swallowing)\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tDifficulty swallowing"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Esophageal spasms are sudden, painful contractions in the muscles of the esophagus that last a few minutes. Experts aren't sure why they happen, although swallowing a pill, a large chunk of food -- or drinking very hot or very cold drinks -- can trigger them. People with heartburn are more likely to get them. The pain can be intense; some people mistake an esophageal spasm for a heart attack. Most esophageal spasms don't need treatment, but chronic esophageal spasms can be disabling and sometimes need medicine or surgery."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "When you swallow, muscles in the esophagus contract to move food into the stomach. In an esophageal spasm, these muscles tighten randomly or too forcefully. Most people don't need treatment for esophageal spasms. The spasms only happen occasionally and the pain stops within a minute or two. Other people have such intense chronic pain that eating becomes almost impossible. Medicine or surgery can treat severe cases."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Millions of people have esophageal spasms in the U.S. every day."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Most people don't need treatment for esophageal spasms. People with more severe cases might need:\n\t\t•\tBetter control of other conditions that are related to esophageal spasms, such as GERD or anxiety disorders\n\t\t•\tNitroglycerin tablets\n\t\t•\tCalcium channel blockers (a type of medicine often used for high blood pressure)\n\t\t•\tAntidepressants (which can ease the pain of esophageal spasm)\n\t\t•\tMedicines to relax the muscles\n\t\t•\tInjections of botulinum toxin\n\t\t•\tSurgery"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Avoid very hot or very cold foods and drinks, because they can trigger esophageal spasms. Make sure to chew your food carefully before swallowing. Try to reduce stress with exercise or breathing exercises."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Very hot or very cold drinks, swallowing large pieces of food"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "If you have pain when swallowing or difficulty swallowing, see your doctor. If you have any sudden, intense chest pain, get emergency help. It can be hard to tell the difference between esophageal spasms and a heart attack."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",

		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "Your doctor will take a medical history and do a medical exam. You may also need X-rays, CT scans, tests of your swallowing muscles, or an endoscopy -- an exam in which a doctor guides a thin tube with a camera down the esophagus."

			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Esophageal spasms may be more common in women and older people. Conditions such as heartburn, GERD (gastroesophageal reflux disease), and anxiety increase the risk."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Cystic fibrosis (CF) is an inherited disease that causes the body to produce abnormally thick and sticky mucus. This mucus blocks the passages in the lungs and in the pancreas. Over time, it can cause life-threatening lung damage and severe digestion problems. The symptoms of CF usually begin in childhood and include repeated lung or sinus infections, a chronic cough, fatigue, wheezing, constipation, salty-tasting skin, poor growth, and greasy stools. Most children who have CF are diagnosed by the time they are age 2."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Most children with cystic fibrosis are fairly healthy until they reach adulthood, and then they begin to have more symptoms. Usually, the lung problems continue to get worse until the person becomes disabled. The life expectancy for people with CF, which has been steadily improving over the last several decades, is 40-plus years. Early diagnosis and treatment helps improve quality and length of life. Treatments for CF include medications, therapy to loosen lung mucus, and surgery."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",

The fungus that causes thrush -- Candida albicans -- thrives when your immune system is weak. Infants, older people, and people with chronic diseases are more likely to get thrush. But anyone can get it, especially after using antibiotics. Thrush may go away on its own. Some people, though, need treatment."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",

While thrush is not usually a serious problem, it can be a sign of another disease. Thrush can pose a danger if you have a seriously weakened immune system. In people getting chemotherapy or people with HIV, thrush can spread through the body. They may need powerful antifungal medicines to control it."

Located throughout the body, lymph nodes often swell and become tender when fighting an infection. For example, you may notice tender lumps under your chin when you have a cold. Those are your lymph nodes hard at work. Most of the time, the swelling goes away after a few days or weeks and is nothing to worry about."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "A broken neck, also called a cervical fracture, is a serious, life-threatening injury. Car accidents, falls, diving accidents, gunshot wounds, and sports injuries can cause a broken neck. A broken neck often injures the spinal cord, too, causing temporary or permanent loss of feeling from the neck down. A cervical fracture can cause severe neck pain that may radiate to the shoulders and arms. It may also cause muscle weakness and numbness, difficulty breathing, loss of bowel and bladder control, and bruising and swelling at the back of the neck. Treatment depends on which of the seven neck vertebrae you broke. Treatment can include neck braces, pain medication, traction, surgery, and physical and occupational therapy."

			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "If you have a broken neck from an auto accident or fall, you may have other injuries, as well. Your doctor will immobilize your neck, do a physical exam, and treat the most severe injuries first. Treatment depends on which cervical vertebra you injured. Neck braces, pain medication, traction, surgery, and physical and occupational therapy all treat neck fractures. Recovery can take months and even longer if you have surgery or have a spinal cord injury."

			"heading": "Anthrax (Skin)",
			"content": "Cutaneous anthrax"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tEnlarged or swollen glands\n\t\t•\tFever\n\t\t•\tSkin rash\n\t\t•\tSkin bumps\n\t\t•\tTender glands\n\t\t•\tSwelling\n\t\t•\tHeadache\n\t\t•\tSkin blisters\n\t\t•\tSkin redness"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Anthrax is a bacterial infection that typically attacks animals such as sheep, cattle, and goats. In rare cases, people may develop anthrax from spores in the soil or infected animals. People may get a blister on the skin if an anthrax spore enters the body through a scrape or cut. The infection can spread to the blood and become life threatening without treatment. The vast majority of people with anthrax infections on the skin recover with antibiotics. Anthrax is extremely rare in the U.S. -- even in animals. But it's more common in parts of Southern and Eastern Europe, South and Central America, Asia, Africa, the Middle East, and the Caribbean. Researchers have developed strains of anthrax as biological weapons. In 2001, 5 people died and 17 people developed infections on the skin after handling letters tainted with anthrax."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Cutaneous anthrax symptoms usually appear within a week of exposure. They start with a sore that turns into a blister. It may look like an insect bite. The sore and blister are painless. The blister then turns into an ulcer covered with a black scab. While some people recover without treatment, getting help can be life saving. Almost all people who get antibiotics for cutaneous anthrax recover without problems. Without treatment, as many as one out of five people with anthrax infections on the skin will die. Anthrax cannot spread from one person to another."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Working on a farm, working with animal carcasses, hides, hair, or wool, being a veterinarian, being in the military in areas with anthrax, working in a lab with anthrax"
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Anthrax poisoning is extremely rare. In the U.S., there are about one or two cases of cutaneous anthrax each year."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Prevention",
			"content": "Anthrax is rare. Most people don't need to take special precautions. People who may have come in contact with anthrax may need antibiotics in case they were infected. Anthrax cannot spread from person to person. There is an anthrax vaccine, but it is not available to the public. Only people at high risk of developing anthrax -- such as members of the military, some lab workers, some veterinarians, and others who work with animals, carcasses, or skins -- can usually get the vaccine."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",

	"Lymphoma": [{
			"heading": "Lymphoma",
			"content": "Hodgkin lymphoma, non-Hodgkin's lymphoma"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tEnlarged or swollen glands\n\t\t•\tChills\n\t\t•\tFever\n\t\t•\tLump or bulge\n\t\t•\tWeight loss (unintentional)\n\t\t•\tNight sweats\n\t\t•\tSwelling\n\t\t•\tFatigue\n\t\t•\tItching or burning\n\t\t•\tSkin rash\n\t\t•\tTires quickly"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Lymphoma is a type of cancer that begins in cells in the lymphatic system, part of your body's immune system. It occurs when lymphocytes, white blood cells that protect you from disease and infection, start behaving abnormally. Lymphoma is divided into two main types, Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, based on the lymphocytes involved. Hodgkin's lymphoma is one of the most curable cancers. Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, which is more common, can be cured in some cases and kept in check for many years in others."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "You're most likely to get lymphoma between the ages of 40 and 70, although you're also at risk for Hodgkin's lymphoma if you're young or elderly. What causes lymphoma isn't certain, but some infections, medical conditions that compromise the immune system, and exposure to toxic chemicals may increase your risk. Lymphomas may grow fast or slowly. You're most likely to experience swollen lymph nodes in the neck, upper chest, armpit, abdomen, or groin. You also may have flu-like symptoms like fever, chills, night sweats, or lack of energy. If you have a slow-growing lymphoma, you may not need to treat it until it progresses. Radiation therapy is the first recommended treatment. Chemotherapy, with or without radiation, also treats lymphoma."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 74,000 men and women get lymphoma each year in the U.S."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Aging, hepatitis B or C, Epstein-Barr, HIV, autoimmune disease, family history of lymphoma, and exposure to toxic chemicals such as pesticides, herbicides, black hair dye, and benzene (a highly toxic solvent) increase your risk for lymphoma."

Psoriatic arthritis most often causes swelling and joint pain in the fingers and toes. But some people can have swelling in the spine, which can cause burning, pain, and stiffness in the lower back. Some people may have mild symptoms, while others may have more severe symptoms."
		},

You may have periods when you feel fine and periods when your symptoms flare up. There is no cure for psoriatic arthritis, but you can keep the symptoms under control with medications. In rare cases, surgery might be needed."

Bone spurs are not painful, but they can cause pain when they rub against other bones and nerves. Most bone spurs are caused by conditions such as osteoarthritis or tendonitis. But in some cases, bone spurs are a natural part of aging. Bone spurs can cause pain and loss of motion in the joint where they occur. Some bone spurs cause no symptoms and may not need treatment. Others may need pain medications or surgery."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Your symptoms will depend on where your bone spur is located. Common areas for bone spurs include the neck, knee, spine, fingers, heel, and shoulder. Bone spurs on your shoulders and knees can make it harder to move those joints. Bone spurs on your heel can cause foot pain and make walking difficult. When bone spurs grow on your spine, it can cause pain, numbness, and tingling in other areas of your body. Bone spurs are only treated if they are causing symptoms. Treatments include pain relievers, anti-inflammatory medications, orthotics, and surgery."

Other causes include roller coaster rides, contact sports, or being shaken or punched. Medication and exercise usually help ease discomfort. Most people recover fully within six weeks. But others may have pain and stiffness that gradually improves over the course of a year. Less than 20% of people still have symptoms 18 months after their injury. Studies show that people who suffer symptoms right after an accident are more likely to have longer-lasting problems from whiplash."

People with Down syndrome usually have similar physical traits. These include a flat-shaped face, eyes that slant upwards, a short neck, small hands and feet, decreased muscle tone, and a small head. They also have delayed mental and social development and learning problems."
		},

			"heading": "What to Expect",

Babies with Down syndrome usually develop more slowly than other babies and usually don't reach an average adult height. People with Down syndrome often have other medical conditions, including eye problems, hearing problems, heart problems, intestinal problems, and thyroid problems. There is no cure for Down syndrome, but physical therapy, occupational therapy, and other programs can help treat developmental and physical problems. People with Down syndrome may also need to see their doctor and other specialists regularly to treat any medical conditions."

	"Spinal_meningitis": [{
			"heading": "Spinal Meningitis",
			"content": "Bacterial meningitis, viral meningitis, meningococcal meningitis"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tStiff neck\n\t\t•\tConfusion\n\t\t•\tHeadache\n\t\t•\tSensitive to light\n\t\t•\tShaking chills (rigors)\n\t\t•\tSeizures (uncontrollable jerking of limbs)\n\t\t•\tApathy\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tFever\n\t\t•\tNausea or vomiting\n\t\t•\tSensitive to noise\n\t\t•\tDisorientation\n\t\t•\tComa"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Spinal meningitis is a swelling of the membranes that cover the spinal cord and brain. It can be a life-threatening emergency. Meningitis is caused most often by a virus, but it also can be caused by a bacteria or fungus. Meningitis causes a severe headache, high fever, stiff neck, fatigue, sore throat, confusion, skin rash, muscle aches, and seizures. In infants, meningitis can cause a high fever, constant crying, and seizures."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "The symptoms of meningitis can start over a few hours or happen over a few days. It often starts with a severe headache, fatigue, and a stiff neck. Contrary to common belief, however, you can have meningitis without having a stiff neck. Meningitis caused by a virus is not as severe and usually gets better in a few weeks. Bacterial meningitis is usually much more serious and needs immediate treatment with antibiotics. If not treated quickly, it can be deadly."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Living with a large number of people, such as in a dormitory or on a military base; pregnancy; working with animals; having a weakened immune system"
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Fewer than 1 in 100,000 people in the U.S. get bacterial meningitis every year."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Prevention",
			"content": "You can help prevent getting or spreading meningitis by following these tips:\n\t\t•\tCarefully wash your hands BEFORE contact with people if you are sick and AFTER seeing people who are sick.\n\t\t•\tIf you are ill, keep your own drinking and eating utensils separate until they are washed.\n\t\t•\tDo not share glasses, utensils, lipstick, or cigarettes if you are sick.\n\t\t•\tCover your mouth when sneezing or coughing.\n\t\t•\tGet vaccinations for bacterial meningitis if you are in a high-risk group."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Bacterial meningitis needs immediate treatment with antibiotics. Viral meningitis is usually treated with over-the-counter pain relievers."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "If you have bacterial meningitis, you usually need treatment in a hospital. For mild cases of viral meningitis, these self-care tips can help ease symptoms:\n\t\t•\tTake over-the-counter pain relievers.\n\t\t•\tGet plenty of rest.\n\t\t•\tDrink lots of fluids."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "See your doctor if someone you live with or work with has meningitis. Seek emergency treatment right away if: You have any symptoms of meningitis, such as severe headache, confusion, irritability, fatigue, weakness, sensitivity to light, high fever, stiff neck, seizures, or a rash; If you have been diagnosed with viral meningitis and the symptoms suddenly become worse."

	"Breast_cancer_(female)": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tBleeding from nipple\n\t\t•\tSwelling\n\t\t•\tEnlarged or swollen glands\n\t\t•\tFever\n\t\t•\tSkin rash\n\t\t•\tWarm to touch\n\t\t•\tDischarge from nipple\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tChills\n\t\t•\tFatigue\n\t\t•\tLump or bulge\n\t\t•\tVisible deformity\n\t\t•\tTenderness to touch"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "After skin cancer, breast cancer is the most common cancer in women. This cancer can also occur in men, although rarely. There are several types of breast cancer, but all start within tissue in the breast. From there, if not caught and treated, cancer can spread to the lymph nodes, brain, lungs, and liver. The earlier breast cancer is found, the better chance of recovery. Over the last two decades, the death rate from breast cancer has gone down steadily. Today, there is a wide range of new and improved treatments that are making it possible for women with breast cancer to live longer than ever before. There are about 3.1 million breast cancer survivors in the U.S. today."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Breast cancer may be found in several ways. You may notice a lump in your breast, or your doctor may discover a lump during a routine exam. Cancer might also be found with a mammogram, which is an X-ray of your breast tissue, before it's large enough to feel. Keep in mind that other less serious conditions can produce the same symptoms as breast cancer. So the doctor will need to do a biopsy to confirm that you have cancer. Treatment will most likely be some combination of surgery, radiation, chemotherapy, and other options. After treatment ends, you'll need regular checkups, and you may continue to take medication to prevent the cancer from coming back."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Almost 300,000 women and 2,300 men in the U.S. are diagnosed with breast cancer each year."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Having a mother, sister, or daughter with breast cancer, being overweight, lack of exercise, excessive alcohol use, taking hormone replacement therapy, having had radiation therapy in the past, having a personal history of breast cancer"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment will likely consist of some combination of the following options:\n\t\t•\tSurgery to remove the cancer, which might also involve removing the breast and lymph nodes\n\t\t•\tRadiation therapy to destroy the cancer in the breast\n\t\t•\tChemotherapy, which uses chemicals to treat cancer that may have spread to other parts of the body\n\t\t•\tHormone therapy to block the effect of certain hormones on cancer growth\n\t\t•\tTargeted therapy, which uses chemicals to attack specific cancer cells without harming other cells in the body\n\t\t•\tIn addition, your doctor will also provide treatment to manage pain and to address any side effects of the cancer treatment."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "During treatment, it's important to take care of yourself by making healthy lifestyle choices, including eating a healthy diet and remaining physically active."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "If you feel a mass or tenderness in your breast that persists through a menstrual cycle, see your doctor. Also see your doctor if you have any skin or nipple changes, pain or swelling in the breast, or discharge from the nipple."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tWhat type of breast cancer do I have?\n\t\t•\tWhat stage is the cancer?\n\t\t•\tWhat are my treatment options?\n\t\t•\tDo I need any other tests?\n\t\t•\tCan this cancer be treated without total breast removal?"
		},

			"heading": "Diagnosed By",

If a mass is found, a breast tissue biopsy may be needed to confirm the diagnosis and to stage the cancer."

Bacteria on the nipple or from the baby's mouth goes into a milk duct through a break in the skin. Lactation mastitis causes the breast to be tender and swollen, but medicines can help cure the infection and relieve pain. It is important that you keep breastfeeding or use a breast pump while you have mastitis in order to keep the milk flowing and your breasts from becoming uncomfortably full."
		},

	"Broken_(fractured)_rib(s)": [{
			"heading": "Broken (Fractured) Rib(s)",
			"content": "Costal fracture, rib fracture"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tBroken bone (single fracture)\n\t\t•\tSwelling\n\t\t•\tVisible deformity\n\t\t•\tBroken bones (multiple fractures)\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tBruising or discoloration\n\t\t•\tTenderness to touch"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Broken ribs are a common injury. A blow to the chest -- during a car accident, a fall, or a football game -- may break a rib. Older people, especially women, have a higher risk of broken ribs because their bones tend to be weaker. Repetitive stress to the bones -- from a severe chronic cough, for instance -- can also break a rib. Broken ribs can cause mild or severe pain. Typically, ribs heal on their own in one or two months. In the meantime, rest and pain relievers can help ease the pain."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "After the injury, the ribs will likely heal within a few months. Most people recover at home. Usually, the rib is just cracked. A completely broken rib could be more serious, because the sharp end of the broken bone could damage organs such as the lungs. More severe injuries may need hospitalization or surgery. Broken ribs can have complications. Sometimes, cartilage in the ribcage is irritated, causing ongoing pain. People with rib fractures tend to take shallow breaths because breathing deeply is painful. That can increase the risk of pneumonia."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Pain may be made worse by moving around, lifting, twisting, bending, taking deep breaths, coughing or sneezing, or sleeping on an uncomfortable pillow or mattress."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatments for rib fracture may include:\n\t\t•\tRest\n\t\t•\tOver-the-counter or prescription medicines to reduce pain and swelling\n\t\t•\tIcing the area for 10 minutes at a time\n\t\t•\tNerve blocks -- special injections of anesthesia\n\t\t•\tSurgery and hospitalization (for severe cases or complications)"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "You should get plenty of rest to let your rib heal. Icing the area and using NSAIDs -- such as ibuprofen or naproxen -- will ease pain and swelling. Painkilling creams -- with capsaicin or arnica -- may help, too. Try to take a deep breath once an hour, even if it hurts. It will help prevent pneumonia and keep the lungs healthy."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "See a doctor promptly if you have sudden or severe chest pain, or sudden shortness of breath."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tShould I cut back on my activity while the bone heals?\n\t\t•\tHow long will it take to be back to normal?\n\t\t•\tWhat are signs of complications?\n\t\t•\tHow often will I need check-ups?"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "Your doctor will ask you questions, examine you, and take X-rays. You may need other tests such as MRIs or CT scans."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Every year, about 1 in 1000 people in the U.S. breaks one rib or more."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Women over 40 are more likely to have rib fractures because of osteoporosis, which weakens the bones. People who play contact sports are at higher risk too. Other risk factors include injuries, alcoholism, and repetitive stress from chronic coughing or activities such as rowing. Conditions such as asthma, obesity, lung disease, and cancer also raise your risk."
		}

	"Chronic_obstructive_pulmonary_disease_(COPD)": [{
			"heading": "COPD",
			"content": "Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, emphysema, chronic obstructive airways disease, chronic obstructive lung disease, chronic bronchitis"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tCough\n\t\t•\tEnlarged finger tips\n\t\t•\tShortness of breath\n\t\t•\tDifficulty talking\n\t\t•\tCurved fingernails\n\t\t•\tNoisy breathing\n\t\t•\tWheezing"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "COPD is a chronic lung disease that makes breathing difficult. Emphysema and chronic bronchitis are the two conditions that make up COPD. People with COPD may have one or both conditions. Smoking is the most common cause of COPD. It often takes many years to develop. People who have emphysema often have shortness of breath, a chronic cough, wheezing, and chest tightness."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "COPD usually develops over many years. Shortness of breath or cough is often the first symptom. These symptoms gradually get worse over time, until just walking across a room can make you feel out of breath. You also may notice that you feel too tired to do the things you used to do. There is no cure for COPD, but quitting smoking and getting treatment can help you feel better and help keep the condition from getting worse."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 10 million people in the U.S. have COPD."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "You may be at higher risk for emphysema if you:\n\t\t•\tSmoke\n\t\t•\tAre exposed to secondhand smoke\n\t\t•\tAre over age 40\n\t\t•\tAre exposed to fumes, dust, or air pollution"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatments for COPD may include:\n\t\t•\tQuitting smoking\n\t\t•\tMedications to open airways\n\t\t•\tOxygen\n\t\t•\tPulmonary rehabilitation\n\t\t•\tSurgery"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Quitting smoking and avoiding secondhand smoke are the best ways to help reduce the damage to your lungs. Avoiding smoke from fireplaces, air pollution, and air that is very cold also can help."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "You should see your doctor if you have any symptoms of COPD. Seek medical care right away if you have severe shortness of breath or chest pain."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tDo I have COPD?\n\t\t•\tWhat tests will I need to check my lung function?\n\t\t•\tWhat are all of my treatment and medication options?\n\t\t•\tShould I do anything differently to keep this from getting worse?"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "Your doctor will take a medical history and do a physical exam. You also may need blood tests, a lung function test, chest X-ray, or CT scan."

	"Pneumonia": [{
			"heading": "Pneumonia",
			"content": "Lung infection"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tCough\n\t\t•\tBody aches or pains\n\t\t•\tFatigue\n\t\t•\tFever\n\t\t•\tShortness of breath\n\t\t•\tNight sweats\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tChills\n\t\t•\tFeeling of not being able to get enough air\n\t\t•\tHeadache\n\t\t•\tExcessive sweating\n\t\t•\tDifficulty talking"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Pneumonia is a lung infection commonly caused by bacteria or viruses. Bacteria cause most cases of pneumonia in adults. Children more commonly get viral pneumonia. The flu virus can also cause pneumonia, especially in older adults. Inhaling food, stomach acid, toxic chemicals, smoke, fungus, or other substances can also cause pneumonia. Pneumonia can be mild or life threatening and may cause cough, shortness of breath, wheezing, chest pain, fever, and chills. Older adults, young children, people with a weak immune system, and those with chronic medical conditions are more at risk for complications from pneumonia. Treatment for pneumonia may include rest and self-care at home or hospitalization, antibiotics, and oxygen therapy, depending on the severity of symptoms. Most people recover in about 2 weeks. Vaccines help prevent some of the more common types of pneumonia in those at risk."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Usually, pneumonia comes on quickly with a cough that brings up yellow or brown mucus, high fever, chills, chest pain, and shortness of breath. Older adults may also appear confused or mentally altered. Walking pneumonia occurs when symptoms come on days or weeks after a cold or other illness with milder symptoms and dry cough. Most people recover at home within 2 weeks with rest and with medication if needed. People with more serious symptoms may need to be hospitalized to help replace fluids and fight the infection with antibiotics or other medicines."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Being old, living in a nursing home, smoking, having a recent cold or flu, having asthma, having COPD, having a weak immune system, having recent surgery or injury, having had a stroke, having a serious health problem such as heart disease"
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "More than 3 million people in the U.S. get pneumonia every year."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Prevention",
			"content": "The pneumonia vaccine is recommended for anyone over age 65, younger than age 4, or anyone with a weakened immune system or certain chronic illnesses. The flu vaccine helps prevent pneumonia from the influenza virus and is recommended for everyone. Washing your hands regularly, especially when you are around people who are sick, can help prevent illness from spreading."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for pneumonia may include:\n\t\t•\tAntibiotics for bacterial pneumonia\n\t\t•\tAntiviral therapy\n\t\t•\tOxygen\n\t\t•\tSteroids"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Pneumonia can be serious, so it's important to see your doctor before treating pneumonia yourself. 		{

	"Asbestosis": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tCough\n\t\t•\tWheezing\n\t\t•\tShortness of breath"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Asbestosis is a serious lung disease that comes from inhaling tiny fibers of asbestos, a mineral widely used in U.S. industry and construction until its use was significantly restricted in the 1970s. People who have worked with asbestos -- such as shipyard, railroad, and construction workers -- are most likely to get the disease. Asbestos fibers lodge in the lungs and cause scarring, which stiffens the lungs and gradually makes breathing more difficult. Asbestosis can lead to cancer and heart or lung failure. There is no cure for asbestosis, but oxygen and medications can help manage it. Anyone who has shortness of breath or a persistent cough should see a doctor, but keep in mind that common and less-worrisome conditions can also cause the same symptoms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Asbestosis symptoms often don't show up for 20 years or 30 years after exposure. Some people don't have symptoms. If you do, they will probably start with shortness of breath, first with exertion and then regularly. You may develop a persistent cough and chest pain. The severity of asbestosis usually depends on how much asbestos you were exposed to and how often. Treatment focuses on alleviating your symptoms. Your doctor may recommend oxygen therapy or an inhaler to thin the secretions in your lungs. In severe cases, a lung transplant may be necessary. Most importantly, if you smoke, you need to stop. Smoking multiplies your risk of developing asbestos-related lung cancer. Asbestos exposure can also cause malignant mesothelioma -- tumors in the membrane encasing the lungs or lining of the abdomen -- which is fatal."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 200,000 people in the U.S. have been diagnosed with asbestosis."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for asbestosis includes:\n\t\t•\tAvoiding further exposure to asbestos\n\t\t•\tQuitting smoking\n\t\t•\tInhaled medication to thin lung secretions\n\t\t•\tOxygen by mask or plastic tube that fits in nostrils\n\t\t•\tFlu and pneumonia vaccines to lessen risk of respiratory infection\n\t\t•\tLung transplant, in severe cases"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "These self-care strategies can help if you have asbestosis:\n\t\t•\tAvoid further exposure to asbestos.\n\t\t•\tIf you smoke, quit.\n\t\t•\tPound on your chest and back repeatedly to loosen mucus from your lungs so you can cough it up.\n\t\t•\tTo drain mucus from your lungs, sit with your head tilted down or lay on your stomach with your head down.\n\t\t•\tGet a yearly flu shot."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Continued exposure to asbestos, smoking"
		},

			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "See your doctor if you have symptoms of asbestosis such as shortness of breath and a persistent cough. If you have severe shortness of breath or sudden chest pain, go to a hospital emergency room."

It is most common in industrial workers, but can happen to anyone who breathes in cement dust or household chemicals. It also can happen if you inhale the contents of your stomach into your lungs, called aspiration pneumonia. Chemical pneumonia can cause a dry cough, headache, chest pain, flu-like symptoms, fever, weakness, disorientation, or shortness of breath. The inhaled chemicals may cause burning of the mouth, nose, eyes, or lips. Some cases may be mild, while others may be severe and require hospitalization."

			"heading": "Exercise-Induced Asthma",
			"content": "Exercise-induced bronchospasm, exercise-induced bronchoconstriction"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tCough\n\t\t•\tShortness of breath\n\t\t•\tWheezing\n\t\t•\tFatigue\n\t\t•\tTightness"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Exercise-Induced Asthma Overview",
			"content": "Exercise-induced asthma causes wheezing, coughing, shortness of breath, and chest tightness during physical activity. Normally when we breathe, air is warmed and humidified by the nose. Exercise-induced asthma occurs because people breathe more through their mouths during exercise. The cold, dry air causes the airways to the lungs to narrow, blocking airflow and making breathing more difficult. Medications can prevent or treat exercise-induced asthma, and switching to a different physical activity may also help."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "If you have exercise-induced asthma, a cough may be your only symptom. Coughing and other symptoms -- wheezing, shortness of breath, chest tightness -- will begin while you're exercising and get worse 5 or 10 minutes after you stop. They may be mild or severe and will likely clear up within a half hour. You could also develop milder symptoms 4 to 12 hours after exercise. These usually resolve within 24 hours."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Up to 15% of people have exercise-induced asthma."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for exercise-induced asthma may include:\n\t\t•\tA short-acting beta2-agonist, also called a bronchodilator, inhaled 10 to 15 minutes before exercise to prevent symptoms for four to six hours; also used to treat symptoms\n\t\t•\tA long-acting bronchodilator, inhaled 30 to 60 minutes before exercise to prevent symptoms for 10 to 12 hours\n\t\t•\tCromolyn or nedocromil, inhaled 15 to 20 minutes before exercise to prevent symptoms during exercise and possibly delayed symptoms\n\t\t•\tLong-term anti-inflammatory medication, such as inhaled steroids\n\t\t•\tAn action plan, devised by your doctor, for what to do in case of an exercise-induced asthma attack\n\t\t•\tWarming up for 6 to 10 minutes before exercise and cooling down after\n\t\t•\tAvoiding cold-weather or sustained-exertion activities"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Avoid sports that make you breathe hard. Also avoid strenuous exercise in very cold weather. Warm up for 6 to 10 minutes before exercise, and take time to slowly cool down after exercise. Limit exercise when pollution or pollen counts are high. Also avoid exercise when you have a cold."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Cold-air physical activities, activities that involve long periods of exertion, air pollutants, high pollen levels, viral respiratory infections"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "See your doctor soon if you experience symptoms of exercise-induced asthma. If you have severe asthma symptoms – such as severe shortness of breath, chest pain, trouble swallowing, hives, or blue skin – call emergency services."

			"heading": "Pleural Effusion",
			"content": "Fluid in the chest, pleural fluid, water on the lungs"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tCough\n\t\t•\tFatigue\n\t\t•\tShortness of breath\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tFeeling of not being able to get enough air"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Pleural effusion is the build-up of fluid in the pleural space, the chest cavity that is lined with a membrane called the pleura. If the fluid pushes the pleura against your lung, part or the entire lung may collapse. You may have difficulty breathing or chest pain. Pneumonia, heart failure, cancer, blood clots, kidney or liver disease, and inflammation of the pleura, can cause pleural effusion. Treatment depends on the cause. Medication and draining the fluid help clear it up."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "If you have no symptoms of pleural effusion, it may be discovered only through a chest X-ray for another reason. Or you may have only symptoms of the disease or condition that caused it. If you have congestive heart failure, the most common cause, you may have shortness of breath, feet swelling, and night waking. Diuretics and other heart failure medications can help clear it up. In other cases, you may need antibiotics for infection, a chest tube to drain the fluid, or chemotherapy, radiation therapy, or surgery."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Nearly 1 million cases of pleural effusion are diagnosed in the U.S. each year."
		},

			"heading": "Risk Factors",

	"Pneumonitis": [{
			"heading": "Pneumonitis",
			"content": "Farmer's lung, mushroom worker's disease, pigeon breeder's disease"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tCough\n\t\t•\tChills\n\t\t•\tFever\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tFatigue\n\t\t•\tShortness of breath"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Pneumonitis is any inflammation of the lung. It can be caused by many things, including breathing in dust from moldy hay, straw, and grain; fungus that can grow in humidifiers, heating systems, and air conditioners; or exposure to certain bird droppings. Some prescription drugs also may cause pneumonitis, including certain antibiotics, chemotherapy drugs, and heart medications. The best way to treat pneumonitis is to avoid coming in contact with whatever irritant bothers you. If you're experiencing severe symptoms, your doctor may recommend a corticosteroid to reduce inflammation. Most people get better. But in rare cases, chronic pneumonitis can lead to lung scarring or pulmonary fibrosis."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Most symptoms go away when you avoid or limit your exposure to the irritant that caused the problem. A prescription-strength anti-inflammatory drug can help ease symptoms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Farmer's lung, which can happen when you are exposed to moldy straw, hay, or grain, is the most common type of hypersensitivity pneumonitis."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Avoiding the culprit irritant is the best approach to treating pneumonitis. Your doctor may prescribe a corticosteroid to reduce inflammation and ease symptoms, or if there is an infection, he or she will prescribe an antibiotic. People with serious breathing problems may have to be temporarily given oxygen through a mask or plastic tube inserted into the nostrils. Sometimes, medicines will be delivered by inhaler or nebulizer."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Wearing a surgical mask or a respirator may help you avoid exposure."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",

During the procedure, your doctor will insert a flexible tube into your nose and down into your lungs. Samples of lung tissue may be collected during the test."

	"Radon_exposure": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tCough\n\t\t•\tShortness of breath\n\t\t•\tFatigue\n\t\t•\tWeight loss (unintentional)"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Radon is a radioactive gas that occurs in rock, soil, water, some building materials, and natural gas. Breathing in high levels of radon over time can cause lung cancer. Often the first symptoms are shortness of breath, fatigue, cough, and weight loss. Because it is odorless, colorless, and tasteless, you may have no idea you are being exposed to a dangerous level of radon unless you have your home tested. Radon can enter your home or a building where you work through cracks in the walls or foundation or through the basement floor. It can also be found in the water supply if you have a private well. The highest concentrations of radon are likely to be on the lower levels or basement of a home or building."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Long-term exposure to radon can cause lung cancer, and the risk is especially high if you smoke. If you know that you have been exposed to unsafe levels of radon over a period of years, talk with your doctor about what tests you should have. If you develop any symptoms that suggest lung cancer, your doctor will examine you and ask for tests that will either confirm or rule out cancer. Keep in mind that other less serious conditions can cause many of the same symptoms."
		},
		{

			"content": "Radon exposure is responsible for about 21,000 deaths from lung cancer each year in the U.S."
		},

			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for lung cancer depends its stage. 		},
		{

Eating well will also help you have more energy and feel better."

		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Scleroderma is an uncommon immune disorder that causes collagen to build up in the tissue, making it harden. People with scleroderma may have tight, stiff skin or hard lumps. Scleroderma can also affect the blood vessels and organs -- such as the lungs, heart, kidneys, and intestines -- causing life-threatening complications. It's most common in women and in people between ages 30 and 50. There is no cure for scleroderma. Treatment helps the symptoms. Keep in mind that more common and less dangerous conditions cause many of the same symptoms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "There are a number of types of scleroderma. Localized scleroderma usually affects the skin only, develops slowly, and doesn't cause serious problems. It may go away on its own. Systemic scleroderma may affect the skin, organs, or both. It often gets worse for three to five years and then may start to get better. Systemic scleroderma can be fatal, depending on what organs it affects. Treatment will ease symptoms and help limit the damage. Most people with scleroderma work with a team of experts to treat the various symptoms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Scleroderma is rare. Doctors diagnose fewer than 1 out of 50,000 people in the U.S. with systemic scleroderma each year."

Squeezing or pressing the nipples can cause a white, yellow, green, or clear discharge to seep out. 	"Achalasia": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tFood getting stuck (swallowing)"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Achalasia is a rare condition that makes it difficult for food and liquid to move from the esophagus into the stomach. It's caused by problems with the muscles and nerves of the esophagus and the lower esophageal sphincter, a muscle that normally would relax to allow the passage of food. It's not clear what damages the nerves and muscles in the first place, but infections or autoimmune diseases are possible causes. Achalasia usually appears in people ages 25 to 60 and sometimes in children. Medications, shots, endoscopy, or surgery may help ease achalasia. If not treated, achalasia can lead to weakness and malnutrition."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Achalasia usually starts out mild, and then gets worse over months or years. Many people with achalasia lose weight because they have trouble swallowing food. Follow-up care is needed over the long term to make sure food and liquid are able to pass through the esophagus. Complications of achalasia include pneumonia, swelling or sores in the esophagus, and an increased risk of esophageal cancer."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About one in 100,000 people in the U.S. has achalasia."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatments for achalasia may include:\n\t\t•\tBotox injections to relax the tightened lower esophageal sphincter muscle\n\t\t•\tMedicines, including calcium channel blockers and long-acting nitrates, to relax the muscle\n\t\t•\tEsophagomyotomy surgery to cut the lower esophageal sphincter\n\t\t•\tWidening the esophagus with a balloon"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Barrett's esophagus occurs when the lining of the esophagus is damaged, usually by acid reflux, leading to cell changes. Chronic heartburn, or GERD (gastroesophageal reflux disease), causes most cases of Barrett's esophagus. Barrett's esophagus has no symptoms, but doctors monitor it because it increases the risk of esophageal cancer slightly. However, the great majority of people with Barrett's esophagus never develops this cancer."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "In people with GERD, stomach acid doesn't stay where it belongs. It backs up into the esophagus, damaging the tissue. As the area heals, Barrett's esophagus -- changes in the cells lining the esophagus -- might develop. Sometimes, people who don't have GERD get Barrett's esophagus. Experts aren't sure why Barrett's esophagus might not need any special treatment. Your doctor will want to keep your GERD symptoms under stricter control, probably with medicine. You might also need regular tests to check for cell changes that could develop into cancer."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",

	"Low_potassium_(hypokalemia)": [{
			"heading": "Low Potassium (Hypokalemia)",
			"content": "Potassium deficiency"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tIrregular heartbeat\n\t\t•\tMuscle cramps or spasms (painful)\n\t\t•\tPalpitations (fluttering in chest)\n\t\t•\tDifficulty relaxing muscles after contracting them"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Low potassium occurs when the level of potassium in your blood drops below normal, and may cause low energy, leg cramps, weakness, dizziness, and nausea. Very low levels can be life-threatening. Your body's nerve and muscle cells need potassium to function. That includes the muscles of your heart. The most common causes are taking diuretics (water pills) or certain other medications, diarrhea, kidney problems, an eating disorder, and chronic abuse of laxatives. Low potassium levels are particularly risky for people with heart disease, because one potential result of low potassium is abnormal heart rhythms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "The normal range for potassium is 3.6 to 4.8 milliequivalents per liter or mEq/l. Anything below 3.6 is considered low. Anything below 2.5 could be life-threatening. You can have a mildly low potassium level for years and have only mild fatigue or leg cramps at times. Often, low potassium is discovered during a routine blood test. As levels of potassium get lower, symptoms increase. If the level goes below 2 mEq/l, there may be total collapse and loss of muscle function. Usually, symptoms go away with treatment. Some abnormal heart rhythms, though, may take time to come back to normal."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Severe cases of low potassium are relatively rare in the U.S. However, as many as eight out every 10 people who take water pills have lower than normal levels of potassium."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment depends on how severe the potassium deficiency is. For very severe symptoms, treatment -- often in the hospital -- includes:\n\t\t•\tHeart monitoring\n\t\t•\tGetting potassium through pills, or if potassium is extremely low, through an IV infusion\n\t\t•\tTreatment of any related health problems\n\nIf your symptoms are mild or if you have a moderately low level of potassium without symptoms, treatment may include taking a potassium supplement as a pill or in liquid form. Don't take potassium supplements without your doctor's supervision. Your doctor may also change your medication of treat the underlying condition."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Low potassium levels should be monitored and treated by your doctor. Don't take a potassium supplement without talking with your doctor first. Your doctor may prescribe a potassium supplement and a follow-up blood test several days after starting it. The doctor may also recommend a change in diet and encourage you to eat foods high in potassium, such as bananas, tomatoes, oranges, cantaloupe, and peaches."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Certain medications, too much alcohol, magnesium deficiency, drinking too much water"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "If you notice a weak, irregular pulse and have been feeling tired or weak, see your doctor for an evaluation. A very low potassium level can be life-threatening. If you are taking water pills and feel weak or faint, have heart palpitations or muscle cramps, contact your doctor immediately or go to a hospital emergency room."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tHow severe is the low potassium?\n\t\t•\tWhat tests do I need?\n\t\t•\tHow can I avoid this problem in the future?\n\t\t•\tDo I need to change any of my medications?"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "Low potassium is often first discovered with a routine blood test. If you have symptoms, your doctor will take a medical history, do a physical exam, and ask for tests to check your potassium level. The doctor may also ask for other tests to rule out other possible causes of your symptoms."
		}

	"Premature_ventricular_contractions_(PVCs)": [{
			"heading": "Premature Ventricular Contractions (PVCs)",
			"content": "Skipped beats, premature ventricular complexes, ventricular premature beats, ectopic heartbeats, extrasystoles"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tIrregular heartbeat\n\t\t•\tPalpitations (fluttering in chest)"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Premature ventricular contractions are extra heartbeats that start in one of the lower chambers of your heart known as ventricles. A PVC most often feels like a flip-flop or fluttering in your heart. Your heart normally beats in a rhythm, but with PVCs the ventricles contract and beat quicker than the next regular heartbeat. PVCs happen to everyone, and you may have several of these abnormal heartbeats in a row. It is not always clear what causes PVCs, but some causes include caffeine, certain medications, exercise, and heart disease. If you are otherwise healthy, then PVCs usually don't need treatment."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "You may notice PVCs more often when you drink alcohol or caffeine, use tobacco, or feel anxious. Usually, PVCs are harmless. But they can be a sign of heart disease, high blood pressure, or another condition. PVCs usually don't need any treatment unless you have heart disease."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Everyone has PVCs at one time or another."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Most PVCs don't need any treatment. If you have heart disease or another medical condition, you may need to take medications to control your heartbeat."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "You may be able to reduce the number of PVCs you have by:\n\t\t•\tReducing stress\n\t\t•\tCutting back on caffeine and alcohol\n\t\t•\tQuitting smoking"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Caffeine, alcohol, anxiety, stress, some medications, illicit drugs such as cocaine and methamphetamine"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "See your doctor if you have any symptoms of PVCs to make sure it's not being caused by a medical problem."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tShould I be concerned about this?\n\t\t•\tDo I need any treatments?\n\t\t•\tWhat can I do to prevent it?\n\t\t•\tShould I cut back on caffeine?\n\t\t•\tCould I have heart disease or another condition?"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "To diagnose PVCs, your doctor will take a medical history and do a physical exam. You also may need an electrocardiogram as well as an outpatient or inpatient heart monitor."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Caffeine, alcohol, nicotine, over-the-counter nasal decongestants, anxiety, stress, heart disease, high blood pressure, drugs such as cocaine and methamphetamine (\"meth\")"
		}
	],

			"content": "Breast lumps"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tLump or bulge\n\t\t•\tSwelling\n\t\t•\tTenderness to touch\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tSkin redness\n\t\t•\tDischarge from nipple"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "A breast cyst is a fluid-filled sac in the breast. A cyst can be too small to feel or as large as a golf ball. Cysts are very common in women ages 30 to 50 and are usually harmless. While most breast lumps are not cancerous, it's a good idea to get them checked out by a doctor just to be sure. Draining fluid from the cyst often makes it go away. If a cyst comes back, it can be surgically removed."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "A woman may discover a breast cyst on her own, or it may be discovered on a mammogram or ultrasound. Breast cysts may become bigger and be slightly painful before a woman's period. Cysts can change shape and even disappear. Often, a woman can have a breast cyst and not know it. Treatment may not be needed for small cysts that don't cause a problem. Draining the cyst usually makes it go away. Cysts that come back are usually removed surgically."

In most cases, it is a single lump in one breast, but women can have several lumps in both breasts. Fibroadenomas are firm and easy to move under the skin. They are painless and have a border that is well defined."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",

Fibroadenomas can get larger during pregnancy and shrink after menopause. If you have a fibroadenoma, you have a slightly higher risk of getting breast cancer later in life. Most fibroadenomas don't need any treatment, but your doctor may decide to remove the fibroadenoma. If the fibroadenoma is not removed, your doctor will watch it over time for any changes. It is very rare for a fibroadenoma to turn into cancer."

			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Fibrocystic breasts are a common and harmless condition; the symptoms are swollen, painful, and lumpy breasts. Hormonal changes during your menstrual cycle trigger fibrocystic breasts. Symptoms may be worst before your period and get better after it's started. Treatments can't cure it, but they may help with discomfort. While fibrocystic breasts aren't a medical problem, always have a doctor check out any new changes in your breasts."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Women ages 30 to 50 are most likely to have fibrocystic breasts. Symptoms usually stop after menopause, when hormone levels drop. Usually, you'll have symptoms in both breasts, although one may feel worse than the other. Some women have minor symptoms while others find the pain and swelling quite uncomfortable. Hormone therapy can make symptoms worse; birth control pills may make them better. Treatments such as painkillers and better-fitting bras help with symptoms. Fibrocystic breasts aren't a medical risk themselves, but they can make breast exams and mammograms to screen for cancer less accurate. Ask your doctor if you will need other types of screening tests."
		},
		{

		},

Wear a sports bra when exercising and sleeping. Some people say that cutting down on caffeine and chocolate can help. While there's not good evidence, try it to see if you feel a benefit. Ask your doctor if any vitamins or supplements such as vitamin E may help. Reducing salt in your diet may reduce water retention."

It is a rare condition that is most often caused by overuse and aging. Occasionally, it can be caused by cancer that spreads to the vertebrae."

Injury, a viral infection, or strain from coughing can trigger the condition. Diseases such as arthritis and fibromyalgia also may cause costochondritis. Usually, there is no clear cause. While harmless, the condition often is mistaken for a heart attack. Costochondritis affects women more than men and usually goes away on its own within a few days or weeks."

While ulcers were once a chronic condition, current treatments make ulcers much more manageable."

			"heading": "Symptoms",

			"content": "Pleurisy is inflammation of pleura -- the lining of the lungs and chest -- that causes sharp pain when you breathe. Many conditions cause pleurisy, usually the flu and pneumonia, but also tuberculosis, chest injury, lung disease, cancer, blood clots, and autoimmune disorders such as lupus and rheumatoid arthritis. Typically, pleurisy clears up when the underlying condition is treated or cured. In some cases, pleurisy occurs with\"pleural effusion,\" a buildup of fluid between the layers of the pleura, which makes it difficult to breathe."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "How long you will have pleurisy depends on what has caused it. Most pleurisy from viral causes clears up in a week or two. If pleurisy is due to cancer, tuberculosis, or other chronic lung disease, it can become a chronic condition requiring on-going treatment."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",

		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Pleurisy treatment depends on the cause. If it is caused by a virus, no treatment is necessary. If it is caused by a bacterial infection, the doctor may prescribe antibiotics. 		},
		{

When the pain lets up, coughing and breathing deeply can help clear mucus and prevent pneumonia."

	"Vertebral_compression_fracture_(thoracic)": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "A vertebral compression fracture occurs when one of the vertebrae in the spine is broken. A vertebral compression fracture can be caused by a severe injury to the spine, such as a car accident, sports injury, or fall. And it can happen if you have a disease such as osteoporosis or cancer. The middle of the spine is the most common spot for compression fractures. A vertebral compression fracture can cause pain in the lower back, upper back, neck, or hip. It also can cause weakness or numbness and tingling."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Most people with a vertebral compression fracture usually have pain in their back. The amount of pain can vary from person to person. Although it is a serious injury, a vertebral compression fracture often can be treated without surgery. In severe cases, you may need surgery to prevent further problems. Even with surgery, some people have chronic back pain after a vertebral compression fracture."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Most spinal compression fractures are seen in elderly people who have osteoporosis."

		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Late-onset Pompe disease is a rare, serious genetic disorder that affects kids and adults. It causes severe weakness in your muscles, including the muscles that help you breathe. People with late-onset Pompe disease don't have enough of a special protein. The protein is supposed to break down a type of sugar called glycogen. Without it, glycogen builds up, damaging the muscles. There's no cure for Pompe disease. However, new treatments can help ease symptoms and slow the disease."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Late-onset Pompe disease can start in early childhood or as late as your 60s. Pompe disease usually shortens a person's life, but many people who develop it as children or adults live for decades. Generally, the later you get it, the slower it progresses.\n\nSymptoms like muscle weakness and breathing problems may interfere with your life. Respiratory infections are common. Thanks to treatment, people with Pompe disease are living longer."
		},

You may need to see many experts -- like a neurologist, respiratory therapist, surgeon, dietitian, physical therapist, and others -- to treat different problems as they develop."

			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) is a new, potentially life-threatening viral illness. It first appeared in 2003 and quickly spread, making more than 8,000 people sick in over two dozen countries. Experts feared that SARS would become a devastating global epidemic. But the disease did not spread to the U.S., and it has now been effectively contained. Because the virus that causes SARS is highly contagious, people with the disease are usually isolated. Treatment includes antibiotics, antiviral medications, and steroid drugs that reduce inflammation in the lungs."

		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Gastrointestinal bleeding -- bleeding in the digestive tract -- is a symptom of an underlying condition. It can be caused by many different conditions. Most can be treated and cured, although some may be life threatening. Bleeding in the esophagus, stomach, and upper part of the small intestine can cause bright red blood in the vomit, vomit that looks like coffee grounds, or black or tarry stool. Bleeding in the lower part of the small intestine, large intestine -- including the colon and anus -- and rectum can cause dark or bright red blood in the stool. It's important to find the source of the bleeding and what's causing it to get the right treatment."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "Seek medical attention right away if you have any severe or sudden bleeding that shows up in your vomit or stool."
		},

			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "The bleeding can be light and last for a long time or it can be sudden and severe. In some cases, you might not notice the bleeding at all. Your doctor can do tests that can find small amounts of blood in the stool. To treat the bleeding, you need to find out what's causing it. Bleeding in the upper part of the digestive tract is most often caused by ulcers, stomach inflammation, swollen veins in the esophagus, and tears in the esophagus or stomach. Bleeding in the lower part of the digestive tract most often is caused by diverticulosis, enlarged blood vessels in the colon, polyps, hemorrhoids, and anal fissures. Blood in the stool can be caused by cancer, inflammatory bowel disease, and infectious diarrhea."
		},
