		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Interstitial lung disease is a group of disorders that cause scarring of lung tissue. This makes it hard to breathe in enough oxygen. Usually, interstitial lung disease develops slowly over time. Pneumonia, infections, autoimmune diseases, radiation therapy, certain medicines, and exposure to asbestos or certain kinds of dust can cause it. Sometimes it has no identifiable cause. People with interstitial lung disease may have shortness of breath, a dry cough, fatigue, fever, weight loss, and muscle aches. Medications can help slow down the rate of lung damage, but people may never have full use of their lungs."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Interstitial lung disease usually gets worse slowly. Shortness of breath and a dry cough are the most common symptoms. You may first notice you feel out of breath after exercise or other strenuous activity. Over time, the shortness of breath usually gets worse, and you may have it more often. You may also have other symptoms, such as fatigue, fever, and muscle aches. In advanced stages of the disease, your lips or skin look blue and the base of your fingernails become enlarged. Treatment for interstitial lung disease depends on what's causing the disease. It's important to start treatment early to prevent more lung damage."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 1 in 2,000 people in the U.S. has interstitial lung disease."

	"Obesity": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tShortness of breath\n\t\t•\tJoint pain\n\t\t•\tHigh blood pressure\n\t\t•\tHeartburn\n\t\t•\tTires quickly\n\t\t•\tOverweight"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Obesity is having too much body fat. Your doctor may use a formula called the BMI (body mass index) to tell if you are obese. Having a BMI of 30 or higher is considered obese. Obesity is a very common and serious health problem in the U.S. If you carry too much fat -- especially around your waist -- you are at increased risk for many health problems, including heart disease, high blood pressure, high cholesterol, diabetes, and stroke. Obesity can also cause depression and low self-esteem. And if you are obese, your children are very likely to be obese. The good news is that even losing as little as 10 to 20 pounds can improve your health. Eating fewer calories and getting more exercise can help you lose weight. For some people, weight loss surgery may help."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "If you are obese, you are more likely to develop serious health problems such as heart disease; type 2 diabetes; some kinds of cancer including colon, gall bladder, kidney, and postmenopausal breast cancer; breathing problems such as sleep apnea and asthma; and osteoarthritis. Women may have pregnancy complications, such as high blood pressure and problems during labor and delivery, and your infant is more likely to have a high birth weight and some birth defects. Your children are also more likely to be obese and at risk for type 2 diabetes, high blood pressure, and high cholesterol. Obesity commonly causes emotional issues in children and adults, such as depression, low self-esteem, and social isolation.\n\nYour doctor and a dietician can help you develop a realistic plan for healthy weight loss and getting more activity and exercise. Counseling or a weight loss program can provide support and help with emotional aspects of eating, such as knowing when you tend to overeat and developing new habits for those situations. In some cases, your doctor may also prescribe medication for weight loss. Prescription and over-the-counter weight loss products can interact with other medications or produce serious side effects, so use them under a doctor's supervision. If you are very obese or have serious weight-related health problems, weight loss surgery may help. Trying to lose weight can seem hard, but even small lifestyle changes and losing 10 pounds can make you feel better, improve your health, and help prevent health problems."
		},

		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "A thyroid nodule is a common, abnormal growth on the thyroid gland, which regulates growth and metabolism. Iodine deficiency, a thyroid condition, a cyst, inflammation, or cancer can cause thyroid nodules. They are almost always benign, or noncancerous, and only rarely are a sign of thyroid cancer. You usually don't need to treat a benign nodule, but a cancerous one should be removed through surgery. Other treatments depend on the cause."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "You're most likely to get a thyroid nodule if you are an aging woman. You probably won't have any symptoms, although you might see or feel a lump on your neck or have trouble swallowing. Your doctor may be the one to discover it during a routine physical exam. Very likely, the nodule is benign and your doctor will just want to monitor it every six to 12 months. But the doctor may want to shrink it or remove it surgically if you have trouble breathing or swallowing because it is large. Though rare, cancer in a thyroid nodule is most likely if you're under 30 years old or over 60."
		},

	"Pneumothorax_(spontaneous)": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tShortness of breath"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Pneumothorax, or a collapsed lung, occurs when air collects in the chest around the outside of the lung. This puts pressure on the lung, making it hard to breathe. You also may notice sharp chest pain, rapid heart rate, fatigue, cough, and in some cases, bluish skin. Rib fractures, gunshot wounds to the chest, knife wounds, diseases such as COPD or asthma, and certain medical procedures can cause pneumothorax. Smoking cigarettes or marijuana, scuba diving, flying, and being at high altitude can all also cause a collapsed lung. A collapsed lung can also happen on its own with no cause. This is called spontaneous pneumothorax. A small spontaneous pneumothorax often goes away on its own with rest and oxygen. Treatment for a large pneumothorax may include surgery or inserting a chest tube to let air escape."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "If you have sudden, sharp pain in the chest, shortness of breath, and other symptoms of a collapsed lung, get immediate medical help."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "If you have a collapsed lung, you will notice sudden, sharp chest pain, shortness of breath, rapid heart rate, cough, and other symptoms. If this occurs, get immediate medical help. For a small pneumothorax, you may be able to rest at home with oxygen while it heals. For a larger collapsed lung, you'll have to stay in the hospital for a few days. Your doctor will put in a chest tube to allow the air to escape. In some cases, you may need lung surgery to repair the lung and help prevent it from collapsing again. If you have had a collapsed lung in the past, you are at risk for having another one."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Not seeking medical help, smoking, having an underlying lung disease like COPD, asthma, or pulmonary fibrosis"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for a collapsed lung includes:\n\t\t•\tOxygen\n\t\t•\tUsing a needle to draw air from the space around the lung\n\t\t•\tHospitalization and a chest tube to allow air to escape\n\t\t•\tSurgery to repair the lung and help prevent it from collapsing again"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Self-care may include:\n\t\t•\tResting at home\n\t\t•\tBreathing extra oxygen\n\t\t•\tNot smoking"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "See a doctor if you have any symptoms of a collapsed lung."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tCould a collapsed lung be causing my symptoms?\n\t\t•\tWhat could have caused it?\n\t\t•\tDo I need treatment?\n\t\t•\tWill this happen again?\n\t\t•\tWhat can I do to help prevent it?"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "Your doctor can diagnose a collapsed lung by taking your medical history and doing a physical exam. During the exam, the doctor will listen to your lungs. Decreased or no breathing sounds are signs of a collapsed lung. Other tests may include taking a blood sample and doing a chest X-ray."
		},

		},

	"Bleeding_esophageal_varices": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tDifficulty swallowing\n\t\t•\tBloody or red colored vomit\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Varices are enlarged veins in the lower esophagus caused by high blood pressure in part of the circulatory system. The cause is almost always cirrhosis of the liver. Symptoms may include coughing up blood and black, tarry stools. Bleeding esophageal varices is a medical emergency and requires immediate care to avoid life-threatening loss of blood. Treatment usually involves tying off the bleeding vein."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "Bleeding esophageal varices is a medical emergency and needs immediate attention. Call emergency services or your local emergency services right away if you have bloody vomit or black or bloody stools."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Often the bleeding stops on its own. Even so, bleeding esophageal varices is a medical emergency. Several treatments can stem the flow of blood. But varices that have bled once have about a 70% chance of bleeding again in following two years. The risk of death increases when varices bleed again. The danger is highest in the first few days after an episode of bleeding. The risk of dying from bleeding esophageal varices is closely associated with how severe the liver disease is."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Drinking alcohol increases the danger of bleeding varices."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Medications that reduce blood pressure in the veins of the esophagus can help reduce the likelihood of bleeding. To stop bleeding, doctors use a variety of treatments, including:\n\t\t•\tTying off veins with an elastic band so they can't bleed; this usually is done with an endoscope.\n\t\t•\tInjecting a solution that shrinks bleeding varices\n\t\t•\tPrescribing medications that slow blood flow into the portal vein, which carries blood to your liver\n\t\t•\tDiverting blood flow away from the portal vein; this treatment, called a transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS), is used only when other methods have failed.\n\t\t•\tLiver transplant (if there is severe liver disease)"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Bleeding varices are a life-threatening emergency. The most important thing you can do is get immediate medical help. After treatment, avoiding alcohol and drugs that are metabolized by the liver will help reduce your risk of another attack of bleeding esophageal varices."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tHow serious is my condition?\n\t\t•\tWill the bleeding stop on its own?\n\t\t•\tWhat can be done to stop the bleeding?\n\t\t•\tHow can I reduce the chances that bleeding varices, once treated, will bleed again?\n\t\t•\tAm I a candidate for a liver transplant?"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "To check for bleeding esophageal varices, your doctor will examine your esophagus using an instrument called an endoscope, looking for swollen veins. CT and MRI scans may be used to check your liver and blood circulation around the liver. An ultrasound also may be done to give your doctor a more complete picture of the condition of your liver."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 50% of all people with cirrhosis will develop esophageal varices. These varices commonly bleed."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "People with liver disease who continue to drink alcohol have a higher risk of bleeding varices. Bacterial infections of the digestive tract also increase risk."
		}

		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tDifficulty swallowing\n\t\t•\tSwelling\n\t\t•\tBlue colored skin\n\t\t•\tHeartburn\n\t\t•\tSkin rash\n\t\t•\tVisible deformity\n\t\t•\tColor change\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tStiffness or decreased movement\n\t\t•\tConstipation\n\t\t•\tNumbness or tingling\n\t\t•\tSkin thickening\n\t\t•\tJoint pain\n\t\t•\tSkin hardening"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "CREST syndrome is a type of systemic scleroderma, a rare autoimmune disease that causes tissues to harden throughout the body. Collagen can build up in the skin, making the hands and fingers -- and other areas -- feel tight and stiff. CREST syndrome can affect the organs, too, such as the lungs, kidneys, and intestines. Some people have mild disease. For others, CREST syndrome is life threatening. There is no cure, but treatment helps with symptoms. Note that many less serious conditions can cause similar symptoms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "CREST syndrome and other types of scleroderma are most common in people between ages 30 and 50. Usually, CREST comes on slowly. It may start with Raynaud's phenomenon -- fingers and toes that hurt and turn pale or blue in the cold. Skin on the hands, lower arms and legs may thicken and become shiny, discolored, and tight. Many people with CREST have difficulty swallowing and lung problems. CREST can be mild or severe depending on what organs it affects. Treatment helps ease symptoms and suppress the immune system's attack."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Doctors diagnose fewer than one out of 50,000 people in the U.S. with CREST or other forms of systemic scleroderma each year."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "CREST syndrome always needs medical treatment. Over-the-counter drugs -- such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen -- can help with pain. Your doctor may suggest changes to your lifestyle. Regular exercise and stretching will help you stay flexible. Use sunscreen to protect your skin outside. If you have Raynaud's phenomenon, don't smoke and dress warmly when it's cold. Make sure to get all recommended vaccines."

			"heading": "Made Worse By",

	"Hyperparathyroidism": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tHeartburn\n\t\t•\tFatigue\n\t\t•\tHigh blood pressure\n\t\t•\tConstipation\n\t\t•\tNausea or vomiting"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Hyperparathyroidism is a disorder of the parathyroid glands that makes them secrete too much parathyroid hormone (PTH). PTH helps maintain a balance of calcium and phosphorus in the body. When the parathyroid glands secrete too much PTH, blood calcium rises, causing hyperparathyroidism. Too much calcium in the blood can cause kidney stones. Too little phosphorus affects bones and teeth. In most cases, hyperparathyroidism is caused by a benign (noncancerous) tumor. Or sometimes one or more of these glands become enlarged and overactive (hyperplasia). In very rare cases, cancer is present. Hyperparathyroidism can cause vague feelings of fatigue and weakness, increased thirst, impaired thinking, and bone fractures. Some people don't experience any symptoms. Treatment depends on the type and severity of your disease. You may take medication, have surgery, or need no treatment."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "If you have mild symptoms, you may not need treatment. You may only need regular checkups with your doctor. You will also need to drink lots of water, exercise, and avoid diuretics. In moderate to severe cases, surgery is very successful at curing the disease. Sometimes the doctor prescribes a medication that turns off PTH. If an underlying disease is causing your problem, the doctor will treat the condition. In most cases, you feel better right away with treatment."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 100,000 people in the U.S. develop hyperparathyroidism each year."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Kidney failure, rickets, genetics, increasing age, being female, vitamin D deficiency, taking lithium"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Surgery is the main treatment for hyperparathyroidism. It removes the enlarged gland or glands. Some doctors also prescribe medication called calcimimetics that turn off the secretion of PTH. The doctor also will treat any underlying disease that is causing hyperparathyroidism."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Drink lots of water, get plenty of exercise, and do not smoke. Also avoid diuretics such as thiazides. Limit daily calcium intake to less than 1,200 mg and vitamin D intake to less than 600 IU."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Immobilization, vomiting, diarrhea"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "See the doctor if you have any symptoms of hyperparathyroidism. This is especially important if you become pregnant. Untreated, this condition can be dangerous to a developing fetus. Seek immediate medical care if you have symptoms of hyperparathyroidism and also have uneven, patchy skin discoloration, especially if you have kidney failure."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tWhat caused this condition?\n\t\t•\tWhat should I watch for?\n\t\t•\tDo I have to have surgery? What can I expect afterward?\n\t\t•\tDo I need to do anything special to stay healthy?\n\t\t•\tShould my children also watch for this condition?"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "Blood tests can spot high levels of calcium and parathyroid hormone and low levels of phosphorus. Urine tests can check how much calcium is leaving the body."
		}
	],

			"content": "Fractured sternum, sternal fracture, chest trauma"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tBruising or discoloration\n\t\t•\tTenderness to touch\n\t\t•\tSwelling\n\t\t•\tVisible deformity"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "A broken breastbone occurs when something hits the front of the chest with enough force to break the breastbone, or sternum. Most sternum fractures are caused by motor vehicle accidents. Sports and workplace injuries as well as cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) can also cause the injury. A broken breastbone may cause pain, swelling, bruising, and difficulty breathing. Serious complications can also occur, including injury to the heart or lungs. A fractured sternum is a medical emergency, so it's important to get immediate medical attention. Depending on the severity of the injury, treatment may include rest at home with OTC pain relievers or hospitalization, narcotic pain medication, and treatment for any other injuries. Doctors don't wrap the sternum or put a cast on the chest, because these fractures usually heal better when the chest can rise and fall more regularly during breathing."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENC",
			"content": "Anyone with a broken breastbone should get immediate medical help."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "A broken sternum can occur from a car accident or workplace injury and may cause pain over the breastbone, swelling, bruising, and difficulty breathing. The condition requires emergency care. For mild cases, treatment may include rest at home and OTC pain relievers. For a severe fracture, you may be hospitalized and given narcotic pain relievers for severe pain along with oxygen to help you breathe."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Deep breaths, movement"
		},
		{

Gas comes from swallowing air when you eat or drink and from the breakdown of foods in the large intestine. Half of the gas passed through the rectum comes from swallowed air. Some foods and food additives are harder to digest and may cause excess gas in the large intestine. These include high-fiber foods such as beans, whole grains, and certain fruits and vegetables."

	"Gastritis": [{
			"heading": "Gastritis",
			"content": "Gastric irritation"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tBloating or fullness\n\t\t•\tBloody or red colored vomit\n\t\t•\tTenderness to touch\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tNausea or vomiting\n\t\t•\tUpset stomach"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Gastritis is an inflammation of the stomach lining caused by alcohol, aspirin, spicy foods, stress, excess acid, or a virus. In serious cases, the stomach lining becomes damaged. Gastritis causes stomach upset, irritation, and pain that can last just minutes or for hours. In some people, gastritis becomes a chronic problem."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Minor stomach upset from eating a spicy meal usually gets better within a few hours. Avoiding aspirin and other anti-inflammatory medications also helps reduce stomach irritation. However, if your symptoms last a day or two, it's important to see a doctor. Chronic gastritis can lead to ulcers and stomach bleeding. It also increases the risk of stomach cancer. Treatment includes drugs that coat and protect the stomach lining or reduce stomach acid. Severe gastritis that results in vomiting or diarrhea with blood requires emergency care."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "There are many millions of cases of gastritis in the U.S. every year."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for gastritis may include:\n\t\t•\tAntacids\n\t\t•\tAcid-suppressing medications (proton pump inhibitors)\n\t\t•\tBland diet\n\t\t•\tAvoiding alcohol and tobacco\n\t\t•\tAvoiding medications that irritate the stomach, such as anti-inflammatory pain medications\n\t\t•\tAntibiotics, if gastritis is caused by bacteria"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Minor gastritis can usually be treated at home with antacids and acid-suppressing medicine available over the counter. If your symptoms are severe or last more than a day or two, see your doctor right away."
		},

			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",

		},

		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tBloating or fullness\n\t\t•\tDecreased appetite\n\t\t•\tNausea or vomiting\n\t\t•\tTenderness to touch\n\t\t•\tStomach cramps\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tDiarrhea\n\t\t•\tIncreased passing gas\n\t\t•\tUpset stomach"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Giardiasis is an infection of the small intestine by the parasite giardia. Giardiasis causes diarrhea, gas, bloating, nausea, and stomach cramps. However, some people have giardiasis without any symptoms. The disease spreads through the feces of an infected person. Consuming contaminated water or food, or swallowing water in ponds, lakes, or streams infected with the parasite are common ways the disease spreads. Children in daycare centers, hikers and backpackers who drink water from streams, and people who have anal sex are more at risk for giardiasis. Symptoms often go away without treatment in two to four weeks, but if not treated, the illness may become chronic in some people. Antibiotics shorten symptoms and cure the disease."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Bloating, gas, diarrhea, and other symptoms start one to three weeks after infection with giardia and last two to six weeks. Antibiotics can shorten the length of the illness. Some people develop symptoms of lactose intolerance, an allergy to dairy products, during the infection and for months after treatment."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Risk factors include traveling to developing countries, drinking untreated water, not practicing good hygiene when camping, swimming or playing in lakes or ponds infected with giardia, caring for someone who has giardia, and anal sex. Children still in diapers who go to daycare centers are also at risk."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 2% of people in the U.S. are infected with giardia."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Prevention",
			"content": "Here are ways to prevent spreading giardiasis:\n\t\t•\tWash your hands often, especially after using the bathroom.\n\t\t•\tDrink only treated water.\n\t\t•\tBoil or filter water from streams and ponds when camping.\n\t\t•\tAvoid brushing your teeth or making ice or drinks with contaminated water.\n\t\t•\tDon't eat raw foods grown in areas where giardia might be present.\n\t\t•\tAvoid oral and anal contact during sex."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Giardiasis may get better on its own in two to four weeks. However, antibiotics and anti-parasite medications can shorten symptoms."
		},
		{

			"content": "Self-care for giardiasis includes:\n\t\t•\tDrinking plenty of fluids\n\t\t•\tTaking anti-diarrheal medication\n\t\t•\tDrinking diluted electrolyte drinks (too much sugar can cause stomach upset)\n\t\t•\tAvoiding alcohol and caffeine\n\t\t•\tAvoiding dairy products if having symptoms of lactose intolerance"

			"content": "Helicobacter (H. pylori) is a common type of bacteria that can live in the stomach and upper intestines. H. pylori causes the majority of peptic ulcers, which are sores or holes in the lining of the stomach or upper intestine. An H. pylori infection weakens the stomach lining. This allows stomach acid to eat away at the lining, causing stomach pain and burning. Not everyone has H. pylori in their stomach, and many who do have it aren't bothered by the bacteria."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Some people with H. pylori infections never have a problem. Others develop ulcer symptoms a few weeks or months after the infection starts. With treatment, most ulcers clear up in a few weeks. If not treated, ulcers get worse and become a chronic problem. Chronic peptic ulcers increase the risk for intestinal cancer. Severe ulcers can cause internal bleeding or a blockage in the stomach. Perforated ulcers are those that wear a hole through the stomach wall and are a medical emergency."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",

It's best to see your doctor to find out the cause of ulcer symptoms, and get antibiotics."

Uterine fibroids need the female hormone estrogen to grow, so they are most common in women during their childbearing years. Small fibroids often have no symptoms. Larger fibroids can cause a feeling of fullness in the abdomen, cramping, heavy periods, longer periods, increased urination, and pain with sex."

Some fibroids cause heavy bleeding, which causes anemia. Large or multiple fibroids that cause problems are treated with hormones, intrauterine devices, or, in some cases, removed surgically. Fibroids are a major cause of hysterectomy in the U.S."

			"heading": "Budd-Chiari Syndrome",
			"content": "Hepatic vein obstruction, hepatic veno-occlusive disease"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tBloating or fullness\n\t\t•\tSwelling\n\t\t•\tNausea or vomiting\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tBulging veins\n\t\t•\tDistended stomach"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Budd-Chiari syndrome is an extremely rare liver condition. If veins that carry blood from the liver get blocked, the built-up pressure can damage the liver. Symptoms may include pain, swelling, and vomiting blood. Blood clots in the veins or tumors pressing on the veins may cause it. Conditions that increase the risk of clots, such as immune diseases and infections, raise the risk of Budd-Chiari syndrome. It's a serious condition; it can be life threatening, especially without treatment. Medications and surgery can help."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Budd-Chiari syndrome can develop at any age, but most often appears in a person's thirties or forties. The liver will probably be swollen. Fluid may build up in the tissues of the abdomen. If a blood clot causes the problem, blood thinners and clot-busting drugs may help. Some people need angioplasty, a procedure to open up a blocked vein. If a tumor is pressing on the vein, a surgeon may remove it. People with severely damaged livers need transplants."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Budd-Chiari syndrome is quite rare. Some estimates suggest that about 1 out of every 1,000,000 people develops it each year. It's most likely to occur in a person's 30s or 40s."

			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Colon cancer is cancer that starts in the colon or rectum, which make up the large intestine. It usually starts as a pre-cancerous growth called a polyp that evolves into a cancer over years. Often, people with colon cancer have no symptoms until the cancer is so big it blocks the bowel or has spread to other organs. However, polyps and early colon cancer are easily spotted during a colonoscopy and can be completely cured at that stage. You increase your risk for colon cancer if you are overweight, eat a high-fat diet with a lot of red meat, smoke, or drink heavily."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Colon cancer often has no symptoms, so you can have it and not know it. The cancer often starts as a small growth, or polyp, which can be detected with screening tests. Removing polyps before they become cancerous can prevent colon cancer. If not caught early on, colon cancer can grow large enough to block or put a hole in (perforate) the bowel. By the time symptoms such as chronic constipation or blood in the stool appear, the cancer is often at a late stage and may have spread to lymph nodes or other organs, making it much harder to treat."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",

		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Mallory-Weiss syndrome occurs in the mucous membrane where the esophagus and stomach connect. Vomiting or coughing strongly or for a long period of time can cause the membrane to tear and possibly bleed. Seizures may also cause tearing. People in their 40s or 50s are most likely to have Mallory-Weiss tears, but children can have them, too. Pregnant women are also at risk due to vomiting in the first trimester. Mallory-Weiss tears often heal on their own in a few days. In rare cases, surgery is required. Blood loss is a concern, so get medical care right away."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "Go to the emergency room if you have signs of Mallory-Weiss syndrome and your doctor isn't available. Complications can include blood loss and dehydration."

			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Tears from Mallory-Weiss syndrome usually heal in two to three days. Once tears heal, they don't normally bleed again. But having blood clotting problems or liver disease may lead to bleeding in the future. Instead of eating or drinking, your doctor may want you to have intravenous fluids, given through a needle in the arm. Then you can usually have clear liquids and eventually solid food."
		},

			"heading": "Made Worse By",

Scarring of the liver is the most common cause. Most esophageal varices don't cause any symptoms until they start to bleed. Then they can cause bloody or black stools, vomiting, vomiting blood, or lightheadedness. If not treated quickly, the bleeding can cause shock or death."
		},

Bleeding varicies are a medical emergency and need treatment to stop the bleeding right away. Treatments may include medications, banding the varices to stop the bleeding, or surgery."

	"Stomach_cancer": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tBloody or red colored vomit\n\t\t•\tNausea or vomiting\n\t\t•\tCoffee grounds colored vomit\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tWeight loss (unintentional)"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Stomach cancer is a cancer that starts in the stomach and may spread to other organs. Almost all stomach cancers are adenocarcinoma, which begins in the glandular tissue of the stomach. Early stomach cancer may cause no symptoms, or cause commonly misdiagnosed symptoms such as indigestion, nausea, poor appetite, and bloating. Because of this, stomach cancer is often detected at a late stage, when it is difficult to cure. Surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation treatments are used to treat stomach cancer."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "If you are diagnosed with stomach cancer, you will probably need surgery. If it is in a very early stage, the cancer may be removed through an endoscope, a long flexible tube that goes down the throat to the stomach. If the cancer has spread in the stomach, you may need surgery to remove part or all of the stomach. Some lymph nodes and part of the intestine, esophagus, or other nearby organs may also be removed. If all of your stomach is removed, the surgeon will make a new\"stomach\" out of intestinal tissue. If all or part of your stomach is removed, you may need to change your eating habits to eat several small meals a day. Working with a nutritionist to keep your diet healthy can help. When stomach cancer is diagnosed early, before it has spread, 61% of people survive five years or longer. That survival rate drops to about 28% if the cancer has spread to lymph nodes, and to about 4% if the cancer has metastasized to other parts of the body."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",

			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Dietary changes cause many symptoms. For instance, eating more high-fat foods than usual can trigger diarrhea or upset stomach. Even healthy dietary changes can have unexpected results. Eating too many high-fiber foods can cause gas, pain, and diarrhea. Dramatic weight loss from eating a healthier diet increases the risk of gallstones. Some people develop health conditions that affect how they can digest foods. People with lactose intolerance will have an upset stomach and other symptoms after eating dairy products. Celiac disease causes bloating and pain when a person eats wheat or other grains containing gluten. Whenever you have any new or unusual symptoms, consider whether changes to your diet could be causing them."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "The specific side effects of dietary changes will vary. An extra cup of coffee in the morning could cause acid reflux, rapid heartbeat, and anxiety. Many people aren't aware of food allergies or intolerances until they begin to eat more of the food than usual. People who radically change their diets -- such as those on extreme diets or who have eating disorders -- are at risk for nutritional deficiencies. They may have all sorts of symptoms, such as changes to their skin, hair, and mood. For many people, symptoms from dietary changes are temporary and will clear up as their bodies adjust."

Anyone can have colon polyps, but they are more common if you're over age 50 or if someone in your family has had colon polyps or colon cancer. Polyps usually don't cause any symptoms. They are most often found during a routine screening of the colon with a colonoscope or sigmoidoscope. In most cases, the polyps are removed during the screening and don't need any more treatment."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Colon polyps start as small growths in the colon. Most of these polyps are not cancerous. But as the polyps grow, some can turn into cancer. Most colon polyps don't cause any symptoms, so doctors recommend that people over age 50 have routine screenings to look for them. Polyps are usually removed during the screening. But in some cases, you may need surgery to remove larger polyps or polyps that are hard to reach. If a polyp has turned into colon cancer, you will need surgery, as well as radiation or chemotherapy."

Anal fissures are quite common in babies. Usually, anal fissures heal on their own. Rarely, chronic anal fissures may need treatment such as surgery."

Anal fissures usually feel better within days but may take weeks to heal completely. Most children and adults don't need treatment. Once an anal fissure heals, it's likely to return. Eating a healthy high fiber diet may reduce the chances. Anal fissures that don't heal may need surgery or other treatments. Anyone with ongoing symptoms of an anal fissure should see a doctor. 	"Diverticulosis": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tConstipation\n\t\t•\tDiarrhea\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tStomach cramps"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Diverticuli are small pouches that bulge out from weak spots in colon walls. Over time, pressure and strain from passing hard stools causes these weak areas. The condition is common in people over age 40, possibly in those who don't get enough fiber in their diet. Most people with diverticulosis have no discomfort or symptoms. However, bacteria and fecal matter sometimes get trapped inside these pouches, causing inflammation and pain, a condition known as diverticulitis. Diverticulitis can cause pain, cramping, infection, bleeding, and other serious complications."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Most people with diverticuli in their colon walls have no symptoms or have mild cramps and pain, bloating, and constipation, most likely due to irritable bowel syndrome. Occasionally, bleeding originates from a diverticulum, causing a diverticular bleed.  If diverticulitis, inflammation and pain of the diverticula, develops, some cases will clear up on their own in a week or two. But in many other cases, mild pain may get worse over a few days, or severe pain may come on suddenly. You may also have fever, chills, nausea, sweating, and other symptoms. If this happens, it's important to see a doctor. If not treated, an abscess may form in the intestinal wall. A fistula, a tube that connects from the intestinal wall to another organ or to the skin, also can form. Treatment with antibiotics can ease symptoms. For severe cases of diverticulitis, surgery can repair a fistula, a colonic perforation, or intestinal blockage."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About half of people age 60 and older have diverticulosis. 10% to 25% go on to develop diverticulitis."
		},

			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Diverticulosis typically requires no medical treatment. Your doctor will probably recommend that you eat a high-fiber diet."

It can happen in children and in adults who have been assaulted, or who have used an object for sexual pleasure. In most cases, the objects don't cause any symptoms. The sooner the item is removed, the less chance it will cause infection or other complications. Most doctors can't do this in the office, so you may need to go to the emergency room. Doctors have a few different ways of removing the object, depending on where it is in the rectum. Sometimes you may need surgery to remove it. Most people don't have any long-term problems after the object is removed. But a small number of people have a serious infection or other bowel problems."

	"Intestinal_Ileus": [{
			"heading": "Intestinal Ileus",
			"content": "Adynamic ileus, paralytic ileus, nonmechanical bowel obstruction"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tConstipation\n\t\t•\tDecreased appetite\n\t\t•\tStomach cramps\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tNausea or vomiting"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Intestinal ileus is a potentially dangerous condition that happens when the muscles in the intestine slow down or stop working. Food, gas, and liquid build up in the intestine because they can't move smoothly through the digestive system. Without treatment, it can lead to serious complications such as life-threatening peritonitis infection. Intestinal ileus is often caused by abdominal surgery. You may have abdominal cramping or swelling, vomiting, and constipation. You may need medication to treat it and ease your symptoms or more extensive treatment if complications develop."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Intestinal ileus often happens in the first three days after abdominal surgery. But certain drugs, atherosclerosis or\"hardening of the arteries,\" and conditions such as kidney failure can also cause it. You may have severe constipation, bloating, vomiting, and cramps that come and go. Intestinal ileus often clears up on its own, especially if it's caused by surgery, but your doctor will hospitalize you for a few days to watch it and relieve your symptoms. You won't be allowed to eat or drink. A tube may be put through your nose into your stomach to suck out built up air and fluid. You may also get medication to get your intestinal muscles moving and to treat the cause. How well and quickly you recover depends on what caused the intestinal ileus and how serious it is."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Taking laxatives"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment of an intestinal ileus may include:\n\t\t•\tWatchful waiting, to see if it clears up on its own\n\t\t•\tNo food or drink until the intestines start working normally\n\t\t•\tIV fluids and electrolytes\n\t\t•\tStopping any medication that causes ileus\n\t\t•\tNasogastric suction, where gastric juices are sucked out of the stomach through a tube inserted through the nose\n\t\t•\tMedication to stimulate normal intestinal contractions\n\t\t•\tColonoscopic decompression, where a tube is inserted into the colon to relieve pressure\n\t\t•\tChewing gum\n\t\t•\tVery rarely, surgery to remove part of the bowel"
		},

			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "You may be able to help your recovery from ileus in the hospital by being as active as you can. Getting out of bed to sit in a chair or taking a walk may help your intestines get moving. Chewing gum may also help."

	"Low_fiber_diet": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tConstipation"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "A low-fiber diet limits fruits, vegetables, and grains that contain plant fiber that passes through the body undigested. It is one of the main causes of constipation, which occurs when you have less than three bowel movements a week. You also may have hard, dry stools that are difficult to pass. Some people need to follow a low-fiber diet after surgery, or because of digestive problems such as inflammatory bowel disease. But most Americans should eat 20 grams to 35 grams of fiber a day. Unfortunately, most of us only get about 4 grams to 15 grams a day. Fiber is found in fruits, vegetables, beans, and whole grains such as whole-wheat bread, brown rice, and whole-grain cereals."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Eating a low-fiber diet limits your bowel movements. It can ease diarrhea, and help with inflammation or sensitivity in the digestive system. However, most people should gradually reintroduce fiber into their diet to avoid constipation and get the health benefits from dietary fiber, which helps prevent heart disease and diabetes. Chronic constipation may be a sign of other medical conditions such as irritable bowel syndrome or low thyroid. Some medications, such as some antidepressants and narcotic pain relievers, also cause constipation. In these cases, treating the underlying health problem or changing medications or dosage relieves constipation."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "More than 4 million people in the U.S. have frequent constipation."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Your doctor may recommend you increase fiber in your diet by eating more fruits, vegetables, beans, and whole grains. If you cannot eat those foods, your doctor may recommend fiber supplements. If you must follow a low-fiber diet for medical reasons, your doctor may prescribe stool softeners or laxatives to help with constipation."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "You can help prevent constipation caused by a low-fiber diet by:\n\t\t•\tEating a high-fiber diet with plenty of fruits and vegetables, whole grains, beans, nuts, and seeds\n\t\t•\tGetting regular exercise\n\t\t•\tDrinking plenty of fluid\n\t\t•\tTaking fiber supplements as needed\n\t\t•\tGoing to the bathroom when you feel the urge"
		},

			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Certain medications, lack of exercise, not drinking enough fluids"

			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "You should see your doctor if you've tried self-care but still have constipation, or you have unusual changes in your bowel habits, unusual weight loss, or abdominal pain. Get immediate medical attention if you have severe abdominal pain, vomit blood, or have black, tarry stools."
		},

	"Taking_iron_supplements": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tConstipation\n\t\t•\tBlack (tar) colored stools"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Everybody needs iron to help make red blood cells. Not having enough iron in your body can cause anemia, or low blood count. People who don't get enough iron in their diet or who have anemia may need to take iron supplements. Sometimes taking iron supplements can cause side effects such as headache, a metallic taste in your mouth, nausea, vomiting, constipation, black or dark green stools, or stomach pain. Taking too much iron can cause severe vomiting, severe stomach pain, and fever. In children, taking too much iron can even cause death. How much is enough? Most adult men need about 8 milligrams of iron each day while most adult women need about 18 milligrams of iron a day. Pregnant women need 27 milligrams of iron each day. Iron supplements are available in tablets, liquids, syrups, and elixirs."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Talk with your doctor about taking the right dose of iron for you. Iron is best absorbed when taken on an empty stomach, but sometimes this can increase your risk of stomach upset. Your doctor may suggest starting with half the recommended dose to lessen these effects. Your doctor may also suggest taking the iron in a few doses during the day. Be sure to check with your doctor if you take iron supplements for more than a few months because iron can build up in your system and cause poisoning."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Nearly 3% of men, 30% of women, and 50% of pregnant women in the U.S. don't get enough iron."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Talk with your doctor about how much iron you need to take for your condition."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Since people absorb iron differently and have different needs for iron, it's best to talk with your doctor about taking iron supplements. If you take iron supplements without a prescription from your doctor, be sure to read the label carefully and follow the directions."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Taking iron supplements on an empty stomach, or taking more iron than you need makes symptoms worse. Do not take iron supplements if you have a disease known as hemochromatosis."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",

		},

	"Polycystic_kidney_disease": [{
			"heading": "Polycystic Kidney Disease",
			"content": "Polycystic kidneys, PKD, autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, ADPKD"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tDistended stomach\n\t\t•\tSwelling\n\t\t•\tFrequent urination\n\t\t•\tPain with urination\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tBlood or red colored urine\n\t\t•\tNausea or vomiting\n\t\t•\tHigh blood pressure"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Polycystic kidney disease is a genetic condition that causes cysts to grow in the kidneys. This can lead to reduced kidney function and kidney failure. PKD is a condition that runs in families. Many people may not have symptoms of PKD until they reach middle age. Once symptoms start, they can include abdominal pain, headaches, and pain in the sides and back. PKD can also cause blood in the urine, increased urination at night, high blood pressure, joint pain, painful menstruation, kidney infections, and kidney stones. There is no cure for PKD, but treatments can often help ease symptoms for many years."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Most people with PKD don't have any symptoms for many years. The cysts in the kidneys usually grow slowly. Once the cysts get large, they can cause high blood pressure, loss of kidney function, cysts on the liver and other organs, heart valve problems, and colon problems. PKD usually progresses slowly, but can eventually cause kidney failure. People who have kidney failure need dialysis or a kidney transplant. There is no cure for PKD, but treatments can often help ease symptoms for many years."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 600,000 people in the U.S. have PKD."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "You may be at higher risk for PKD if you have a family history of the condition."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",

		},

			"content": "Follow your doctor's instructions about drinking fluids."

		{

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "When you have Gaucher's (pronounced go-SHAYS) disease, fats collect in certain parts of your body, like the liver, spleen, lungs, and bone marrow. People with Gaucher's disease don’t have enough of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase, which breaks down fatty molecules in the body. Without enough of the enzyme, dangerous levels of these fats build up in your body’s cells. There are three main types of Gaucher's disease. Types 2 and 3 can affect your brain and spinal cord."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Children born with type 2 Gaucher's usually have severe brain damage and may not live past age 2 or 3. Type 3 Gaucher's usually progresses more slowly. People with this form may live into adulthood."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "It’s not clear how many people are born with Gaucher's disease, but types 2 and 3 are less common than type 1. Type 2 happens in about 1 in 100,000 babies. Type 3 happens in 1 in 50,000 babies. Gaucher's disease is more common in Middle Eastern and Asian countries than in the United States."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Gaucher's disease is caused by genes that you inherit from your parents. If both parents carry the gene, there is a 1 in 4 chance that their child will have the disease.  Even if you don’t have it, you may still carry the gene. Tests can tell whether you carry it or not."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Some symptoms of type 2 Gaucher's disease, such as brain damage, do not get better with treatment. Treatment for type 3 often includes enzyme replacement therapy, usually given by IV every 2 weeks for life. This can help reduce liver and spleen size, bone problems, and anemia, but it doesn’t help problems with the brain or the nervous system. Other treatments include blood transfusions for anemia and joint replacement surgery. But enzyme replacement therapy makes these treatments less common."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "A healthy lifestyle including diet, exercise, and a positive outlook are helpful."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Symptoms get worse on their own. In type 3 Gaucher's disease, waiting to start enzyme replacement therapy may allow symptoms to get worse faster."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "Gaucher's disease requires ongoing medical care. You will need to see a doctor for enzyme replacement therapy, and you will need regular blood tests and monitoring."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\t\t•\tWhen should I or my child start enzyme replacement therapy?\n\t\t•\tWhat are the risks of the enzyme replacement therapy drug you prescribed?\n\t\t•\tWhat tests are needed on a regular basis?\n\t\t•\tWhat is the outlook for my or my child’s condition?\n\t\t•\tShould other family members be tested?"

			"content": "Sudden, severe bone pain or broken bones, fevers, and very easy bleeding need medical attention right away."

	"Food_poisoning": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tNausea or vomiting\n\t\t•\tDiarrhea\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Food poisoning occurs when you eat food that is contaminated with bacteria, viruses, or parasites. This can happen when food is improperly handled or stored. The most common symptoms of food poisoning include abdominal pain, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, fever, chills, and weakness. Symptoms most often begin within two to six hours after eating the food, but it can be longer or shorter depending on the type of food poisoning. You can treat most types of food poisoning at home."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "With common types of food poisoning, you will usually feel better within a few days. In most cases, you won't need any treatment. But you may need to take antibiotics for some types of bacterial food poisoning, such as listeria. The most common complication of food poisoning is dehydration. You may need to seek medical care if you can't keep down enough fluids to replace what you lose from vomiting or diarrhea. Certain types of food poisoning, such as E. coli, botulism, and salmonella, can cause more serious complications."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "There are an estimated 76 millions of cases of food poisoning in the U.S. every year, affecting one out of six Americans."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "The most important treatment for most cases of food poisoning is rest and fluids. Your doctor may suggest taking a medicine to help stop or slow diarrhea. In some cases, you may need antibiotics or other medications. If you become dehydrated, you may need to go to the hospital to receive fluids into a vein."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "You can treat most cases of food poisoning at home by following these tips:\n\t\t•\tGet plenty of rest.\n\t\t•\tTake small sips of water or other liquids or try sucking on ice chips. Avoid caffeinated drinks and milk.\n\t\t•\tAvoid solid foods until your stomach has settled.\n\t\t•\tWhen you begin eating again, start with bland foods, such as toast, crackers, bananas, apple sauce, or rice."
		},

		},

		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Drug abuse occurs when you use illegal drugs or misuse legal drugs for a year or longer with harmful results. Regular use can result in drug dependence, which is when the body needs the drug to behave naturally. Genes, peer pressure, and emotional problems may play a part in why people become dependent on drugs such as heroin, oxycodone, cocaine, alcohol, LSD, and marijuana. Drug dependence and abuse can result in a number of physical problems, including an increased or decreased heartbeat and digestion issues, and in severe cases, death. It may be dangerous to stop using drugs suddenly, causing withdrawal and problems such as delusions. It's important to get help to stop using drugs safely."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "It can be dangerous to drive, ride a bike, skateboard, work with machinery, or swim while under the influence of drugs. Risks of being dependent on drugs and abusing drugs include overdose, depression, and problems with concentration and memory. Tolerance can develop, requiring higher doses of the drug to achieve the desired “high.” If you inject drugs, the risks include infections and HIV. There may be withdrawal symptoms when the drug's effects wear off, causing jumpiness, anxiety, shakiness, sweating, irritability, or tiredness. In serious cases, people may have hallucinations, fevers, or seizures. Once people have abused drugs, they need to be careful not to use them again, because relapses are common. Support from family and friends during these times can help."

			"heading": "Intestinal Obstruction",
			"content": "Bowel obstruction, mechanical bowel obstruction"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tNausea or vomiting\n\t\t•\tBloating or fullness\n\t\t•\tDistended stomach\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tConstipation\n\t\t•\tStomach cramps"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Intestinal obstruction happens when part of the intestine is partially or completely blocked. Waste, fluid, and gas build up in the intestine because they can't get out of the body. You may have pain, constipation, or vomiting. If the blockage isn't cleared up, it can cut off the blood supply to the intestine, which can be fatal. With immediate hospital treatment, most people fully recover."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "If you have severe abdominal pain, see your doctor immediately or go to a hospital emergency room."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Most intestinal obstructions occur in the small intestine and are caused by adhesions, or bands of scar tissue from prior abdominal surgeries. Tumors cause most intestinal obstructions in the large intestine, or colon. Crohn's disease and abdominal cancer or surgery increases your risk for an intestinal obstruction. At the hospital, doctors will start IV fluids and may pass a tube through your nose into your stomach to suck out fluids and air. You may not need further treatment or you may need surgery to remove a tumor, gallstone, part of the bowel, or scar tissue, or to repair a hernia. About 85% of partial small intestine obstructions clear up without surgery, while about 85% of complete small intestine obstructions need surgery."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",

	"Lactose_intolerance": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tNausea or vomiting\n\t\t•\tDiarrhea\n\t\t•\tFrequent bowel movements\n\t\t•\tStomach cramps\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tFoul smelling stools\n\t\t•\tIncreased passing gas"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Lactose is a type of sugar found in dairy products. Lactose intolerance occurs in people who don't produce lactase, the enzyme that digests lactose. Undigested lactose ferments in the colon, leading to gas, bloating, and other symptoms. Some people produce less lactase as they get older. Diseases that affect the stomach lining, infections of the small intestine, and bowel surgery can affect how much lactase is available to digest lactose. Some people with lactose intolerance can eat small amounts of dairy. Lactase supplements can help people with severe intolerance to dairy products."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Stomach cramps, pain, gas, diarrhea, or nausea occur 30 minutes to two hours after eating dairy products. Symptoms range from mild to severe depending on how much lactose is in the food and how well the body digests it."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Millions of people in the U.S. have some degree of lactose intolerance."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "First, determine how much lactose you can tolerate. Most people can ingest some. Following that step, treatment includes:\n\t\t•\tAvoiding dairy products\n\t\t•\tUsing lactase supplements\n\t\t•\tDrinking lactose-free milk"
		},

			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tNausea or vomiting\n\t\t•\tDecreased appetite"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Morning sickness is nausea and vomiting that occurs while a woman is pregnant. Despite its name, morning sickness can happen any time of the day. Increasing hormone levels are thought to cause the condition. A woman may have just mild nausea or have both nausea and vomiting. Most women have morning sickness starting the first month of pregnancy and lasting though the 14th or 16th week. Some women have nausea and vomiting throughout their pregnancy. Morning sickness won't harm the baby unless nausea and vomiting are so severe that you can't keep down fluids. If this happens, it's important to see a doctor. It may help to eat crackers or dry toast in the morning when you get up, or to eat smaller, more frequent meals. Drinking ginger ale or tea may also help ease morning sickness. For severe morning sickness, the doctor may recommend vitamin B6 supplements, anti-nausea medication, or hospitalization with IV fluids."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "You may have mild nausea or both nausea and vomiting starting in the first month of pregnancy. It may occur only in the morning or at other times during the day. Try to avoid unpleasant smells, get plenty of rest, and avoid spicy or fatty foods. If nausea and vomiting are severe, or if they last longer than your fourth month of pregnancy, talk to your doctor. Morning sickness usually eases up on its own after the first trimester. Some women find that it helps to eat crackers or dry toast in the morning, drink ginger ale or eat ginger products, and eat smaller more frequent meals. Never take anti-nausea medications or any other supplements to ease morning sickness without first talking with your doctor."
		},

Experts think it results when sensory input about motion from the brain, the eyes, and inner ear conflict. Some people feel better if they keep their eyes focused on the horizon or on stationary objects. A variety of medications help prevent motion sickness."

Other ways to prevent motion sickness include: avoiding amusement park rides or virtual reality rides, avoiding alcohol or heavy meals before taking a trip, sitting in the front seat of the car, driving if possible, and getting plenty of fresh air."

		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Henoch-Schönlein purpura causes small blood vessels in the skin to leak because of swelling. It is most common in children aged 2-6 but can effect anyone. No one is sure what causes it, although it may be an abnormal reaction of the immune system to an infection or insect bite. The most common symptom is a purple bruise-like rash on the legs and buttocks. It also can affect blood vessels in the joints, kidneys, and intestines. People with Henoch-Schönlein purpura also can have abdominal pain, joint pain, or blood in the urine. It usually gets better on its own, but ongoing medical care is needed if the kidneys are involved."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Henoch-Schönlein purpura usually lasts about 4-6 weeks and gets better without treatment. Some people have it more than once, but the symptoms are usually milder after the first time. HSP usually doesn't cause any long-term problems. But in rare cases it can lead to kidney damage, kidney failure, and problems with the bowel. Your doctor will check your kidneys to make sure they haven't been damaged."
		},

	"Diverticulitis": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tDiarrhea\n\t\t•\tConstipation\n\t\t•\tStomach cramps"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Diverticuli are small pouches that bulge out from weak spots in colon walls. Over time, pressure and strain from passing hard stools causes these weak areas. The condition is common in people over age 40, possibly in those who don't get enough fiber in their diet. Most people with diverticulosis have no discomfort or symptoms. However, bacteria and fecal matter sometimes get trapped inside these pouches, causing inflammation and pain, a condition known as diverticulitis. Diverticulitis can cause pain, cramping, infection, bleeding, and other serious complications."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Most people with diverticuli in their colon walls have no symptoms or have mild cramps and pain, bloating, and constipation, most likely due to irritable bowel syndrome. Occasionally, bleeding originates from a diverticulum, causing a diverticular bleed.  If diverticulitis, inflammation and pain of the diverticula, develops, some cases will clear up on their own in a week or two. But in many other cases, mild pain may get worse over a few days, or severe pain may come on suddenly. You may also have fever, chills, nausea, sweating, and other symptoms. If this happens, it's important to see a doctor. If not treated, an abscess may form in the intestinal wall. A fistula, a tube that connects from the intestinal wall to another organ or to the skin, also can form. Treatment with antibiotics can ease symptoms. For severe cases of diverticulitis, surgery can repair a fistula, a colonic perforation, or intestinal blockage."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About half of people age 60 and older have diverticulosis. 10% to 25% go on to develop diverticulitis."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Diverticulosis typically requires no medical treatment. Your doctor will probably recommend that you eat a high-fiber diet."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "If you have diverticulosis, self-care may include:\n\t\t•\tHigh-fiber diet\n\t\t•\tDrinking plenty of fluids\n\t\t•\tTaking fiber supplements\n\t\t•\tGetting regular exercise"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Low-fiber diet, constipation"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "Most people with diverticulosis have no symptoms. Some people, however, may feel crampy pain in the lower abdomen, bloating, or constipation if their condition has become diverticulitis. There may also be tenderness in the abdomen, fevers and chills. If you have symptoms of diverticulitis, see your doctor."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tHow severe is my diverticulosis?\n\t\t•\tWill my current diet help prevent further symptoms of diverticulosis?\n\t\t•\tWhat can I do to help prevent diverticulitis?"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "Your doctor will take your medical history and do a physical exam. Other tests may include blood tests, barium X-ray, sigmoidoscopy, colonoscopy, ultrasound, or CT scans. Often, diverticulosis is not diagnosed until it has progressed to diverticulitis and causes pain."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Age, low-fiber diet, lack of exercise, constipation, and obesity increase your risk."
		},

			"content": "If you have severe bleeding from the colon or intense pain, get immediate medical care. These could be signs of a diverticular bleed, perforation, a large abscess, peritonitis, or an intestinal obstruction that requires immediate surgery."

			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Intestinal ischemia is a rare but serious condition that occurs when blockage or narrowing of a blood vessel decreases the flow of blood to the intestines. Blood clots are one cause. If severe, intestinal ischemia can cause life-threatening gangrene and damage or rupture the intestines. If it comes on suddenly, you may have severe abdominal pain and bloody stools. Getting help right away is critical. Medication and surgery are usually successful in treating it if it is caught early."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "If you have sudden, severe abdominal pain, call emergency services or get to a hospital emergency room immediately."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "With sudden, or acute, intestinal ischemia, you may have mild to severe pain in the abdomen, an urgent and forceful bowel movement, and blood in your stools. You may have had symptoms of chronic intestinal ischemia leading up to this, such as pain after meals that gets worse over time. Treatment can range from medication to treat infection and the underlying cause to emergency surgery. If a stent is inserted to widen an artery, you'll be in the hospital overnight. Otherwise, you may need surgery to remove dead tissue or remove or bypass an obstruction. In this case, you may be hospitalized for about a week. In some cases, you may need to take anticoagulant medication, which prevents blood clots from forming, for several months or the rest of your life."

	"Ascaris_worms": [{
			"heading": "Ascaris",
			"content": "Roundworms"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tWorms in stool"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Ascarisis is an infection by a roundworm (ascaris), the largest of all intestinal parasites. Roundworms are not very common in U.S., but they are in other parts of the world. The worms live in the small intestine and worm eggs are passed through the stool. If a person goes to the bathroom outside, or if human sewage is used for fertilizer, the dirt can become infected with worm eggs. Eating food grown in contaminated soil or putting your fingers in your mouth after touching infected dirt can spread the parasite. Ascaris can grow as long as 8 to 14 inches. Most people have mild cases and may not have symptoms. However, a serious case can lead to intestinal blockage or other serious complications that need surgery. Medications can kill the worms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Many people are infected with ascaris and don't know it until they spot a worm in their stool. Once eggs hatch, small larvae move into the bloodstream and then to the lungs. This can cause coughing, wheezing, and even a type of pneumonia as the worms move through the lungs. The larvae move to your throat, where you cough them up and then swallow them. Worms can live 10 to 24 months in the intestines, where they lay eggs that end up in stool. 6 to 8 weeks after being infected, stomach symptoms such as stomach pain, nausea, and vomiting can occur. In children, ascarisis can cause malnutrition. Treatment with drugs can kill the worms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Exposure to feces or worm eggs, eating food handled by someone who has worms and has not washed their hands, eating food grown in contaminated dirt"
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 4 million people in the U.S. are infected with ascaris."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Prevention",
			"content": "These steps can help prevent ascarisis:\n\t\t•\tWash your hands thoroughly after going to the bathroom and before handling food.\n\t\t•\tWash, peel, and cook raw vegetables that have been grown in areas where ascaris may be present.\n\t\t•\tAvoid contact with soil fertilized with manure or fertilizer made from human waste."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Ascarisis treatment includes:\n\t\t•\tWorm-killing medications\n\t\t•\tSurgery, if needed, to remove worms or to clear blockages"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "Call your doctor if you have symptoms of ascarisis, notice a worm in your stool or mouth, or if you are being treated for the condition but your symptoms are not improving.\n\nGet immediate medical help if you have severe stomach pain and vomiting."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tCould an infection with ascaris or another condition be causing my symptoms?\n\t\t•\tWhat treatment do I need?\n\t\t•\tHow long before my symptoms go away?\n\t\t•\tHow do I avoid getting this again?"

	"Celiac_disease": [{
			"heading": "Celiac Disease",
			"content": "Sprue, gluten intolerance, gluten sensitivity"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tFoul smelling stools\n\t\t•\tSkin bumps\n\t\t•\tDiarrhea\n\t\t•\tSkin rash\n\t\t•\tWeight loss (unintentional)"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Celiac disease causes damage to the lining of the small intestine and prevents it from absorbing food properly. It is caused by a reaction to gluten, a protein found in wheat, rye, and barley. Celiac disease can cause gas, diarrhea, bloating, and weight loss. In the long run, it may lead to malnutrition, osteoporosis, and anemia because of decreased absorption of vitamins and minerals from the intestine. Celiac disease tends to run in families, but can also occur in people without a family history of the disease."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Celiac disease is difficult to diagnose, because the symptoms are similar to many other conditions. Once you are diagnosed, you can treat celiac disease by avoiding all gluten. This will stop the symptoms and heal the small intestine. Most people notice an improvement in symptoms within a few days of starting a gluten-free diet. But it may take several months or years for the small intestine to heal completely. Besides diarrhea and abdominal pain, celiac disease can cause fatigue, depression, joint pain, arthritis, osteoporosis, mouth sores, muscle cramps, and tingling in the legs and feet. Be sure to tell your doctor about any possible complications."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About one in 133 people in the U.S. have celiac disease. For those who have a close relative with celiac disease, the number is about one in 22."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "The only treatment for celiac disease is a gluten-free diet."

			"content": "You can stay well by avoiding all gluten. Even a small amount of gluten can hurt your small intestine."

	"Endometriosis": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tConstipation\n\t\t•\tHeavy menstrual bleeding\n\t\t•\tPain with sexual intercourse (female)\n\t\t•\tBloating or fullness\n\t\t•\tDiarrhea\n\t\t•\tVaginal bleeding between periods"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Endometriosis occurs when tissue cells that line the uterus start growing outside the uterus. This tissue can grow on the fallopian tubes, ovaries, bladder, bowels, or other areas in the pelvis. In rare cases, the cells grow in other areas of the body. The displaced tissue may bleed during a woman's menstrual period just like it does in the uterus. Over time, scar tissue called adhesions form, causing pain, cramping, and sometimes infertility. Endometriosis usually starts when a woman is in her 20s to early 40s. It slows down after menopause."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Endometriosis may be mild or severe. Often it develops slowly, and symptoms get worse gradually until menopause when they taper off. Some women never know they have endometriosis. But for others, endometriosis causes severe pain. Endometriosis can also cause infertility, even in women who don't have symptoms. Women who have children are less likely to have it as pregnancy provides a break from the monthly hormonal cycle. Infrequently, endometriosis can cause complete obstruction of the small intestines or colon."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Approximately 1 in 25 women have endometriosis."
		},

			"heading": "Treatment",

		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Endometriosis should be evaluated and treated by a doctor. If you think you have the symptoms, get it checked out."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Irregular or short menstrual cycles and heavy periods."
		},
		{

		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "To diagnose endometriosis, your doctor will take a medical history and do a physical, including a pelvic exam. As needed, your doctor may also do an ultrasound, CT scan, MRI, cell biopsies, and laparoscopy. A laparoscopy is a lighted scope inserted into your abdomen while you are sedated to view your pelvic organs."

			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Hydronephrosis occurs when one or both kidneys swell with urine that can't drain out of the kidney to the bladder. If hydronephrosis comes on suddenly, it can cause excruciating pain. It's important to get hydronephrosis diagnosed early to prevent permanent kidney damage. A kidney stone, blood clot, tumor, enlarged prostate, or enlarged uterus during pregnancy may cause it. Treatment usually focuses on relieving the blockage so the urine can flow from the kidney."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",

		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Hydrophrenosis can damage your kidney before you even have symptoms, so a doctor should monitor people who are at risk for it. If it is mild and chronic, you may have no symptoms or just a dull aching between the ribs and the hip. If it comes on suddenly, you may have writhing pain in that area, along with nausea or vomiting. If blood clots or kidney stones cause hydronephrosis, it may clear up without treatment. For other causes, medication, insertion of a drainage tube, or surgery is needed to drain fluid from the kidney, remove the blockage, or treat infection. If untreated, hydronephrosis can lead to kidney failure and death. But in most cases, the kidneys recover well even if they have been blocked for a few weeks. Kidney infections and blood poisoning are possible complications of hydronephrosis."
		},
