	"Pancreatitis": [{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Pancreatitis is inflammation of the pancreas camera.gif, an organ in your belly that makes the hormones insulin and glucagon. These two hormones control how your body uses the sugar found in the food you eat. Your pancreas also makes other hormones and enzymes that help you break down food.\n\nUsually the digestive enzymes stay in one part of the pancreas. But if these enzymes leak into other parts of the pancreas, they can irritate it and cause pain and swelling. This may happen suddenly or over many years. Over time, it can damage and scar the pancreas."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed by",
			"content": "Your doctor will do a physical exam and ask you questions about your symptoms and past health. You may also have blood tests to see if your levels of certain enzymes are higher than normal. This can mean that you have pancreatitis.\n\nYour doctor may also want you to have a complete blood count (CBC), a liver test, or a stool test.\n\nOther tests include an MRI, a CT scan, or an ultrasound of your belly (abdominal ultrasound) to look for gallstones.\n\nA test called endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatogram, or ERCP, may help your doctor see if you have chronic pancreatitis. During this test, the doctor can also remove gallstones that are stuck in the bile duct."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Most attacks of pancreatitis need treatment in the hospital. Your doctor will give you pain medicine and fluids through a vein (IV) until the pain and swelling go away.\n\nFluids and air can build up in your stomach when there are problems with your pancreas. This buildup can cause severe vomiting. If buildup occurs, your doctor may place a tube through your nose and into your stomach to remove the extra fluids and air. This will help make the pancreas less active and swollen.\n\nAlthough most people get well after an attack of pancreatitis, problems can occur. Problems may include cysts, infection, or death of tissue in the pancreas."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk factors",
			"content": "Several things can increase your risk of pancreatitis, including:\n\t\t•\tAlcohol abuse. The amount needed to cause pancreatitis is not known. Alcohol tolerance varies from one person to another. Moderate consumption is considered no more than 2 alcoholic beverages a day for men and 1 a day for women and older people.\n\t\t•\tA family history of pancreatitis.\n\t\t•\tA high level of fat (triglycerides) in the blood.\n\t\t•\tGallstones. A small gallstone can move far enough into the bile duct to block the flow of pancreatic enzymes into the small intestine.\n\t\t•\tHaving cystic fibrosis.\n\t\t•\tSmoking cigarettes.\n\t\t•\tStructural problems of the pancreas or the bile and pancreatic ducts, especially a condition in which the pancreas is divided and has two main ducts (pancreas divisum).\n\t\t•\tTaking certain medicines, including estrogen therapy and some antibiotics."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When To Call a Doctor",
			"content": "Call your doctor immediately if you have severe belly (abdominal) pain with vomiting that does not go away after a few hours, or mild to moderate pain that does not improve with home treatment after a couple of days. These symptoms may be caused by pancreatitis.\n\nWatchful waiting\n\nPancreatitis can be a severe, potentially life-threatening illness. It is not appropriate to take a wait-and-see approach, which is called watchful waiting, if you have severe pain in the upper area camera.gif of the abdomen that does not go away in a few hours.\n\nWho to see\n\nThe following health professionals can diagnose and treat pancreatitis:\n\t\t•\tFamily medicine physician\n\t\t•\tInternist\n\t\t•\tGastroenterologist (specialist in diseases of the digestive system)\n\t\t•\tNurse practitioner\n\t\t•\tPhysician assistant\n\t\t•\tSurgeon"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Prevention",
			"content": "You cannot completely prevent pancreatitis caused by gallstones. But you may be able to reduce your risk of forming gallstones by staying at a healthy weight with a balanced diet and regular exercise. For more information, see the topic Gallstones.\n\nYou can reduce your chance of having pancreatitis by not drinking alcohol excessively. The amount of alcohol needed to cause pancreatitis varies from one person to another. Generally, moderate consumption is considered no more than 2 alcoholic beverages a day for men and 1 a day for women and older people.\n\nSmoking may increase your chance of having pancreatitis. If you smoke, it's a good idea to quit."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self care",
			"content": "If you have ongoing (chronic) pancreatitis caused by excessive use of alcohol, you will need to quit drinking to reduce severe pain and complications. Drinking large amounts when you have chronic pancreatitis can shorten your life. For more information on quitting alcohol, see the topic Alcohol Abuse and Dependence.\n\nAlthough the role of diet in pancreatitis is not clear, doctors recommend eating a low-fat diet and staying at a healthy body weight."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Medications",
			"content": "In addition to pain medicine, people who have chronic illness may take pancreatic enzymes and insulin because their damaged pancreas no longer produces enough of these.\n\nMedicine choices\n\t\t•\tYou may need one or more medicines to treat chronic pancreatitis. Be safe with medicines. Read and follow all instructions on the label.\n\nPain medicine. Mild pain is first treated with a medicine such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen. If you have stronger pain, you may be given an opiate pain reliever.\n\nPancreatic enzyme supplements. In advanced chronic pancreatitis, the pancreas may stop producing the enzymes needed to digest fats, proteins, and carbohydrates. Enzyme supplements at meals can help the body digest fats, allowing you to retain nutrients and gain weight.\n\nInsulin. Advanced chronic pancreatitis can lead to diabetes if the part of the pancreas that produces insulin becomes damaged.\n\nSide effects of pancreatic enzymes that are given to treat chronic pancreatitis include abdominal (belly) discomfort and soreness of the mouth and the anus. People who are allergic to pork or who do not eat pork for other reasons should not take these enzymes, because they are made of pork protein. In young children, high doses of pancreatic enzymes could cause a bowel obstruction."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Surgery",
			"content": "Surgery of the pancreas is avoided, if possible, because the gland is easily damaged. But surgery may be needed to remove infected or damaged tissue (pancreatic necrosis). The gallbladder may be removed to prevent future attacks from gallstones.\n\nOne of two surgeries can be done to remove the gallbladder if gallstones are causing pancreatitis:\n\t\t•\tLaparoscopic gallbladder surgery\n\t\t•\tOpen gallbladder surgery\n\t\t•\tSurgeons may choose among several techniques to remove damaged pancreatic tissue."
		}
	],

The urge to have a bowel movement, rectal fullness, pain, and other symptoms can occur for a short time or become a chronic problem. Antibiotics treat STDs, the most common cause of proctitis. For conditions such as Crohn's disease, long-term therapy helps relieve proctitis symptoms."

		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Appendicitis is a serious infection of the appendix, a small fingerlike tube located where the large and small intestine join. About half of people who have appendicitis feel abdominal pain that begins near the belly button and moves to the lower right. If not treated rapidly, the appendix will likely burst, spreading infection throughout the abdomen, a dangerous condition known as peritonitis. Surgery to remove the appendix, called an appendectomy, can prevent this. People 10 years old to 30 years old are most likely to have appendicitis."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "Appendicitis is a medical emergency. If you have appendicitis symptoms, including abdominal pain for more than four hours:\n\t\t•\tImmediately see your doctor or go to a hospital emergency room.\n\t\t•\tDo not take a laxative or enema for constipation because it could make the appendix burst.\n\t\t•\tDo not take pain medication because it could mask symptoms.\n\t\t•\tDo not eat or drink because this could delay or complicate surgery."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Appendicitis often begins with vague pain that may get worse with moving, coughing, sneezing, or taking deep breaths. Loss of appetite, vomiting, low-grade fever, worsening pain, and constipation or diarrhea also may develop. You should get an urgent evaluation at your doctor's office or a hospital emergency room. If the diagnosis is not certain, the doctor may do tests and closely observe you for several hours, in or out of the hospital, to see if more conclusive signs develop. If you are likely having appendicitis, you'll get immediate surgery to remove the appendix. If you have surgery and the appendix has burst, the doctor will insert a tube to drain fluid from the abdomen for a few days. After an appendectomy, you need to restrict physical activity and diet over the next two to four weeks. Recovery time is longer if the appendix has burst."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Causes",
			"content": "Ascites happens when pressure builds up in the veins of your liver and it doesn’t work as it should. These two problems usually are caused by another condition -- cirrhosis, heart or kidney failure, cancer, or an infection.\n\nThe pressure blocks blood flow in the liver, which over time keeps your kidneys from removing excess salt from your body. This, in turn, causes fluid to build up."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosis",
			"content": "Your doctor will give you a physical exam and will want to know more about your symptoms. He may perform a variety of tests, including blood work, an ultrasound, or a CT scan.\n\nIf he thinks you have ascites, your doctor will use a needle to remove fluid from your abdomen for testing. This procedure is called a paracentesis. It will help your doctor determine the cause of your condition, so it can be properly treated.\n\nIn most cases of ascites, your doctor will refer you to a liver specialist, who may discuss a liver transplant."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Since ascites prevents the flushing of salt through your pee, the first step is to cut down on the salt you eat, by a lot. Your doctor also may prescribe “water pills,” also called diuretics, to help flush the extra fluid from your body.\n\nTwo of the most common diuretics are:\n\t\t•\tFurosemide (Lasix)\n\t\t•\tSpironolactone (Aldactone)\n\nThey both help your kidneys remove more sodium and water.\n\nIf change in diet and prescription diuretics aren’t effective, or your symptoms are severe, your doctor may have to use paracentesis to remove large amounts of excess fluid through a needle inserted into your abdomen. This procedure must be combined with a low-salt, low-liquid diet, otherwise the fluid will simply come back.\n\nIf these treatments don’t work, you may need a surgery to place a shunt in your liver or replace it altogether."
		}
	],
	"Dysmenorrhea_(menstrual_cramps)": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tStomach cramps\n\t\t•\tBloating or fullness\n\t\t•\tMuscle cramps or spasms (painful)\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tHeavy menstrual bleeding\n\t\t•\tVaginal bleeding"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Dysmenorrhea means unusually painful or long-lasting menstrual cramping, bleeding, and pain. Most women experience some cramping and pain during their period. But some women experience severe pain, cramping, diarrhea, nausea, headache, or dizziness during their period. These symptoms make it hard to work or go to school. There are two types of dysmenorrhea: primary and secondary. Primary occurs naturally -- some women just have more painful periods than others. High levels of the hormone prostaglandin are thought to cause painful periods. Secondary dysmenorrhea occurs because of another medical problem such as endometriosis or fibroid tumors. Taking pain relievers and using a heating pad will treat most cases of primary dysmenorrhea. For painful periods due to medical problems, treating the medical problem can relieve symptoms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Painful periods usually start soon after a young woman starts menstruating. Pain and other symptoms start at the beginning of the period or just before and get better in one or two days. Symptoms may vary from one month to the next. Some women have less pain as they get older, but many don't. Most women treat painful periods with pain relievers and heating pads. Prescription pain relievers, birth control pills, or using an IUD that contains hormones also can relieve pain and cramping. Unusual pain and heavy bleeding that lasts longer than usual may be signs of another medical problem, so it's best to see a doctor to find the cause."
		},

Some tumors in the ovaries are noncancerous, but others are cancerous and can spread to other parts of the body. Epithelial tumors cause most ovarian cancer and occur mostly in women who have been through menopause. Surgery and chemotherapy are used to treat ovarian cancer. Almost half of the women who get it survive five years or more."

You may want to get a second opinion before moving forward. Most likely you will have surgery to remove both fallopian tubes and ovaries, as well as the uterus. You also may need chemotherapy, which can cause hair loss and other side effects."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Gastroenteritis is irritation of the stomach and intestines. Viruses, bacteria, parasites, or food-borne illness can cause it. Gastroenteritis symptoms include abdominal pain and cramping, nausea, diarrhea, and vomiting. While sometimes called the\"stomach flu,\" the flu virus does not cause gastroenteritis. The illness usually spreads easily from contact with a sick person. Eating or drinking contaminated food or beverages also will spread the illness. Most people recover in a few days by drinking plenty of fluids and resting. Antibiotics treat gastroenteritis caused by bacteria or some parasites. Infants, older adults, and people with chronic illnesses are at higher risk for dehydration from gastroenteritis."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Symptoms usually start about one to two days after infection. In most cases, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea get better within 24 to 48 hours. Some symptoms may continue two weeks or more, depending on the cause of infection. Drinking clear fluids helps prevent dehydration. If nausea and vomiting make it difficult to drink fluids, call the doctor."

		{
			"heading": "Prevention",
			"content": "Gastroenteritis can be very contagious. These steps can help prevent the illness from spreading:\n\t\t•\tCarefully wash your hands every time you come in contact with someone with the illness.\n\t\t•\tDon't eat spoiled, raw, or undercooked foods.\n\t\t•\tIf you have gastroenteritis, stay away from others as much as possible until your symptoms go away.\n\t\t•\tWash your hands often, especially after using the bathroom.\n\t\t•\tKeep children home from school if they are ill with diarrhea, nausea, or vomiting.\n\t\t•\tWash your hands or use hand sanitizer after touching handrails and other surfaces in public places.\n\t\t•\tWhen traveling, drink bottled or filtered water and avoid ice and raw food."

Your immune system can be weakened by an infection, such as HIV, or by medications to treat cancer, for example.\n\nIf you’re generally in good health and you get a bout of diarrhea, you may wait a couple of days. Treat it as you would any illness that causes diarrhea.\n\nIf you feel very sick, which can happen in serious cases, then see your doctor sooner. Some of the symptoms to watch for include:\n\t\t•\tDiarrhea for more than 2 days\n\t\t•\tSigns of dehydration (dark pee, dry mouth and skin, dizziness)\n\t\t•\tSevere pain in your gut or rectum\n\t\t•\tFever of 102 F or more"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Tests and Diagnosis",
			"content": "Diarrhea and vomiting are common campylobacteriosis symptoms, but they can also be symptoms of many other illnesses. This is true for bloody stools, too.\n\nTo make an official diagnosis, your doctor may ask for a stool sample, which will be sent to a lab.\n\nSomeone at your doctor’s office will give you a special container in which to collect the sample. It can take several days to get the results.\n\nIn rare cases, a doctor may order a blood test, but these results take even longer -- up to 2 weeks."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Most people get over the infection without medicine or special treatments. You should drink lots of fluids while you have diarrhea.\n\nUnless your doctor tells you otherwise, don’t take anything to prevent vomiting and diarrhea. That’s your body’s way of getting rid of the infection.\n\nIf your immune system is weak, your doctor might prescribe medicine to fight the infection.\n\nDoctors will often first try levofloxacin (Levaquin). If you can’t take it for some other reasons, they may prescribe one of these common antibiotics that are used to treat several types of infections:\n\t\t•\tAzithromycin (Zithromax, Zmax)\n\t\t•\tCiprofloxacin (Cipro, Cetraxal, Ciloxan)"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Prevention",
			"content": "The most effective way to avoid campylobacteriosis is to cook poultry to at least 165 F. The meat should be white, not pink. You should never eat chicken that looks undercooked.\n\nHeating foods and pasteurizing dairy products are the only ways of knocking out the bacteria in foods that have been contaminated.\n\nHere are some other tips:\n\t\t•\tWash your hands before cooking and after touching raw poultry or meat.\n\t\t•\tKeep uncooked meat and poultry away from other foods, such as vegetables, by using separate cutting boards, utensils, and cooking surfaces.\n\t\t•\tWash your hands after touching a pet or pet feces.\n\t\t•\tMake sure your child or anyone with diarrhea washes his or her hands well."

			"content": "Amebiasis is an intestinal infection caused by a one-celled parasite called Entamaeba histolytica. It is most common in tropical countries that have poor sanitation. Most people have no symptoms, but nearly 10%-20% of people who get this infection have diarrhea, cramps, gas, fever, and fatigue. Most people in the U.S. get amebiasis from contaminated food or water when traveling. But it also can spread from person to person from improper hand washing or contact with the mouth or rectal area of someone who has the infection."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Most people with amebiasis don't have symptoms. Those who do have symptoms usually get them about two to four weeks after exposure to the parasite. In rare cases, the parasite can spread to the liver or other organs and cause more severe symptoms or even death. Amebiasis is treated with antibiotics and usually clears up in about two weeks."
		},

			"heading": "Risk Factors",

	"Antibiotic-associated_diarrhea": [{
			"heading": "Antibiotic-Associated Diarrhea",
			"content": "Acute diarrhea, AAD, Clostridium difficile, C. difficile"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tDiarrhea\n\t\t•\tBloody or red colored stools\n\t\t•\tNausea or vomiting\n\t\t•\tChange in stools\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tFever\n\t\t•\tChange in bowel habits"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Antibiotic-associated diarrhea (AAD) is frequent, watery bowel movements that happen after taking antibiotics. In addition to killing the bacteria that are causing an infection, antibiotics can also kill friendly bacteria in your digestive tract. Those friendly bacteria normally keep the harmful bacteria in your intestines in check, so there's a balance. Taking an antibiotic can upset that balance and let the harmful bacteria take over. This can cause mild or severe watery diarrhea, up to 15 or 20 times a day. You may also have other symptoms such as abdominal cramping. In some cases, all you need is to get extra fluids. The doctor may also stop your antibiotics. But if it is severe, you need urgent medical care. This may include intravenous (IV) fluids and a new antibiotic. Most severe cases are caused by a bacterium called Clostridium difficile."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "Seek emergency medical care if you have severe symptoms such as diarrhea more than 10 times a day; bowel movements that are bloody, black, or contain mucus; severe abdominal pain; nausea, fever, or severe dehydration."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Symptoms may begin 5 to 10 days after taking antibiotics. Less often, symptoms begin several weeks later. For mild diarrhea, drink extra fluids and call the doctor. You may need no further treatment or the doctor may stop your antibiotics. If diarrhea is severe, the doctor may prescribe a new antibiotic to treat the diarrhea. You may need intravenous (IV) antibiotics in the hospital. In rare cases, you may need surgery to remove an infected colon. If not treated, AAD can be fatal. Even with treatment, diarrhea may come back and need repeated treatment."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Lack of fluids, age, illness, poor immune system, use of opiates, use of diarrhea medications"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment may involve:\n\t\t•\tTaking extra fluids\n\t\t•\tStopping any antibiotics that are causing the diarrhea\n\t\t•\tTaking a new antibiotic to get rid of infection\n\t\t•\tTaking probiotic supplements, but only if prescribed by the doctor"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",

			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tDiarrhea\n\t\t•\tJoint aches\n\t\t•\tFever\n\t\t•\tNausea or vomiting\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tDry mouth\n\t\t•\tIncreased thirst\n\t\t•\tStomach cramps"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Salmonella are a type of bacteria -- usually spread through contaminated food -- that can infect the body and cause diarrhea, cramps, and fever. Salmonella bacteria are a common cause of food poisoning. High heat kills salmonella, but the bacteria may be in undercooked meat, eggs or poultry or unwashed fruit or vegetables. Pet birds and reptiles such as snakes and turtles can spread it, too. People who are infected may spread it to others directly or through food. Salmonella may cause small outbreaks within a family or larger ones in hospitals or restaurants. Usually, the infection is not serious and goes away on its own.  Untreated salmonella infection is rarely life threatening."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "People with salmonellosis -- infection with salmonella -- develop symptoms within three days. Usually, they last for five to seven days. A person may still spread the bacteria to others even after the symptoms are gone. Most people don't need treatment. If the diarrhea is severe, IV fluids can prevent dehydration. Some people -- such as infants, older people, and people with HIV or other conditions that weaken the immune system -- have a higher risk of complications. A small number of people infected with salmonella go on to develop Reiter's syndrome, which causes chronic joint pain, eye irritation, and pain during urination."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Being a child, being older; having a disease that weakens the immune system such as HIV; having birds or reptiles as pets; eating undercooked meat, poultry, or eggs; eating unwashed fruit or vegetables; drinking unpasteurized milk; not washing hands before eating or preparing food"
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Salmonella infects about 1.4 million people each year in the U.S."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Prevention",
			"content": "Salmonella bacteria live inside the intestinal tract of many animals. When feces from an infected animal -- or person -- contaminates food, the bacteria may spread. Always cook meats, eggs, and poultry thoroughly. Scrub fruits and vegetables before eating. Never eat raw eggs in foods such as cookie dough or salad dressing. Wash counters, tables, and utensils after preparing raw food that may carry salmonella. Anyone who keeps birds or reptiles as pets must wash hands immediately after touching them. People can still carry the bacteria even if they no longer have symptoms. Anyone who has been diagnosed with salmonella infection should not prepare food for others until doctors are sure the bacteria are gone."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Usually, people with salmonella infections don't need treatment. However, some need:\n\t\t•\tIV fluids\n\t\t•\tAntibiotics"

			"content": "Shigellosis is irritation of the stomach and intestines caused by Shigella bacteria. The main symptom is bloody diarrhea. Other symptoms include abdominal cramps and fever. In very severe cases, the person may have seizures, stiff neck, headache, and extreme fatigue. Shigella bacteria are found in the stool of an infected person. In the U.S., it's most common in kids under age 5. The illness spreads though direct contact -- such as failing to wash your hands after changing a diaper -- or by eating or drinking contaminated food or beverages. In the U.S., most outbreaks occur in schools, nursing homes, or daycare centers. Most people with mild symptoms get better in 5 to 7 days by drinking plenty of fluids and resting. Your doctor may prescribe antibiotics if you have more severe symptoms."

If nausea and vomiting make it hard to drink fluids, call the doctor. Antibiotics can shorten the illness in people with more severe symptoms. Get immediate medical help for severe symptoms such as confusion, tiredness, stiff neck, and headache. In rare cases, some people develop a type of reactive arthritis after the infection has passed. Some people have no symptoms at all, but can still spread the bacteria."

Although most people who have cholera have mild or no symptoms, about 5% of people have severe dehydration that can cause death very quickly. Cholera is spread in water or food that is contaminated with the bacterium Vibrio cholerae. It is rare in most industrialized countries, but it still occurs in parts of Africa, Asia, India, Mexico, and Central and South America. People can also get cholera from eating raw shellfish that are contaminated with the bacteria."

	"Kidney_stones": [{
			"heading": "Kidney Stones",
			"content": "Nephrolithiasis"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tCloudy urine with strong odor\n\t\t•\tFrequent urge to urinate\n\t\t•\tBlood or red colored urine\n\t\t•\tFever\n\t\t•\tNausea or vomiting"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "A kidney stone forms when excess waste in the urine crystallizes into a hard mass. If the stone lodges in a ureter, a tube from the kidneys to the bladder, it acts like a dam, holding back urine and causing the kidney to swell. This creates extreme pain. Some tiny stones pass easily if you drink a lot of fluid. But larger stones may need to be broken into pieces with shock wave lithotripsy so they can pass or be removed via cystoscopy. Fever or nausea with a kidney stone is an emergency."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "If you have severe pain, with a fever and chills or nausea and vomiting, see your doctor immediately or go to a hospital emergency room."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Often, a tiny kidney stone is flushed out of the body in urine and you feel no symptoms. But if it's too large to pass easily, you'll feel sudden, sharp cramping pain in the lower back and may have blood in the urine. Sometimes you can take care of kidney stones at home by drinking plenty of fluid and taking pain medication as needed. It may take hours or days for the stone to pass. But you should get medical help immediately if you have severe pain, or fever or chills, which could signal an infection. When you go to an emergency room, you may get intravenous fluids and medication for pain, nausea, and inflammation. If size or location makes it difficult for the stone to pass, you may get extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy to break it into smaller pieces, so it can move through the urinary tract easier. This is an outpatient procedure and recovery takes only a few days. Other procedures or surgery to remove stones can be used. Having one kidney stone increases your risk of having more stones or developing kidney disease. You may receive medication to prevent stones from forming again."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Dehydration can make kidney stones worse."
		},

			"heading": "Treatment",

		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "These home-care strategies may help when you have a kidney stone:\n\t\t•\tDrink 2 to 3 quarts of water a day.\n\t\t•\tTake ibuprofen for pain.\n\nThese lifestyle strategies may help prevent future kidney stones:\n\t\t•\tDrink 12 glasses or water daily (or more if you live in a hot climate).\n\t\t•\tReduce salty foods in your diet, including sandwich meats, canned soups, packaged meals, and some sports drinks.\n\t\t•\tTalk to your doctor or a registered dietitian about other diet changes, depending on the cause of your kidney stones."

	"Miscarriage": [{
			"heading": "Miscarriage",
			"content": "Spontaneous abortion"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tVaginal bleeding\n\t\t•\tMissed or late menstrual period"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "A miscarriage happens when a pregnancy is lost before the 20th week, usually within the first three months. If you're having a miscarriage, you're most likely to have light or heavy bleeding. You may need no treatment or your doctor may do a procedure to complete the miscarriage and prevent hemorrhaging and infection. You may never know what caused your miscarriage, but it often happens because the fetus isn't developing as it should. Your risk of miscarriage is higher if you are over 35 years old or have had two previous miscarriages. Miscarriage is fairly common, but it can be a very difficult emotional experience. Most women who have a miscarriage go on to have a healthy pregnancy."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "Go to a hospital emergency room immediately if you are pregnant or think you may be pregnant and have heavy vaginal bleeding (more than one pad every hour), are passing tissue, have a history of ectopic pregnancy, are dizzy or pass out, have a fever over 100.4 degrees Fahrenheit, or are vomiting. If you have passed tissue, put it in a container to take to the hospital."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "If you are pregnant and have any symptoms of a miscarriage such as bleeding that gets heavier, cramps, abdominal pain or low back ache, or a gush of fluid from your vagina, your obstetrician may tell you to come to the office or go to a hospital emergency room to check for miscarriage. If your pregnancy looks healthy, you may need bed rest for several days until the bleeding stops. If you've had a miscarriage but there is still some tissue in the uterus from the fetus or placenta, the doctor may remove it. Or the doctor may give you medication to help you pass the tissue at home. If the miscarriage is complete, you probably won't need treatment. You may have cramping or spotting for a few days after a miscarriage, but heavy bleeding, fever, or pain could signal an infection. Physical recovery could take a few days or weeks, depending on how long you were pregnant. It may take longer to recover emotionally."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Activity, aspirin use"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for a miscarriage may include:\n\t\t•\tD&C (dilation and curettage) procedure -- the uterus is dilated and remaining fetal or placental tissue is gently removed\n\t\t•\tOral medication to help pass the tissue"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "These self-care strategies may help after a miscarriage:\n\t\t•\tAvoid sex or putting anything into your vagina for two weeks to avoid infection.\n\t\t•\tCall your doctor if you have any signs of infection, such as severe bleeding, pain, or fever.\n\t\t•\tAvoid heavy work or strenuous exercise for a week.\n\t\t•\tMake sure you are emotionally ready before getting pregnant again. You can get pregnant within two weeks of a miscarriage.\n\t\t•\tDiscuss the timing of your next pregnancy with your obstetrician.\n\t\t•\tMany women find it difficult to cope with the loss of a pregnancy. If you feel that you need more emotional support, consider seeing a counselor."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",

			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Premature labor occurs when a women starts labor before 37 weeks of pregnancy. It can happen for reasons such as stress, infection, or multiple births. But premature labor also can happen for no apparent reason. Women who have premature labor may have contractions, cramping, bleeding or leaking fluid from the vagina, or back pain. Babies born earlier than 37 weeks have a higher risk of health problems, so doctors often use medications to try to stop labor. The earlier the baby is born, the more health risks he or she faces."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "Seek medical care right away if you have any symptoms of premature labor."
		},

But if you have steady contractions that last more than an hour, it might be premature labor. In some cases, doctors can use medications to try to stop the labor. But sometimes, it's not possible and the baby is born early."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",

	"Broken_(fractured)_upper_back_vertebra": [{
			"heading": "Broken (Fractured) Upper Back Vertebra",
			"content": "Vertebral fractures, thoracic fractures"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tBroken bone (single fracture)\n\t\t•\tSwelling\n\t\t•\tBruising or discoloration\n\t\t•\tTenderness to touch\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tStiffness or decreased movement\n\t\t•\tVisible deformity"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Upper back fractures, also called thoracic spine fractures, can occur from a high-impact injury or from weakened bones. Automobile accidents, falls, gunshot wounds, and sports accidents can all cause spinal fractures. These types of injuries often also damage the spinal cord. Certain conditions that weaken bones, including osteoporosis, long-term use of steroid medications, and tumors can cause compression fractures. These occur when the vertebra become so weak that they eventually collapse. Spinal fractures may cause moderate to severe back pain, numbness and tingling, and loss of bowel or bladder control. Osteoporosis can affect several vertebrae at a time, causing a curve in the back called a dowager's hump. Treatment may include rest, pain medication, braces or casts, medication to strengthen bones, physical therapy, and surgery."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "Get immediate medical help if you have back pain and high fever or loss of bladder or bowel control."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "If you have a spinal fracture from an auto accident or fall, you may have other injuries, as well. Your doctor will do a physical exam and treat the most severe injuries first. Spinal fractures caused by osteoporosis may have no symptoms at first and are sometimes discovered when X-rays are done for other reasons. Treatment depends on your symptoms and the type of spinal fracture you have. Rest at home, hospitalization, pain medications, braces or casts, medications to strengthen bones, physical therapy, and surgery all treat spinal fractures. Recovery can take months and even longer if you have surgery or have a spinal cord injury."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Movement, not getting treatment"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for a fractured spine may include:\n\t\t•\tRest\n\t\t•\tPain medication\n\t\t•\tMuscle relaxants\n\t\t•\tPhysical therapy\n\t\t•\tBracing and casts\n\t\t•\tCalcium supplements and medications to help build bone\n\t\t•\tSurgery to stabilize the fracture\n\t\t•\tKyphoplasty or vertebroplasty, where a type of cement is injected into a collapsed vertebra"
		},

	"Ankylosing_spondylitis": [{
			"heading": "Ankylosing Spondylitis",
			"content": "Rheumatoid spondylitis, spondylitis, spondyloarthropathy, seronegative bundle arthropathy"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tMorning joint stiffness\n\t\t•\tStiffness or decreased movement"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Ankylosing spondylitis is a long-lasting spinal condition in which the joints between the bones of the spine become inflamed. Over time, this causes the bones to fuse together, making your spine less flexible. Ankylosing spondylitis has no known cause but does run in families. It is much more common in men and usually starts between ages 20 and 40. People who have ankylosing spondylitis usually have pain and stiffness in the lower back that is worse at night and gets better with exercise. Complications can include eye inflammation, trouble breathing, heart problems, and spinal fractures. Treatment can relieve pain and stiffness and help prevent significant damage to your spine."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "The symptoms of ankylosing spondylitis usually develop slowly. You may first notice pain in your lower back, especially when you have been inactive or in the morning after you wake up. The pain may come and go and usually gets better with exercise or other activity. Over time, the pain may get worse, and you may find it harder to move your lower spine. In some cases, it can cause a curve in the spine, which can make it hard to breathe deeply. Ankylosing spondylitis is usually treated with medication, but some people need to have surgery."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 300,000 people in the U.S. have ankylosing spondylitis."

	"Spinal_tumor": [{
			"heading": "Spinal Tumor",
			"content": "Spinal cord tumor or malignancy, central nervous system tumor"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tStool leaking (incontinence)\n\t\t•\tNumbness or tingling\n\t\t•\tAbnormal gait (walking)\n\t\t•\tWeakness\n\t\t•\tUrine leaking (incontinence)\n\t\t•\tUnable to move leg"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Spinal tumors are cell growths surrounding the spinal cord. They can be benign (noncancerous) or malignant (cancerous) and can affect the spinal cord and vertebrae. Unlike tumors in other areas of the body, even benign tumors in the spinal area can be serious and life threatening. Spinal tumors can cause back pain, weakness and numbness in the legs and arms, and more serious issues such as paralysis and changes in bladder and bowel control. Treatment depends on the type of tumor. If cancerous, treatment depends on where the cancer started, and how far along it is. Recent research in treating cancer has resulted in more treatment options than ever before."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "How quickly symptoms develop and progress depends on the type of tumor and its location in relation to the spinal cord. Cancerous, or malignant tumors, tend to grow more quickly than benign tumors. While treatment can provide relief of symptoms, damage to the nerves may be permanent, causing permanent disability. Loss of bladder and bowel control is common with advanced tumors. Paralysis is a late sign and is usually permanent if the spinal cord has been damaged. Treatment depends on the type of tumor and where it's located. The goal is to completely remove the tumor, but that's not always possible. Even if the tumor can't be removed, there are a number of options that may minimize the damage it does. After treatment stops, tumors can return. Therefore, long-term follow-up care is important."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "The chance of developing a malignant spinal or brain tumor in a person's lifetime is less than 1%."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "A history of cancer elsewhere in the body, such as breast or lung cancer, family history of brain or spinal cord tumor, exposure to radiation, certain immune system disorders"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment will depend on the kind of tumor and where it's located. Treatment options include:\n\t\t•\tSurgery\n\t\t•\tRadiation therapy\n\t\t•\tChemotherapy\n\t\t•\tTargeted therapy\n\t\t•\tDrugs to relieve inflammation and take pressure off of the nerves"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",

Get immediate care of you have progressive muscle weakness, numbness, or significant changes in bowel or bladder function."

	"Lumbar_(low_back)_strain": [{
			"heading": "Lumbar Strain and Lumbar Sprain",
			"content": "Low back strain, low back sprain, weightlifter's back, Lumbago"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tMuscle cramps or spasms (painful)\n\t\t•\tStiffness or decreased movement\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tTenderness to touch"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Lumbar strains and sprains are the most common causes of lower back pain. People may get them from picking up something heavy, industrial work, or sports that require lifting, pushing, or twisting. Lumbar strains develop when the muscles stretch too far or tear. Lumbar sprains are rips in the ligaments, the tough bands of tissue that connect the bones. Practically, the distinction between strains and sprains doesn't matter very much. The treatment including medications that help with pain while the muscles or ligaments heal is the same for either condition. Most people recover within a few weeks."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "You may get a lumbar strain or sprain from a sudden injury or from chronic overuse. The pain can be severe and debilitating. After the injury, resting for up to three days may help. After that, you need to move around or the pain and stiffness may get worse. Treatment with painkillers, ice, and stretching helps with the symptoms while your body heals. If you haven't recovered within two weeks, your doctor may do tests to make sure that you don't have another injury. Untreated strains and sprains can develop into chronic pain."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Nearly 60% to 80% of people will have lower back pain at some point. Lumbar strains and sprains are the most common cause."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for lumbar strains and sprains includes:\n\t\t•\tBed rest for a short time, no more than 3 days\n\t\t•\tNSAIDs, such as ibuprofen, ketoprofen, and naproxen, for pain and swelling\n\t\t•\tIce packs\n\t\t•\tUltrasound\n\t\t•\tPhysical therapy, heat, and stretching exercises once you're feeling better\n\t\t•\tOther medications, such as muscle relaxants"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Even if your back still hurts, don't rest in bed for more than a few days. Use NSAID painkillers such as ibuprofen, ketoprofen, and naproxen and ice packs to relieve pain. If you don't feel better within two weeks, see a doctor. Once you're better, prevent further injuries by using a back brace, exercising regularly, keeping a healthy weight, squatting instead of bending over when lifting heavy objects, and reducing stress with techniques such as breathing exercises and meditation."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Not allowing your back to heal, stress, and smoking may make lumbar strain worse."

Cauda equina syndrome is a rare, painful medical emergency that occurs when an injury, fractured or narrowed spine, herniated disc, tumor, or infection compress the nerves. Trapped nerves cause severe, gnawing pain, numbness, and tingling in the lower back, buttocks, and thighs. Surgery to relieve the pressure can help prevent bowel and bladder incontinence, paralysis, and permanent nerve damage."

Some people with severe lumbar spinal stenosis have trouble walking more than a block or two. Spinal stenosis is usually treated with medication, corticosteroid injections, and physical therapy. 	"Ovarian_cysts": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tIrregular menstrual periods\n\t\t•\tBloating or fullness\n\t\t•\tVaginal bleeding between periods"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Ovarian cysts are small liquid-filled pockets that form in or on the ovaries. Follicular cysts are the most common type. In the ovary, eggs form and grow in a sac called a follicle. When a follicle doesn't open to release the egg it grows larger and becomes a cyst. Another type of cyst forms when a follicle closes off after releasing the egg. Both of these cysts usually go away on their own without symptoms. Other ovarian cysts form from different types of tissue. Ovarian cysts are very common and usually occur during a woman's childbearing years. The majority is not cancerous. While most ovarian cysts have no symptoms, some can grow large and cause pain and cramping."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Most ovarian cysts have no symptoms and go away on their own. They may be detected during a pelvic exam and usually need no treatment. If they become large, break open, or twist around they can cause sudden, sharp pelvic pain, pain with bowel movements, pain with intercourse or exercise, nausea, and vomiting. Surgery can remove large or painful cysts."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "All women have follicular cysts at some point in their life."

			"content": "\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tFever\n\t\t•\tFrequent urge to urinate\n\t\t•\tPain with sexual intercourse (female)\n\t\t•\tVaginal discharge\n\t\t•\tFrequent urination\n\t\t•\tIrregular menstrual periods"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Pelvic inflammatory disease is an infection in a woman's uterus, ovaries, or fallopian tubes. PID most often is caused by a sexually transmitted disease such as gonorrhea or Chlamydia, but it can have other causes. It can cause abnormal discharge, abdominal pain, pain with sex, nausea, pain with urination, abnormal periods, and fever. PID can be treated with antibiotics. But if it isn't treated promptly, it can cause serious problems, including not being able to get pregnant, chronic pelvic pain, and ectopic pregnancy."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "PID can be difficult to diagnose because early symptoms may be mild. But if not treated promptly, it can cause serious infection and scarring inside the uterus, fallopian tubes, or ovaries. This can lead to long-term problems, including infertility and chronic pelvic pain. Once diagnosed, PID is treated with antibiotics. Your sex partner also needs to be treated. In severe cases, you may need to be treated in the hospital."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Between 750,000 and 1 million women in the U.S. get pelvic inflammatory disease every year."

	"Dysfunctional_uterine_bleeding": [{
			"heading": "Dysfunctional Uterine Bleeding",
			"content": "Also known as: DUB, uterine hemorrhage"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tBleeding\n\t\t•\tHeavy menstrual bleeding\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tMuscle cramps or spasms (painful)"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Dysfunctional Uterine Bleeding (DUB) is vaginal bleeding that is not part of a normal period and not caused by trauma or disease. It's caused by an imbalance of the female hormones estrogen and progesterone. The most common reason for this is a menstrual cycle in which no egg is released. When there's no egg, the body doesn't produce progesterone. Without it, estrogen causes the lining of the womb to enlarge and thicken. When the lining is shed, which can happen any time during the cycle, the bleeding is often heavy and may include clots. DUB is most common in teens and women nearing menopause. Other causes of bleeding can include pregnancy, cancer, fibroids, trauma, certain drugs, and inherited bleeding disorders."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "The time between your menstrual periods may change each month. You may also notice spotting and blood in the urine between periods. Bleeding either between periods or during your period may be exceptionally heavy. You may go through pads or tampons at the rate of one per hour. Menstrual bleeding may also last more than seven days. If the bleeding is caused by an imbalance in hormones, the cycle usually returns to normal within a few months of starting treatment with birth control pills."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About one out of every 10 women will experience excessive vaginal bleeding at some point in her life."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment of DUB usually involves hormonal therapy, for instance with birth control pills, to restore proper balance and regulate the menstrual cycle, if no other cause of bleeding is found. Treatment for abnormal bleeding that's not caused by hormonal issues will depend on the underlying cause."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Any unusual vaginal bleeding should be evaluated by a doctor. In addition:\n\t\t•\tBed rest can improve symptoms.\n\t\t•\tDo not take aspirin or other nonsteroidal pain pills. Doing so can increase the bleeding.\n\t\t•\tKeep track of the number of tampons and pads used to help the doctor know how much bleeding there is."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Aspirin and other nonsteroidal pain relievers that may promote more bleeding, blood thinners, activity such as walking and running"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "Call your doctor for an appointment for any unusual vaginal bleeding. If you can't see your own doctor right away, go to an emergency room if you have unusual vaginal bleeding and other symptoms such as lightheadedness, severe pain, or fever."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\t\t•\tWhat might be causing this bleeding?\n\t\t•\tIs there some way I can stop the bleeding?\n\t\t•\tWhat other symptoms should I look out for?\n\t\t•\tAre there any treatments that can help prevent this from happening again?"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "The doctor will take a medical history and perform a physical, including a thorough pelvic exam. Tests to identify or rule out possible causes of the bleeding may include: a Pap smear, pregnancy test, blood test (to check for anemia), endometrial biopsy, ultrasound, hysteroscopy (visual exam of the womb using a scope), and possibly a dilatation and curettage (D and C)."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Being a teenager who has recently started having periods, being near menopause, a history of hormonal fluctuations"
		}
	],
	"Dysmenorrhea_(menstrual_cramps)_(female)": [{
			"heading": "Dysmenorrhea",
			"content": "Painful menstruation, menstrual cramps"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tBloating or fullness\n\t\t•\tHeavy menstrual bleeding\n\t\t•\tVaginal bleeding\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tMuscle cramps or spasms (painful)\n\t\t•\tStomach cramps"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Dysmenorrhea means unusually painful or long-lasting menstrual cramping, bleeding, and pain. Most women experience some cramping and pain during their period. But some women experience severe pain, cramping, diarrhea, nausea, headache, or dizziness during their period. These symptoms make it hard to work or go to school. There are two types of dysmenorrhea: primary and secondary. Primary occurs naturally -- some women just have more painful periods than others. High levels of the hormone prostaglandin are thought to cause painful periods. Secondary dysmenorrhea occurs because of another medical problem such as endometriosis or fibroid tumors. Taking pain relievers and using a heating pad will treat most cases of primary dysmenorrhea. For painful periods due to medical problems, treating the medical problem can relieve symptoms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Painful periods usually start soon after a young woman starts menstruating. Pain and other symptoms start at the beginning of the period or just before and get better in one or two days. Symptoms may vary from one month to the next. Some women have less pain as they get older, but many don't. Most women treat painful periods with pain relievers and heating pads. Prescription pain relievers, birth control pills, or using an IUD that contains hormones also can relieve pain and cramping. Unusual pain and heavy bleeding that lasts longer than usual may be signs of another medical problem, so it's best to see a doctor to find the cause."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 50% of women have naturally occurring painful periods."

		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Uterine fibroids are common noncancerous growths in the uterus. They usually grow slowly but may grow to weigh several pounds. Uterine fibroids need the female hormone estrogen to grow, so they are most common in women during their childbearing years. Small fibroids often have no symptoms. Larger fibroids can cause a feeling of fullness in the abdomen, cramping, heavy periods, longer periods, increased urination, and pain with sex."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Most fibroids cause no problems, and almost never turn into cancer. But as they grow, fibroids can disrupt the normal shedding of the uterine lining during menstrual periods. Some fibroids cause heavy bleeding, which causes anemia. Large or multiple fibroids that cause problems are treated with hormones, intrauterine devices, or, in some cases, removed surgically. Fibroids are a major cause of hysterectomy in the U.S."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Approximately one in five women of childbearing age in the U.S. have uterine fibroids."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",

			"heading": "Urethritis",
			"content": "Urethral syndrome, ngu, non-gonococcal urethritis, urethral inflammation"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tCloudy urine with strong odor\n\t\t•\tFrequent urination\n\t\t•\tPain with sexual intercourse (female)\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tPain with urination"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Urethritis is an inflammation of the tube that carries urine out of the body. It affects both men and women and can be passed from partner to partner during sex. Typically, it comes from a bacterial or viral infection. The most common bacteria are those that cause STDs such as chlamydia or gonorrhea. Irritation can also cause urethritis, such as irritation from using a catheter or contraceptive foams. Urethritis can be passed from one person to another even when no symptoms are present. Untreated, urethritis can cause permanent damage to the urethra and other organs. In women, it can cause sterility if the infection reaches the fallopian tubes."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Once the cause is found, urethritis usually responds quickly to treatment. If it's caused by irritation, it will generally clear up on its own without treatment once the irritation is stopped. For urethritis caused by infection, the doctor may start you on a general antibiotic until the agent that's causing the infection is known. Then the doctor may change the antibiotic to one that more effectively targets the specific germ. If the urethritis has been caused by an infection, your partner will need to be treated. You'll also be told not to have sex until the infection is cleared up. Urethritis that lasts six weeks after treatment starts is called chronic. Chronic urethritis is harder to treat, and the doctor will likely take a more aggressive approach to the use of antibiotics."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "There are 4 million cases of urethritis every year in the U.S."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment depends on what's causing the urethritis. If it's being caused by irritation, simply removing the irritant may clear it up. For urethritis caused by infection, the doctor will prescribe antibiotics based on what kind of infection it is. The doctor may also prescribe pain medication."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Urethritis should be evaluated by a doctor. It's important to avoid sex while being treated for urethritis that's caused by an infection. Also, practicing safe sex once the infection has cleared up will help prevent it from coming back."
		},

High doses of some vitamins -- such as vitamin A -- can cause more severe symptoms, including headaches, organ damage, hair loss, dry skin, and other problems. It's important to tell your doctor about all the vitamins you take, and the doses. Some vitamins may interact with medications. Together, you and your doctor can come up with a vitamin regimen that is right and safe for you."

This is because urine usually becomes more concentrated and decreases at night. But if you drink fluids before bed -- especially alcohol or caffeinated drinks -- you may wake up several times a night to urinate. Needing to urinate at least twice during the night is called nocturia."

			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "An overactive bladder can cause you to feel a sudden, strong need to urinate. It can happen when nerve damage causes your bladder to contract when it shouldn't. Childbirth, infections, diabetes, prostate problems, and stroke are some causes of overactive bladder. It is more common in older adults, but it can happen at any age. An overactive bladder can cause frequent urination, a sudden need to urinate, and an accidental loss of urine. Left untreated, overactive bladder can cause people to limit their activities because of embarrassment."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Many people don't seek help for an overactive bladder because they think it's a normal part of aging. But there are many treatments for overactive bladder. Treatments include medication, bladder retraining, electrical stimulation, and surgery. Your treatment will depend on the type of nerve damage you have and the symptoms you're having."

			"content": "\t\t•\tFrequent urge to urinate\n\t\t•\tBlood or red colored urine\n\t\t•\tPain with urination\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tFrequent urination"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Bladder cancer is the fourth most common cancer in men and fifth most common cancer overall in the U.S. It occurs mainly in people ages 50 and older. Cigarette smoking, exposure to toxins at work, certain types of radiation therapy and chemotherapy, chronic bladder infections, long-term catheter usage, and parasites increase the risk for bladder cancer. Early stages of bladder cancer often have no symptoms. Symptoms of bladder cancer can include blood in the urine, pain with urinating, frequent urination, and a strong urge to urinate. Surgery and other methods successfully treat early bladder cancer; however, it tends to come back even after treatment."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Bladder cancer often causes few if any symptoms, so you can have it and not know it. Blood in the urine is the most common symptom. Bladder cancer symptoms are similar to other conditions such as urinary tract infection, so it's important to get checked. If cancer is found, your age and overall health as well as the cancer stage and whether it has spread determine the type of treatment. Treatment may include a combination of surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, and biological therapy. The five-year survival rate for bladder cancer caught early is 88% to 98%."

	"Excessive_fluid_intake": [{
			"heading": "Excessive Fluid Intake",
			"content": "In severe cases: Water intoxication, Hyponatremia"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tFrequent urge to urinate\n\t\t•\tFrequent urination"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Drinking a lot of water or fluids usually makes you urinate often. But when you drink too much fluid, you can dilute the sodium in your blood to dangerously low levels. This life-threatening condition is called hyponatremia or water intoxication. The body needs sodium to regulate blood pressure, maintain fluid balance, and help nerves and muscles function normally. Too little sodium in the body allows the excess water to move inside cells, making them swell. While most cells in the body have room to expand, swollen brain cells press against the skull, causing headache, confusion, fatigue, convulsions, and hallucinations. Fluids and electrolytes given through an IV help rebalance sodium levels. Marathon runners and other endurance athletes are at risk for hyponatremia. But many people drink more liquid than their body really needs. In general, doctors recommend that healthy adults in temperate climates drink 8 to 9 cups of water a day."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "Call emergency services or get emergency care if you have convulsions, feel confused, have hallucinations or other symptoms of hyponatremia."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Mild symptoms of excess fluid intake include headache, irritability, loss of appetite, and muscles cramps. Mild cases can be treated with adjustments in diet, lifestyle, and medications. Severe symptoms can come on quickly and lead to convulsions, coma, and death. People with severe hyponatremia need emergency treatment with IV fluids and electrolytes."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Continuing to drink fluids excessively"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for hyponatremia may include:\n\t\t•\tDietary changes\n\t\t•\tAdjusting medications\n\t\t•\tIntravenous fluids and electrolytes\n\t\t•\tTreatment for any underlying medical condition"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Prevention is the best self-care. Drink sports drinks along with water when exercising, and only drink until you feel quenched."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "Call your doctor if you feel like you urinate too often. That can be a symptom of many other problems, including diabetes or infection. Get immediate medical care if you have symptoms of hyponatremia."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\t\t•\tCould excess fluid intake be causing my symptoms?\n\t\t•\tDo I need any ongoing treatment to prevent symptoms?\n\t\t•\tWhat can I do to prevent this from happening again?"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "Your doctor will perform urine and blood tests, including a blood test measuring the sodium level in your body."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Almost one-sixth of marathon runners develop some level of hyponatremia from drinking too much fluid."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Drinking too much fluid, being an endurance athlete, taking diuretics, vomiting, having diarrhea, sweating a lot, medical conditions including heart failure and kidney disease"

	"Gonorrhea_(female)": [{
			"heading": "Gonorrhea (Female)",
			"content": "Gonoccocal urethritis, the Clap"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tFrequent urge to urinate\n\t\t•\tVaginal discharge\n\t\t•\tPain with urination\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tFrequent urination"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Gonorrhea is a sexually transmitted disease (STD) caused by gonorrhea bacteria. The disease spreads through vaginal, anal, and sometimes oral sex. Many women have gonorrhea and have no symptoms. Symptoms may be mild and include painful urination, vaginal discharge, or bleeding between periods. If not treated, gonorrhea can cause pelvic inflammatory disease and infertility. Serious complications may occur, including arthritis, skin sores, and inflammation of the brain or liver. Pregnant women with gonorrhea can pass it to their baby during birth, causing eye, joint, and blood infections. About 60% of people with gonorrhea also have chlamydia, another STD. Antibiotics treat and cure gonorrhea."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Gonorrhea often has no symptoms, which means you can have the infection and not know it. When symptoms occur, they usually come on one to 14 days after being infected. The infection usually causes vaginal discharge and painful urination. If the infection travels to the fallopian tubes and ovaries, it can cause low back pain, abdominal pain, fever, nausea, and vomiting. Even without symptoms, gonorrhea can spread and cause more serious complications such as infertility and arthritis. Treatment with antibiotics cures gonorrhea. All of the infected person's sexual partners need treatment to prevent passing it back and forth."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Being sexually active with more than one person, having a sexual partner who has other sexual partners, not using condoms, having sex with someone who has gonorrhea"
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Every year, about 700,000 people in the U.S. get gonorrhea."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Prevention",
			"content": "Having a long-term monogamous relationship with one partner or not having sex are the surest ways to prevent this STD. Using a latex condom every time you have any type of sexual contact can help prevent gonorrhea from spreading."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Antibiotics will treat gonorrhea infections. It's important to take all of the medication as directed, or the infection may return. Do not have sex while taking antibiotics, because you can still spread the disease. Be sure all sexual partners are also treated."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "Call your doctor if you have any symptoms of an STD, such as vaginal discharge or painful urination. Get immediate medical help if you have fever and abdominal pain along with vaginal discharge."

	"Crabs": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tItching or burning\n\t\t•\tVisible bugs or parasites\n\t\t•\tSkin rash"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Crabs, or pubic lice, are tiny, six-legged insects that infest pubic skin and hair and cause intense itching. They may also attach themselves to underarm hair, eye lashes, and eyebrows. Pubic lice are different from head or body lice. Crabs are a type of sexually transmitted disease (STD). Sexual contact, although not necessarily intercourse, spreads lice from one person to another. Pubic lice on a child's eyelashes or eyebrows may be a sign of sexual abuse. Getting crabs from toilet seats or clothing is very unlikely. Crabs cause intense itching and skin irritation. Prescription and over-the-counter (OTC) ointments or shampoos treat pubic lice."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Symptoms may start right away or may not start for two to four weeks after infection. Itching may be worse at night. Scratching the skin may cause sores that can become infected. An OTC or prescription ointment or shampoo and combing hair to remove nits will treat pubic lice."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",

		},

			"content": "Not having sexual contact with people who have crabs will prevent the condition from spreading. Dry cleaning items can also kill crabs.\n\t\t•\tGet tested for other STDs."

			"heading": "Chronic Pelvic Pain",
			"content": "Pelvic pain syndrome"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tPressure or fullness"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Chronic pelvic pain causes ongoing pain in the lower abdomen that lasts for at least six months. A number of conditions such as endometriosis, pelvic inflammatory disease, irritable bowel syndrome, and fibroids can trigger it. In many cases, doctors can't figure out the exact cause. The pain ranges from mild to severe. For some women, it's bad enough to interfere with sleep, work, and sex. Treating the pain and -- when possible -- controlling the underlying cause will help."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Chronic pelvic pain can be deeply frustrating. Getting a diagnosis may take a long time. You may not feel pain every day. It may come and go. For some women, it follows the menstrual cycle. The severity may vary, too. If your doctor can figure out a specific cause, controlling the underlying condition will help. If not, treatment will focus on relieving your pain. Doctors aren't sure why, but many women with chronic pelvic pain have a history of sexual abuse. Seeing a therapist may help. Often, a combination of approaches works best."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 15%-20% of women aged 18-50 have chronic pelvic pain."
		},

		},

			"heading": "Self Care",

		},

	"Endometrial_cancer": [{
			"heading": "Endometrial Cancer",
			"content": "Uterine cancer, cancer of the uterus"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tHeavy menstrual bleeding\n\t\t•\tVaginal discharge\n\t\t•\tVaginal bleeding between periods"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Endometrial cancer occurs in the lining of the uterus (womb), called the endometrium. Endometrial cancer, the most common uterine cancer, tends to occur in women aged 60-70.There are no screening tests for endometrial cancer. However, sometimes Pap test results show abnormal cells from the endometrium, which may indicate cancer. Regardless, the Pap test does not effectively detect endometrial cancer. Common symptoms include unusual vaginal bleeding and discharge, pelvic pain, and pain when urinating and during sex. Endometrial cancer is usually found at an early stage and treatment with surgery and radiation therapy cures most cases."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Ninety percent of women with endometrial cancer have long periods of heavy bleeding or abnormal vaginal bleeding, either between periods or after menopause. At first the flow may look watery with streaks of blood, then it becomes bloodier. A lump or mass in the uterus, pelvic pain, or weight loss occurs in later stages of the disease. While other conditions cause similar symptoms, you should see your doctor for any unusual bleeding or pelvic discomfort. Catching endometrial cancer early makes it easier to treat."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 43,500 women in the U.S. develop endometrial cancer each year."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "You may have higher risk if you are obese, have never been pregnant, have taken estrogen without progesterone, have a family history of endometrial cancer, or have taken tamoxifen, a medication used to treat breast cancer. Women who started puberty early or went through menopause late are also at higher risk."

	"Genital_herpes_(female)": [{
			"heading": "Genital Herpes (Female)",
			"content": "Herpes simplex virus type 2, HSV2, herpes genitalis"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tBody aches or pains\n\t\t•\tFatigue\n\t\t•\tSkin blisters\n\t\t•\tSkin irritation\n\t\t•\tTender glands\n\t\t•\tJoint aches\n\t\t•\tEnlarged or swollen glands\n\t\t•\tFever\n\t\t•\tSkin bumps\n\t\t•\tSkin open sore"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Genital herpes is a sexually transmitted disease (STD) caused by the herpes simplex virus. In women, genital herpes causes small blisters to form on and around the vagina and anus, as well as tingling and pain. Sores can also appear inside the vagina. These sores break open and form scabs, healing in about one to two weeks. There are two types of herpes virus, HSV1 and HSV2. HSV2 causes most cases of genital herpes. HSV1 causes herpes on the mouth and lips. However, HSV1 can be spread to the genitals through oral sex. Herpes is more likely to spread when sores are present, but it can be passed on even without symptoms. Mothers with an active infection can pass herpes to their baby during childbirth. People with a weak immune system, such as those with HIV, may have herpes on other parts of the body, including the eyes, spinal cord, lungs, or esophagus. In between outbreaks, there are no symptoms, however the virus remains\"hidden\" in the nerve cells and may reappear at any time. There is no cure for the herpes virus. However, antiviral medication can help prevent outbreaks and shorten them when they occur. Over time, outbreaks become less severe and tend to occur less often."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Many people have no symptoms or only mild symptoms and may not know they have herpes. When symptoms do occur, they usually appear about two weeks after exposure to the virus. The first outbreak can be more severe and last longer than later occurrences. Signs that an outbreak is going to occur include tingling, pain, or sensitivity in the area. Blisters develop soon after. Fever, muscle aches, and headache are more common symptoms during the first outbreak. Sores heal in about one to two weeks. Most people have four to five episodes the first year they have symptoms, then outbreaks taper off over time. Antiviral medication can help prevent and shorten herpes outbreaks."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Having sex with someone with herpes, having oral sex with someone with herpes on their lips, having multiple sex partners"
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About one out of six people ages 14 to 49 has genital herpes."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Prevention",
			"content": "Having a committed, monogamous relationship with a herpes–free partner can protect you from herpes. Here are other ways to prevent herpes from spreading:\n\t\t•\tDo not have sex with anyone with herpes sores on their mouth or genitals.\n\t\t•\tDo not have sex if you have herpes sores on your mouth or genitals. If you have herpes, even if you don't have sores, tell any potential sexual partners about it before you have sex.\n\t\t•\tUse a latex condom every time you have sex.\n\t\t•\tPeople with frequent outbreaks can use antiviral drugs to help limit occurrences and lower the chance of passing on herpes."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Genital herpes treatment includes:\n\t\t•\tAntiviral medications\n\t\t•\tAntibiotics if needed for bacterial infections of the sores"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Self-care for genital herpes includes:\n\t\t•\tWear loose-fitting, cotton underwear and pants; avoid nylon.\n\t\t•\tClean the area with gentle soap; don't use scented soaps.\n\t\t•\tAvoid heat and sunlight, which can irritate the sores.\n\t\t•\tTake pain relievers if needed.\n\t\t•\tDo not use douches, feminine deodorants, or antibacterial soap.\n\t\t•\tApply a cool, damp cloth to soothe the area or try a hot bath.\n\nSome studies have shown that taking lysine supplements or using lysine ointment on the skin may help prevent and treat herpes."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "Call your doctor if you have symptoms of herpes, especially if you are pregnant or have HIV. Get immediate medical help if you have a high fever, shortness of breath, fatigue, or if you can't urinate. If you are having a first outbreak of herpes, but can't get in to see your doctor within a few days, go to the emergency room."

	"Polycystic_ovary_syndrome_(PCOS)": [{
			"heading": "Polycystic Ovaries",
			"content": "Multiple ovarian cysts, PCOS, stein-leventhal syndrome"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tExcessive body hair growth\n\t\t•\tIrregular menstrual periods\n\t\t•\tExcessive facial hair growth (female)"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) is the most common cause of female infertility. In most, but not all, women with the condition, the ovaries have many small cysts. Women with PCOS may not ovulate regularly or at all, and have trouble getting pregnant. Other symptoms may include irregular periods, increased body and facial hair, acne, and obesity. Doctors don't know exactly what causes PCOS, but it happens when hormones get out of balance. With PCOS, a woman's body makes more androgens, the male sex hormones. Other hormones, including estrogen, progesterone, and insulin, are also out of balance. Over time, especially if not managed, PCOS increases the risk of such problems as repeated miscarriages, diabetes, heart disease, and cancer."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Symptoms of PCOS develop slowly over the years and are different from woman to woman. Some have many symptoms. Some only have a few. The most common reasons women with PCOS first see a doctor include menstrual problems, male pattern hair growth, infertility, and weight gain. There is no cure for PCOS, but the symptoms can be managed. Once it's diagnosed, regular checkups and screenings as well as developing healthy lifestyle habits can help protect against serious long-term effects such as heart disease and diabetes."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "1 in every 10 - 20 women of childbearing age has PCOS."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "There is no cure for PCOS, but treatment can control the symptoms and help prevent problems such as diabetes, heart disease, and cancer. Treatment may include:\n\t\t•\tLifestyle changes, including exercise, healthy diet, and not smoking\n\t\t•\tBirth control pills to control menstrual cycles, reduce male hormone levels, and treat other symptoms such as acne\n\t\t•\tMetformin (Glucophage) to help control blood sugar levels, reduce testosterone levels, and treat other symptoms\n\t\t•\tFertility medications to stimulate ovulation\n\t\t•\tAnti-androgen medications to reduce excess hair growth and acne"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Keys to managing PCOS and avoiding long-term complications include:\n\t\t•\tRegular exercise\n\t\t•\tA healthy diet\n\t\t•\tLosing weight to help keep hormones balanced and regulate the menstrual cycle\n\t\t•\tNot smoking\n\nOver-the-counter acne medicines can help with skin problems. Unwanted hair can be removed with tweezing, waxing, shaving, electrolysis, or laser hair removal. Taking part in a support group can help with feelings of sadness and depression."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Being overweight"
		},
		{

	"Urinary_incontinence_(stress)_female": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
