		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Urinary incontinence is the accidental loss of urine. With stress incontinence, the loss of urine happens when pressure is put on your bladder. It may happen if you cough, laugh, sneeze, exercise, stand, or have sex. It is caused when the muscles around your bladder become weak because of injury, childbirth, medications, or surgery. Stress incontinence is most common in women. Lifestyle changes, Kegel exercises, and some devices can help. In some cases, surgery can be effective."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Most women with stress incontinence only have a small amount of urine leakage with physical activity. It might not happen every time you are active. In some cases, it can get worse right before your period. You may also notice it's worse if your bladder is full. Stress incontinence is treated with behavioral changes, pelvic floor exercises, medications, and surgery."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Pyridium is a medication used to treat urinary pain, burning, urgency, frequency, and discomfort caused by urinary tract infections (UTIs) or irritation. The medication eases UTI symptoms, but it does not kill bacteria and will not cure the infection. Pyridium causes the urine to turn bright orange-red or brown, a harmless side effect. Other side effects may include headache, upset stomach, and dizziness. You should get emergency help if you are taking Pyridium and have yellow skin or eyes, rash, fever, confusion, bluish-purple skin, shortness of breath, sudden decrease in the amount of urine, or swelling in the face, hands, legs, and feet."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Pyridium is taken as a pill usually three times a day after meals. The medication begins to ease urinary pain and burning soon after taking it. It turns urine bright red-orange or brown and can stain clothing and cause discoloration of contact lenses while you are taking it. Potential side effects such as dizziness, headache, or upset stomach may go away as your body gets used to the medication."

	"Paroxysmal_nocturnal_hemoglobinuria_(PNH)": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tBlood or red colored urine\n\t\t•\tSwelling\n\t\t•\tDifficulty moving joint\n\t\t•\tFatigue\n\t\t•\tIrregular heartbeat\n\t\t•\tSkin redness\n\t\t•\tColored sputum\n\t\t•\tWeakness (generalized)\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tBruising or discoloration\n\t\t•\tEasy bruising\n\t\t•\tHeadache\n\t\t•\tPale skin\n\t\t•\tExcessive sweating\n\t\t•\tDark colored (brown) urine\n\t\t•\tDifficulty breathing"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "If you have PNH, your red blood cells are missing a protein that protects them. Without the protein, blood cells break down too soon. This can cause a range of symptoms. You may feel tired or weak, or you may have more serious problems like blood clots or bone marrow failure. Treatment depends on your symptoms. A change in a gene in your bone marrow causes PNH, but it isn't passed on in families. Anyone can get PNH, but you're more likely to get PNH if you have aplastic anemia (when your body doesn’t make enough red blood cells)."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Stresses on your body, such as infections or hard exercise, can trigger blood in the urine, especially at night or in the morning. This happens when the red blood cells break down and leak into your urine. If you have a low level of PNH cells, your symptoms may be mild. They can get worse, though. About 1 in 3 people get blood clots. If you have one, get help right away. PNH makes you 20% to 30% more likely to get aplastic anemia. Anemia can raise your chances of bone marrow failure -- when your bone marrow does not make healthy blood cells anymore. About 5% or less of people with PNH get leukemia."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "PNH is rare. About 1 to 2 people in 1 million get it."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Having aplastic anemia"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "If you have a few mild symptoms, you may only need folic acid and iron supplements. If you have anemia, you may need a blood transfusion. Your doctor will prescribe a blood thinner to prevent clots. Soliris (eculizumab) can improve many symptoms of PNH. If you don't have enough healthy white or red blood cells, your doctor may suggest taking a blood cell growth drug to help your bones make more. If you have bone marrow failure, your doctor may also suggest other drugs to treat it. A bone marrow transplant may also help."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "You can live an active life with PNH. To ease tiredness, pace yourself, get help with housework and other chores, and plan activities for your high-energy times of day. Get plenty of sleep. Aim to walk 30 minutes a day. Break it into 10-minute segments, if you need to. Eat healthy and protect against germs to avoid infections. Coping with PNH can be stressful at times. Talk to your family, friends, a support group, or therapist."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Infections, alcohol, hard exercise, airplane travel and high altitudes, pregnancy, surgery"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "It can take a long time to diagnose PNH, sometimes months or years. See your doctor if any of your symptoms gets worse."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "Your doctor will be able to diagnose PNH with blood tests. They measure some proteins in your blood and how many red and white blood cells you have."
		},

Hemolytic uremic syndrome is most common in children. It usually occurs after an E. coli infection, but can also happen after other types of infections. Adults can also get it, but it is much less common. Hemolytic uremic syndrome can cause vomiting, bloody diarrhea, irritability, weakness, fever, little or no urination, and easy bruising. In severe cases, it can cause death."

Treatment for HUS may include IV fluids, blood transfusions, dialysis, and steroid medications. Adults with HUS may also need plasma exchange."

			"content": "Gonorrhea is one of the most common sexually transmitted diseases (STDs). It is caused by gonorrhea bacteria and spreads through vaginal, oral, or anal sex. Your sex partner may pass it to you even if he/she doesn't have symptoms. You cannot catch gonorrhea from casual contact such as by shaking hands or from a toilet seat. The most common symptoms for men are painful urination and a white, yellow, or green discharge from the tip of the penis. The symptoms for women are different. Antibiotics can cure the disease in both men and women. But untreated, gonorrhea can lead to complications such as infertility."
		},

			"heading": "What to Expect",

All of the infected person's sexual partners need treatment to prevent passing it back and forth. Untreated gonorrhea can lead to complications such as infertility and arthritis. It can also spread to the blood."

			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Some objects are made to be used in the vagina, such as tampons and vaginal suppositories. Other objects that are not intended for use in the vagina may be put in either accidentally or intentionally. It's very common for children to have foreign objects in the vagina. Little girls may place foreign objects such as crayons in their vagina while exploring their bodies. Adolescent girls just starting to use tampons may leave one in accidentally and then put another in. Adult women may forget and leave tampons in, too. If left in for more than a day, a tampon can cause itching, irritation, and vaginal discharge. A rare but life-threatening staph infection, called toxic shock syndrome, can also occur when tampons are left in too long. Some women intentionally place objects in their vagina for sexual pleasure. Small objects don't usually cause pain, but can cause infections and other problems if not removed. Women who are sexually abused may be assaulted with large or sharp objects that cause bleeding, bruising, and pain."
		},

This staph infection comes on suddenly and causes fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. Anyone with these symptoms should get immediate medical attention. In rare cases, infection in the pelvis may cause scarring and infertility."

	"Diabetes_insipidus": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tFrequent urination\n\t\t•\tDrinking excessive fluids\n\t\t•\tIncreased thirst"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Diabetes insipidus is a rare condition in which the kidneys can't store water, causing frequent urination. You become extremely thirsty and urinate often. Because you use the bathroom so frequently, sleep can be disrupted or you may wet the bed. Diabetes insipidus isn't related to diabetes mellitus, or\"sugar\" diabetes. Central diabetes insipidus occurs when the body doesn't make enough of a hormone that controls the amount of water kidneys hold. Having a head injury or tumor are possible causes. Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus occurs when the kidneys don't respond to the hormone. This less common type can be caused by kidney disease or medicines such as lithium. Diabetes insipidus can also happen during pregnancy and after drinking too many fluids due to abnormal thirst caused by an underlying condition. Mild cases of diabetes insipidus may not need to be treated. In more severe instances, doctors may recommend medication or surgery."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "With proper care, diabetes insipidus normally doesn't cause serious problems or shorten your life span. Because the condition makes you urinate often, you need to stay hydrated. Not drinking enough liquids can lead to tiredness, muscle pain, and dehydration. This can lead to dry skin, fever, and a rapid heart rate. Children, older adults, and people with other illnesses may be more likely to have such complications."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "One in 25,000 people in the U.S. has diabetes insipidus."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Family history of diabetes insipidus"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment of diabetes insipidus may include:\n\t\t•\tTaking medications such as the synthetic hormone desmopressin to manage central DI\n\t\t•\tTaking hydrochlorothiazide and eating a low-salt diet to help control nephrogenic DI\n\t\t•\tHaving surgery to remove tumors or growths\n\t\t•\tSwitching medications if a certain drug is causing DI"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "You can help ease symptoms of diabetes insipidus by having something to drink with you at all times so you don't get dehydrated."

			"content": "Not getting treatment"
		},
		{

		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Body lice are tiny insects that live in clothing and bedding. Their bites cause an itchy rash. Body lice are different from head lice and pubic lice. They're not a risk for most people. In the U.S., only people who can't bathe or change clothes regularly -- like the homeless or refugees living in crowded conditions -- tend to get them. While mostly just a nuisance, body lice can spread some diseases. Good hygiene is the best treatment."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "You can get body lice from an infected person or clothing, especially if you're living in a cramped or dirty place. An adult body louse has six legs and is the size of a sesame seed. Despite the name, body lice don't actually live on your body. They live and lay eggs in your clothing, often in the seams. They only crawl onto your skin to bite you and feed on your blood. The itchy bites are most common in areas usually covered by clothes, like the trunk, armpits, and groin. When lice keep biting in the same area, the skin can get darker and thicker. When you have body lice, doctors call it pediculosis."
		},

		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Because the lice live on your clothes and not your body, treatment is simple. You just need to bathe regularly and change your clothes, bedding, and towels at least once a week.\n\nWash your clothes in water that's at least 130 degrees Fahrenheit, and then run them through the dryer on a hot cycle. Heat kills the lice and eggs. You can also kill them by dry-cleaning clothes or sealing them in a plastic bag for 2 weeks. Some people also use a medicine called a pediculicide. But you probably don't need it as long as you wash your clothes regularly."

	"Vaginal_dryness": [{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Vaginal dryness is a common problem that affects most women at menopause. It can, though, occur at any time. It's usually caused by a lack of estrogen, which your body stops making at menopause. Estrogen stimulates glands that lubricate the vagina. Without its effect, the vagina becomes dry and less elastic. This can cause itching and discomfort as well as painful intercourse. Vaginal dryness can be treated with water-based lubricants that are sold over the counter. Lubricants provide temporary relief and can make sex more comfortable. It can also be treated with estrogen. Estrogen applied directly to the vagina works well with less risk than estrogen taken by mouth."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Vaginal dryness increases as estrogen levels go down. Symptoms vary from woman to woman. Using water-based lubricants can make sex more comfortable. Also, regular sexual activity -- with a partner or by yourself -- can help keep the vagina lubricated. Vaginal dryness is a chronic condition. But treating it with estrogen applied directly to the vaginal walls can be an effective way to control symptoms. If you have or have had breast cancer, though, be sure to talk with your doctor about whether or not you should use estrogen."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Most women past menopause have vaginal dryness to some degree."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Vaginal dryness without symptoms or that does not have a negative effect on your life does not need treatment. Vaginal estrogen comes in several forms, including:\n\t\t•\tVaginal creams\n\t\t•\tAn estrogen ring that's inserted and replaced every three months\n\t\t•\tAn estrogen tablet that dissolves inside the vagina"

	"Bartholin_cyst": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tLump or bulge\n\t\t•\tSwelling\n\t\t•\tFever\n\t\t•\tDrainage or pus\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tChills\n\t\t•\tSkin redness"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Bartholin's cysts form in the Bartholin's glands located on either side of the vaginal opening. These glands make fluid that lubricates the skin around the opening of the vagina. When the duct to the gland becomes blocked, a cyst forms. If a cyst becomes infected with bacteria, it develops into a painful abscess. Sexually transmitted diseases sometimes cause Bartholin's cysts to form. A cyst or abscess usually occurs only in one gland. Bartholin's cysts are very common and range in size from a penny to a golf ball, although some can get even bigger. Draining the cyst relieves pain and swelling."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Bartholin's cysts start as a small lump near the opening of the vagina. The lump may be painless and go away on its own. If it gets bigger and becomes painful, it's likely that it has become infected. Sitting in a warm bath for 10-15 minutes three to four times a day can drain the cyst. It that doesn't help, the doctor can drain it. Surgery can treat cysts that keep coming back. If needed, antibiotics treat STDs."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "2% of women of childbearing age will have a Bartholin's cyst."

		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Yeast infections, or candidiasis, can occur anywhere in the body. They are caused by an overgrowth of yeast. Yeast organisms are always present in the body. Sometimes they multiply beyond their normal numbers, causing symptoms. Yeast infections can occur in the vagina, in the mouth (called thrush), on the skin, in nail beds, and in other parts of the body. Diaper rash can be a form of candidiasis. Antifungal medications are usually enough to cure yeast infections. In people with seriously weakened immune systems, candidiasis can spread through the body and become a serious threat."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "With proper treatment, most yeast infections go away on their own. Vaginal yeast infections, thrush, and diaper rash usually clear up in 1 to 2 weeks. In people with weakened immune systems, yeast infections are more stubborn and may recur. When candidiasis infection spreads throughout the body in someone with a suppressed immune system, it can be fatal."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Candidiasis is the most common of all yeast infections. Candida is found in 30% to 55% of healthy young adults."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "A variety of treatments are available to treat candidiasis. They include anti-fungal creams, lotions, pills, lozenges, and vaginal suppositories. Talk to your doctor to find the option that is right for you. For stubborn infections, your doctor may recommend a prescription oral anti-fungal drug."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",

Call your doctor or go to an emergency room if symptoms interfere with drinking or eating. People with compromised immune systems should contact their doctor immediately if they develop symptoms of a yeast infection. Candidiasis can be life threatening in people with severely weakened immune systems."

	"Dysfunctional_uterine_bleeding_(female)": [{
			"heading": "Dysfunctional Uterine Bleeding",
			"content": "Also known as: DUB, uterine hemorrhage"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tBleeding\n\t\t•\tHeavy menstrual bleeding\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tMuscle cramps or spasms (painful)"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Dysfunctional Uterine Bleeding (DUB) is vaginal bleeding that is not part of a normal period and not caused by trauma or disease. It's caused by an imbalance of the female hormones estrogen and progesterone. The most common reason for this is a menstrual cycle in which no egg is released. When there's no egg, the body doesn't produce progesterone. Without it, estrogen causes the lining of the womb to enlarge and thicken. When the lining is shed, which can happen any time during the cycle, the bleeding is often heavy and may include clots. DUB is most common in teens and women nearing menopause. Other causes of bleeding can include pregnancy, cancer, fibroids, trauma, certain drugs, and inherited bleeding disorders."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "The time between your menstrual periods may change each month. You may also notice spotting and blood in the urine between periods. Bleeding either between periods or during your period may be exceptionally heavy. You may go through pads or tampons at the rate of one per hour. Menstrual bleeding may also last more than seven days. If the bleeding is caused by an imbalance in hormones, the cycle usually returns to normal within a few months of starting treatment with birth control pills."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About one out of every 10 women will experience excessive vaginal bleeding at some point in her life."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment of DUB usually involves hormonal therapy, for instance with birth control pills, to restore proper balance and regulate the menstrual cycle, if no other cause of bleeding is found. Treatment for abnormal bleeding that's not caused by hormonal issues will depend on the underlying cause."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Any unusual vaginal bleeding should be evaluated by a doctor. In addition:\n\t\t•\tBed rest can improve symptoms.\n\t\t•\tDo not take aspirin or other nonsteroidal pain pills. Doing so can increase the bleeding.\n\t\t•\tKeep track of the number of tampons and pads used to help the doctor know how much bleeding there is."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Aspirin and other nonsteroidal pain relievers that may promote more bleeding, blood thinners, activity such as walking and running"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "Call your doctor for an appointment for any unusual vaginal bleeding. If you can't see your own doctor right away, go to an emergency room if you have unusual vaginal bleeding and other symptoms such as lightheadedness, severe pain, or fever."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\t\t•\tWhat might be causing this bleeding?\n\t\t•\tIs there some way I can stop the bleeding?\n\t\t•\tWhat other symptoms should I look out for?\n\t\t•\tAre there any treatments that can help prevent this from happening again?"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "The doctor will take a medical history and perform a physical, including a thorough pelvic exam. Tests to identify or rule out possible causes of the bleeding may include: a Pap smear, pregnancy test, blood test (to check for anemia), endometrial biopsy, ultrasound, hysteroscopy (visual exam of the womb using a scope), and possibly a dilatation and curettage (D and C)."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Being a teenager who has recently started having periods, being near menopause, a history of hormonal fluctuations"
		}

	"Foreign_object_in_the_vagina_(female)": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tDrainage or pus\n\t\t•\tVaginal discharge\n\t\t•\tPain with urination\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tItching or burning\n\t\t•\tVaginal bleeding between periods"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Some objects are made to be used in the vagina, such as tampons and vaginal suppositories. Other objects that are not intended for use in the vagina may be put in either accidentally or intentionally. It's very common for children to have foreign objects in the vagina. Little girls may place foreign objects such as crayons in their vagina while exploring their bodies. Adolescent girls just starting to use tampons may leave one in accidentally and then put another in. Adult women may forget and leave tampons in, too. If left in for more than a day, a tampon can cause itching, irritation, and vaginal discharge. A rare but life-threatening staph infection, called toxic shock syndrome, can also occur when tampons are left in too long. Some women intentionally place objects in their vagina for sexual pleasure. Small objects don't usually cause pain, but can cause infections and other problems if not removed. Women who are sexually abused may be assaulted with large or sharp objects that cause bleeding, bruising, and pain."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Smaller objects may not cause symptoms at first, but if left in place, itching, irritation, infection, foul odor, and vaginal discharge can occur. Symptoms should quickly go away once the object is removed. While rare, toxic shock syndrome can happen when tampons are left in place for too long or not changed often. This staph infection comes on suddenly and causes fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. Anyone with these symptoms should get immediate medical attention. In rare cases, infection in the pelvis may cause scarring and infertility."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",

	"Vaginal_dryness_(female)": [{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Vaginal dryness is a common problem that affects most women at menopause. It can, though, occur at any time. It's usually caused by a lack of estrogen, which your body stops making at menopause. Estrogen stimulates glands that lubricate the vagina. Without its effect, the vagina becomes dry and less elastic. This can cause itching and discomfort as well as painful intercourse. Vaginal dryness can be treated with water-based lubricants that are sold over the counter. Lubricants provide temporary relief and can make sex more comfortable. It can also be treated with estrogen. Estrogen applied directly to the vagina works well with less risk than estrogen taken by mouth."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Vaginal dryness increases as estrogen levels go down. Symptoms vary from woman to woman. Using water-based lubricants can make sex more comfortable. Also, regular sexual activity -- with a partner or by yourself -- can help keep the vagina lubricated. Vaginal dryness is a chronic condition. But treating it with estrogen applied directly to the vaginal walls can be an effective way to control symptoms. If you have or have had breast cancer, though, be sure to talk with your doctor about whether or not you should use estrogen."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Most women past menopause have vaginal dryness to some degree."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Vaginal dryness without symptoms or that does not have a negative effect on your life does not need treatment. Typically, treatment involves the use of water-based moisturizers and lubricants to relieve dryness and the discomfort of sex. Estrogen applied directly to the vagina can also manage symptoms. Vaginal estrogen comes in several forms, including:\n\t\t•\tVaginal creams\n\t\t•\tAn estrogen ring that's inserted and replaced every three months\n\t\t•\tAn estrogen tablet that dissolves inside the vagina"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "\t\t•\tUse water-based lubricants and moisturizers to relieve the discomfort of sex and for temporary relief of dryness.\n\t\t•\tDon't abstain from sex because of dryness. Regular sexual activity can promote natural lubrication of the vagina.\n\t\t•\tAvoid using hand lotions, soap, and bubble baths.\n\t\t•\tAvoid douching.\n\t\t•\tUse a sitz bath or soak in a bathtub of warm water to relieve burning sensations."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Sexual intercourse without lubrication, certain medications such as allergy and cold medications, douching"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "Make an appointment with your doctor if vaginal dryness is making you uncomfortable, interfering with your lifestyle, or affecting your relationship with your partner."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\t\t•\tCan you identify what's causing this vaginal dryness?\n\t\t•\tWhat can I do to decrease the dryness?\n\t\t•\tWill hormone creams help?\n\t\t•\tHow can I reduce pain during intercourse?\n\t\t•\tCould this be something more serious than just vaginal dryness?"
		},

			"content": "The doctor will take a medical history, ask about your symptoms, and do a physical exam, including a pelvic exam. The doctor may also ask for a blood test, urine test, and additional tests to rule out other conditions that could cause your symptoms."

			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Menopause, treatment for cancer, childbirth, breastfeeding, smoking, certain medications, certain immune diseases"

			"heading": "Overview",

Common bacteria or bacteria from sexually transmitted diseases -- which may spread from the urethra or bladder -- are the usual causes. While the symptoms can be painful (and alarming), oral antibiotics usually control epididymitis quickly."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "STDs like gonorrhea or chlamydia cause most cases of epididymitis in young, sexually active men. Other bacteria typically cause epididymitis in boys and older men. Antibiotics should clear up most cases of epididymitis. Pain should improve within one to three days. (If you have an STD, sexual partners should be treated too.) You might need medicines to reduce swelling and pain. Untreated epididymitis can cause abscesses, chronic pain, infertility, and other serious problems. Epididymitis is not always caused by bacteria. It can result from viruses, surgery, medical treatments, and injuries. It's also a side effect from amiodarone, a medicine for heart problems. In these cases, painkillers, treatment of any underlying cause, and medication changes can help."

	"Genital_herpes_(male)": [{
			"heading": "Genital Herpes (Male)",
			"content": "Herpes, herpes virus 2, HSV-2, herpes simplex virus type 2, herpes genitalis"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tBody aches or pains\n\t\t•\tFatigue\n\t\t•\tSkin blisters\n\t\t•\tSkin irritation\n\t\t•\tJoint aches\n\t\t•\tEnlarged or swollen glands\n\t\t•\tFever\n\t\t•\tSkin bumps\n\t\t•\tTender glands"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Genital herpes is a sexually transmitted infection that causes small, painful sores on the genitals. The herpes simplex virus type 2 causes genital herpes. It is passed from one person to another during sex. You can get genital herpes when your skin, penis, or mouth touches someone who has herpes. It is most contagious when the person has active sores, but you still can get herpes even when the person has no obvious symptoms. Herpes can cause pain, itching, and painful sores around your genital area, buttocks, and thighs. Once you have herpes, you can have outbreaks throughout your life. Some people who have herpes never have any symptoms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "The symptoms of herpes usually appear about two weeks after you are exposed to the virus. You first may notice tingling or pain in your genital area or on your thighs or buttocks. After a few days, small blisters appear in these areas. You also may have a fever and other flu-like symptoms. When the blisters break, they leave painful ulcers. The first outbreak is usually the most severe and may take up to four weeks to heal. After that, you can have outbreaks every few weeks or months. These outbreaks are usually milder than the first and don't last as long. Some people never have another outbreak. There is no cure for herpes, but antiviral medications can help relieve symptoms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "You may be at higher risk for genital herpes if you have sexual contact with someone with herpes."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "One out of 9 American men ages 14 to 49 has genital herpes."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Prevention",
			"content": "The best way to prevent herpes is to have sex with just one partner who does not have herpes. You can also help prevent spreading herpes by:\n\t\t•\tLimiting your number of sex partners\n\t\t•\tUsing a latex condom every time you have sex\n\t\t•\tAvoiding sex if you or your partner has active herpes sores\n\t\t•\tTelling your sex partner if you have herpes, even if you don't have any symptoms"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Genital herpes is usually treated with antiviral medications. You may take these drugs only when you feel an outbreak starting or you may take them every day."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "You can help ease the symptoms of genital herpes by following these tips:\n\t\t•\tTake a warm bath.\n\t\t•\tKeep the affected area clean and dry.\n\t\t•\tWear clothes that are loose fitting.\n\t\t•\tWear cotton underwear.\n\t\t•\tUse an over-the-counter pain reliever."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "See your doctor if you have any symptoms of genital herpes or if you have severe symptoms with any outbreak of herpes."

		},

			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Wearing underwear or pants made of synthetic fabric or wearing tight clothing can make the symptoms of herpes worse. Having sex also can make symptoms worse."

		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Syphilis is a sexually-transmitted disease caused by a type of bacteria. Syphilis goes through three stages: primary syphilis, secondary syphilis, and tertiary syphilis. There may be no symptoms or mild symptoms in the first stages. But if syphilis is not treated with antibiotics, it can cause irreversible damage to the brain, nerves, and heart."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "In the first stage, syphilis causes a painless sore on the genital area. This sore appears about two to three weeks after infection and clears up in a few weeks on its own. About two to eight weeks later, the second stage of syphilis may cause a rash all over the body, achy muscles and joints, headache, or flu-like symptoms. If the syphilis is not treated in the first two stages, it can spread to the brain, heart, and nervous system and cause severe health problems. It can take many years for the syphilis to move into the third stage. Syphilis can be treated at all stages with antibiotics. But if it is not treated until the third stage, it may cause long-term health problems."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "You may be at higher risk for syphilis if you:\n\t\t•\tHave unprotected sex\n\t\t•\tHave sex with other men\n\t\t•\tHave sex with many partners\n\t\t•\tHave HIV"
		},

			"heading": "Testicular Torsion",
			"content": "Twisted testicle, torsion of the testes, testicular ischemia, testicular twisting"

			"heading": "Symptoms",

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Testicular torsion occurs when the testicle twists on the cord that provides blood flow to the testicle. When the cord is twisted, blood flow is cut off, causing severe pain and swelling. Testicular torsion is an emergency and should be treated by a doctor right away. If not treated within a few hours, it can damage the testicle permanently. Testicular torsion is most common in boys and young men ages 10 to 25, but can happen at any age. It tends to run in families. It may occur after sleep, exercise, or an injury to the scrotum. In some cases, it happens for no apparent reason."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "Testicular torsion is an emergency. See your doctor or go the emergency room right away if you have any symptoms of testicular torsion."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Symptoms -- sudden, severe pain in one testicle -- usually don't go away until a doctor is able to untwist the testicle or until surgery corrects the problem. If it is not treated within about six hours, the testicle may need to be removed or may not work correctly. Sometimes, the testicle may untwist on its own. Even if your symptoms go away, you still need to see a doctor right away, because it may happen again."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "The only treatment for testicular torsion is surgery. Your doctor may be able to untwist the testicle without surgery, but you will still need surgery so it doesn't happen again."

			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Urethritis is an infection and inflammation of the urethra, the small tube that carries urine out of the body from the bladder. Urinary tract infections, herpes, and sexually transmitted diseases such as gonorrhea and chlamydia commonly cause it. Irritation from soaps, lotions, and spermicides also cause this infection. You may have no symptoms or you may have burning or pain during urination and a frequent, urgent need to urinate. Women are most likely to get urethritis. Treating it early with antibiotics usually clears it up without complications. Left untreated, however, it can lead to bladder and kidney infections and other health problems."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "If you think a chemical irritant is causing urethritis, you may be able to clear it up in a few days by avoiding the irritant. Otherwise, try to see a doctor within 24 hours. You'll probably need to take an antibiotic for one day to two weeks. If the urethritis is due to sexually transmitted infection, your partners also will need treatment. You should avoid sex or use a condom until you and your partners have finished treatment."

	"Menorrhagia": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tHeavy menstrual bleeding"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Menorrhagia is very heavy or prolonged menstrual bleeding. Hormonal imbalance, pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), using an IUD, uterine fibroids, abnormal pregnancy, and other factors can cause it. For some women, bleeding is so severe that it disrupts work and causes anemia. Birth control pills, hormones, or surgery usually treat it."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Menorrhagia usually occurs in women over 30 years old. Your periods will be regular, but you will have severe daily bleeding or bleeding that lasts more than seven days. You may also have abdominal pain. You may feel that menorrhagia interferes with your daily activities, affects your mood, and reduces your quality of life. If you develop anemia, you may have symptoms such as shortness of breath, heart palpitations, and fatigue. These can require hospitalization for possible transfusion and intravenous estrogen therapy. Treatment for menorrhagia depends on the cause. Your doctor will also determine treatment based on factors such as your age, desire to have children, and the extent of the condition."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 10% of women in the U.S. have menorrhagia."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatments for menorrhagia focus on reducing blood flow. It may include:\n\t\t•\tNonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), which can also reduce cramping\n\t\t•\tIron supplements, if you also have anemia\n\t\t•\tOral contraceptives\n\t\t•\tProgestin hormone therapy by mouth, IUD, or injection\n\t\t•\tMedication to enhance blood clotting\n\t\t•\tOperative hysterectomy (removal of a polyp or fibroid)\n\t\t•\tEndometrial ablation or resection (surgical removal of the uterus lining)\n\t\t•\tHysterectomy surgery to remove the uterus"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "If you have menorrhagia, eat foods with iron – such as wheat bran, molasses, dried fruit, and iron-fortified bread, pasta, and cereal -- to prevent anemia. Also, eat foods high in vitamin C – such as oranges and grapefruit – to help your body absorb iron. Maintain a healthy weight, so your body produces less estrogen, which makes bleeding worse."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Anemia, some medications"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "See your doctor if you have menstrual bleeding that soaks more than one tampon or sanitary pad an hour or lasts more than seven days. Seek immediate medical care if you feel dizzy or weak, have trouble breathing, or have heavier menstrual bleeding than usual."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Uterine cancer develops in the upper part of the uterus, or womb, and can be cured when caught early. There are several types of uterine cancer, but all typically cause unusual vaginal bleeding, discharge, and pain in the early stages. By far the most common is endometrial cancer, which appears in the inner lining of the uterus. Uterine sarcoma is a more rare type that grows in the outer layer of muscle or other tissues of the uterus. Treatment including surgery, radiation, and chemotherapy usually works well when the cancer is caught early. The vast majority of women make a full recovery."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Most uterine cancer is slow growing. Spotting or unusually heavy vaginal bleeding after menopause or between periods is the most common sign of uterine cancer. Later stages may cause pain and weight loss. The best treatment for uterine cancer depends on the type and how advanced it is. Endometrial cancer responds better to treatment than uterine sarcoma. Keep in mind that unusual bleeding does not mean you have cancer. Lots of other conditions can cause it. But it's important to be cautious. Catching uterine cancer early makes treatment more successful."
		},

			"heading": "How Common",

			"content": "Being underweight means weighing less than you need for good health. As a rough guide, having a BMI (body mass index) below 18.5 means you are underweight. You can use many online calculators to find out your BMI. Eating disorders, thyroid problems, an inadequate diet, intense exercise, alcoholism, medications, depression, and many illnesses can cause you to become underweight. Being underweight can lead to fatigue, muscle weakness, fainting or dizziness, digestive problems, hair loss, dry skin, thinning bones, missed menstrual periods, and other problems. Being severely underweight can be life threatening."
		},

If you have an eating disorder, you may need counseling to help you get to a healthy weight. Being severely underweight, or underweight for a long time, can cause osteoporosis, heart and lung problems, and even death."

	"Cervical_cancer": [{
			"heading": "Cervical Cancer",
			"content": "Cancer of the cervix"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tVaginal bleeding between periods\n\t\t•\tVaginal discharge"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Cervical cancer is cancer that begins in a woman's cervix, the lower end of the uterus, which connects to the vagina. It is almost always caused by human papillomavirus (HPV), which is spread by skin contact during sexual activity. Cervical cancer is highly preventable and highly treatable when found early. Getting the HPV vaccine can prevent this cancer. Getting regular Pap tests can detect it early when it is curable. Pap smears have greatly reduced deaths from cervical cancer in the U.S."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Cervical cancer develops slowly and usually doesn't show up until you're over age 30. In its early stages, you're most likely to discover it or the precancerous cells that can develop into it through regular Pap tests. You may have no symptoms or have abnormal vaginal bleeding or discharge and, in later stages, pelvic pain. Your oncologist will recommend treatment based on how far it has progressed as well as your age and health. If you have only abnormal tissue, you'll likely have surgery to freeze and kill it or to burn it off with a laser beam. In a later stage, you may need a hysterectomy to remove the uterus. If you want to have children, a trachelectomy, which preserves the uterus, may be an option. If the cancer has spread, you'll probably need chemotherapy and/or radiation therapy."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Each year, about 12,000 women in the United States are diagnosed with cervical cancer."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "You are at increased risk if you have HPV or a weakened immune system, don't get regular Pap tests, smoke, have given birth to five or more children, have had multiple sex partners -- particularly with no condom usage -- were exposed to the drug DES in utero, or used birth control pills for five or more years."
		},

		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Trichomoniasis, or trich, is a sexually transmitted disease (STD) caused by the trichomonas parasite. The disease spreads through sexual intercourse or from vulva to vulva contact. Anal or oral sex will not spread the disease. Most women who have trich have no symptoms. Symptoms, when they do occur, include a yellow-green, foul-smelling discharge, vaginal itching, painful urination, or pain with intercourse. Having trich can increase a woman's risk for getting HIV if exposed to the virus. Prescription medication treats and cures trich. Both a woman and her partner need treatment to prevent the disease from coming back."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Trichomoniasis often has no symptoms, which means you can have the infection and not know it. When symptoms occur, they usually come on 1 to 4 weeks after being infected. The infection often causes a yellow-green, frothy, foul smelling discharge. Vaginal itching may occur along with painful urination. Abdominal pain rarely occurs. This STD clears up quickly with treatment, but if not treated, it may go on indefinitely. Both sexual partners need treatment to prevent passing it back and forth."
		},

			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Being sexually active with more than one person, having a sexual partner who has other sexual partners, not using condoms, having sex with someone who has trichomoniasis"

			"heading": "Peyronie's Disease",
			"content": "Curvature of the penis"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tCurved or bent penis during erection\n\t\t•\tPain during erection\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tErectile dysfunction"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "In Peyronie's disease, hardened plaques of tissue form in the shaft of the penis. The plaques are benign; they are not cancerous and won't lead to serious illness. But over time, these plaques can cause the penis to bend abnormally or to become shortened when erect. Intercourse may become painful or impossible. In a small percentage of men, the symptoms may go away over time. In others, they may get worse. Although some treatment may help, none has been shown to dramatically reverse the condition. Surgery works for some men, but it can cause impotence. A safer alternative may be a penile prosthesis."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "In a small percentage of men, Peyronie's disease goes away on its own. The penis returns to normal. Most men learn to live with the condition. Although a number of treatments have been tried, none has been shown to be significantly effective. Not surprisingly, almost half of men with Peyronie's disease experience depression. Your doctor can help you find ways to remain sexually active."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "A recent study found symptoms of Peyronie's disease in 3.2% of men ages 30 to 80."
		},

		},

If you are unable to have intercourse because of the curve of your penis, surgery may be done to correct the problem. However, surgery may cause impotence. Another option is a penile prosthesis."

Erectile dysfunction is a consistent problem. Some medications, stress, injuries, high blood pressure, hardening of the arteries, diabetes, and other health conditions can cause it. While erectile dysfunction is more common as men get older, it's not inevitable. Treatments can help men at any age. Erectile dysfunction also can be a sign of an underlying condition that needs medical care."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "The risk for erectile dysfunction begins to rise in middle age. Symptoms slowly may get worse or appear suddenly, depending on the cause. In most cases, a medication side effect or health problem triggers ongoing erectile dysfunction. Changing medications or getting treatment for the underlying condition may help. Less often, stress or anxiety is the problem. In these cases, therapy may be a good idea. Medications, such as Cialis, Levitra, and Viagra help men with erectile dysfunction keep erections and have sex. For some, injections, vacuum pumps, and surgical implants are the best approach."

	"Priapism": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tErectile dysfunction"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Priapism is an often painful erection that lasts more than four hours. It isn't caused by sexual stimulation, but occurs when blood is trapped in the penis and cannot drain. It can also happen when too much blood flows into the penis. Although rare, priapism is a medical emergency and can lead to erectile dysfunction or scarring if not treated. Doctors don't always know what causes priapism. But certain medications, recreational drug use, and some medical conditions – especially sickle cell disease – can cause it. If treated right away, priapism usually has no long-lasting effects."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Priapism is different from normal erections. It lasts longer, usually four hours or more. It isn't caused by sexual arousal or stimulation, or it lasts well beyond them. The erection is often painful and the glans penis – the cone-shaped end of the penis – is soft. If these symptoms appear, stop taking any drug that may have caused it, including those used to stimulate erections, and get medical help immediately. The less common type of priapism, known as nonischemic or high-flow priapism, may get better on its own. But with the most common type, ischemic or low-flow priapism, tissue damage can begin within four to six hours. The doctor will start treatment by injecting medication into the penis and might also drain blood with a needle. If necessary, a shunt may be inserted surgically to divert blood flow. If a ruptured artery is the cause, your doctor may do surgery to tie it off. You may need additional treatment if sickle cell disease caused the priapism."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Up to 89% of adults and 27% of children with sickle cell disease have priapism."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Risk factors include:\n\nAge -- between 5 to 10 years old and 20 to 50 years old if you don't have sickle cell disease, and 19 to 21 years old if you do:\n\t\t•\tPenile injection therapy for erectile dysfunction\n\t\t•\tDrinking alcohol or using cocaine or marijuana\n\t\t•\tTaking some medications for depression, mental illness, or high blood pressure\n\t\t•\tBlood disorders such as sickle cell disease, leukemia, thallasemia, or multiple myeloma\n\t\t•\tPlatelet disorders such as thrombotic thrombocytopenia purpura\n\t\t•\tTrauma to the genital area or acute spinal cord injury\n\t\t•\tBlack widow spider bites"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Medical treatment for priapism may include:\n\t\t•\tIce packs to reduce swelling\n\t\t•\tLight exercise, such as climbing stairs, to draw blood away from the penis\n\t\t•\tMedication for pain\n\t\t•\tIntracavernous injection – injecting medication into the penis to narrow veins, reducing blood flow and swelling\n\t\t•\tSurgical ligation – tying off a ruptured artery to restore normal blood flow\n\t\t•\tAspiration – using needle to drain blood, reducing pressure and swelling\n\t\t•\tSurgical shunt – inserting a shunt to divert blood flow and restore normal blood circulation\n\t\t•\tTreatment of underlying conditions, such as sickle cell disease\n\t\t•\tEmbolization – inserting coils, glues, or spheres into the penis to reduce blood flow"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "These self-care strategies may help prevent another episode of priapism:\n\t\t•\tRest and refrain from sexual activity, according to your doctor's advice.\n\t\t•\tAvoid triggers such as recreational drugs or alcohol.\n\t\t•\tTalk to your doctor about other medications if a prescription drug was the cause.\n\t\t•\tIf priapism is likely to recur, ask your doctor about drugs you can take at first sign of recurrence.\n\t\t•\tIf an underlying condition caused your priapism, treat it."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Not getting treatment. The longer the erection lasts, the more likely you are to get permanent erectile problems and scarring."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "If you have a painful erection that goes away on its own within a couple of hours, you should still see your doctor. Go to a hospital emergency room if you have an erection that lasts more than two hours."
		},

		},

			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "The doctor will take a medical history and do a physical exam. You'll be asked about using drugs, and recent injuries to the area. The doctor will draw some blood from the penis to do a blood gas analysis, in order to find out which type of priapism you have."

		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Testosterone deficiency is a shortage of the male sex hormone that can affect a man's sex drive, appearance, and state of mind. Testosterone helps the male body change from a boy to a man and is important for muscle bulk, healthy red blood cell levels, and sexual function. After age 30, a man's level of testosterone gradually starts to decrease. Levels also may be low due to testicle injury, cancer and cancer treatment, diseases that affect the hypothalamus and pituitary glands, and certain medicines. Hormone replacement therapy may raise testosterone to normal levels in most men."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "It's normal for men to be less interested in sex and have fewer erections with age, so you may not want to adjust your testosterone levels if they start to drop. If you have prostate cancer or breast cancer, you should not have hormone replacement therapy. For most men, increasing the testosterone in your body with hormone therapy is generally safe. However, side effects can include acne, urinating less, and enlarged breasts. Some types of therapy may be uncomfortable. Shots can be painful, and testosterone applied directly to the skin can be irritating. The goals of therapy are to improve signs of masculinity, as well as sexual function and muscle and bone strength."

They can cause alarming but harmless side effects, such as dark black stool and a black tongue. These are normal symptoms that will go away after stopping the medication. When bismuth combines with sulfur in the saliva and digestive tract, it turns black. Anyone who has not taken a medication with bismuth and has a discolored tongue or black stool should see a doctor."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "The tailbone, also called a coccyx, is a set of three to five small bones connected to the end of the spine. A broken tailbone can occur from a fall on ice or pavement or from a direct hit, such as in contact sports. Women can also fracture or dislocate their tailbone during childbirth. In general, women are more at risk for a tailbone injury because their hips are wider and the tailbone is more exposed. A fractured tailbone may cause severe pain when sitting, bruising in the area, and pain with bowel movements. Women with a tailbone injury may experience pain with sexual intercourse. Treatment with anti-inflammatory medication, using a doughnut-shaped cushion to sit on, and stool softeners helps relieve pain as the injury heals. Corticosteroid injections may help treat pain that doesn't respond to other methods."
		},

Taking anti-inflammatory medication can ease pain and swelling. The doctor may prescribe stool softeners to prevent constipation and make bowel movements easier. Using a donut-shaped pillow to sit on will relieve pressure on the tailbone. Most people recover from a tailbone injury in a few weeks."

			"content": "\t\t•\tMuscle cramps or spasms (painful)"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Proctalgia fugax is a rare but benign condition that causes spasm-like anal pain. Unlike pain from other rectal conditions, such as some hemorrhoids or anal fissures, proctalgia fugax pain often appears on the left side and may not be related to bowel movements. Proctalgia fugax attacks generally last a few minutes or less, so the condition is usually not treated. It does not lead to any illness or complications. People under age 45 and women are most likely to have it."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Proctalgia fugax symptoms may appear daily and then disappear for weeks or months. When they come, you'll have sharp, stabbing, or cramp-like pain at the anal opening. It may be on the left side, occur at night, and be strong enough to wake you up. You may also feel urgency to have a bowel movement but not pass any stools. Most likely, the pain will last less than a minute, although it may last a couple of hours. In most cases, there is no treatment for a proctalgia fugax attack, because it is fleeting. Hot baths, medications, or biofeedback may help in more severe cases."
		},

			"content": "About 8% of people in the U.S. have proctalgia fugax."

			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Sciatica is pain, numbness, weakness or tingling in the leg. The pain is caused by an injury to the sciatic nerve, which runs from your back down into your buttock and leg. The sciatic nerve is the largest nerve in the body. Branches of this nerve connect to all the nerves of the legs and feet. Medical problems such as a slipped disk or degenerative disk disease cause most cases of sciatica. Pregnancy can also cause sciatica. Usually, you feel the pain, numbness, or tingling only on one leg or foot, not on both sides."
		},

			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Sciatica is the sign of another medical condition, such as a slipped disk, arthritis, periformis syndrome, spinal stenosis, or injury to the spine. Your doctor may recommend some at-home treatments or exercises to help relieve your symptoms."

A little rest may help with pain at first, but bed rest for more than a day or two may make symptoms worse.\n\t\t•\tTry sleeping on your side, in the fetal position with a pillow between your legs.\n\t\t•\tUse over-the-counter pain relievers as needed."

Bursae are small sacs of fluid that cushion the bones, ligaments, and muscles around your joints -- in this case, on either side at the bottom of the pelvis. If you injure the area or just put pressure on it by sitting all day you can irritate the bursa, causing pain and swelling. People with desk jobs are more likely to develop it. Painkillers, ice, and other treatments will help. Untreated bursitis can become a chronic problem."

Get a more comfortable chair or use cushions. Make sure you have footwear with good support. If you're overweight, lose some weight and exercise more."

	"Rectal_prolapse": [{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Sitting too much, being overweight, not exercising enough, arthritis, and gout"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tProtruding rectal material"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Rectal prolapse is an uncommon condition that occurs when the rectum, the lower part of the colon, slips out of place and protrudes from the anus. Most commonly, it occurs in women over age 60. Straining with bowel movements, pregnancy and childbirth, and muscle weakening due to aging may cause it. Surgery can correct it. Rarely, it occurs in small children. Anyone who has symptoms of rectal prolapse -- such as an inability to control bowel movements, or bleeding, discharge, or pain during bowel movements -- should see a doctor. Keep in mind that other conditions may also cause these symptoms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Rectal prolapse in adults occurs because ligaments and muscles that hold the rectum securely in place weaken and stretch. In the early stages of rectal prolapse, the rectum usually stays in the body most of the time. You may feel a lump outside your anus only after a bowel movement, especially if you strain. After a while, it may protrude when you stand, walk, sneeze, or cough. You can probably push it back in. But if you don't treat it, more of the rectum may protrude permanently. Stool softeners can help if constipation and straining are causing the prolapse, but they won't correct it. Surgery is required to secure the rectum to your inner pelvis. The sooner you get surgery, the better the results are likely to be. If you are younger and healthy, you will probably have abdominal surgery. If you are older or not in good health, you'll have rectal surgery. You'll be in the hospital three to seven days for abdominal surgery and less for rectal surgery. For most people, surgery clears up all or most symptoms of rectal prolapse."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Rectal prolapse occurs in just 1% of people over age 65 in the U.S."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for rectal prolapse may include:\n\t\t•\tStool softeners and bulk laxatives\n\t\t•\tAbdominal surgery to lift the rectum and attach it to pelvic bones\n\t\t•\tAbdominal surgery to remove a section of the rectum and attach the remainder to the pelvic bone\n\t\t•\tRectal surgery to remove a segment of the rectum\n\t\t•\tRectal surgery to insert a wire or plastic loop to hold the sphincter closed"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",

		},

			"content": "A broken or fractured hip is a break in the thighbone under the hip joint. Usually a fall or injury causes the break. Conditions such as cancer or osteoporosis can weaken the bone, making it more likely to break. Females lose bone mass faster after menopause, so women ages 65 and older are most likely to have a hip fracture. A broken hip is serious and can keep you from walking, so you need immediate medical care. Surgery is usually necessary to fix or replace the hip. Physical therapy and using a walking aid help most people recover in a year or possibly earlier."

You will need to use crutches, a cane, or a walker for several months or longer. You'll also need physical therapy. There is a risk for blood clots, but medicine can reduce the chance of getting them. Most people recover within a year and regain most or all of the motion they had before breaking their hip. Other people will still need help and may not be able to live by themselves. In cases where surgery is not an option, bed rest can lead to complications such as bedsores and infections."

			"heading": "Symptoms",

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "The labrum holds the ball part of your ball-and-socket hip joint in place. An injury – such as a car accident or sports injury – can tear the labrum. The labrum can also tear as a result of repetitive motions such as a pivoting motion that's common in a sport like golf. And some people are born with an abnormality in their hip that causes greater wear. Some people with a labral tear have no symptoms. Others notice a pain in their hip or groin. Some may also notice a catching sensation in their hip when they move. Others have stiffness and a limited range of motion. A labral tear can result in chronic hip pain and, over time, contribute to the development of arthritis. A hip labral tear may be treated with medications, physical therapy, and surgery."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "A sudden hip labral tear may feel like a pinching sensation that gets worse with walking. But in most cases, the pain develops gradually and gets worse over time. Many people describe a constant dull ache that is punctuated with episodes of sharp pain. Activity often makes the pain worse. At first, treatment consists of rest, pain medications, and physical therapy. Surgery may be used to repair the labrum and relieve symptoms. If the labrum can't be repaired, the result may be chronic hip pain and arthritis with difficulty walking."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Nearly two out of every three people with pain, clicking, and locking of the hip have a labral tear."

	"Repetitive_motion_injuries": [{
			"heading": "Repetitive Motion Injuries",
			"content": "Factory worker's syndrome, repetitive stress injuries, overuse syndrome, cumulative trauma disorder"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tJoint pain\n\t\t•\tNumbness or tingling"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Repetitive motions like those done in assembly work or sports can injure joints, muscles, and tendons over time. These injuries can cause numbness, tingling, and weakness in a hand, arm, leg, or foot. Repetitive motion injuries are common in the workplace, but they also can come from playing a sport, doing housework, or even working in a garden. The most common injuries are tendinitis and bursitis. Carpal tunnel syndrome is another common repetitive motion injury that affects nerves and tendons in the wrist. Left untreated, these injuries can lead to permanent disability."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Some people with repetitive motion injury may not even be aware of an injury. The first sign is finding it hard to do things that are normally easy. The longer a repetitive injury goes untreated, the more severe it can become. If treated early, most repetitive motion injuries clear up with treatment, rehab and physical therapy. Most people can regain full function of whatever body part is involved. If not treated early, a repetitive motion injury can cause temporary or permanent disability."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Repetitive motion injuries account for half of all sports injuries seen by doctors. And carpal tunnel syndrome may affects millions of people in the U.S."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment may include:\n\t\t•\tAvoiding or reducing the activity that is causing the injury\n\t\t•\tResting the injured body part\n\t\t•\tUsing a splint or brace for support\n\t\t•\tTaking pain medications\n\t\t•\tSurgery, if needed, to repair the injured joint, muscle, or nerves\n\nPhysical therapy, occupational therapy, or other type of rehab program to strengthen the injured body part and learn new ways of doing things to avoid reinjuring the affected area."

			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Tendinitis is an inflammation of the tendon due to overuse or injury. It can also be caused by some bacterial infections (such as Lyme disease or gonorrhea) as well as some autoimmune diseases. Tendons are the tissue that connects muscle to bone. Weight lifting, active sports, and heavy physical labor often cause tendon strains. Muscle strain or trauma to the tendons can cause small tears in the muscles and tendons, leading to inflammation and soreness. More severe strains can cause stiffness and temporary muscle weakness. Tendinitis often occurs in the wrists, elbows, shoulders, knees, hips, ankles, or heels."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Tendinitis will heal in about 7 to 14 days. Severe tendinitis can take months to heal without intensive treatment."

			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Most tendinitis can be self-treated at home. When first injured, start by applying an ice pack for 15 to 20 minutes, every 4 to 6 hours, and rest the area. After 24 hours you may apply heat, but don't overdo it. When you feel ready, start gently stretching and massaging the area. Take anti-inflammatory medicines with meals as long as soreness lasts."

	"Avascular_necrosis": [{
			"heading": "Avascular Necrosis",
			"content": "Osteonecrosis, aseptic necrosis, ischemic necrosis"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tJoint pain\n\t\t•\tDifficulty walking\n\t\t•\tUnable to move joint\n\t\t•\tStiffness or decreased movement\n\t\t•\tUnable to move leg\n\t\t•\tUnable to bear weight"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Avascular necrosis (AVN) is the death of bone tissue due to poor blood supply. Eventually, the bone can collapse, causing severe pain. AVN often occurs in the hip, but it can also affect shoulders, knees, ankles, and, rarely, the jaw bone. AVN causes no symptoms early on, but eventually causes joint pain. By the time AVN is diagnosed, the disease has usually progressed. Treatment is generally lifelong, beginning with pain relievers and crutches to take the weight off the joint. Most people with AVN eventually need surgery to repair bone or replace the joint. Factors that can lead to AVN include certain medications such as corticosteroids, injury, excess alcohol use, radiation therapy, and chemotherapy. Medical conditions such as cancer, lupus, sickle cell, and osteoporosis also increase the risk for AVN."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Joint pain usually develops gradually, especially when putting weight on the joint. As the disease progresses, joint pain occurs even at rest and can be severe if the bone collapses. Pain and bone loss can make it difficult to move the affected joint. The disease progresses from joint pain to bone collapse and loss of joint function over the course of a few months to a year. Treatment depends on the severity of the disease and is usually an ongoing process. Early on, pain relievers and keeping weight off the affected bone can help relieve symptoms. Most people with AVN will eventually need surgery. Surgery can help repair smaller areas of bone loss. Total joint replacement is usually needed for late-stage AVN."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "In the U.S. 15,000 people are diagnosed with AVN every year."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for AVN includes:\n\t\t•\tPain relievers\n\t\t•\tUsing crutches, a walker, or cane to take weight off the affected joint\n\t\t•\tLimiting activities\n\t\t•\tRange of motion exercises\n\t\t•\tSurgery to repair bone\n\t\t•\tTotal joint replacement"
		},
		{

		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Putting weight on the affected joint"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "If you notice joint or bone pain, or if you have groin pain when you put weight on your hip joints, call your doctor. If you have severe joint or bone pain that comes on suddenly, get immediate medical help."
		},
		{

		{

	"Bursitis_(iliopsoas)": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tJoint pain\n\t\t•\tLump or bulge\n\t\t•\tWarm to touch\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tSkin redness\n\t\t•\tTenderness to touch"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Iliopsoas bursitis can cause pain in the groin and legs. Bursitis is swelling of the bursae, small sacs of fluid that cushion the bones, ligaments, and muscles around the joints -- in this case, on the inside of the hip joints. Arthritis or injuries can irritate the bursae, causing pain and swelling. Older people and runners are more likely to develop iliopsoas bursitis. Painkillers, ice, and other treatments will help. Untreated bursitis can become a chronic problem."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Pain usually develops over weeks or months. It may spread through the thigh into the knee. It may be worse after sitting for a long time or when extending the leg. People with iliopsoas bursitis may limp, because they take a short step with the painful leg. Swollen bursae can actually feel like a hernia and press on the nerves, causing numbness or tingling in the leg. While bursitis is not a serious problem, it's important to get the right diagnosis and get help. Most people do well with at-home treatments or cortisone injections. Iliopsoas bursitis rarely requires surgery."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Millions of people in the U.S. have bursitis."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatments for bursitis include:\n\t\t•\tNSAIDs -- such as ibuprofen, ketoprofen, and naproxen -- to help with pain and swelling\n\t\t•\tIcing the area; wrap ice in a thin towel rather than apply it directly to the skin.\n\t\t•\tInjections of cortisone, painkillers, or dextrose into the bursa\n\t\t•\tPhysical therapy\n\t\t•\tWeight loss\n\t\t•\tAntibiotics, in rare cases where an infection causes the symptoms\n\t\t•\tSurgery, in rare cases"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Use over-the-counter NSAIDs -- such as ibuprofen and ketoprofen -- to help with pain and swelling. Take them with food and follow the directions on the label. Ice the area. You need to rest and avoid doing anything that hurts while you heal. Using a cane may help you get better faster. Make sure you have footwear with good support. Lose weight if you're overweight."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Extending the leg, walking, jogging, standing for long periods of time"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "If you have pain in the legs or groin that doesn't go away, see the doctor."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Trochanteric bursitis is an inflammation of the small, fluid-filled sac (bursa) at the outside point of the hip (greater trochanter). If this cushioning bursa becomes irritated, it can become painful. Bursitis can result from an injury, overuse of the joint, poor posture, surgery, or certain conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis. Hip bursitis is more common in women, and middle-aged or elderly people. The pain worsens when you walk, squat, climb stairs, or lie on your side. Often, rest and avoiding repetitive activities that stress your hip can relieve the pain. If that doesn't help, medical treatment can include pain relievers, corticosteroid injections, physical therapy, and, rarely, surgery to remove the bursa."

	"Gout": [{
			"heading": "Gout",
			"content": "Rich man's disease, the disease of kings"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tJoint pain\n\t\t•\tSwelling\n\t\t•\tSkin redness\n\t\t•\tUnable to bear weight\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tDifficulty walking\n\t\t•\tWarm to touch"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Gout Overview",
			"content": "Gout is a type of arthritis caused by too much uric acid in the body. This happens when the body produces excess uric acid or when the kidneys don't remove enough of it. Uric acid builds up in the fluid around the joints, and crystals form that cause intense pain and inflammation. Gout typically affects the big toe, but can also affect heels, ankles, knees, fingers, wrists, and elbows. Over time, excess uric acid can cause kidney stones and lumps of uric acid crystals under the skin. The condition runs in families. Being overweight, taking certain medications, eating high-fat foods such as organ meat, and drinking alcohol can lead to gout attacks in some people. With treatment, most people with gout can control the condition."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Gout attacks come on suddenly, usually at night, causing severe joint pain, redness, and swelling. The joint can be so sensitive that pressure from a sheet feels excruciating. An attack can last from a few hours to several days. Over time, attacks come more often and last longer. Controlling uric acid levels will prevent attacks and lessen symptoms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About five out of 1,000 people in the U.S. have gout."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for gout includes:\n\t\t•\tDrugs to lower uric acid levels\n\t\t•\tPain relievers\n\t\t•\tMedications to stop swelling and inflammation\n\t\t•\tCorticosteroids"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "For a full-blown gout attack, you will need medical attention. You can help avoid future attacks by:\n\t\t•\tAvoiding certain foods (shellfish, organ meats, red meat, anchovies, herring)\n\t\t•\tAvoiding alcohol\n\t\t•\tDrinking plenty of fluids\n\t\t•\tGetting regular exercise\n\t\t•\tLosing weight slowly, if you are overweight. Rapid weight loss can cause kidney stones."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "A diet high in red meat, organ meat, and shellfish, alcohol, primarily beer, some medications such as diuretics"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "If you are experiencing extreme joint pain, fever, or hot, red, swollen joints, call your doctor."
		},

			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",

		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",

			"content": "Obesity, a family history of gout"

	"Pseudogout": [{
			"heading": "Pseudogout",
			"content": "False gout, pyrophosphate arthropathy"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tJoint pain\n\t\t•\tStiffness or decreased movement\n\t\t•\tSwelling"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Pseudogout is a type of arthritis similar to gout, where crystals form in the joints, causing swelling and pain. Pseudogout is often mistaken for gout or other types of arthritis. However, with pseudogout, crystals form from calcium pyrophosphate, not uric acid. The condition often occurs in the knees, but it can also affect the hips and hand and arm joints. Pseudogout has no clear cause, although the condition may run in families and tends to affect older adults. Certain medical conditions such as hypothyroidism and joint injury can also lead to pseudogout. Treatment helps reduce inflammation and pain in joints."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Pseudogout attacks can come on slowly over a few days. Attacks can be very painful and disabling and last for days or weeks. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications (NSAIDs) can help reduce pain and inflammation. Draining joint fluid helps reduce swelling. Treating any underlying health condition and taking daily medication may lessen the risk for attacks and help prevent joint damage."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Three percent of people ages 50 and older and 50% of people ages 90 and older have pseudogout."
		},
		{

		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Drinking plenty of fluids, avoiding pressure on the joint, rest"
