	"Septic_arthritis": [{
			"heading": "Septic Arthritis",
			"content": "Infectious arthritis"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tJoint pain\n\t\t•\tStiffness or decreased movement\n\t\t•\tSkin redness\n\t\t•\tWeakness (generalized)\n\t\t•\tSwelling\n\t\t•\tFever\n\t\t•\tWarm to touch"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Septic arthritis is a joint infection that comes on suddenly and causes intense pain and swelling. If not treated promptly, it can cause permanent bone and joint damage that may require surgery. It's most often caused by bacteria -- especially Staphylococcus aureus, or\"staph\" – that travel through the bloodstream from an infection elsewhere in the body. But bacteria also can enter the joint through an open wound, surgery, or unsterile injections. You're most likely to get septic arthritis if you are over age 60 or have certain joint or health problems. Antibiotics and draining fluid from the joint help clear it up. The sooner you get treatment, the more likely you are to recover fully."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "If you have sudden, severe joint pain with signs of infection, such as fever and chills, see your doctor immediately."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Septic arthritis usually affects only one joint, most often the knee. But you also may get it in your hip, shoulder, wrist, ankle, elbow, hands, or feet. The joint will probably be stiff, red, and warm, and very painful, especially when you move it. You also may have chills and fever. Your doctor will start you on IV antibiotics right away. The doctor also may drain the joint with a needle. After several days, you may be able to start gentle exercises. You'll probably continue with oral antibiotics for up to six weeks and may get physical therapy to help you regain strength and flexibility. If antibiotics and drainage don't clear up the infection in several days, or if the infection is in a large joint such as the knee, hip, or shoulder, you may need surgery. Joint replacement surgery is rare, but may be needed if you have severe joint damage and destruction."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "The longer septic arthritis goes untreated, the more damage it can do to the joint and the more likely it is to spread infection."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for septic arthritis may include:\n\t\t•\tIntravenous and oral antibiotics\n\t\t•\tDraining the joint to eradicate infection and reduce pain\n\t\t•\tArthroscopy to irrigate the joint and remove dead or damaged tissue\n\t\t•\tOpen joint surgery to drain and clean large joints\n\t\t•\tJoint replacement surgery, if joint damage is severe\n\t\t•\tPhysical therapy"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",

		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "See your doctor if you have symptoms of septic arthritis such as sudden, severe joint pain and swelling. If you also have signs of infection such as fever or chills see your doctor right away."

			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Stress fractures are small breaks that usually occur in the feet or leg bones. They typically are caused by overuse. Stress fractures develop over time, causing pain and swelling. Constant stress, such as from running, prevents the bone from repairing itself, and small fractures occur. Athletes and people in the military commonly get stress fractures. People with osteoporosis, a condition that weakens bones, are also at risk for stress fractures. Resting for several weeks and using braces or casts allows fractures to heal."
		},

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Hidradenitis suppurativa is an uncommon chronic disease that affects sweat glands in the groin and armpit, known as the apocrine glands. It can cause flares of painful, pus-filled, red bumps and scarring. In some cases, it can lead to severe infections or squamous cell carcinoma, a skin cancer. Antibiotics, injections, and anti-inflammatories are used to treat it, but surgery is the most effective treatment. If you've had acne, you're more likely to get hidradenitis suppurativa. Because it can cause chronic pain, many people who have it develop depression."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "Hidradenitis suppurativa can cause cellulitis, a skin infection that can spread to the lymph nodes and bloodstream. If you have a high fever or chills, nausea and vomiting, or a red area that enlarges, hardens, or feels numb, go to a hospital emergency room."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Hidradenitis suppurativa can flare for several days and go into remission for years. It usually begins as one or more tender nodules in areas where hair grows, including the armpits, groin, and between the buttocks or where the skin rubs together, such as between legs or under a woman's breast. Within hours or days, the bumps get bigger, become inflamed and painful, and drain pus, which causes scarring. You also may have a foul odor, caused by bacterial infection. If your hidradenitis suppurativa is mild, you can apply warm compresses and wash the area with antibacterial soap to relieve the odor. There are no cures for hidradenitis supporativa. Surgery is the most effective treatment, but it can cause scars and complications, so dermatologists try other treatments first. Injections in the lesions usually reduce swelling and tenderness within days. Oral and topical antibiotics, birth control pills, retinoids, and isotretinoin (used to treat severe acne) may help clear it up. If your condition gets worse over time or you develop scarring, you may need surgery. If you have depression because of chronic pain or disfigurement, it may help to get counseling."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Heat, humidity, stress, deodorant, being overweight, shaving the affected area, wearing tight, synthetic clothing"

		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "These self-care strategies can help relieve symptoms of hidradenitis suppurativa:\n\t\t•\tApply warm compresses or take warm baths.\n\t\t•\tAvoid prolonged exposure to heat and humidity.\n\t\t•\tWear loose, non-synthetic clothing.\n\t\t•\tDon't shave or apply deodorant to the area if irritation occurs.\n\t\t•\tWash the area daily with antibacterial soap to reduce odor.\n\t\t•\tTake nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medication for swelling and pain.\n\t\t•\tTry meditation, deep-breathing exercises, or other stress-reduction techniques.\n\t\t•\tGet counseling if you feel isolated or depressed because of the condition.\n\t\t•\tLose weight, if you are obese"

	"Lymphogranuloma_venereum": [{
			"heading": "Lymphogranuloma Venereum",
			"content": "LGV, Climatic Bubo"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tEnlarged or swollen glands\n\t\t•\tSkin open sore\n\t\t•\tSkin bumps\n\t\t•\tTender glands"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Lymphogranuloma venereum, or LGV, is a sexually transmitted disease caused by Chlamydia trachomatis bacteria. It can be spread through skin-to-skin contact or sexual penetration. It can make the lymph glands in the groin tender and swollen. Painful anal or rectal inflammation also can occur, affecting bowel movements. LGV has been uncommon in the U.S. and other industrialized nations, but in the last decade, there have been outbreaks in North America and Europe among men who have sex with men. Treatment with antibiotics can clear it up. Anyone with LGV symptoms should see a doctor. Keep in mind that other conditions can cause similar symptoms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "In the first stage, you may notice a small non-painful bump or irritation in the genital area three to 12 days after being infected. It will heal within a few days. This sore also can be hidden inside the urethra, vagina, or rectum, so you should see a doctor if you had sex with someone with LGV, even if you don't have symptoms. Within two to six weeks, the infection may spread to the lymph nodes in the groin, making them tender and swollen. If you were infected via anal intercourse, you may have anal pain, inflammation, and discharge. If you don't treat the infection early, scarring and narrowing (strictures) can develop, which can cause diarrhea and pain with bowel movements. You'll need to take an antibiotic -- usually doxycycline -- for three weeks. You'll also need to notify anyone you've had sex with in the last 60 days, so they can be evaluated and treated. Sex should be avoided until you finish treatment and your symptoms have disappeared. If you have HIV, you'll receive the same treatment, but it may take longer to clear up your symptoms."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Being a man who has sex with men, having multiple sexual partners, having unprotected anal sex, having HIV"
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Fewer than 600 cases of lymphogranuloma venereum are diagnosed in the U.S. each year."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Prevention",
			"content": "The only way to prevent lymphogranuloma venereum or any STD is to abstain from sexual contact or be in a mutually exclusive relationship with someone who does not have an STD. These strategies can also help prevent LGV:\n\t\t•\tIf you have had sex in the previous 60 days with someone who has LGV, get tested. You may be able to prevent it by taking antibiotics for a week.\n\t\t•\tDon't have sex with anyone who has LGV until they have finished antibiotic treatment (three weeks) and have no symptoms.\n\t\t•\tWear latex condoms -- or make sure your partner does -- during sex. Used correctly, they may help prevent LGV. But STDs can occur from exposure to genital areas that are not covered by a condom."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for lymphogranuloma venereum includes:\n\t\t•\tAntibiotics\n\t\t•\tAbstaining from sex until treatment is finished and symptoms are gone"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "These self-care strategies may help while getting treated for LGV:\n\t\t•\tAvoid being re-infected by having sex with anyone who has LGV.\n\nIf a sexual partner is also being treated for LGV, avoid sex until the person finishes treatment and symptoms have disappeared."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",

			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "If you suspect a dislocated shoulder, seek emergency care immediately. Waiting can cause pain and additional damage to the shoulder."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "A dislocated shoulder is an emergency and needs immediate medical attention. Doctors will assess the injury, provide pain medications, and then put the shoulder back in its normal position. Most people are able to return to their normal activities after a period of rest and recovery. But shoulders that have dislocated are more likely to dislocate again, especially when the first injury happens in people younger than 20. If there is damage to the ligaments in the shoulder, doctors may recommend surgery in order to prevent it from happening again. People who have dislocated shoulders are at higher risk of getting arthritis in their shoulders."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Not getting medical treatment right away"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Doctors may provide medication to deaden pain in the shoulder and sometimes a sedative to help people relax. Then they push or pull the shoulder back into alignment. This usually is done in an emergency room. In rare cases, it may need to be done under general anesthesia in an operating room. After the shoulder is back in place, the arm is immobilized in a sling. You may need prescription pain relievers for the first few days. The shoulder should remain immobile for several weeks. After that, physical therapy, including range of motion and strengthening exercises, can help."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Immediately after the injury, keep the shoulder immobile. Use a sling. If one is not available, you can make a sling with a piece of cloth such as a large towel or a sheet. Place a pillow between the arm and body to support the injured shoulder. Don't eat or drink anything. It's better to have an empty stomach while the shoulder is put back in place."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",

	"Rotator_cuff_injury": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tGuarding or favoring joint\n\t\t•\tStiffness or decreased movement\n\t\t•\tJoint pain\n\t\t•\tWeakness\n\t\t•\tPopping or snapping sound from joint"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "The rotator cuff is a group of muscles covering the top of the upper arm bone that keep it in place in the shoulder joint and allow the arm to rotate. Aging, overusing the muscles and tendons over time, or a sudden trauma, such as a car accident or fall, can inflame, strain, or tear the rotator cuff. You may feel pain and have limited movement in your shoulder. Rest, ice, and physical therapy often can heal an injury, but it may take surgery to repair a complete tear."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "You're most likely to tear your rotator cuff if you're over age 40.  Repetitive overhead motions, like pitching a baseball or painting, can cause a chronic tear or bursitis, an inflammation. You may feel gradual weakening and pain that interrupts your sleep. A deep ache in the shoulder may be tendinitis, which also can lead to a tear. Suddenly tearing the cuff may cause shooting pains from your shoulder and limit your movement. Physical therapy, rest, anti-inflammatory medications, and steroid injections often heal rotator cuff injuries. If a tear doesn't heal after six to eight weeks, you may need surgery to regain full range of motion. In extreme cases, shoulder replacement surgery may be necessary."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "It's estimated that 20%-30% of people have symptomatic rotator cuff injuries."

			"content": "\t\t•\tInability to move\n\t\t•\tWeakness\n\t\t•\tJoint pain\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tNumbness or tingling\n\t\t•\tUnable to grip (hands)"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "An injury to the brachial plexus involves a network of nerves in the neck and shoulder that control movement and sensation in the shoulder, arm, and hand. An injury to the neck or shoulder can damage these nerves. Most injuries to the brachial plexus happen at birth during delivery. Sports injuries and other accidents, as in surgery, also can cause it. And sometimes the pressure from a tumor or inflammation can cause it. The effects of a BPI range from tingling and numbness to not being able to use your arm at all. Some BPIs heal on their own. Others cause permanent disability."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "BPI can result in several different kinds of nerve damage. Some BPIs heal on their own with the help of physical or other kinds of therapy. Recovery may take weeks or months. If you need surgery to repair the nerves, it may be five to 12 months before the surgery is performed. Surgery is sometimes postponed to allow the nerves an opportunity to heal on their own."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "BPI can be a common injury from contact sports or vehicle accidents."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Some injuries heal on their own after several weeks or months. The doctor may prescribe pain medication as well as physical therapy to protect the function of the joints and muscles. If the injury doesn't heal on its own, the doctor will likely recommend surgery, which is usually done five months to a year after the initial injury."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Brachial plexus nerve injuries need a doctor's care."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Continuing to strain or stretch the arm and shoulder"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "Call the doctor if you notice symptoms of BPI, especially if you have been involved in an accident or have had surgery."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\t\t•\tHow long will it take to regain use of my arm?\n\t\t•\tWill I still be able to take part in my usual recreation or work activities?\n\t\t•\tHow long will the pain last? 		},

			"heading": "Bursitis (Subdeltoid)",
			"content": "Subacromial bursitis"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tJoint pain\n\t\t•\tStiffness or decreased movement\n\t\t•\tWarm to touch\n\t\t•\tSwelling\n\t\t•\tSkin redness\n\t\t•\tTenderness to touch"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Subdeltoid bursitis is an inflammation of the small sacks of fluid (bursa) that cushion bones and muscles around your shoulder joint. Usually, this inflammation is caused by an injury or overuse of the shoulder. It causes pain that develops over the front inside part of your shoulder, sometimes spreading down the arm. This pain may come on suddenly after an injury or develop gradually over time. You may feel it only with activity or all the time. The pain may come and go, but doesn't usually heal on its own. Treatment can range from anti-inflammatories and physical therapy to injections of corticosteroids or anesthetic."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "If the shoulder is injured, symptoms of bursitis can appear quickly. More often, symptoms develop and get worse over time from overuse of the shoulder joint. Anti-inflammatories and physical therapy may help you recover, although it can take weeks for pain to subside. If it does not get better, the doctor may suggest an injection of corticosteroids and local anesthetic. If you have an injection, pain may increase for a few days following treatment and then subside. If you experience partial relief or if symptoms return, the doctor may suggest a repeat injection 4 to 6 weeks later. You should typically have no more than 4 injections within a year."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Shoulder problems account for about 7.5 million visits to the doctor each year in the U.S."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment may include:\n\t\t•\tNonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDS)\n\t\t•\tPhysical therapy, including special exercises\n\t\t•\tInjection of corticosteroid and local anesthetic\n\t\t•\tAntibiotics if the bursitis is infectious\n\nFollowing injection, apply ice wrapped in a thin towel to the affected area for 20 minutes 2 or 3 times daily for 1 or 2 days. Several days later, begin heat and gentle stretching, but no overhead activities or vigorous exercise until your doctor says it's okay."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "To control symptoms on your own, rest your shoulder, take nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDS) if your doctor says it's okay, and try massage, which helps some people."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Certain movements, such as a tennis serve or carrying or supporting a partner while dancing or skating"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "See a doctor if pain does not get better with self-care or you cannot do your usual activities."
		},

		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "Subdeltoid bursitis can be hard to diagnose, because symptoms can vary greatly from person to person. The doctor may diagnose subdeltoid bursitis with a physical exam, by checking your range of motion, and noting symptoms of pain and swelling with palpation. Sometimes, a special injection can help diagnose the problem as well as treat it. If pain lessens after injection, subdeltoid bursitis is more likely the cause."

	"Frozen_shoulder": [{
			"heading": "Frozen Shoulder",
			"content": "Adhesive capsulitis"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tJoint pain\n\t\t•\tStiffness or decreased movement"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Frozen shoulder causes increasing pain and stiffness in the shoulder. Eventually pain may cause the joint to\"freeze,\" making movement difficult. Frozen shoulder may result from inflammation or scarring of the tissue that surrounds the shoulder joint. Frozen shoulder typically clears up on its own. Medications and physical therapy can help ease discomfort and improve movement."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Frozen shoulder progresses through three stages. Pain and stiffness increase during the\"freezing\" stage. Range of motion is most severely limited during the\"frozen\" stage. Then the disease enters a\"thaw,\" where pain and stiffness gradually ease. Full recovery may take from six months to two years."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Frozen shoulder occurs in about 2% of the general population."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "The causes of frozen shoulder aren't well understood. Frozen shoulder occurs much more frequently in people with diabetes. Hypothyroidism, hyperthyroidism, Parkinson's disease, and heart disease also are linked to frozen shoulder. The problem can develop after a shoulder has been immobilized after surgery or an injury. One way to prevent frozen shoulder is to move the joint as soon after surgery or an injury as possible."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Frozen shoulder generally gets better over time, although full recovery may take several years. Treatment focuses on controlling pain and restoring motion. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications such as aspirin and ibuprofen reduce pain and swelling. Steroid injections may be prescribed to suppress inflammation in the shoulder joint. Physical therapy often helps improve range of motion. If pain and stiffness don't improve, your doctor may consider surgery. One approach involves stretching the tissue around the shoulder to break down any scar tissue. Another approach, called shoulder arthroscopy, uses pencil-sized instruments inserted through tiny incisions to cut through tight portions of the lining of the shoulder."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Over-the-counter pain relievers can ease the discomfort of frozen shoulder. Heat applied to the shoulder area also can ease pain. Gently moving your shoulder will help keep it more flexible. It's wise to talk to your doctor about specific exercises to do."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "Call your doctor if shoulder pain or stiffness persists for more than several weeks or gets in the way of doing everyday activities."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\t\t•\tCould my symptoms be caused by an underlying condition that should be treated, such as diabetes?\n\t\t•\tWhat kinds of exercises can I do to prevent my shoulder from becoming more stiff?\n\t\t•\tWhat pain relievers should I use to control the pain?\n\t\t•\tHow long will it be before the symptoms begin to resolve?"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "Your doctor will gently move your shoulder and arm to test your range of motion and see where pain occurs. Your doctor will also ask you to move your shoulder on your own to see how much your range of motion is limited. Tests such as X-rays, magnetic resonance imaging (MRIs), and ultrasound may be used to rule out problems such as arthritis or torn rotator cuff injuries."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Moving your shoulder may worsen the pain of frozen shoulder. Unfortunately, being inactive may cause more stiffness and further limit range of motion. On balance, doctors say it's wise to try to move your shoulder as much as you can."
		}

	"Separated_shoulder": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tJoint pain\n\t\t•\tLump or bulge\n\t\t•\tUnable to move arm\n\t\t•\tStiffness or decreased movement\n\t\t•\tVisible deformity"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "A separated shoulder occurs when the ligaments that hold the collar bone to the shoulder blade tear. It can be partial, with mild pain, or complete, with severe pain and a bump or bulge above the shoulder. A blow to the outside of the shoulder or falling directly on the shoulder commonly causes it. Usually, a separated shoulder heals on its own, but sometimes surgery is necessary."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "Call emergency services if you have a weak pulse or if a severe blow caused the injury. If you have severe pain, cold or numb fingers, very limited range of motion, or shoulder deformity, go immediately to a hospital emergency room or contact your doctor."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "With a mild shoulder separation, the ligament is sprained and the collarbone doesn't move. You may have mild pain. In a more severe case, one or two ligaments may be torn and the collarbone is out of alignment. In the most severe case, two ligaments are torn and the joint is deformed. This is very painful. Ice, rest, and medication can relieve swelling and pain, and a sling can provide comfort while the joint begins to heal. If you have significant deformity, you may need surgery to reconstruct the ligaments. With or without surgery, you'll need rehabilitation to regain motion, strength, and flexibility. The more severe a separation is, the longer it takes to recover pain-free use of your shoulder. But most people recover full function in a short amount of time."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Complete separation, other injuries to the shoulder"
		},

	"Hyperhidrosis": [{
			"heading": "Hyperhidrosis",
			"content": "Hyperidrosis, polyhidrosis, excessive sweating, palmoplantar hyperhidrosis, gustatory hyperhidrosis, generalized hyperhidrosis, primary focal hyperhidrosis"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tExcessive sweating"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Hyperhidrosis occurs when an overactive nervous system produces overactive sweat glands. This excessive sweating can begin as early as childhood or as late as adulthood. You may have excessive sweating limited to one area, such as the soles of the feet, palms of the hands, face, or underarms (primary focal hyperhidrosis). Or it may affect your entire body (generalized hyperhidrosis). Excessive sweating can have a profound impact on your life and your work, especially if you have it on the palms of the hands. Wet clothing and shoes from too much sweating may be uncomfortable, embarrassing, and costly. Medications, special antiperspirants, Botox injections, and electromagnetic treatments can help. In severe cases, doctors may recommend surgery to remove sweat glands."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Nearly 8 million Americans have hyperhidrosis."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Endocrine disorders, neurological problems, certain drugs, cancer, chronic infection, dermatologic syndromes, conditions associated with excess catecholamine discharge, parotid surgery, diabetes, family history, pregnancy or menopause, certain foods"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Depending upon the type of hyperhidrosis and the area affected, your doctor may recommend:\n\t\t•\tAdjustment of your medications, if any\n\t\t•\tTopical aluminum chloride antiperspirant\n\t\t•\tTap water iontophoresis, a weak electrical current applied to the skin's surface\n\t\t•\tOral anti-anxiety medication\n\t\t•\tBotox injection\n\t\t•\tElectromagnetic energy delivered with a handheld device\n\t\t•\tLocal sweat gland excision by curettage or liposuction\n\t\t•\tEndoscopic thoracic sympathectomy (ETS), removal of a part of the sympathetic nervous system"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "These self-care tips may help relieve symptoms:\n\t\t•\tDiscuss with your doctor how to apply topical aluminum chloride antiperspirants.\n\t\t•\tAvoid foods or beverages that stimulate sweating, such as coffee, spicy foods, alcohol, sweets, or foods and drinks with citric acid.\n\t\t•\tKeep your feet as dry as possible with absorbent powder and shoe insoles.\n\t\t•\tWear moisture-wicking socks."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "Some serious conditions can cause hyperhidrosis, so consult a doctor if you have excessive sweating. Get immediate medical care if you have sweating followed by chest pain or pressure or sweating with a rapid heartbeat."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",

		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "The doctor conducts a physical exam and history and possibly tests to diagnose your type of hyperhidrosis and the impact on your quality of life. Gravimetric measurement on the palm or armpits can assess the rate of sweat production. A starch-iodine test assesses the area involved in excessive sweating."

			"content": "Emotional or physical stress, heat, humidity, exercise"

Sometimes a broken bone breaks through the skin. In that case, the wound will be treated and you will be given antibiotics to prevent infection. To ease pain and stiffness, your doctor may recommend either over-the-counter or prescription pain medicine. Applying ice to your elbow will help reduce swelling. Stiffness can be a problem with this injury, so your doctor will recommend exercises to begin to use the joint as soon as the bone is adequately healed."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "A broken elbow requires emergency medical attention. Do not attempt to straighten the elbow or push the bones back in place yourself. To ease pain and swelling, apply an ice pack to the affected area while you await medical help or make your way to an emergency room."

	"Sickle_cell_crisis": [{
			"heading": "Sickle Cell Crisis",
			"content": "Related to sickle cell disease"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tJoint pain"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "A sickle cell crisis is an urgent condition associated with sickle cell disease, a hereditary condition most common in people of African ancestry. It occurs when sickle-shaped blood cells, which are caused by defective hemoglobin, can't move smoothly through some blood vessels. This blocks blood flow to parts of the body, causing a sickle cell crisis -- sudden pain that may require emergency or hospital treatment. Infections, dehydration, and other conditions can bring on a sickle cell crisis. In adults especially, repeated sickle cell crises can cause organ or bone damage. There's no cure for sickle cell disease, but they are ways to help reduce sickle cell crises."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "Go to a hospital emergency room if you have uncontrollable pain or fever, dehydration (often from vomiting), chest pain or shortness of breath, severe abdominal pain, or if you cannot see your doctor immediately for other symptoms of sickle cell crisis."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Most people with sickle cell disease have a sickle cell crisis at some point. Some people have one per year or one per month. You may suddenly have a throbbing, dull, or stabbing pain in your back, knees, legs, arms, chest, or stomach. The pain may be mild or severe, and last hours or more than a week. You may also have shortness of breath, fever, or vomiting. If the pain is mild, over-the-counter acetaminophen may help, but avoid ibuprofen or naproxen unless your doctor says you can take them safely. Your doctor may also prescribe a mild pain reliever. If pain is severe, you may need treatment in an emergency room or hospital. You'll be given intravenous fluids, pain medication, and antibiotics if you have an infection. You may need a blood transfusion and oxygen if you have severe anemia. With lifestyle changes, you may be able to prevent some future sickle cell crises."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Dehydration, overexertion, menstrual period"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for a sickle cell crisis focuses on reducing pain. It may include:\n\t\t•\tOver-the-counter anti-inflammatory medications such as ibuprofen or aspirin\n\t\t•\tUsing a heating pad or taking hot baths\n\t\t•\tRelaxation techniques\n\t\t•\tMassage to decrease muscle stiffness\n\t\t•\tPhysical therapy – gentle exercise and heat and cold treatments\n\t\t•\tIntravenous fluid and medicine\n\t\t•\tOxygen therapy\n\t\t•\tNarcotic pain medication\n\t\t•\tAntidepressants\n\t\t•\tAnticonvulsant medication\n\t\t•\tTreatment for the cause, such as antibiotics for infection\n\nLong-term treatments to control sickle cell disease, such as hydroxyurea, a daily medication that prevents red blood cells from\"sickling\" and reduces the number of crises"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "These self-care strategies may help you prevent a sickle cell crisis:\n\t\t•\tDon't smoke or drink a lot of alcohol.\n\t\t•\tAvoid decongestants such as pseudoephedrine, which can tighten blood vessels.\n\t\t•\tAvoid extremes of heat and cold.\n\t\t•\tExercise regularly, but not to the point of exhaustion.\n\t\t•\tDrink plenty of water, especially when it's hot or you exercise.\n\t\t•\tCall your doctor right away if you have signs of infection such as fever or trouble breathing.\n\t\t•\tGet a flu shot or other vaccines recommended by your doctor.\n\t\t•\tControl other medical conditions, such as diabetes.\n\t\t•\tGet early prenatal care if you become pregnant.\n\t\t•\tAsk your doctor about whether to take oxygen if you'll be traveling to a high altitude.\n\t\t•\tTry to reduce stress. Consider joining a support group or getting counseling."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "See your doctor if you have pain that isn't controlled by your usual pain medication or is different than usual, you are in danger of dehydration (from causes such as vomiting, diarrhea, or inability to drink or keep down liquids), or you are getting an infection. If you can't see your doctor immediately for these symptoms, go to a hospital emergency room."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\t\t•\tCould a sickle cell crisis or another condition be causing my symptoms?\n\t\t•\tWhat tests do I need\n\t\t•\tCan I treat this sickle cell crisis at home ? \n\t\t•\tIf I need hospitalization,\n\t\t•\twhat treatments do I need ? \n\t\t•\tHow can I prevent a sickle cell crisis in the future?"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "To diagnose a sickle cell crisis, the doctor will take a medical history, ask about behavior or activities that may have brought on a crisis (such as pregnancy, alcohol or drug use, dehydration, infection, or bleeding), order blood and urine tests, and may do a CT scan or spinal tap. If you have not been diagnosed with sickle cell anemia, the doctor will ask about your family history of sickle cell disease."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 90,000 to 100,000 people in the U.S. have sickle cell disease."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "If you have sickle cell disease, risk factors for a sickle cell crisis include overexertion, being at a high altitude, smoking, drinking alcohol, dehydration, stress, infection, cold exposure (such as cold weather or swimming in cold water), pregnancy"

	"Bursitis_(olecranon)": [{
			"heading": "Bursitis (Olecranon)",
			"content": "Elbow bursitis, baker's elbow"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tLump or bulge\n\t\t•\tStiffness or decreased movement\n\t\t•\tVisible deformity\n\t\t•\tTenderness to touch\n\t\t•\tSwelling\n\t\t•\tSkin redness\n\t\t•\tWarm to touch\n\t\t•\tJoint pain"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Bursitis is inflammation or infection of the fluid-filled sacs, called bursa, which cushion tendons and bones throughout the body. Bursitis of the elbow occurs when the olecranon bursa at the pointy tip of the elbow becomes irritated or inflamed. Persistent pressure or a blow to the elbow can cause olecranon bursitis. It can also be caused by an infection. If bursitis is caused by inflammation, it will usually go away on its own with rest and time. If you have infectious bursitis, your doctor will drain the fluid and give you an antibiotic."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Elbow bursitis usually goes away on its own with rest and over-the-counter anti-inflammatory medications such as aspirin or ibuprofen. If the bursitis is caused by an infection, however, the area may need to be drained with a needle every few days until the infection is eliminated."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "If your bursitis is caused by an infection, your doctor will drain the fluid from the bursa and prescribe an antibiotic. If the bursitis is caused by inflammation, your doctor may recommend wearing an elbow pad to cushion your elbow, avoiding activities that put pressure on the swollen area, and taking over-the-counter anti-inflammatory medications such as aspirin or ibuprofen. If swelling and pain continue after a few weeks, your doctor may use a needle to remove some fluid from the bursa to ease the pressure and then inject a corticosteroid medication to reduce inflammation. If this isn't enough to relieve your symptoms, your doctor may recommend surgery to remove the bursa. A new bursa will grow back in a few weeks."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "You may be able to relieve the symptoms of bursitis on your own by protecting the joint with an elbow pad, resting the affected area, icing the joint to ease pain and swelling, using compression (elastic bandages), elevating the area to keep blood from pooling, and taking medications such as aspirin and ibuprofen to reduce inflammation."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Continuing to use a painful joint"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "Because elbow bursitis can be infectious, it's important to see a doctor if the symptoms are occurring for the first time. If you've already been diagnosed with bursitis and experience a flare-up, you can try to treat it at home with self care. If the pain persists, make an appointment with your doctor."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\t\t•\tIs the pain I'm experiencing caused by elbow bursitis?\n\t\t•\tDo I have an infection?\n\t\t•\tIf so, will it need to be drained?\n\t\t•\tWill I need to take an antibiotic?\n\t\t•\tWhat can I do to ease the symptoms?\n\t\t•\tShould I rest the elbow?\n\t\t•\tHow long will it be before the pain goes away?\n\t\t•\tWhen can I resume my normal activities?\n\t\t•\tWhat can I do to prevent this from happening again?"
		},

			"content": "Doctors can usually diagnose elbow bursitis simply by evaluating symptoms and examining the affected area. It may take several months for your arm to heal completely. During that time you will have to do strengthening and range-of-motion exercises. 	"Median_nerve_injury": [{
			"heading": "Median Nerve Injury",
			"content": "Carpal tunnel syndrome, pronator syndrome"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tNumbness or tingling\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "The median nerve is an important nerve in your arm and hand. If you damage it with repetitive stress or an injury it swells, causing pain and numbness in the wrist, hand, and all the fingers but the pinky. Carpal tunnel syndrome is the most common median nerve injury -- the nerve gets pinched in the wrist. Jobs that involve repetitive motions -- whether clicking a mouse or swinging a hammer -- can cause it. So can sports injuries and conditions such as arthritis, tendinitis, diabetes, thyroid problems, and pregnancy. Rest and pain relief are common treatments. Some people need surgery."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "An injury such as a fractured wrist can trigger sudden median nerve damage. It usually develops more slowly. Chronic repetitive stress on the wrist can cause it. The exact symptoms and treatment depend on where the nerve is damaged. Rest may be the best treatment. Stop doing anything that worsens the symptoms. Medication can help with pain while you heal. Untreated median nerve damage can lead to chronic pain and permanent weakness."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",

			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "The ulnar nerve runs down the arm and into the hand. If you damage the nerve with repetitive stress or a sudden injury it swells, causing pain and numbness in the forearm, hand, and ring and little fingers. Sports that require gripping or catching, such as tennis, golf, baseball, and bicycling, can cause it. So can the repetitive stress of typing, using a mouse, or leaning on the elbow. As long as you rest the area and allow it to heal, you probably will have no lasting problems."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "The ulnar nerve plays a key role in your hand's ability to feel and move. Injuries, such as a broken arm, can cause sudden ulnar nerve damage. It usually develops more slowly. Chronic repetitive stress or pressure on the palm or elbow can cause it. The exact symptoms depend on where the nerve is irritated. Usually, a few weeks of rest is the best treatment. Medication can help with pain while you heal. Untreated ulnar nerve damage can lead to chronic pain and permanent damage to the hand."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "The main nerve to the hand, called the median nerve, passes through a band of tendons in the wrist called the carpal tunnel. Carpal tunnel syndrome occurs when the area becomes inflamed, pinching the nerve and causing tingling and numbness in the hand and fingers. Repetitive movement from computer work, factory work, or anything that stresses the wrist and forearms can lead to carpal tunnel syndrome. The condition can also cause hand weakness, making it hard to grip objects. Carpal tunnel can run in families. Obesity, diabetes, arthritis, pregnancy, and other conditions often occur with carpal tunnel syndrome. However, anyone with repetitive stress of the hand or wrist can develop the condition."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Carpal tunnel syndrome usually starts slowly with tingling and numbness in the hand and fingers. Often, symptoms start at night. Eventually, tingling and numbness occurs during the day. These sensations may move up to the elbow. Hand weakness develops, making it hard to make a fist or grasp objects. In severe cases, the muscle behind the thumb wastes away. Changing your workspace, taking medication, using wrist braces, and even surgery can relieve symptoms."
		},

			"heading": "How Common",

	"Broken_(Colles_fractured)_wrist": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tBroken bone (single fracture)\n\t\t•\tSwelling\n\t\t•\tBruising or discoloration\n\t\t•\tTenderness to touch\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tWeakness\n\t\t•\tVisible deformity\n\t\t•\tJoint pain"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "A Colles fracture is the most common type of broken bone in the wrist. It happens when the larger of the two bones in your forearm, the radius, breaks near the wrist. It requires prompt medical care so that it heals properly. Otherwise, you may have permanent damage that can make it difficult to use your hand for simple daily tasks. You're also more likely to have continued pain and arthritis in the wrist. Landing on an outstretched hand during a fall is the usual cause of a broken wrist. You may feel immediate pain, swelling, bruising, and tenderness. Your wrist might look crooked or deformed. With prompt casting or surgery, most people recover well."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "Go to a hospital emergency room if a broken wrist is very painful or deformed, you can’t move your wrist, your fingers are numb or discolored, or bone protrudes through the skin."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "When determining the best treatment for a Colles fracture, your doctor will consider factors such as your activity level, hand dominance, bone density, and the nature of the break. If your broken bone is in a good position, the doctor may put it in a splint or cast for about six weeks. If the bone is out of alignment -- and likely to limit use of your wrist in the future -- the doctor may be able to straighten your arm nonsurgically before putting it in a splint or cast. If the bone is badly displaced or shattered into many pieces, you may need surgery. Metal pins or a plate and screws may be implanted to set and stabilize the bone. In some cases, the surgeon uses an external fixator – pins attached to a device on the outside of your arm. After surgery or when your cast is off, you may need physical therapy to help restore wrist movement. You can probably return to light activity in a month or two, and to vigorous activity within six months. Full recovery takes about a year. Depending on the severity of the injury, you could have minor pain and stiffness for another year or develop arthritis in the area."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Thin bone density, injuries from a motorcycle accident, or a fall from a roof or ladder"

		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "A ganglion cyst is a sac-like swelling that forms from the tissue that lines a joint or tendon. These cysts are filled with a jelly-like fluid and commonly grow on wrists and ankles. Ganglion cysts are noncancerous and usually harmless. They may be nearly invisible and have no symptoms. The exact cause is unknown. Often they rupture and go away without treatment. Ganglion cysts that develop in the joint at the end of the finger, called mucous cysts, may be a sign of arthritis. Larger cysts can interfere with joint movement or press on nerves, causing pain. When needed, treatment involves removing fluid from the cysts with a needle or surgically removing the cyst."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Ganglion cysts appear as small, soft bumps that can form on any joint, but usually on the wrist or ankle. They range in size from less than ½ inch to 1½ inches. The cysts may change in size, disappear, and then reappear. While usually painless, a ganglion cyst that presses on nerves may cause pain and limit joint movement. When cysts cause problems, treatment includes removing fluid from the cyst with a needle or surgical removal."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "This condition occurs when the radial nerve in the mid-upper arm is injured. It gets its colorful name from the fact that it often occurs when someone is intoxicated and falls asleep with an arm across the back of a chair. Another common name is\"Honeymooner's Palsy,\" referring to when a couple falls asleep with one person's arm squeezed under the other's body. Nerve damage causes a characteristic symptom called hand drop. When the hand is held out -- palm facing down -- the wrist can't support it and the hand drops. Saturday Night Palsy usually goes away over time when the arm is splinted and put in a sling."

	"Raynaud_phenomenon": [{
			"heading": "Raynaud's Phenomenon",
			"content": "Raynaud's syndrome or raynaud's disease"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tBlue colored skin\n\t\t•\tColor change\n\t\t•\tCold feet\n\t\t•\tSkin open sore\n\t\t•\tCold hands"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Raynaud's phenomenon occurs when cold, emotional stress, or other exposure causes small arteries in the body to tighten, decreasing blood supply to those areas. It is most common in women. People usually get it in their fingers and toes, but it can also affect the nose, lips, or earlobes. It is known for causing\"red, white, and blue\" skin discolorations, as the blood vessels narrow and then dilate. Staying warm, decreasing stress, and other lifestyle changes usually clear it up. Raynaud's is more serious when caused by a connective tissue disease such as scleroderma, lupus, or Sjögren's syndrome."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Exposure to cold and emotional stress usually trigger Raynaud's attacks, or spasms. Smoking and working with vibrating machinery are other triggers. You may experience three skin color changes: white as the arteries collapse, blue when the area is not getting enough oxygen-rich blood, and red (or purple or mottled) as blood returns. An attack can last less than a minute or for several hours."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Raynaud's phenomenon affects 3%-5% of people in the U.S."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "If you're having an attack, warm your feet and hands (or other affected areas) and try relaxation techniques. Other general treatments include:\n\t\t•\tKeeping warm\n\t\t•\tWearing socks, hats, gloves, or mittens in the cold\n\t\t•\tUsing chemical warmers in mittens, pockets, or shoes when outdoors\n\t\t•\tAvoiding smoking and secondhand smoke\n\t\t•\tAvoiding tools that vibrate the hands\n\t\t•\tDecreasing stress\n\t\t•\tAvoiding medications that can aggravate blood vessel spasms\n\t\t•\tAvoiding tight-fitting rings, shoes, or wristbands\n\t\t•\tTaking medication, usually in the case of secondary Raynaud's"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Cold weather, cold water, stress, certain medications"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "See a doctor if you have symptoms of Raynaud's phenomenon, such as color changes in the skin of fingers, toes, lips, ears, nose, or nipples. The affected areas may turn cold, pale, tingly, and numb, and you may feel pain as circulation returns."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\t\t•\tIs there anything I might be doing to cause this?\n\t\t•\tDo I have any conditions that might be causing Raynaud's?\n\t\t•\tWhat can I do to prevent Raynaud's attacks?"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",

	"Acrocyanosis": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tBlue colored skin\n\t\t•\tCold hands\n\t\t•\tExcessive sweating\n\t\t•\tCold feet"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Acrocyanosis is a painless condition in which the hands and feet turn shades of blue, become cold, and sweat. It occurs when the skin's small blood vessels narrow and limit oxygen flow to hands and feet. Acrocyanosis doesn't cause health problems, but it can be uncomfortable and embarrassing. Women tend to develop acrocyanosis more than men. Usually, acrocyanosis is not treated. But in severe cases, medicine or surgery may be recommended."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Acrocyanosis is a long-term condition, but it isn't dangerous. Even without treatment, acrocyanosis doesn't get worse."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Acrocyanosis is fairly common. Because the condition usually isn't treated, however, there aren't firm numbers. It's more common in children and adults younger than 30 years."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "People often don't get treatment for acrocyanosis. They learn to live with it. If you have a broken bone, the doctor will set it then use a splint or cast to keep the bone in place as it heals. Depending on the location of the break and how severe it is, surgery may be used to hold bones in place with wire, plates, pins, or screws. Pain relievers will ease pain and reduce swelling. In about 3 weeks, you can often start gentle hand exercises. The doctor will typically remove the cast in about 3 to 6 weeks, after your bones have healed. In some cases, the fingers will be shorter than they were, but this won't affect your ability to use your hand."

			"heading": "Dyshidrotic Eczema",
			"content": "Acute palmoplantar eczema, dyshidrosis, pompholyx"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tExcessive sweating\n\t\t•\tFlaking skin\n\t\t•\tSkin rash"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Dyshidrotic eczema, or dyshidrosis, is a skin condition affecting the palms of the hands, soles of the feet, or both. Small fluid-filled bumps appear, usually along the edges of the fingers, palms, and soles of the feet. Blisters may be intensely itchy and even painful, making it hard to use your hands or walk. After a few weeks, the blisters dry up and skin flakes off. In more severe cases, the skin becomes red and cracked. The exact cause is unknown, but stress, allergies, frequent hand-washing, and exposure to chromium, nickel, or cobalt seem to trigger outbreaks. Dyshidrotic eczema often occurs in spring and summer and in warmer climates. Some people have outbreaks just once a year, while others may have them monthly. Chronic dyshidrosis can cause thickened skin and pits, ridges, thickening, and discoloration of nails. Treatment includes ointments and creams, antihistamines, corticosteroid creams or pills, and phototherapy."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Blisters develop suddenly and may itch intensely. Larger blisters may be painful. The rash dries out after 2 to 3 weeks and the skin peels. More severe cases make it difficult to use your hands or feet and even work because of itching, large blisters, and pain. Scratching can cause skin thickness and irritation, which makes it harder to treat. Treatment with ointments or creams and antihistamines helps ease mild symptoms. Corticosteroid ointments, pills, other prescription medications, and phototherapy can help treat more severe cases."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Half of people who have dyshidrotic eczema also have atopic dermatitis, or typical eczema."

		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "A pinched nerve in the neck can cause pain that radiates into the shoulder and arm. The medical term for this condition is cervical radiculopathy. A stinger refers to an injury either at the neck or shoulder, which causes a burning or stinging pain that travels from the shoulder to the hand. Most of the time the pain goes away. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs can help ease the discomfort."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "A pinched nerve typically causes a sharp, stinging or burning pain that travels down the arm. The pain may be so sharp that it feels like an electric shock. A pinched nerve can also cause\"pins and needles,\" complete numbness, or weakness in the arm and hand muscles. Extending or straining your neck may make the pain worse. Most pinched nerves get better on their own. But sometimes the pain can go on for hours or days. Unfortunately, if you've suffered one pinched nerve, you're likely to have the problem again."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "No one keeps track of pinched nerves. But one study found that up to 70% of college football players had a burner or stinger during their college careers."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Most pinched nerves go away on their own. If the pain continues, your doctor may recommend physical therapy to stretch and strengthen your neck. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs such as aspirin and ibuprofen help ease lingering pain. A soft collar worn around your neck can help the muscles of your neck to rest and recover. Some patients feel better with acupuncture treatments. If these approaches don't relieve your pain, your doctor may recommend surgery. The goals of surgery are to ease the pressure on the nerve and stabilize the spine. The operation involves removing bone or soft tissue to make more space for nerves."
		},

			"heading": "Symptoms",

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Water retention (edema) occurs when extra fluid builds up in the body's tissues, causing parts of the body to become swollen or puffy. It usually affects the feet, ankles, legs, face, or hands. It can be caused by many things, including sitting or standing too long, eating too much salt, taking certain medicines or treatments such as chemotherapy. Anyone can have water retention. It often affects pregnant women, older adults, and people with medical conditions such as liver disease, kidney disease, or heart failure. Changing your diet and physical activity can help, but sometimes you need medication to reduce severe water retention. Less often, an allergic reaction causes water retention in the airways or on the face. This is an emergency requiring urgent care."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Depending upon its cause, water retention can be temporary or permanent. For example, fluid retention from changing hormone levels in women usually goes away on its own. In many cases, making lifestyle changes will reduce water retention. In serious cases, medication and other measures may help make it manageable. In rare cases, you need urgent care for water retention that affects the airways."

	"Frostbite": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tBlack colored skin\n\t\t•\tNumbness or tingling"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Frostbite happens when the skin and the tissue underneath freezes after being exposed to cold temperatures for too long. The area may be numb and discolored. Frostbite is most common in the fingers, toes, ears, and nose, although it can develop anywhere. It's important to treat frostbite right away to prevent more damage. You can treat mild cases with first aid, but severe cases need emergency medical attention. Untreated or severe frostbite can lead to permanent injury and nerve damage. Anyone can get frostbite, but smoking, alcohol use, certain medications, diabetes, and other conditions increase the risk. Anyone with frostbite is also at risk for hypothermia, which can be life threatening."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "Anyone with frostbite needs medical help as soon as possible. Watch for signs of hypothermia -- such as constant shivering or a body temperature below 95 degrees -- which is life threatening."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "A person with frostbite needs to get out of the cold and take off any wet clothes. If it's not possible to get to a doctor or emergency room immediately, try to warm the affected area slowly. Soak the area in warm -- not hot -- water. If there is any risk that the area could freeze again, do not try to thaw it. As the tissue warms up, the area may swell and turn red. The pain may be intense. The longer the tissue was frozen, the more severe the injury. Minor frostbite doesn't usually cause lasting problems. If it's severe, the damage may be permanent. Some people need amputation."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Not getting treatment, alcohol, smoking, refreezing the area"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatments for frostbite include:\n\t\t•\tFinding shelter\n\t\t•\tElevating the area\n\t\t•\tSoaking the area in warm water -- 104 degrees to 108 degrees Fahrenheit -- for 20 to 30 minutes\n\t\t•\tPain relievers\n\t\t•\tIV fluids\n\t\t•\tRemoval of dead tissue, in severe cases\n\t\t•\tSurgery\n\t\t•\tAntibiotics, if skin is infected"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Only use moist heat -- at about 104 degrees to 108 degrees Fahrenheit -- to thaw out an area with frostbite. Dry heat from a radiator or space heater could injure the tissue. Don't rub the area and try not to move it much. Remove watches or any jewelry that could constrict the area. Drink warm nonalcoholic and caffeine-free drinks. Don't walk on frostbitten feet."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "If you have numbness, skin color changes, or pain after cold exposure, see a doctor right away."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\t\t•\tHow serious is the damage?\n\t\t•\tHow long will I have pain?\n\t\t•\tWhat treatments do I need?\n\t\t•\tWhat's my prognosis?"

			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Broken, or fractured, fingers are among the most common injuries. A broken finger may seem like no big deal, but if it isn't treated promptly, it can put your hand out of alignment, leading to long-term pain and limited movement. Slamming fingers in a door, falling on an outstretched hand, or jamming a finger in sports commonly causes broken fingers. A splint or cast and rehab exercises will usually heal it. If you have pain and swelling and think your finger may be broken, see a doctor right away or go to a hospital emergency room."

		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "If you fracture your finger, you'll probably have immediate sharp pain and it may be crooked. Bending it will hurt, but it may be only dull pain. Within minutes, it may swell, bruise, and stiffen too much to move. Treatment depends on the bone in the finger that is fractured and the type of break. The doctor will put the bone back in place, if necessary, and put on a splint or cast to keep it straight while it heals. It may also be\"buddy-taped\" to the fingers next to it for extra support. You'll need to wear a splint for three weeks or more. Then you'll probably need physical therapy exercises to reduce stiffness and restore movement. In some cases, a broken finger requires surgery to insert pins, screws, or wire to hold the fractured bones together. Depending on how severe the injury is, it may take up to several months to fully recover."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Not getting treatment, continuing to use the finger"
		},

			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Skier's thumb is an injury to a ligament in the thumb. The ligament, which connects bones and helps keep the thumb stable, may tear or stretch. It's called skier's thumb because skier's who fall with a ski pole in their hand often get this injury. Skier's thumb also can occur when you jam your thumb and it bends to the side or backward, when you fall on an outstretched hand, or when your thumb is hooked over the steering wheel during a car crash. Keeping your hand immobilized can help with healing. More serious cases may require surgery. Recovery can last from weeks to months, depending on the severity of the injury."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "If the ligament is partly torn, you will need to keep your hand in a cast for about a month. Then you will wear a removable splint for a few weeks, and do range-of-motion exercises with your hand. If the ligament is completely torn, you will need surgery, followed by a cast to keep the thumb immobilized. After the cast is removed, you will need to do exercises to strengthen your thumb. Healing takes about three to four months. Complications include numbness from nerve injury and stiffness if you don't exercise your hand. Other problems can include long-term pain and a weak thumb joint."

	"Paronychia": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tDrainage or pus\n\t\t•\tSwelling\n\t\t•\tTenderness to touch\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tSkin redness"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Paronychia is a skin infection that causes pain and swelling around the fingernail or toenail. You can get it from aggressive nail biting or clipping, sucking on fingers, pulling hangnails, or from an ingrown toenail. Staphylococcus aureus infection usually causes acute paronychia, sometimes in just one nail. Warm water soaks and antibiotics often clear it up. When skin irritation becomes infected, it can cause chronic paronychia. This more stubborn condition may affect several nails at once and require ongoing treatment. Women and people with diabetes or compromised immune systems are most at risk."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Acute paronychia can come on quickly, with redness, pain, and swelling around the base or side of the nail. A few days of treatment can clear this up. If you also have abscesses, pus-filled pockets that can make walking in shoes very painful, they will need to be drained. If you have diabetes, paronychia could spread to the bloodstream, as well as to deeper tissues and bones. Chronic paronychia develops gradually. You may have symptoms on and off, especially after your nails have been exposed to water or moisture. The nail may also separate from the skin, creating a space for yeasts and bacteria to grow. Your nail may become rigid, green, and brittle. You'll probably need to treat chronic paronychia for several months with topical creams or lotions, and possibly with oral antifungal medication."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Paronychia is the most common hand infection."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatments include:\n\t\t•\tWarm water soaks (for acute paronychia)\n\t\t•\tKeeping nails dry (for chronic paronychia)\n\t\t•\tAvoiding exposure to the cause\n\t\t•\tAbscess draining\n\t\t•\tOral antibiotics or antifungal medication\n\t\t•\tTopical steroid cream or solution\n\t\t•\tSurgery"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "For acute paronychia, soak your affected nails in warm water three or four times a day. Wear vinyl gloves to protect your skin from water or use a skin-drying cream, and keep nails clean and dry. An over-the-counter antibiotic ointment may also be helpful."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Tight shoes, picking at area, water exposure."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "Call your doctor if:\n\t\t•\tWarm soaks don't clear up the problem in a few days\n\t\t•\tYou see pus or an abscess\n\t\t•\tYou have fever, chills, red streaks running from the infection toward your body, or you have joint or muscle pain\n\t\t•\tIf the infection seems to have spread under the nail"

	"Fingernail_injury": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tRed or black spots on fingernails"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Fingernail injuries are typically bruises under the nail, cracks in the nail, or separation of the nail from the nail bed. Cuts and crush injuries – such as closing a door on a finger – usually cause them. They can also involve other damage to the finger, such as bone fractures. Some fingernail injuries should be treated in a hospital emergency room. In some cases, surgery may be needed to reconstruct the nail bed. Severe fingernail injuries usually cause deformity to the nail."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "If your nail is discolored from bleeding under it, you have a subungual hematoma. This usually occurs from a direct blow to the nail, and can be very painful. Small hematomas may be absorbed by the body in a week, but large hematomas under the nail may take months to reabsorb. If you have a nail laceration – a cut through the nail to the nail bed -- it may take several months for the nail to completely regrow. If part of your nail comes off the nail bed or is sticking out of the skin at the cuticle, it's called nail avulsion. Part, or all, of the nail may also have been removed from the finger."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "The fingernail bed is the most commonly injured part of the hand."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "If a subungual hematoma covers more than 25% of your nail and is painful, the doctor will make 1 or 2 small holes in the nail to let the blood drain, relieving the pressure and pain. If the hematoma involves half or more of the nail, the doctor will remove the nail and suture the nail bed.\n\nFor a laceration, the doctor will remove at least part of the nail to repair the nail bed. You'll get stitches and then the nail will be sewn or glued back on, or a temporary gauze dressing will be put on in its place.\n\nNail avulsion usually requires nail bed repair, but if there is no damage to the nail bed, the nail can be placed back under the skin."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "These self-care strategies can help immediately after a fingernail injury, before you see a doctor:\n\t\t•\tRemove jewelry from the affected hand in case of swelling.\n\t\t•\tApply pressure with a clean cloth to stop bleeding.\n\t\t•\tWash cuts or scrapes with soap and warm water and apply a triple antibiotic ointment and bandage.\n\t\t•\tDo not pull at the nail or try to remove it from the nail bed.\n\t\t•\tWrap any amputated parts in a damp, clean paper towel, and put the towel in a zip-locked plastic bag on ice.\n\t\t•\tWrap your hand in a clean towel.\n\t\t•\tCheck to make sure your tetanus shots are up to date."

	"Subungual_hematoma_(bleeding_under_nail)": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tRed or black spots on fingernails\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Subungual hematomas occur when blood pools under a fingernail or toenail. They usually happen because of a crush injury, such as dropping something heavy on your toe or slamming your finger in a car door. They can cause intense pain and purple-black discoloration under the nail. Some can be treated at home, but those that are very painful or are due to significant injuries need to be drained and treated by a doctor. Prompt treatment helps prevent complications such as infection, permanent nail loss, or deformity."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "You'll most likely have red to dark purple discoloration under your nail and pain from the pressure caused by blood trapped between the nail and the nail bed. If the pain is mild and discoloration covers a small part of the nail bed, you can ease the symptoms with ice, elevation, and over-the-counter anti-inflammatory medication. If you have severe pain and blood covers 25% or more of the area under the nail, your doctor will drain it through a small hole in the nail. This usually relieves the pain quickly and painlessly. The nail may fall off after several weeks. If the subungual hematoma covers half or more of the nail, you'll probably need the nail removed and stitches to help a new nail grow back. The nail should grow in within 6 to 12 weeks. If a bone was also broken in your finger or toe during the injury, the doctor may apply a splint and prescribe antibiotics."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Millions of people in the U.S. get hematomas under a fingernail or toenail each year."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for subungual hematoma may include:\n\t\t•\tIcing\n\t\t•\tElevation\n\t\t•\tOver-the-counter anti-inflammatory medication\n\t\t•\tAntibiotic ointment and bandaging\n\t\t•\tDraining the hematoma through a small hole that is either burned with a heated wire (cautery) or drilled into the nail\n\t\t•\tSplinting of the finger or toe after draining the nail or if a bone beneath the nail was broken\n\t\t•\tNail removal and stitches\n\t\t•\tAntibiotics for infection"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "These self-care strategies will help heal a subungual hematoma:\n\t\t•\tIce the area for 20 minutes at a time during the first 24 to 48 hours.\n\t\t•\tElevate the arm or leg above heart level during the first 24 to 48 hours.\n\t\t•\tTake over-the-counter ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin) for pain. Take as directed, with food.\n\t\t•\tIf the nail came off or was removed by the doctor and the nail bed wasn't cut, soak the area in warm, soapy water for 10 to 15 minutes three times a day. Apply antibiotic ointment and dressing after soaks.\n\nSee your doctor if the hematoma gets worse or there are signs of infection, such as warmth, redness, swelling, or fever."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Separation of the nail from the nail bed, nail deformity, nail loss, infection"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "See your doctor or go to a hospital emergency room if you have intense pain or the hematoma covers one-quarter or more of the area under the fingernail or toenail."

		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Mallet finger is an injury to the fingertip that stretches, tears, or ruptures the tendon that straightens the finger. It often happens in sports, when a ball hits the end of the finger or thumb. You'll have pain and swelling and may not be able to straighten your finger. To avoid permanent damage, it's important to see a doctor promptly for an evaluation. Usually you need a splint to help heal a mallet finger, but surgery is sometimes necessary."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "You may have pain, tenderness, and swelling on the outside joint of the finger right after your finger is hurt. It will soon swell and turn red. Ice and elevation will help with tenderness and swelling. Call your doctor right away, especially if there is blood beneath the nail or the nail is detached. These could signal a nailbed cut or compound fracture. If your finger is not broken or there is only a small fracture, your doctor may apply a splint to be worn for up to eight weeks. After that, you may need to do exercises to restore full use of your finger. The doctor will also treat cuts or damage to the skin. If you have a broken bone, you may need surgery. Surgery may also be necessary if the tendon is completely torn, you can't use your finger, or a joint is misaligned. Most people regain full function of their finger and have no long-term problems."

	"Blood_clot_in_the_legs": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tBulging veins\n\t\t•\tSwelling\n\t\t•\tSkin redness\n\t\t•\tTenderness to touch\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tLump or bulge\n\t\t•\tWarm to touch\n\t\t•\tMuscle cramps or spasms (painful)"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Blood clots in the leg form when blood thickens and clumps in a thigh or calf vein. But a clot deep in the leg, especially the thigh, can break off, travel to the lungs, and block blood flow – a condition called pulmonary embolism. This can damage the lungs and other organs and cause death. Sitting for a long time or bed rest, surgery, or lower body injury, such as a broken hip, can cause a blood clot in the leg. You may feel leg pain or have no symptoms. Anticoagulants, or blood thinners, can help stop the blood clot from forming or getting bigger."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "Call emergency services if you have any symptoms of pulmonary embolism such as shortness of breath or chest pain, or are coughing up blood. Go to a hospital emergency room immediately if you are at risk for deep vein thrombosis and have leg pain or swelling."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "A blood clot close to the skin in your leg is generally not dangerous. A blood clot deep in your leg – also called deep venous thrombosis -- may have swelling, warmth, and pain that is worse when standing or walking. But up to half of people don't experience any symptoms unless the clot causes a pulmonary embolism. Then you may have shortness or breath or pain with deep breaths, or you may cough up blood. Your doctor may decide to monitor the clot if it is small and below your knee. If it is in the thigh, you may be able to clear it up at home with blood-thinning medication used for three months or more. If you have a serious underlying condition or are pregnant, you may need to be hospitalized. Having one blood clot in the leg makes you prone to more, so your doctor will also recommend preventive measures such as wearing compression stockings."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for a blood clot in the leg may include:\n\t\t•\tBlood thinners such as warfarin (Coumadin) and heparin, to keep the clot from getting bigger and decrease clotting\n\t\t•\tRegular blood tests\n\t\t•\tThrombolytic inhibitors, clot-busting medications to dissolve large clots in life-threatening situations\n\t\t•\tSurgery to insert a filter in a large vein, the vena cava, to prevent a clot from reaching the lungs; used in people who can't take blood-thinners\n\t\t•\tCompression stockings to help prevent swelling and new clots\n\t\t•\tElevating the leg above the heart"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "These self-care strategies may help prevent another blood clot in the leg:\n\t\t•\tWear compression stockings, according to your doctor's advice.\n\t\t•\tDon't sit or stay in bed for long periods of time.\n\t\t•\tWalk around, move your legs, stretch and flex your feet, and drink plenty of liquids on long trips.\n\t\t•\tLose weight if you are overweight.\n\t\t•\tElevate your feet while sitting or in bed."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "Get immediate medical help if you think you have a blood clot in your leg. If you have leg pain or swelling, go to a hospital emergency room. If you have symptoms of pulmonary embolism, call emergency services."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\t\t•\tCould a blood clot in my leg or another condition be causing my symptoms?\n\t\t•\tWhat tests do I need?\n\t\t•\tWhat treatments should I get for a blood clot in the leg?\n\t\t•\tIf I am taking blood thinners, what over-the-counter medications should I avoid?\n\t\t•\tIf I am taking blood thinners, could any foods affect their effectiveness?\n\t\t•\tWhat can I do to prevent future blood clots in my legs?"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "To find out if you have deep vein thrombosis, the doctor will take a medical history and do a physical exam, and may do an ultrasound, MRI, CT scan, and a blood test called a D-dimer test to measure a substance in the blood that's released when a clot dissolves. Venography, injecting dye into a vein in order to do an X-ray, is not used as often."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Almost one million people – most older than age 40 -- develop deep vein thrombosis each year in the U.S."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "You are at increased risk for blood clots in the leg if you have a personal or family history of deep venous thrombosis; have a blood clotting disorder; take hormone therapy or birth control pills; have a deep vein injury from surgery or a broken bone; have been bedridden or sitting for a long period of time, such as on an airplane; are pregnant or recently gave birth; are older than age 60; are overweight or obese; smoke; have heart failure; have a catheter in a vein; or have had some forms of cancer or cancer treatment."
		}
