	"Varicose_veins": [{
			"heading": "Varicose Veins",
			"content": "Varicosity, varicosis"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tBulging veins\n\t\t•\tSwelling\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tItching or burning"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Varicose veins are twisted and enlarged veins that rise under the skin's surface. They often appear on the back of the calf and on the inner leg, and may cause pain or itching. Varicose veins occur when the valves in veins don't work correctly. Instead of moving blood to the heart, the valves allow blood to pool and swell the veins. Varicose veins commonly occur in women, especially pregnant women, and older adults. You're more likely to get varicose veins if you stand on your feet a lot at work, or are overweight. Wearing compression stockings and keeping your legs elevated while you rest can help. Severe varicose veins can be treated with surgery or injections."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Varicose veins can get worse and cause complications, such as a rash that itches (dermatitis) and blood clots. Try wearing compression stockings and keeping your legs elevated, when possible, for relief. If your varicose veins are painful or very unsightly, laser and surgical procedures may help."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 20 million to 25 million people in the U. S. have varicose veins."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatments for varicose veins may include:\n\t\t•\tKeeping your legs raised while sitting or sleeping\n\t\t•\tNot standing a lot\n\t\t•\tWearing compression stockings to improve blood flow\n\t\t•\tVein-stripping surgery (removal of leg varicose veins)\n\t\t•\tSclerotherapy (chemical injections to close off veins)\n\t\t•\tLaser surgery"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "You can ease the symptoms of varicose veins with these self-care tips:\n\t\t•\tTake breaks when sitting or standing for a long time.\n\t\t•\tDon't cross your legs while seated.\n\t\t•\tTry to keep your legs above heart level while sitting or sleeping.\n\t\t•\tExercise to move your legs.\n\t\t•\tLose weight if you're obese or overweight.\n\t\t•\tDon't wear shoes with high heels for long stretches of time."

			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Leg cramps develop when a muscle in the leg tightens and doesn't loosen up. They usually last seconds or minutes, but they can go on for longer. Leg cramps are rarely a serious problem. Muscle strain, dehydration, and low levels of certain minerals often cause them. Pregnancy, some medical conditions, and medicines, such as statins and diabetes drugs, increase the risk of leg cramps."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Any of us can get leg cramps after a long walk or intense workout. Usually, they go away on their own. Some people have leg cramps at night that keep them up and leave them exhausted the next day. If your leg cramps become painful or frequent -- or make it hard to sleep -- see a doctor. An underlying medical condition may be causing your cramps. Treatment may help."
		},

			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Almost everyone has leg cramps at one time or another."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Almost everyone treats leg cramps at home. Walking and stretching the leg can relieve a cramp. Relax the muscles with rest, a warm bath, or massage. Stress can sometimes play a role in cramping. Try breathing exercises or activities such as yoga. Always warm up and stretch before and after exercising. Make sure you're drinking enough water -- especially during exercise -- and eating a healthy diet. Cut down on alcohol and caffeine."
		},

Blood clots in the leg -- called deep vein thrombosis (DVT) -- can cause these symptoms. Leg cramps that happen with walking may be an sign of claudication, a vascular disease caused by a narrowing or blockage of the arteries that supply blood to the legs."

It can take months to heal."

		},

			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment will depend on the severity of the injury.\n\nA pulled hamstring typically recovers with RICE, which stands for rest, ice, compression, and elevation. To give your leg a rest, your doctor will recommend taking a break from activity. The doctor may also recommend using crutches to take the weight off your injured leg. Ice packs applied several times a day will reduce swelling and ease pain. Wearing a compression bandage and elevating your leg will further reduce swelling and speed healing.\n\nOnce the pain and swelling have eased, your doctor may recommend physical therapy.\n\nFor serious tendon tears, surgery is required. The tendon is reattached to the bone using stitches or staples. You will use crutches while the hamstring heals. Recovery from a serious hamstring tear can take six months or more."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "An ACL injury happens when you tear or overstretch the anterior collateral ligament on the inside of your knee. You can have a partial tear or a full tear. The ACL is most often injured during sports or other activities that cause you to make sudden stops and changes in direction. If you have an ACL injury, you may hear a loud popping sound or have severe pain or swelling in the knee. It also may feel like your knee is unstable. You may need surgery to reconstruct the ACL."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "You may find it difficult to walk or put weight on your knee after an ACL injury. The symptoms usually get worse for several hours after your injury. If you have a mild strain, the ACL may heal on its own with physical therapy. If you have a torn ACL, your doctor may recommend surgery to rebuild the ACL. It can't be sewn back together, so it is replaced with part of a tendon from another part of your leg."

		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "A posterior cruciate ligament injury happens when you tear the PCL ligament in the back of the knee. Together, the ACL and the PCL form an X in the middle of your knee and help hold it together. The PCL is the strongest ligament in your knee, so it usually takes a strong force to tear it. PCL injuries most often happen in automobile accidents or from a direct hit to the knee. It can also happen if you fall hard on your knee. A PCL injury causes pain and swelling in the knee. Your knee might also feel weak or unstable. The symptoms of a PCL injury can be mild. Unlike an ACL injury, surgery often isn't needed for a PCL injury."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "The symptoms of a PCL injury can sometimes be mild. They may be more severe if you've also injured other ligaments in your knee. Many people with a PCL injury don't need surgery. The type of treatment you need depends on the severity of your injury and whether you have injured other parts of your knee. In many cases, your PCL injury may heal with a knee brace and physical therapy."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "PCL injuries are much rarer than injuries to other ligaments in the knee."

Many tears will heal on their own. Some need surgery."

People who are overweight or have arthritis may take longer to recover from a meniscus tear. Also, people who continue to play high impact sports after their injury will have a harder time healing."

			"content": "A knee strain is a stretch or tear of a muscle or of a tendon, a band that connects muscle to bone. Jumping, running, and not warming up before exercise can stretch a muscle or tendon too far, causing a strain. Some people develop strains from overuse at work. Strains also are called pulled muscles. Rest, painkillers, ice, and other treatments will help. Knee strains usually heal on their own, although it may take several weeks at least."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "A strained knee may be swollen and bruised. A severe strain may cause a popping sensation when you hurt yourself. With mild strains, treating symptoms at home and resting the knee may be enough while the muscles or tendons heal. It may take a few weeks. Moderate strains may take months to heal. Severe strains may need surgery for a full recovery. If the pain is intense or doesn't start getting better within a few days, see a doctor. Untreated strains can develop into painful chronic injuries."

			"content": "You usually can treat a mild knee strain at home. Use ice and NSAIDs such as ibuprofen, ketoprofen, or naproxen to reduce swelling and pain. Follow your doctor's instructions about stretching exercises. While you recover, switch to low-impact exercise such as swimming or using an elliptical trainer. If you're overweight, slimming down will take pressure off the knee. Once you're feeling better, always stretch well before exercise. Step up exercise gradually."
		},

			"heading": "Symptoms",

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Osteochondritis dissecans is a joint problem in which a fragment of cartilage and bone breaks off from the end of a larger bone. A blow or repetitive stress -- from pitching a baseball, for instance -- may cause it. These loose fragments may stay in position or float around and get stuck in the joint. You may feel pain and swelling; the joint may stick or lock up. Children and teens who play competitive sports are more likely to get osteochondritis dissecans. Usually, the bone heals on its own. Some people need surgery."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Osteochondritis dissecans is most common in the knees. It may occur in other joints such as the elbows, shoulders, hips, and ankles. Usually, rest is the treatment. It may take some time to heal -- you may not be able to play sports for 6-8 weeks. Exercising before you're healed could worsen the injury. Children and teens tend to heal completely. Adults may have ongoing problems; some develop arthritis in the joint. Adults are more likely to need surgery to fix the damage."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "The incidence of osteochondritis dissecans has been estimated to be between 15 and 30 people per 100,000 per year, with men affected two and a half times more than women."

	"Bursitis_(anserine)": [{
			"heading": "Bursitis (Anserine)",
			"content": "Pes anserine bursitis"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\t\t•\tStiffness or decreased movement\n\t\t•\tSwelling\n\t\t•\tWarm to touch\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tSkin redness\n\t\t•\tTenderness to touch"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Bursitis is an inflammation in a joint bursa, a small sac of fluid that cushion bones, ligaments, and muscles around your joints. The anserine bursa lies at the inside of the knee between the shinbone and three tendons. When inflamed, it causes pain, especially when you bend your knee. Pain may be more severe at night. Anserine bursitis is common in athletes, people with arthritis, and people with diabetes. It can result from acute trauma, such as a blow below the knee, or from wear and tear, especially in someone who is overweight."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "It can take about six to eight weeks of treatment for the bursitis to ease up. Getting relief often means making changes in your normal activities. For instance, climbing stairs can make it worse. So can taking part in sports, or doing other activities that put strain on the knee. During recovery, you may work with a physical therapist or trainer who can teach you exercises to stretch your hamstrings and strengthen the muscles that support the knee. You may take medication such as aspirin or ibuprofen for pain. Anserine bursitis can become a chronic source of pain and swelling if not treated promptly. If the bursitis doesn't improve with treatment, a more aggressive approach involving injections and other procedures may be needed."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Bursitis is common in people who have osteoarthritis in the knee, especially those who are runners or who are overweight."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "In most cases, the doctor will recommend:\n\t\t•\tApplying an ice pack to the knee several times a day to reduce pain and inflammation\n\t\t•\tUsing an elastic bandage on the knee to provide support\n\t\t•\tResting the joint for a limited amount of time -- too much rest can cause stiffness and additional pain on moving\n\t\t•\tUsing medication such as aspirin or ibuprofen for pain\n\nThe doctor also may refer you to a physical therapist to learn specific exercises that will stretch the tendons and strengthen support for the knee. If the bursitis does not improve after treatment, the doctor may prescribe injections of a steroid and anesthetic to reduce the inflammation and provide pain relief."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "A Baker's cyst can cause swelling behind the knee. Fluid leaks from the knee joint, causing a soft, squishy, and usually painless bulge on the back of the knee. It's easiest to see a Baker's cyst when a person is standing up straight and can compare the backs of his or her knees. Baker's cysts are fairly common and harmless. Knee cartilage injuries and arthritis can cause them. In children, Baker's cysts may develop without a particular cause and then disappear. Most people don't need treatment. In adults, Baker's cysts may shrink on their own and then return."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "While Baker's cysts don't usually hurt, the joint may feel stiff. If the cyst actually bursts, a person may have pain, swelling, and bruising on the knee and calf. As long as it's not painful, a doctor may suggest keeping an eye on the cyst without getting any treatment. If it is painful, a doctor may focus on the underlying problem, such as a knee injury or arthritis. Rarely, surgeons need to drain or surgically remove a large Baker's cyst. However, the cyst may return after it's removed."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "About 1 out of every 4 adults with osteoarthritis has a Baker's cyst."

		},

You can break one or both of these bones because of a fall, a sports injury, overuse, or a serious accident or injury. A broken bone in the lower leg can cause severe pain, swelling, tenderness, bruising, or shortening of the leg. The break can be a small hairline fracture or a severe break that shatters bone. Treatment can range from a splint or cast to surgery. If you think you have broken your leg, get medical attention right away."

This is called an open fracture. Most broken lower leg bones are treated with splints or casts. You may need surgery if there are several breaks or the bone is shattered. Most broken bones heal in about 6 to 8 weeks. Getting treatment right away helps ensure proper healing."

A bruise causes crushing of the muscle and connective tissue. Torn blood vessels can lead to a bluish appearance on the skin, but the skin does not break. In most cases, a bruised shin is a minor injury that heals quickly. Much less often, serious damage to nerves and blood vessels can result from injuries that cause bruising."

			"content": "Erythema nodosum is an inflammation of the fatty layer below the skin. It usually causes painful, red lumps on the shins. But the lumps can also appear on other parts of the body, including the arms, ankles, buttocks, and thighs. It often goes away on its own. Erythema nodosum also can cause fever, achy joints, or swelling. Infections, illnesses, and reactions to some medications can cause it. Sometimes, it has no cause. Although erythema nodosum can be uncomfortable, it is not dangerous."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "You may notice the achy joints and fever before you have the red lumps. The lumps start out as painful and hot. After a few days, they become darker, and then start to fade and become flat. Sometimes the lumps may leave bruises. Erythema nodosum usually gets better in three to six weeks without any treatment. If your symptoms are severe, you may need to take a medication to relieve your symptoms. If you have another condition that's causing erythema nodosum, you may get treatment for that condition."

			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Heat cramps are muscle pains or spasms caused by intense sweating, usually during exercise. They are most likely to occur in the abdomen, arms, or legs. Heat cramps almost always go away on their own if you stop exercising, rest in a cool place, and drink plenty of fluid with electrolytes."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",

		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "A broken ankle is a break in one or more of the three bones that meet in the ankle joint. The ankle may be quite painful, bruised, and swollen. The severity of a broken ankle varies. If only one bone is broken, a person may still be able to walk and only need a brace or cast. People who break several bones may not be able to put weight on the foot at all. They may need surgery to install plates, screws, or pins to stabilize the joint and prevent long-term problems. Anyone who may have a broken ankle needs medical attention right away."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "If you hurt your ankle and have severe pain, numbness, deformity, or can't put any weight on your foot, see your doctor right away or go to the emergency room."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Prompt treatment is important; it reduces the risk of serious instability. A doctor may first put the ankle in a brace. Once the swelling goes down, the doctor may recommend further treatment. It will take six weeks or more for the bones to heal after a broken ankle. Recovery will take longer if tendons or ligaments are damaged as well. It may be three to four months before people feel back to normal and even longer before they can exercise normally. Full recovery from a severe break can take up to two years."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Not getting treatment, smoking, diabetes, being older"
		},

		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "A broken ankle always needs medical treatment. Resting, icing, and elevating the ankle may help with pain and swelling. So will over-the-counter painkillers, such as ibuprofen, ketoprofen, and naproxen. You may need to use crutches while the bones heal. Ask your doctor about physical therapy and strengthening exercises as you recover."

	"Sprained_ankle": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "An ankle sprain is an injury to some of the ligaments that hold the bones of the foot together. Ligaments are elastic and meant to stretch. But if you pull the ligaments in the foot too far by twisting or rolling the foot you can damage them, spraining the ankle. In severe sprains, the ligaments break. A soccer player might sprain an ankle pivoting on the field; an office worker might sprain an ankle stepping off a curb in high heels. Provided you rest the foot, ankle sprains usually heal on their own."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "The symptoms vary depending on whether you stretched or tore the ligament. Mild sprains may cause minor pain. A severe strain may make it impossible to walk. The good news is that even bad sprains rarely need surgery. You may need a cast or crutches to protect the ankle while it heals. After a sprain, the swelling and pain may get better within 2-3 days. Full recovery often takes 4-6 weeks. If you don't rest the foot until the ligaments have healed, you could develop chronic problems, such as pain and instability in the ankle."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Millions of people sprain an ankle each year in the U.S."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "You often can treat an ankle sprain at home. Rest the ankle and ice the area. Elevate your foot when you're sitting and lying down. Over-the-counter NSAIDs such as ibuprofen and ketoprofen will help with pain and swelling. Limit the weight you put on your foot while it heals. You may need a brace or crutches. Make sure to let the ankle heal completely before returning to sports."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Not resting the foot after a sprain, wearing shoes that don't offer enough support, and playing sports that require sudden twisting, such as tennis, football, basketball, and soccer."

Ankle bursitis is often caused by overusing your ankle, by doing too much jumping, walking, or running. Gout, infection, and rheumatoid arthritis can also cause it. Ankle bursitis causes pain, swelling, redness, and stiffness around the ankle or back of the heel. Resting and icing the ankle usually helps. In some cases, you may need a corticosteroid injection or, rarely, surgery."

			"content": "The Achilles tendon connects your calf muscle to your heel and makes it possible to point your toes, walk, jump, and run. It is the largest and strongest tendon in the body, but it can become weak from age or lack of use. Achilles tendon ruptures sometimes occur in\"weekend warriors\" when playing sports such as basketball, tennis, and racquetball. Middle-aged men who don't get regular exercise are most at risk for this injury. Surgery, special casts, and physical therapy help the tendon heal. Most people can resume normal activities after 4 to 6 months."
		},

			"content": "Anyone who thinks they have ruptured his or her Achilles tendon should get immediate medical attention. Surgery to reattach the tendon can help you return to activities more quickly, and it has a lower risk for reinjury than nonsurgical treatment. Nonsurgical treatment involves wearing special casts and braces that help the tendon heal on its own. Both treatments along with physical therapy can effectively restore strength and function to the injured foot in about 4 to 6 months."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Broken, or fractured, bones in feet are very common. You are most likely to break a metatarsal, one of the long bones of the mid-foot, or the phalanges, the short bones in the toes. Most bones break suddenly during an injury or accident, but repetitive stress, from an activity such as overtraining, can cause tiny cracks in bones called stress fractures. Athletes are at high risk for both. It's important to see a doctor for treatment so that you are less likely to develop persistent pain, arthritis, or other chronic foot problems. You can usually heal a broken foot by resting, icing, and immobilizing it, but surgery is sometimes necessary."

Bone fractures usually heal in three to four weeks, but the stress put on the foot while walking can make healing take longer."

			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Shoes should protect feet and prevent injury. But poorly fitting shoes can cause injuries such as blisters, bunions, ligament tears, nerve irritation, and even permanent deformities. High heels and narrow toes cause the biggest problems. Changing shoes and over-the-counter products often can heal problems caused by poorly fitting shoes, but you may need to see a doctor. If you have diabetes, you are especially vulnerable to injury and should see a doctor for any foot injury."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Regularly crowding your feet into shoes can cause blisters, calluses, and sore feet. If you wear shoes with pointed toes, thin soles, and high heels, your bodyweight also shifts, putting extra stress on the ball and forefoot. You may get bunions, hammertoes, or an ankle, knee, calf, or back injury. If your shoes are too big, your foot can slide around and develop blisters or foot strain. Ice, heat, rest, shoe inserts, foot pads, over-the-counter pain relievers and products such as corn removers, and wearing better shoes can heal some foot problems. If they don't, your doctor may recommend other measures or surgery."

	"Corns_and_calluses": [{

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Corns and calluses are areas of thick, hard skin on the hands and feet. They're the body's natural defense against pressure and friction -- from wearing tight shoes or using hand tools, for instance. Calluses are usually painless patches on the palms or on soles of the feet. Corns are smaller and painful; they show up on the top or sides of the toes. While harmless, you can treat corns or calluses if they're bothering you."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Constant friction and pressure on the skin makes corns and calluses grow. Reducing that friction -- by wearing a pair of shoes that fit better or using gloves while you work -- may make a corn or callus disappear in a few weeks. If they're not hurting, don't worry about corns or calluses. They can be a good thing -- if you work with your hands, calluses may protect them from cuts and blisters. If they bother you, soak in warm water and then gently sand away the rough parts. Don't try to cut off a corn or callus yourself."
		},

			"heading": "How Common",

	"Metatarsalgia": [{
			"heading": "Metatarsalgia",
			"content": "Forefoot pain syndrome"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tJoint pain\n\t\t•\tSwelling\n\t\t•\tUnable to bear weight"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Metatarsalgia is pain in the metatarsal joints at the ball of the foot. Stress fractures, poorly fitting shoes, nerve problems, being overweight, arthritis, bunions, and hammertoes can cause this joint pain. In some cases, there is no clear cause. Most people recover from metatarsalgia with rest, ice, over-the-counter pain relievers, and shoe inserts. Sometimes, doctors will do surgery to realign the metatarsalgia bones."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Metatarsalgia usually starts with dull pain that gets worse over time, making walking difficult. How long the ball-of-foot pain lasts depends on what causes it. A stress fracture may heal in a few weeks, but some people with nerve problems may need surgery if the pain doesn't improve. However, most people don't need surgery."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "There are millions of cases of metatarsalgia in the U.S. every year."

	"Bunions": [{
			"heading": "Bunions",
			"content": "Hallux valgus"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tSwelling\n\t\t•\tSkin redness\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "A bunion is a bony bump at the base of the big toe. It's caused by the big toe leaning in toward the second toe, which makes the joint at the base of the big toe enlarged. The bump may become red, inflamed, and painful. Bunions can become so painful that wearing shoes and walking becomes difficult. Some people develop small bunions, called a bunionette, along the outside of the foot, at the base of the little toe. Wearing tight shoes or high heels make bunions worse. Foot injury, nerve conditions of the foot, abnormal foot bone development at birth, certain types of foot structure, and arthritis can cause bunions. Jobs that put a lot of stress on the joint can also lead to the condition. For example, ballet dancers often get bunions. Early treatment by wearing wide-toed comfortable shoes, padding the bunion, taking anti-inflammatory medication, and using shoe inserts, or orthotics, can often help slow bunion development. Surgery to realign the bones, called a bunionectomy, helps most people with painful, severe bunions."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "A bunion starts with the big toe gradually leaning in toward the second toe. A bump forms on the outside of the big toe joint. Over time, the toe becomes more misaligned and redness, joint pain, and other symptoms may develop. Some people have no symptoms. The condition gets worse over time and once a bunion develops, it won't go away. Treating early symptoms by wearing wide-toed comfortable shoes with a low heel, padding the bunion, taking anti-inflammatory medication, and using shoe inserts can often help slow the progression of the condition. Left untreated, a bunion becomes more deformed and pain can make walking difficult. Surgery effectively treats severe bunions."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Up to 55% of women in the US have bunions."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Treatment for bunions may include:\n\t\t•\tOrthotics, or shoe inserts, to help reposition the foot\n\t\t•\tCorticosteroid injections or over-the-counter pain relievers\n\t\t•\tPhysical therapy\n\t\t•\tSurgery"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Self-care for bunions includes:\n\t\t•\tIcing the foot\n\t\t•\tWearing shoes with a big toe box and heels less than 2 inches tall\n\t\t•\tPadding the bunion\n\t\t•\taping the foot into a normal position\n\t\t•\tUsing spacers between the big toe and second toe\n\t\t•\tAvoiding activities that cause bunion pain, such as standing for a long time"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",

		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Thrombophlebitis is the swelling of a vein that is caused by a blood clot. It occurs most often in the veins of the leg but also can affect the veins of the arms or neck. When these clots occur in deeper, larger veins they are called deep vein thrombosis. When they occur in smaller veins near the surface of the skin, they are called superficial thrombophlebitis. Deep clots are dangerous because they can break off and travel to the lungs or heart. Superficial clots are not usually dangerous, but they can cause redness, swelling, and pain."
		},
		{
			"heading": "EMERGENCY",
			"content": "Seek medical care right away if you have severe swelling or pain, have shortness of breath, or cough up blood."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Most blood clots cause redness, swelling, or pain, though some don't have any symptoms. Clots in the deep veins may cause swelling of the leg that you may notice more when you stand or walk. Clots in the deep veins can cause serious problems, including pulmonary embolism, heart attack, or stroke. In some cases, these deep clots also can damage the valves in the leg veins. Most cases of thrombophlebitis can be treated with medications or surgery."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Putting pressure on the affected area can make symptoms worse and increase the damage to the vein."
		},

		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "See your doctor if you have any symptoms of thrombophlebitis, if your symptoms don't get better with treatment, or if your symptoms get worse or change. The symptoms of thrombophlebitis include swelling, redness, warm skin, or pain in the area where the clot is located. Sometimes, there is also a fever. But in some cases, you may have no symptoms."

	"Morton's_neuroma": [{
			"heading": "Morton's Neuroma",
			"content": "Intermetatarsal neuroma"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tNumbness or tingling"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Morton's neuroma is thickening of nerve tissue on the ball of the foot, usually between the bones of the third and fourth toes. It can feel like you're walking on a marble. Women experience it much more than men. High heels with narrow toes, genetic susceptibility, and repetitive stress from activities like running and court sports can cause it. Morton's neuroma may cause sharp pain and lead to permanent nerve damage. More comfortable shoes, pain medication, shoe inserts, and cortisone injections usually relieve it, though surgery is sometimes necessary."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Early symptoms of Morton's neuroma may come and go. As the neuroma enlarges and nerve damage worsens, they may become more intense and last for several days or weeks. The earlier you treat it, the more likely you are to avoid surgery. You may be able to clear up mild Morton's neuroma with self-care strategies like resting the foot, wearing better-fitting shoes, icing and massaging the area, and taking anti-inflammation medication. If it recurs or becomes severe, your doctor may suggest cortisone injections, padding, or shoe inserts. You should continue to treat Morton's neuroma for two months after you stop feeling pain. Surgery to remove a small portion of the nerve or release tissue around it is a last resort, usually for larger neuromas or those that have caused symptoms for a long time. About half of people who have surgery recover within two months."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Morton's neuroma occurs in women 5-10 times more often than in men."
		},

		},
		{

		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Turf toe is a painful sprain in the big toe. Athletes who play on hard surfaces -- such as artificial turf, concrete, or wood -- are most likely to get it. Football players are especially prone. Dancers, soccer players, basketball players, and many others get it too. Recovery usually takes a few weeks but can take six weeks or longer. If you don't allow the injury to heal, turf toe can become a chronic problem."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "As you're running, you use the big toe to spring off for your next step. If you bend the toe back too far, you overstretch the ligaments, resulting in turf toe. You may get turf toe if you're pushed forward suddenly -- for instance when you're tackled in football. With good treatment, you will probably be able to play again in 1 to 2 weeks. Some injuries will take longer to heal. Full recovery can take 6 to 12 months."
		},
		{

			"content": "About 1 in 10,000 people get turf toe every year in the U.S."

		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Most people can treat turf toe at home. You'll probably need to rest the foot for 1 to 2 weeks. Wrap the foot and keep it elevated when you're sitting or lying down. Don't run at all, and limit your walking. Use ice packs and take over-the-counter NSAIDs -- such as ibuprofen and ketoprofen -- to ease pain and swelling. The big toe may be taped or strapped to the toe next to it to relieve the stress on it. Make sure that you have a good pair of shoes with proper arch support."
		},

			"heading": "Made Worse By",

	"Hammertoe_and_mallet_toe": [{
			"heading": "Hammertoe and Mallet Toe",
			"content": "Hammertoe deformity, lesser-toe deformities"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tVisible deformity\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Hammertoe and mallet toe are similar conditions that occur when one of the small toe joints becomes abnormally bent, causing the toe to curl down like a claw. Hammertoe affects the middle joint in the toe, and mallet toe occurs in the upper toe joint. These deformities usually affect the second toe, but may occur in the other small toes. Poor-fitting shoes, high heels, and shoes that are too small often cause toe problems. Tight shoes squeeze the toes, and over time, tendons and muscles become shorter, keeping the toe in a bent position. Hammertoe and mallet toe can cause toe pain, calluses and corns, and difficulty walking. Splinting, stretching the toe, wearing low-heeled shoes with plenty of toe room, toe exercises, and in severe cases surgery can treat hammertoe and mallet toe."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "At first toes just have a slight bend, and you can still move your toe and toe joints. Over time, the bend becomes worse and difficult to move, causing pain when you walk or wear shoes. Corns may develop on the top of the toe and you may get calluses on the bottom from rubbing on your shoes. Hammertoe and mallet toe will get worse over time. Getting treatment early on can help treat the condition and prevent it from getting worse."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Researchers estimate that up to 20% of people in the U.S. will develop toe deformities during their lifetime."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\treatment for hammertoe and mallet toe includes:\n\t\t•\tWearing well-fitting, low-heeled shoes with plenty of toe room\n\t\t•\tUsing padding to protect corns and calluses\n\t\t•\tUsing orthotics to help correct toe position\n\t\t•\tPain relievers\n\t\t•\tCorticosteroid injections\n\t\t•\toe exercises\n\t\t•\tStrapping or splinting the toe\n\t\t•\tSurgery"

			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tenderness to touch\n\t\t•\tSkin bumps"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Plantar warts grow on the soles of the feet. They tend to occur in areas where there is pressure or friction, such as on the heel. They can be painless or quite tender. Plantar warts often go away on their own. A variety of treatments, including home remedies and treatments your doctor can perform, are used to remove plantar warts."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Plantar warts develop over a relatively short period of time, unlike calluses or corns, which develop slowly. Often, these warts go away on their own. To speed the process, you can use home remedies available at the drug store, or soak your feet and gently sand down the wart with pumice stone. Because plantar warts can be tender or painful and make walking difficult, your doctor may want to remove the wart with a laser or by freezing it. Treatment is usually successful. But warts can grow back or appear in new places."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Risk Factors",
			"content": "Using public showers, having breaks in the skin on the bottom of the foot, having a weakened immune system"
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Between 7% and 10% of Americans are believed to have warts at any given time. Only a fraction of those warts are plantar warts."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Prevention",
			"content": "Avoid walking barefoot (except on sandy beaches). Wear sandals or flip-flops in public shower rooms. Change shoes and socks daily. Dry your feet thoroughly after showering or bathing. Cover warts with waterproof tape in public showers or swimming pools to avoid infecting others."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Your doctor may recommend any of a variety of techniques to remove a plantar wart. These include:\n\t\t•\tA mild acid applied to the wart\n\t\t•\tA topical drug called Efudex, which kills cells in the wart\n\t\t•\tLaser, ultrasound, or electrical treatments to destroy the wart\n\t\t•\tCryotherapy to freeze the wart off, using liquid nitrogen\n\nFor stubborn plantar warts, your doctor may recommend immunotherapy, which primes the immune system to destroy the virus that causes warts."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Most plantar warts go away on their own. But several home remedies may help ease the discomfort or help get rid of warts. These include:\n\t\t•\tPutting a doughnut-shaped piece of moleskin around the wart to take the pressure off it when you walk\n\t\t•\tSoaking your foot for 20 minutes to soften the wart and then sanding it down gently with a pumice stone or other abrasive material\n\t\t•\tUsing a corn or callus trimmer (available at most drug stores) to pare away the surface of the wart\n\t\t•\tApplying an over-the counter wart remover\n\t\t•\tApplying duct tape to the wart, which may make it go away (keep the wart covered 6 out of 7 days a week, and replace the duct tape each day)."
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",

If you’ve tried to treat a plantar wart using home remedies and it still bothers you after six weeks, call your doctor. Also contact your doctor immediately if you experience severe pain, swelling, redness, or bleeding around the site."

	"Plantar_fasciitis": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort\n\t\t•\tenderness to touch\n\t\t•\tSwelling"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Plantar fasciitis is an inflammation of the thick band of tissue running from the heel bone to the toes that supports the arch of your foot. The main symptom is pain on the bottom of the heel. Stretching exercises, well-fitting shoes, shoe inserts, and other simple treatments ease pain for most people. A small percentage may need surgery."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Plantar fasciitis symptoms get better in almost everyone with appropriate treatment. But it can take time -- up to 9 months or more -- to see real improvement. Very few people require surgery."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "Approximately 2 million people are treated for this condition every year."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "The goal of treatment is to ease pain and stretch the muscles and tendons of the foot. Your doctor may recommend a variety of treatments, including:\n\t\t•\tAnti-inflammatory medications such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin)\n\t\t•\tExercises to stretch the muscles in your feet and calves\n\t\t•\tIcing the painful area for the first few days\n\t\t•\tResting for at least a week\n\t\t•\tWearing properly fitting shoes\n\t\t•\tUsing a heel cup or other shoe inserts\n\t\t•\tUsing night splints, which stretch the fascia and speed healing\n\t\t•\tWearing a short cast or cast boot\n\t\t•\tExtracorporeal shockwave therapy (ESWT), which uses high-energy impulses to stimulate healing\n\t\t•\tMassage therapy\n\nIf these approaches don't work after about 12 months, your doctor may recommend surgery to lengthen the muscles of the calf."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "You can reduce the risk of developing plantar fasciitis and ease pain if you already have it by wearing shoes that fit properly and doing exercises that stretch your foot and calf muscles. If your heel is painful, avoid doing repetitive impact activities such as running. Over-the-counter pain medications, used as directed, can help relieve pain."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Poor-fitting shoes, tight hamstring muscles"
		},
		{
			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "If self-care measures haven't worked, see your doctor if you still have pain at the bottom of the heel that's usually worse in the morning when you first walk or after a period of sitting or lying down, or pain that's worse after – not during -- exercise or activity."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Questions to Ask Your Doctor",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tWhat is causing the pain in my heels?\n\t\t•\tWhat should I do to relieve the pain?\n\t\t•\tIs surgery an option for me?\n\t\t•\tWhat can I do to prevent this from happening again?"

			"heading": "Diagnosed By",
			"content": "Doctors look for mild swelling, redness, and tenderness on the bottom of the heel. Your doctor may order an X-ray to rule out other problems, such as fractures or arthritis."

	"Flatfeet": [{
			"heading": "Symptoms",
			"content": "\n\t\t•\tPain or discomfort"
		},
		{
			"heading": "Overview",
			"content": "Flat feet, or pes planus, is a condition in which the arch of the foot falls with age or, in young children, never fully develops. Flat feet can make standing uncomfortable or painful. For most people, well-fitting shoes with arch support or orthotic inserts are enough to ease discomfort. In rare cases, surgery may be necessary to repair the arch."
		},
		{
			"heading": "What to Expect",
			"content": "Flat feet can usually be treated with shoes with good arch support or with the use of arch support inserts. Stretching exercises for feet and calves can also help. In severe cases, surgery may be necessary to repair the arch."
		},
		{
			"heading": "How Common",
			"content": "With age, many people develop flat feet because the tendon that supports the arch loses its strength. According to a 2006 study, less than 1% of children aged 3 to 6 have flat feet that require arch supports."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Treatment",
			"content": "Flat feet in very young children is rarely treated since their arches are likely to develop normally as they get older. Flat feet in adults is usually treated with well-fitting shoes that have good arch support. Heel cups or orthotic devices that are inserted into shoes can also help cushion feet. If flat feet continue to be painful, your doctor may recommend surgery to restore your arch."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Self Care",
			"content": "Choosing well-fitting shoes with plenty of room and good arch support can help relieve pain or discomfort from flat feet. Foot and calf exercises, foot massage, soaking your feet in warm water, and occasional use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications such as aspirin and ibuprofen are also helpful."
		},
		{
			"heading": "Made Worse By",
			"content": "Wearing ill-fitting shoes without arch support, being overweight or obese"
		},

			"heading": "When to See Your Doctor",
			"content": "See your doctor if your feet or legs hurt even with well-fitting shoes."
		},
